HEADLINE: Imagine; 
Stealth Anti-Environmentalism

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
George W. Bush was a man with a serious environmental problem throughout his campaign for the presidency. And shortly after he took office, environmental groups successfully managed to cast him as "pro arsenic," for his administration's attempts to change water safety standards. 
 Then came Sept. 11, after which the biggest environmental groups fell silent, fearful that attacking the president would make them appear unpatriotic. 
 In response, the administration pressed ahead as quietly as possible -- largely through the regulatory process -- to allow road-building in national forests, reverse the phase-out of snowmobiles in national parks, make it easier for mining companies to dig for gold, copper and zinc on public lands, relax energy-efficiency standards for air conditioners, bar the reintroduction of grizzly bears in the Northwest and make it easier for developers to eliminate wetlands. Most recently, the administration approved the largest timber salvage operation in the nation's history in the Bitterroot National Forest, openly skirting the public appeals process, a move that has been halted by the courts.
The administration also pushed for drilling for oil in a wildlife refuge in Alaska as an attempt to bolster national security. And the fog of war has obscured, too, the administration's policy on global warming. Last summer, after President Bush rejected the international Kyoto treaty on global warming, he pledged to start research programs to study climate shifts and find new technologies to cut emissions without harming the economy. But government scientists say that administration officials are now telling agencies not to expect additional money to pay for new efforts. 
Many of these actions would have received front-page coverage as part of the evolving "pro-business" tilt of the Bush White House.
 KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

HEADLINE: On Film as in Life, You Are What You Forget 

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
IF you had your choice this season, what would you forget? How about everything?
 In the new movie "The Majestic," a screenwriter played by Jim Carrey drives his car off a bridge and emerges with a rumpled shirt and a near-complete loss of memory. As he wanders around making doe eyes at people he cannot recognize, he is in good company. If the movies are any indication, this is shaping up as the season for convenient forgetting. 
 In "Memento," Guy Pearce plays a former insurance investigator who cannot form short-term memories. He knows who he is, but has to write notes on his body to remember what he is doing from one moment to the next. In David Lynch's "Mulholland Drive," a starlet played by Laura Harring survives a car accident with a case of total amnesia, then embarks on a Nancy Drew quest to discover her missing identity. 
Tom Cruise in "Vanilla Sky" draws a blank on the most important event in his life (hint: it's also the last). And in Woody Allen's "Curse of the Jade Scorpion," a hypnotist forces the lead character to commit crimes, then forget them immediately.
The movies play out a forgetfulness that has permeated the culture in recent years. The stock market, the Internet and even history departments have all yielded their own versions of amnesia. Though it is a conventional plot device, this forgetting offers a window on broader fantasies and anxieties. 
"These films crop up in multiples for a reason," said Denise Mann, a chairwoman of the producers program at the school of theater, film and television at the University of California at Los Angeles. "There's a sense of social unease that's coming out in the movies." 
Books play along as well. In "The Corrections," the celebrated novel by Jonathan Franzen, a drug company is developing a formula that wipes out past personality.
There have been waves of amnesia movies in the past. Robert Sklar, a professor of cinema studies at New York University, points to a similar spate after World War II, including "Spellbound," "The Blue Dahlia," "Somewhere in the Night," "Deadline at Dawn" and "Love Letters." The films used amnesia to address the social dislocations of the war, Mr. Sklar said. "So many of the men or their families were trying to reconstruct their pasts. Amnesia was a metaphor for gaps in time that the war created."
The current amnesia movies play with a new set of dislocations. 
Though it may be tempting to relate them to Sept. 11, the movies were all conceived years before, during the economic boom, which produced waves of collective amnesia. Dot-com diehards crowed that the business cycle no longer existed, and the exuberance of the market allowed anyone to believe the past was irrelevant. No matter that you flunked out of college, you could still be an Internet zillionaire. 
Wealth was similarly wrenched from its connection with the past, tied not to your salary history but to your stock options, whose worth lay wholly in years to come. There was little need to remember the past; security lay in your purchase, however abstract, on the future. 
Identity became fluid, as anyone who has ever gone into a chat room knows. Memory could be erased with the stroke of a computer key. 
It was a period for ahistoric thinking, and as you might expect, history suffered, falling into its own version of willful amnesia. The past, it seemed, could be rewritten. Joseph J. Ellis, the Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of Thomas Jefferson and John Adams, lied to his Mount Holyoke students that he had fought in Vietnam. Edmund Morris reinvented himself as a historical figure in his 1999 book, "Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan," concocting various encounters with Reagan over the years. 
Most recently, critics have accused Michael A. Bellesiles, whose 2000 book, "Arming America: The Origins of a National Gun Culture," presented evidence that gun ownership was rare in our history, of fabricating some of his research. (Mr. Bellesiles has promised a rebuttal.) 
The movies play off this greater amnesia, creating stories around it. Amnesia is the flip side of nostalgia. Instead of wallowing in an idealized past, the movies present the past as forever out of reach, beyond the power to recollect. It has to be reconstructed. 
In "The Majestic," after Carrey's auto accident, he has to reinvent his identity from clues around him. Drawing on the memories of the local townspeople, who mistake him for a missing war hero, he creates a nobler self than the one he left behind. Losing his past was the nicest thing that could happen to him. This may seem like a boomer's-eye view of death -- with the convenient bonus that no one has to die. But Frank Darabont, the film's director and producer, said: "It's really a way to experience one's rebirth. It's a story about somebody finding his better self. What better way to get there than to empty the vessel?"
But in most of these movies, this metaphorical rebirth has a darker side. In a culture obsessed with individuality, what could be more horrifying than to lose one's identity?
The consequences are often dire. In "Memento," for example, the lead character uses his loss of memory to behave without conscience, knowing he will not remember his actions. 
In this way, amnesia in today's culture taps a far bleaker fantasy than nostalgia, said Ms. Mann of U.C.L.A. "We want to return to the affluence and calm of the Eisenhower era, but we can't get back there because of inexplicable events of random violence," she said, citing the school shootings of recent years as one example of violent disruption. In the movies, similarly, characters lose access to their past after violent trauma. 
Slavoj Zizek, a psychoanalyst who has written extensively about the movies, ties the vogue for amnesia to a much broader disruption, stemming from shifts in global politics. "Until the collapse of communism we had large stories to tell," he said. But it became impossible to understand the events after 1990 in simple terms such as East versus West. "If we take any political event today, it explodes into a thousand narratives," he said. 
For all this, the traumas of the season have exposed the limits of amnesia. It's easy to wish to forget the events of Sept. 11. But this is a trap; memory is probably what everyone needs right now. However painful the associations, a knowledge of the past -- of history and language -- became more valuable than ever.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Hussein and bin Laden: How Opposites Attract

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AS the United States ponders whether to expand the war on terrorism to Iraq, various officials and ex-officials have tried to connect the dots between Osama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein. Administration officials debate the credibility of claims by Czech officials of a meeting in Prague between an Iraqi intelligence officer and Mr. bin Laden's leading suicide operative in the Sept. 11 attacks. R. James Woolsey, the former director of central intelligence, has tried to link Mr. Hussein to the anthrax attacks in America.
 But what, if anything, connects Mr. bin Laden, the religious extremist master of terror, with Mr. Hussein, the secular president of Iraq? 
 Clearly, the two men share a hatred of the United States and its military presence in the Persian Gulf, and a conviction that the international community was using economic sanctions to starve the Iraqi people. 
And both are skillful mythmakers. Mr. bin Laden has portrayed himself as a modern-day prophet, reciting poetry and posing in front of caves, bathed in sunlight, like Muhammad. Mr. Hussein has been even more creative. He never served in the army, but in 1990 he promoted himself to field marshal. In the 20-foot-high paintings that dominate Iraq's landscape, he has been a desert horseman, a wheat-cutting peasant and a cement-carrying construction worker.
But that's where the similarity ends. Mr. bin Laden preaches an extremist, militant version of Islam and claims loyalty only to God. He has attacked the Saudi royals as "infidels" for allowing American troops to be based near the holiest shrines in Islam. 
Indeed, after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, Mr. bin Laden, fresh from the war against Soviet invaders of Afghanistan, came calling on Prince Sultan, Saudi Arabia's defense minister. According to an oft-told story in official Saudi circles, Mr. bin Laden said Saudi Arabia didn't need a foreign infidel army to defeat Iraq; he and his followers could do it. "There are no caves in Kuwait," Prince Sultan then said. "What will you do when he lobs missiles at you with chemical and biological weapons?" Mr. bin Laden replied, "We will fight him with faith." 
Mr. Hussein, by contrast, is a secular state builder whose loyalty is to himself. In his modernization campaign, he has allowed drinking of alcohol in public and freedom in women's dress. He has used ruthlessness, cunning and expansionism to exterminate his enemies in his quest to physically and intellectually homogenize a diverse population and mold Iraq into the most powerful nation-state in the Arab world. 
That includes repression of Iraq's Shiite community, roughly 55 percent of the population. In the 1970's, the country's most respected Shiite leader, Ayatollah Mohammad Bakr al-Sadr, supported an underground religious movement that preached a return to Islamic principles in government and social justice for all. Antigovernment riots in the name of Islam were crushed.
In 1979, after the ayatollah led a procession lauding the Islamic revolution in Iran, Shiites staged massive riots against the Iraqi regime. The following year, the ayatollah, his sister and their followers were executed. When Shiites in the south revolted after the 1991 gulf war, Mr. Hussein sent in his elite Republican Guards, who strafed crowds, doused the wounded with gasoline and set them on fire and publicly hanged captives as a lesson to would-be plotters.
"Not only is Saddam not an Islamic fundamentalist, he has been at war with the fundamentalists," said Judith Yaphe, a senior research fellow at the National Defense University. "The only loyalty he trusts is loyalty to himself. So God is a rival."
Yet Mr. Hussein, like Mr. bin Laden, understands the power of religion and has used its imagery to reinvent himself. In what many Muslims regarded as heresy, Mr. Hussein, a Sunni Muslim, had a family tree done that traced his ancestry to Mohammad's daughter Fatima, his son-in-law Ali and their son Hussein, the spiritual patrons of Shiites. During the war against Iran, Mr. Hussein denounced Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's claims to the leadership of the Islamic world. The Persians, he said, could not lead the Muslim world. 
In the late 1980's, Mr. Hussein made the pilgrimage to Mecca that every good Muslim must do at least once. Photographs of Mr. Hussein draped in the white shroud of a pilgrim, kissing the Black Stone at the Grand Mosque have been hung in the courtyards of Shiite mosques across the country. 
Recently, Mr. Hussein has taken his use of religion to a level not even Mr. bin Laden aspires to. In a mosque outside Baghdad sits a handwritten copy of the Koran. Officials claim that in the last 3 years Mr. Hussein gave 50 pints of blood to produce the ink for the 600-page book.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Saddam Hussein's image dominates Iraq. (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Backing Bloomberg, Latinos' Hopes Are High 

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
Latino New Yorkers voted Republican in significant numbers for the first time in this year's mayoral election, becoming a significant factor in Michael R. Bloomberg's victory. Now they want results.
 From average voters to political, business and grass-roots leaders, many said they expected the new administration to appoint Latinos to high-ranking positions and increase their numbers in city government to a share more reflective of their population in the city. Currently, Latinos make up about 27 percent of the population, and about 15 percent of the city government's employees. 
 "Numbers count," said State Senator Olga A. Mendez, a Democrat and one of the few Puerto Rican elected officials who endorsed Mr. Bloomberg in the mayoral race. She said she has lobbied for her own preferences, including Tino Hernandez, who was just reappointed chairman of the city Housing Authority.
Another priority is shielding schools, hospitals and public housing from budget cuts.
"I can't see any more cuts than we've suffered in the past eight years," said Luis Garden-Acosta, a Brooklyn community leader who is on the mayor-elect's transition committee. "That would be unconscionable."
Mr. Garden-Acosta said the mayor should reward Hispanic voters by spending on services, even if that means Police Department cutbacks or tax increases, which Mr. Bloomberg ruled out during his campaign. Mr. Garden-Acosta said the police could save money by reducing waste and duplication and altering its use of some personnel. And he said Mr. Bloomberg should expand after-school programs, even if doing so required a surcharge on taxpayers.
But Ms. Mendez said she trusted that Mr. Bloomberg would use his business skills to creatively address problems without extra spending -- by attracting private money, for example, or striking favorable deals with state and federal officials -- as he tackles rebuilding the city's economy after the trade center attack.
"We have to look for reasonable solutions because there's no money," she said. "The budget deficit is going to be terrible. I have faith that he'll come up with new ideas."
In neighborhoods like Corona, Queens, where up to half of the mostly Democratic Latino electorate defected to Mr. Bloomberg's camp, voters did not have to think hard when asked what the new mayor should do: fix public schools with crumbling buildings and inadequate teaching, do something about six-week waits for doctors' appointments and household budgets squeezed by jumps in rent of $350 or more.
In political circles, meanwhile, the initial focus has been on trying to turn the Hispanic Bloomberg vote into real gains by getting Latinos appointed to commissions and high-level posts. 
Those interviewed were hesitant to give specific numbers, but said they expected more representation in decision-making positions, and more diversity in agencies that need it.
"We need people at Bill Cunningham's level if the constituency is going to get its due," said Juan Figueroa, president and general counsel of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, referring to William Cunningham, a top aide of Mr. Bloomberg's.
Expectations among Latinos range from high to nil. Political leaders like Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic Party leader who supported Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer's mayoral bid, said he had never spoken to Mr. Bloomberg nor shaken his hand and personally expected nothing from him.
Some Latino supporters of Mr. Bloomberg's said that the mayor-elect did not really owe them anything, that he never made any promises beyond building an administration of "the best and the brightest" to reflect the city's demographics.
To that end, some members of the mayor-elect's transition committee said they had made sure to offer the names of qualified Latinos for consideration for every available position, and to give their opinion of other candidates being considered for important agencies, like the Human Resources Administration.
"We were as concerned about Latinos being in the mix as we were that other candidates were Latino-friendly," one committee member said.
Angelo Falcon, a senior policy executive with the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, said the onus was on the Latino leadership to push its agenda.
"We got people's attention," Mr. Falcon said. "The question is what do we do now with that attention? That's not real political power."
He added: "It's not like he's going to repay us and we can sit on our hands. If we don't put the issues in front of his face, he's not going to deal with them."
So far Mr. Bloomberg seems to be off to a good start with his Latino constituency. Symbolic gestures, like traveling to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic and holding a breakfast meeting with Mr. Ferrer, the Democrat who lost to Mark Green in the party primary, right after his election, have signaled a new, more inclusive style of leadership than that of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, some Latino political leaders said.
Many also praised him for the high number -- 10 -- and diversity of Latinos in his transition committee, from Mr. Garden-Acosta and Susana Torruella Leval, president of El Museo del Barrio, to the labor leader Dennis Rivera and Andy Unanue, chief operating officer of Goya Foods. 
Mr. Bloomberg also appointed a Puerto Rican woman, Carol A. Robles-Roman, his deputy mayor for legal affairs.
"He has shown he's putting aside electoral politics and wants to work with all the sectors," said Miguel Martinez, a newly elected member of the City Council who was born in the Dominican Republic and whom Mr. Bloomberg asked to accompany him to the Caribbean last month, even though Mr. Martinez had endorsed Mr. Green in the election.
The Rev. Ruben Diaz, a councilman who also supported Mr. Bloomberg's candidacy, said, "We're getting access to City Hall." He said he expected the mayor's commissioners and deputy mayors to be reachable as well.
Mr. Bloomberg won 47 percent of the Hispanic vote, voter surveys showed, even though most Latino voters are registered Democrats and their turnout in the Democratic primary was a record high of about 28 percent, prompted by a viable Latino candidate.
But that candidate, Mr. Ferrer, a New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent, narrowly lost the primary runoff to Mr. Green, who offended many Ferrer supporters with his negative advertisements.
Hispanic voters struck back by either staying home or splitting the vote between Mr. Green and Mr. Bloomberg. Mr. Green won 49 percent of the Hispanic vote, voter surveys showed.
Now many Hispanic New Yorkers are optimistic that Mr. Bloomberg will come through for them.
"People's expectations are higher and rightly so," Mr. Figueroa said. "We haven't been at the table and we're barely touching it, but we're touching it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael R. Bloomberg, right, and Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat, in the Dominican Republic last month. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TRANSFER OF POWER; 
Afghan Leader Is Sworn In, Asking for Help to Rebuild

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 22 

 BODY:
Appealing for help from God, his fellow citizens and the outside world to unify and rebuild his war-ravaged nation, Hamid Karzai, an Afghan tribal leader with a regal bearing and an aristocratic lineage, was sworn in today as chairman of an interim government that replaces the defeated Taliban.
 Resplendent in a purple and green traditional robe, Mr. Karzai bowed his head five times as a diverse array of Afghan leaders and 2,000 spectators applauded his inauguration. 
 In the audience was Gen. Tommy R. Franks, commander of the United States-led campaign that brought down the Taliban and routed Osama bin Laden's terrorism network, which is blamed for the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. 
Adding to the optimism and calm that pervaded the capital today was the show of unity by two Afghan military commanders who had been expected to snub the ceremony: Gen. Rashid Dostum, the dominant commander in northern Afghanistan, and Gen. Ismail Khan, a powerful leader in the west. Both arrived in Kabul this morning. General Khan entered the packed hall during Mr. Karzai's speech.
In that speech, in which he struck a plain-spoken, humble tone, Mr. Karzai called on Afghans here and around the world to join in the challenge of reconstructing a nation brought down by decades of conflict.
"In this critical time, when our motherland is watching our actions, let us come together and be brothers and sisters," he said. "Let us be good to each other and be compassionate and share our grief. Let us forget the sad past."
Dozens of foreign ministers, ambassadors and foreign military officers looked on as Mr. Karzai spoke. General Franks and James F. Dobbins, the United States special envoy, were in the front row. Nearby were the foreign ministers of Iran, Pakistan and India and the Russian special envoy to Afghanistan.
Mr. Karzai then swore in the 29 members of his cabinet, who are to administer the country for six months, the first phase of a political transition intended to lead to elections within two and a half years.
The new government faces a staggering task.
Afghanistan is a desolate, drought-stricken landscape of bombed-out factories and graveyards where the prime economic activities are smuggling and primitive farming. Vast swaths of its south remain ruled by tribal councils and bandits. Eighty percent of the population is illiterate. One out of four children die before the age of 5. 
The new government will be tested in other ways. Mr. Karzai and the three Northern Alliance leaders who are expected to dominate the cabinet are from a generation of younger moderates who say they are different from the generation of older warlords who ravaged the country in the early 1990's. 
The four men put the blame for Afghanistan's internal strife on outside countries that have backed and armed different factions, rather than on Afghans themselves. With nations in the region and the United States now pressing for unity, Afghans will have to show whether that is true.
Yunus Qanooni, the new interior minister and one of the senior Northern Alliance leaders, said the ceremony was the first time in Afghan history that power had been peacefully transferred between two parties.
Burhanuddin Rabbani, head of the Northern Alliance and the internationally recognized president of Afghanistan even after the Taliban gained control of most of the country, handed power over to Mr. Karzai under a United Nations-brokered accord reached by Afghan parties near Bonn three weeks ago.
"It is privilege for the Afghan nation that we are all under this roof," Mr. Qanooni said, referring to the array of Pashtuns, Tajiks, Hazaras and other ethnic groups that filled the stage. "Afghans have decided not to hear a single gunshot. Instead they want to listen to the music of peace."
The ceremony culminated in Mr. Karzai's taking a new Afghan oath of office, in which he pledged to protect the rules and laws of Islam and also to defend human rights.
As the oath was administered by the acting head of the Afghan Supreme Court, members of the audience leaned forward in their chairs and craned their necks to see the stage. As Mr. Karzai uttered the final words of the oath, Mr. Rabbani stepped forward, and the new and former Afghan leaders embraced.
At a news conference after the ceremony, Mr. Karzai said the government would be measured by its achievements, or lack of them. The line in his speech that had received especially loud applause was a call to end the corruption that plagues the country and could threaten the efficient use of an estimated $16 billion in reconstruction and development aid.
"The significance of this day in Afghan history really depends on what happens in the future," Mr. Karzai said in fluent English. "If we deliver, this will be a great day. If we don't deliver, this will go into oblivion." 
But hints of potential political division lingered in the cavernous, Soviet-style assembly hall in the Interior Ministry where the ceremony was held. An enormous banner depicting Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Northern Alliance military leader who was assassinated in September, hung from the stage.
The loudest shouts and applause were prompted by mentions of Mr. Massoud's death. Troops and commanders from the often-fractious alliance, which is dominated by Tajik, Uzbek, Hazaras and other northern minorities, clearly dominated the audience.
Mr. Karzai, a Pashtun and former deputy foreign minister, is from the southern city of Kandahar, and he was once a rival of the Northern Alliance. He is a supporter and relative of the exiled former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, whom many Pashtuns support. 
The new government itself emerged from a political compromise. Many of its members were chosen because they filled ethnic or gender quotas that made the Bonn agreement acceptable to the country's factions. 
Eleven departments will be run by Pashtuns, eight by Tajiks, five by Hazaras, three by Uzbeks and three by other minorities. 
Various officials, including General Dostum, an Uzbek, have complained that the three most powerful departments -- interior, defense and foreign -- went to the Tajik-dominated Northern Alliance. 
But for today at least, unity appears to have prevailed. General Dostum, during his appearance here, issued a statement of support for the new government. Pashtuns and Hazaras said they felt comfortable in Kabul, which is being run by police officers drawn from the Northern Alliance.
The arrival of General Franks this morning momentarily ended the festive atmosphere outside the hall, where martial music played and the police welcomed dignitaries. 
Reporters shouted questions about reports that American warplanes had attacked a convoy of tribal leaders headed for the ceremony, mistakenly thinking that they were fleeing Taliban or members of Mr. bin Laden's Al Qaeda network.
Today, residents of Asmani Kilai in eastern Paktia Province told the Reuters news agency that airstrikes Thursday night and Friday morning destroyed houses and a mosque and killed civilians in the village as well as people in the convoy. One villager suggested that a rival commander might have deliberately misinformed American forces about the identity of the people in the convoy in order to settle a score.
But General Franks said he had received reports that the convoy had fired on American aircraft before it was bombed. "We'll take a hard, firm look at it," he said. "It looks like it was a good target at this point."
Amid continuing questions about Mr. bin Laden's whereabouts, Reuters said today that Pakistan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, told Beijing state television that there was a strong possibility that Mr. bin Laden was killed in the bombing of the Tora Bora mountains. He added that Pakistan was still keeping a strong watch at the border for him.
"He is not in Pakistan, that we are reasonably sure, but we can't be 100 percent sure," General Musharraf said. "And if he does enter, if we identify him, he will be handed over."
 Near Kandahar, engineers worked Saturday to expand a temporary prison camp at the Marine base in expectation of receiving 100 to 300 more Al Qaeda and Taliban detainees. The camp currently holds 16 inmates. 
Inside the hall in Kabul, the talk was of victory over the Taliban and hope for the future. The line that seemed to draw the most emotion in the audience was not from an Afghan speaker, but from the Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel. He made a reference to Mr. Massoud, the slain alliance commander, that captured the combination of grief, exhaustion and aching hope. 
"I am sure," Mr. Michel said, "that Mr. Massoud is proud of his nation today." That single sentence sent tears rolling down scores of weathered, wrinkled and scarred cheeks in the audience.

HEADLINE: ARTS ONLINE; 
Driven by a Higher Calling, Not Dot-Com Dollars

BYLINE:  By Matthew Mirapaul 

 BODY:
Romance without finance, as the jazz musician Tiny Grimes once sang, is a nuisance. Art without money, on the other hand, is such a familiar refrain that it is almost expected.
 And so it was in 2001 for the online arts, which flourished despite a dearth of dollars. The collapse of countless e-commerce ventures may have prompted many to dismiss the Internet as a viable economic platform, but it certainly remains vital as a creative medium. 
 "The dot-com bust has cleared out the carpetbaggers and left the Internet to those who really care about it," said Jon Ippolito, a digital artist and new-media curator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
The sheer volume of work produced in 2001 indicates that enthusiasm for the medium is still high among artists, even if their interest was fueled by the realization that they were not going to get rich designing Web pages for Sow-Ear.com. Perhaps they were motivated by the recognition that making digital art might yield greater, if less tangible, rewards.
There was good art, too, including works that helped define the emerging genre. "Feed," by the New York artist Mark Napier, is the most refined example yet of an artist's browser, displaying Web pages as though they were tiny, animated Abstract Expressionist paintings. "The Apartment," by Marek Walczak and Martin Wattenberg, New York artists, converted a viewer's typed words into a virtual 3-D space, its walls made from images culled from the Net. And "life_sharing," by the Italian duo known as 0100101110101101.org, made all of their computing activities public in an effort to show that art imitates one's hard drive.
Mr. Napier said Net art met the real world in 2001. "We're past the initial glow of excitement about a new medium," he said. "Now the challenge is to take this beyond a small group of intrepid explorers and the gee-whiz of a new technology and into an art form that can engage a larger audience and sustain itself in the long run." As the year opened, museums were primed to supply that audience. "Feed," at feed.projects.sfmoma.org, and "The Apartment," at turbulence.org/ Works/apartment, were shown during high-profile digital-art exhibitions at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York. 
Institutional support seemed to fade along with the technology sector's prospects, though. The oft-postponed opening of the Guggenheim Virtual Museum was delayed again while the museum built its dot-com site and now must be considered "vaporware," which is the computer industry's term for promised products that never arrive. The Museum of Modern Art in New York, which had planned to commission a series of online works in 2001, has put up only one, an indecipherable piece by the video artist Tony Oursler, and has none scheduled yet for next year. The San Francisco Modern's $50,000 competition for digital art has been postponed while the museum searches for a new director.
High-tech companies were in no position to pick up the slack. The financially ailing Lucent Technologies pulled the plug on its sponsorship of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's new-media program. Intel, which had mounted a series of online exhibitions at its ArtMuseum.net site, is donating the venture to a nonprofit organization, people familiar with the deal said. The site may be reborn next year as part of ArtAndCulture .org. An Intel spokesman said the site's status had not changed, and he declined to comment on plans for it. 
"It's a really hard time for funding right now," said Beau Takahara, director of ZeroOne, a Silicon Valley nonprofit organization that supports tech-art initiatives. She continued: "For two months after Sept. 11, it was virtually impossible to ask anyone for a gift. Now the asking seems possible -- the holiday spirit seems to be kicking in -- but the companies are still really hurting."
Yet online artwork continues to be made. An example of this might be found in etoy, a group of anonymous artists who use the Internet to mimic -- and thus comment on -- corporate behavior. Two years ago the online retailer eToys.com sued the artists over their longstanding etoy.com Web address, claiming it confused their customers. This year eToys.com is bankrupt, but the etoy artists are as active as ever.
The etoy and "life_sharing" projects illustrate how the genre is evolving away from the computer screen and its interactive graphics. The Internet is increasingly being used as an element in larger, conceptually oriented pieces that spill over into the physical as performances or installations. 
As wireless technology becomes more pervasive, digital artists are adapting it to their own devices. For instance the artist Patrick Lichty has organized an online exhibition, at voyd.com/ia, of works made for handheld computers. In 2002 the public-art presenters Creative Time are planning a series of wireless-based projects, including one that will transform a segment of SoHo sidewalk into a computer screen that displays text messages sent from cellular telephones.
Christiane Paul, the Whitney's new-media curator, has selected a wireless work, "Tap" by James Buckhouse, for the museum's 2002 Biennial exhibition, and she expects to see more made. "Information networks should be nomadic and flexible," she said, "and our current setup of the static computer hooked up to a network somehow contradicts that concept."
Digital artists have not abandoned the screen completely. They continue to explore the aesthetics of computer games. Interactive-sound projects, which are programmed to produce music in response to a visitor's actions, are becoming more sophisticated. Doo-wop fans will adore Jim Andrews's "Nio," at vispo.com. An intriguing new musical poem, "Story Problem," by the author Terri Ford and the multimedia designer Erik Loyer, will go online officially on Jan. 1 but can be previewed now at bornmag.org/projects/sp.
How is all this work being produced if there is no financial support for it? It is often simply a labor of love. Some institutions do appear willing to support the nascent genre in other ways. The Guggenheim has begun a preservation initiative, and the Whitney is home to an online-art history project, "Idea Line," at whitney.org/artport, that traces themes in the genre's growth.
For Tilman Baumgartel of Berlin, the author of "net.art 2.0" (Verlag fur Moderne Kunst Nurnberg, 2001), there is more to online art than money. "In the middle of the 90's, people treated me like I was crazy because I didn't found a start-up to become a millionaire," he said. "Now all the people that wanted to become millionaires with the Net have disappeared. But, hey, the Net art scene is still exciting."
As a Gershwin-loving Santa might sing, "Ho, ho, ho, who's got the last laugh now?"

HEADLINE: Drama and Pragmatism Drive Fight Over aHiring 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
The news release last Friday by SANgate Systems did not tell the half of it.
 SANgate, a privately held data storage start-up company based in Southborough, Mass., announced that Patrick Courtin had joined the company as chairman and chief executive. 
 Mr. Courtin, whose most recent stop on a 20-year career in technology companies was at a software company called Gensym, was quoted as being "thrilled" with SANgate's potential. Thomas Crotty, a board member whose venture capital firm, Battery Ventures, is a major SANgate shareholder, was said to be "extremely pleased" to have someone with Mr. Courtin's experience and track record on board. 
What SANgate did not mention was that Mr. Courtin was hired less than a month after EMC, the data storage giant, got a Massachusetts court to quash SANgate's previous choice for chief, Doron Kempel. Until SANgate tapped him in September, Mr. Kempel had been general manager of an EMC division developing products for storing and retrieving multimedia data. 
EMC argued that Mr. Kempel's contract barred him from moving to a potential competitor within 12 months of leaving EMC. As part of SANgate's legal response, Mr. Crotty submitted an affidavit asserting that the company would need six months to find a replacement for Mr. Kempel if he could not come aboard and that it faced "irreparable financial damage."
Asked on Friday to square the court testimony with the sudden appearance of Mr. Courtin, Mr. Crotty said that presenting a dire outlook in defense of Mr. Kempel had been simply "part of the process." Battery Ventures was in fact prepared to move quickly to provide a successor because it has a partner, Cornel Faucher, whose sole job is maintaining a list of suitable candidates to lead the companies in which Battery invests. 
"SANgate's board moved into interview mode the day after the ruling," Mr. Crotty said. "Also, this happens to be a good time to be looking because of the economy. A normal search can take six months."
Is SANgate, which has no products yet, really a threat to EMC, which will finish 2001 with revenues of about $6.8 billion? That was probably not the point to EMC, which has a reputation for strictly enforcing provisions in its employment contracts that restrict who can hire its workers. By EMC's philosophy, it is better to be paranoid than sorry.
"Does it make people think twice about hiring EMC employees?" said Mr. Crotty. "Absolutely. It's a business strategy that, much as I hate to admit it, is working for them."

HEADLINE: Patents; 
A mother dreams up a way forchildren to study while they eat breakfast.

BYLINE:  By Teresa Riordan 

 BODY:
DIANE ZEGARRA, a pastor and entrepreneur in Hermon, Me., says her moment of inventive insight was divinely inspired.
 "My daughter was 7 years old at the time, going to a private Christian school, and she was very slow in her reading class," Mrs. Zegarra said. "She was really discouraged with school to the point where she wanted me to home-school her. So I just prayed and I asked the Lord to give me an idea." 
 First, Mrs. Zegarra had a dream. "I saw a big, thick book with pages turning and I saw these drawings on these pages," she said. "In my heart I knew that these were all the inventions that had not been invented yet."
Two weeks later, Mrs. Zegarra had a "vision."
"I was praying at about 5 o'clock in the morning and this idea, it just flashed through my head," she said. "I saw my daughter sitting at the kitchen table, staring at a cereal box."
But it wasn't an ordinary cereal box. "This cereal box was inside a beautiful cover and her papers were in there," she said. Mrs. Zegarra said she saw her daughter reading blissfully -- not the back of the cereal box but rather, her homework, which had been tucked inside the special, clear cover.
"I told this girl that cuts my hair about it," Mrs. Zegarra said. "I knew this was an awesome idea but I can't sew. She said, 'I can make you one.' "
So Mrs. Zegarra, who was operating a second-hand store out of the side of her house at the time, brought some materials to her beautician. 
They fashioned a prototype of Mrs. Zegarra's idea out of clear polyvinyl. The result was something like a see-through tote bag that a cereal box sits inside. It had an 8-by-10-inch pocket into which homework sheets could be inserted, and other pockets for things like erasable markers.
Mrs. Zegarra said her daughter, Christina, was so excited by the box cover that she spent every morning at breakfast working on her homework, and soon she was reading at grade level.
"As a study aid, it changed her life," Mrs. Zegarra said.
So Mrs. Zegarra decided to bring her invention -- for which she recently received United States patent 6,279,747 -- to the marketplace. That is when her tribulations began.
To pay for patent fees and prototypes, Mrs. Zegarra said, she and her husband sold their car and van.
Finding manufacturing costs too high in the United States, they went to her husband's home country, Peru, where they had a company in Lima make 200 of the study aids, she said.
"I've probably got $30,000-plus into this bag," Mrs. Zegarra said.
Once back in Maine, Mrs. Zegarra started marketing her study aid, selling it locally for $20 to $25.
She said she was approached by a doctor who promised her a licensing deal, but then reneged. "I had patent pending but he copied my whole invention." Mrs. Zegarra said. "When I found that out, I just cried." 
This fall, she and her husband were laid off as youth pastors at the Abundant Life Church, a nondenominational church, leaving her with few resources to promote her invention. "I didn't want to go on the government," she said. "My husband could have collected unemployment, but we wanted to trust in God."
Then another idea came to Mrs. Zegarra, who said she had been increasingly worried about money. "We have a huge garden out back," she said. "So I made three loaves of zucchini bread and sliced them up and went out to sell them. My husband started laughing at me. But I was home in 20 minutes and I had $14 in my hand."
So she began selling breakfast and lunch to car mechanics and office workers on a regular basis.
Mrs. Zegarra still hasn't licensed her study aid, though her ambition is to have it featured on QVC, the television shopping network. But, she noted, the Lord works in mysterious ways. She and her husband recently started their own ministry, which meets weekly in their converted two-car garage. And Mrs. Zegarra's food business is prospering. "I sell more than 100 brownies and cakes a day," she said. "I never intended it to be so successful."

HEADLINE: Shoplifting Is Adding to Retailing Difficulties 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
As a guard at the new Toys "R" Us flagship store in Times Square, Alvin Foote has seen plenty of bold thieves this season. There are the children who stuff video games under their shirts. There was the man who wheeled a shopping cart into the store with a large gift box in it and then tried to wheel it out again full of toys without passing the registers.
 Then there was the man who tried to steal the giant stuffed giraffe. "The head was coming out of the jacket, so we caught him," Mr. Foote explained. 
 In a year of shopping woes that include plunging profit margins and unseasonably warm weather, add a rising tide of shoplifters to the threats that retailers must combat.
The number of people on the make for the proverbial five-fingered discount always surges during holiday times as stores grow more crowded and thieves find it easier to blend in without detection. This year, however, loss prevention experts see a convergence of factors, including a weakening economy, psychological stress from the Sept. 11 attacks and the trend toward longer store hours with smaller staffs, that may swell the ranks of shoplifters much more than usual.
Not until retailers do their final inventories in January will the damage done this season really be known, if ever. Major retailers are reluctant to discuss crime in their stores. "We hate to talk about anything negative this time of year," said a Bloomingdale's spokeswoman, Anne Keating. Several chains including Best Buys and Wilson's: The Leather Experts say they have seen no recent increase in shopper theft.
Losses from shoplifting gradually rose over recent years to about $13 billion in 2000, the most recent figure available, according to the University of Florida Retail Security Survey. More current statistics are difficult to come by because most large cities -- including Los Angeles and New York -- do not track shoplifting as a separate category but include it in petty larceny. The Chicago police say retail theft is down 10 percent for all 2001, but have no numbers available for the last three months alone -- the period in which retailers noticed more shoplifting. 
Still, there is evidence that it is a tough season out there. The Denver Police Department, one of the few large metropolitan forces that has a separate citywide shoplifting unit, says that for October and November cases were up 12 percent from last year. December is not over, but already complaints appear to be higher than they were in the 2000 holiday season. "We've seen a big rise this year," said Diane Stark, a detective, who says electronic items and DVD's are particularly popular among crooks. "We think it is because the economy is bad and a lot of people are being laid off." Moreover, the toll has been heavy enough in recent months that some retailers have had to speak up. The CVS Corporation, one of the nation's largest drugstore chains, says shrinkage, the industry term for unexplained inventory losses, started to rise noticeably at the beginning of the third quarter with thieves going after items like batteries and disposable cameras. "Clearly I believe the weak economy is certainly a factor in increased shrinkage," Tom Ryan, chief executive of CVS, told stock analysts during a call a month and a half ago to report the company's third-quarter earnings. Mr. Ryan said he expected the problem to continue into the first half of 2002.
Convenience stores are also expecting a rise in theft on goods with high resale value. "The general sense is that with a down economy some items like batteries, razors and phone cards are seeing more organized theft," said Jeff Leonard, spokesman for the National Association of Convenience Stores.
If there is any clear factor motivating the fleet of hand it is the slowdown of the national economy, which has led to job loss and fear of job loss. During the boom years of the late 1990's shoplifting losses rose less than $1 billion in five years. Losses from employee theft rose much more swiftly.
The current economic downturn will increase shoplifting by $1 billion in 2002 alone, according to a study commissioned by Checkpoint Systems, which manufactures security tags for retail products, from Retail Forward, Inc., a retail research and consulting firm. 
"Looking at the past 30 years, there is a significant correlation between shoplifting and variables that change significantly in an economic downturn such as unemployment claims, the savings rate and retail prices," said Frank Badillo, the senior retail economist who designed the study for Retail Forward .
Retail crimes demand not just motive, of course, but also opportunity, and this season retailers are providing plenty of the latter. To cut costs, stores have dramatically scaled back their staffs. Seasonally adjusted employment at department stores plunged by 45,000 this October and November, according to the Department of Labor. 
Not all of those employees would have been walking the floors and deterring theft. But the labor cuts come when everyone from Kmart to Saks Fifth Avenue is suddenly adding extra hours in a last-ditch effort to save a dismal season.
"Retailers are running extended hours without hiring extra employees or putting in overtime hours," said Burt Flickinger III, the managing director of Reach Marketing, a consulting firm in Westport, Conn. "Executives are now running scared that when they do inventories at the end of the fiscal year, they will pay a record price in missing inventories."
There are roughly two kinds of shoplifting. Shoplifting by professional gangs represents a minority of offenders, but a disproportionate amount of financial damage. The more common type is the impulse shoplifter. This person is motivated not by need but by anger. Over the years, various rich and famous people have been caught in the act. 
Earlier this month, for example, the actress Winona Ryder was arrested on charges of shoplifting at the Saks Fifth Avenue boutiques in Beverly Hills after she was found removing the security tags from some $4,760 in clothing.
Since impulse shoplifting has been linked to such psychological factors as stress and depression, several shoplifting counselors also think the attacks of Sept. 11 and the aftermath could greatly increase the ranks of this type of thief.
"Shoplifting is not about financial problems. It is about getting something for nothing," said Peter Berlin, executive director of Shoplifter's Alternative, a national nonprofit group that treats shoplifters. "Many people do as a substitute for loss: the loss of health, a loved one, a job, or a stock market loss. It is a kind of payback."
Mr. Berlin said he has polled his shoplifter support groups, which treat some 30,000 people, to see how Sept. 11 would effect their behavior. "Everyone said the compulsion was the same or greater," he said. "No one said it was less."

HEADLINE: Christmas Dinner For 1,000 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The soup kitchen at the Church of the Holy Apostles on Ninth Avenue in Chelsea is the largest in New York. And the operators of the kitchen will try to make today, Christmas Eve, a little special for the people in tough circumstances who show up for a meal.
 The ranks of the hungry and the homeless are swelling in New York. And it's not easy to have a merry Christmas when your wallet is empty, your stomach is tightening from hunger, and you haven't a place to stay. 
 Holy Apostles sees some of the hardest cases -- the men who aren't working, who may be abusers of drugs or alcohol, who may be mentally ill or H.I.V. positive, or may have spent time in prison. They don't get a lot of sympathy. But they are human. And today they will be able to sit down in a warm and clean environment with more than 1,000 other hungry and homeless New Yorkers, and feast on a traditional holiday dinner. They'll have roast turkey with giblet gravy, mashed potatoes, glazed carrots, cranberry sauce, pumpkin pie, ice cream -- the works.
But those are just a few of the homeless New Yorkers. Between 25,000 and 30,000 people are showing up at the homeless shelters each night, and many others are sleeping in the subways, in the parks or on the street.
It wasn't that long ago that we were crowing about the economy, patting ourselves on the back and telling anyone who would listen that it was the best of times. And, yet, across the country hundreds of thousands of people were struggling with the desperate and demoralizing experience of homelessness. That population has only grown as a result of the economic downturn of the past several months and, especially in New York, the devastating economic effects of the Sept. 11 tragedy.
"Before it was announced that we were in a recession we knew it," said the Rev. William Greenlaw, the soup kitchen's director, in a reference to the increased demand at Holy Apostles. "Now we're getting the ripple effect from 9/11."
The evidence of increased homelessness can be seen across the city this holiday season, and the problem is likely to get substantially worse before it improves.
The homeless population served by the shelter system consists primarily of families with children. For them, unsure of where they will be staying on any given night, the quest for a happy holiday is less than a top priority.
Annette Quinones and her 5-year-old daughter, Taylor, were among those who showed up to apply for shelter at the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx. When she was asked what she would be doing for Christmas, Ms. Quinones said: "Nothing. Trying to get housing." She added, "It's a sad way to spend Christmas and there are lots of people in this situation."
Marcia Dristell was also at the assistance unit, with her two children, Arshad, 10, and Melicia, 9. Ms. Dristell said her son was hearing impaired and had not been to school in a month because the family has been bouncing from one temporary location to another. When Arshad was asked what he wanted for Christmas, he said, "All I want is a house to live in peace and to go to school."
One of the reasons so many people were homeless even before the economy tanked was the shortage of housing that could be afforded by people earning low wages. Try renting an apartment in New York on a hamburger-flipper's pay. When the downturn hit, individuals who were earning more than the minimum wage but still were barely making enough to stave off eviction notices were suddenly finding themselves out of work entirely. With no savings to fall back on, many ended up homeless.
Americans have been waging war on the poor for a long time. The late-90's boom shielded this shameful practice for awhile, but now, with unemployment rising and welfare time limits kicking in, the signs of distress are becoming more and more visible.
Homelessness is not an unsolvable problem. There are programs that are successfully housing previously homeless people, whether they were working families or individuals who simply could not afford housing, or people who were physically disabled, or who suffered from mental illness, or men and women addicted to alcohol or drugs. The blueprints for such programs are available. What has been lacking is a national commitment to address the myriad problems associated with poverty.
Homelessness is just one of them.

HEADLINE: Koizumi Calls for Vigilance After Japan Sinks Suspicious Boat 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 23 

 BODY:
Japan's prime minister called for increased territorial vigilance today after a pitched naval battle in which the Japanese Coast Guard traded heavy fire with a vessel suspected of being a North Korean spy ship before it sank just inside an economic zone claimed by China. The ship's entire crew of 15 is believed to have drowned.
 "The situation is deplorable in that armed, suspicious boats are infesting waters around our country in this manner," Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said today. "We need to consider countermeasures." 
 Since taking office last April, Mr. Koizumi, a nationalist, has raised the profile of Japan's military, sending ships to the Indian Ocean to help the United States in the war against terrorism and winning passage of a new law that allows Japanese military ships to use greater force in patrolling national waters.
Coast Guard officials briefed reporters in Tokyo today on the incident. They said that in waters midway between Shanghai and Japan's southernmost main island, two bodies of Asian men were recovered from the South China Sea today. Korean writing was found on one man's life preserver and on a bag of candy in the other's pocket. A third body sank before it could be recovered. Autopsies are planned for Monday to determine whether the men committed suicide to avoid capture, a characteristic of North Korean intelligence operations.
After the ship sank on Saturday night at 10:13 local time, the three Japanese Coast Guard vessels involved in the pursuit trained their search lights on the site, spotting about half a dozen crew members clinging to flotsam in the water. But the Japanese did not rescue the men, reportedly on orders from commanders in Tokyo, who feared that they were armed. Two hours after the sinking, no more crew members were seen alive.
Today, Naoto Kan, secretary general of Japan's opposition Democratic Party, called for an investigation of the battle, Japan's first naval engagement in almost half a century.
Although North Korea had not responded by this evening, the sinking and loss of life are a further blow to relations between two countries that last had direct talks on normalizing ties 14 months ago.
On Friday afternoon, just before sunset, a Japanese maritime patrol plane spotted a 100-ton vessel built like a fishing boat, but without fishing gear. The boat, about 90 miles northwest of Amami-Oshima Island, was well inside Japan's 200-mile exclusive fishing zone, according to the Coast Guard. It appeared identical to a fast-moving North Korean spy boat that eluded pursuing Coast Guard boats two years ago, officials said. 
On Saturday morning, a Coast Guard boat, the Inasa, caught up with the boat inside Japanese economic waters. Over two hours, crew members of another Coast Guard boat, the Mizuki, used a bullhorn to order the boat to stop. The Japanese boats fired a total of 13 warning shots across its bow, officials said. The boat, which had been zigzagging, bumped the Inasa. 
When the Japanese tried to board it, about 10 men on board brandished metal pipes. Just after sunset, the Mizuki fired several hundred rounds from its 20 millimeter machine gun into the fleeing boat. In a videotape supplied today by the Coast Guard, the ship could be seen bursting into flames.
But the crew managed to douse the fire, and the ship continued to flee due west, toward the Chinese mainland. By 9 p.m. the Japanese pursuit group had grown to four ships, and commanders decided to surround the vessel. As one of the Japanese ships, the Amami, came within 25 yards, two men emerged from blankets on the deck of the mystery boat and fired automatic weapons at the Japanese, wounding two sailors. Crew members in the wheelhouse also fired on the Japanese.
In response, the Inasa fired "186 rounds in self-defense," Shigehiro Sakamoto, a Coast Guard official, said. During the gun battle, a large explosion, apparently unrelated to the firing, was heard aboard the mystery ship, Japanese sailors reported. Shortly after the explosion, the ship sank and 15 crew members were seen jumping into the water.
"It is possible that crew members themselves sank the ship deliberately," Shinzo Abe, Japan's deputy chief cabinet secretary, said today.
In Beijing today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said the boat was not Chinese, but expressed "concern toward Japanese use of military force in the East China Sea."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ARMY BASE; 
In a Rugged Military Town, a Lonely Christmas

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: FORT DRUM, N.Y., Dec. 23 

 BODY:
The call came one Saturday night in October as the Santiago family sprawled on the living room couch watching television. The phone conversation lasted just a few seconds, but Stacy Santiago knew from her husband's stony expression what it meant.
 Two hours later, Sgt. Jose Santiago, a biochemical specialist with the Army's 10th Mountain Division, was gone, leaving her with their three children and persistent anxieties about his safety. He could not say where he was going, but the desert-style battle fatigues Sergeant Santiago donned gave away the destination. "I knew he was going to Afghanistan," she said. 
 Over the past two months, similar calls have cleaved hundreds of other families whose lives are tethered to Fort Drum, the northeast's biggest military installation and home to the 10th Mountain Division, the fabled quick-strike battalion whose members have been scouring Afghanistan's craggy terrain in search of Osama bin Laden and other members of Al Qaeda. Although a spokesman for the base would not discuss troop deployments, Army officials say at least 1,000 men and women from the division have been sent to Central Asia since October, with many others poised to join them. 
It is a particularly lonely and unnerving Christmas for families like the Santiagos, who have had little contact with those stationed in Afghanistan or neighboring Uzbekistan. "I've already broken down a few times," Mrs. Santiago, 31, said as she prepared Christmas dinner for five other women whose husbands are in Central Asia. "It's been rough, and it's going to be worse on Christmas when we're opening the presents."
While many families here are grappling with similar emotions, pride and patriotism are the reigning sentiments here in Watertown, population 25,700, where life is dominated by the military and nearly everyone knows someone who goes to work in fatigues. There are 10,500 military personnel and another 2,000 civilians employed at the base, whose main entrance begins about nine miles from Watertown's Victorian-era public square. Mary Corriveau, the assistant city manager, said, "We're always aware of what's going on in the world, aware that our soldiers are in harm's way, but we know they're out there protecting our freedom."
Spreading across 109,000 acres near the Canadian border, Fort Drum is one of the biggest employers in northern New York, a region best known for its punishing winters, numbing job losses and steadily declining population. But here in Watertown, that story had a different ending. Starting in the early 1980's, when the Pentagon designated Fort Drum home for the 10th Mountain Division, the military embarked on a $1.3 billion expansion. For the city, it was like a second chance at life. 
"Fort Drum has been very good to Watertown," said Karen Delmonico, president of the local chamber of commerce. "It's been our savior." Although downtown Watertown still has the down-and-out look of many upstate cities, the fringes of town are buzzing with so-called big box retailers, a new mall and fast-food outlets.
Still, with the base drained of soldiers and talk of recession in the air, many businesses were expecting a ruinous holiday season. But early Christmas sales and stunningly mild weather -- the first snow fell Friday -- have staved off disaster, merchants say. "So far we have no complaints," said Sheila Barney, 48, whose family-owned furniture store, Truesdell's, more than doubled its showroom space last year. The expansion, she said, has been largely fueled by young military families who generally stay two or three years before being transferred. 
But the pizzerias, video rental stores and military haberdashers that depend on an enlisted man's paycheck have seen much of their business dry up since the war on terror began. At Jefferson Community College, where a third of its 3,000 students work for the Army, enrollment has fallen sharply since September. "If the war goes on, we could be seriously impacted for the spring semester," said the registrar, Donna Eisele, whose son and husband work at the base. 
Besides the men and women now in Afghanistan, thousands of others are on peacekeeping missions in places like Kosovo, Bosnia and South Korea. Many of the remaining soldiers have been given leave for the holidays. "Right now, we're deader than a mackerel," said William G. McKinney, the owner of Bradley's Military Supply, just outside the main gate.
During October and November, Mr. McKinney's overworked staff embroidered 2,600 name tags, added pouches to hundreds of rucksacks and sewed 10th Mountain Division patches onto the shoulders of scores of tawny fatigues. (The division insignia is a pair of crossed swords that form the Roman numeral 10 inside a powder keg.)
"The guys would never say where they were going, but we had a good idea," he said, holding up the type of floppy hat that is indispensable in the desert sun. "This mission has been incredibly secretive."
As one of the nation's most active military bases, Fort Drum is accustomed to the vagaries of global unrest. Over the past decade, its troops have served in hot spots like Somalia, Haiti and the Sinai Peninsula, and many wives here say they have grown accustomed to long stretches sleeping alone. "It's rough but this is what you get when you marry a military man," said Tara DeButts, 33, whose husband has been stationed at Korea's demilitarized zone for the past year. "For us, Christmas is hoping your spouse will be here and hoping he'll be okay if he's not."
The hardship can be even more difficult for those with spouses in Afghanistan. To start with, the mission seems more perilous, the communication more sporadic and the end date still undetermined. For a month after he left, Mrs. Santiago did not hear from her husband, although the five-minute satellite phone calls have been coming every week or so since. "At 4 minutes and 20 seconds, an operator comes on to say the call is over," she said. "It's hard because he can't talk about where he is or what he's doing."
The Army offers counseling and financial assistance to the women, and there's always Diane Sykes, the unofficial den mother to lonely wives and single young men whose families live in faraway states. A 15-year Fort Drum veteran who works at the post bowling center, Mrs. Sykes drags them out five nights a week. "You can't let them hole up in their homes and say 'woe is me,' " said Mrs. Sykes, 47, whose husband and two sons have spent many a Christmas on foreign missions. (Michael, her oldest, will go to Korea next month.)
As slushy snow fell last Thursday, Mrs. Sykes held court at Seaway Lanes, her voluble laugh nearly drowning out the sound of crashing pins. All around her were soldiers or army wives, nearly all of them smoking, many of them clutching bottles of Miller Lite as they waited their turn to bowl. The mood was buoyant and at that moment, at least, no one was grumbling about the domestic toll of overseas military engagements. "It's hard at first, but we all learn to take care of ourselves," said Mrs. Sykes, her arm draped around the shoulder of Mrs. DeButts. "You miss them, but you just carry on. This is what the military is about. It's sink or swim for the guys and sink or swim for us."

 Flight Fraught with Danger

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; 
Among the Poor, Sympathy for the Families of Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
A man known as Brother Sanchez approached the men who sat, still in their coats and warm knit hats, at a long cafeteria table at the Help House Love Kitchen, inside the Manhattan Bible Church in Inwood. Very politely, Brother Sanchez, who works as a cook at the soup kitchen, asked for a moment of silence so that he could bless their supper. Part of what he said, in a rapid, almost guttural chant, went like this: "We pray for the tragedy of the trade center, Lord God, all those families who lost people, Lord God, and the plane crash that hurt so many families, Lord God."
 There were, in the room, some people whose problems were the same on Sept. 12 as they were on Sept. 10 -- disability, addiction, homelessness. There were others who simply had too thin a cushion between them and the hard times that have set in since: a man who could no longer find freelance work, a woman raising two children on her own. This holiday season, these people, the hungry and the sick, have been eclipsed by the families of firefighters and executives as icons of neediness. But among them, there is little resentment. 
 In interviews over the past few days, the city's poorest people voiced complex and conflicting opinions about money and who gets it. True, the lines they stand in for what might be the day's only meal are growing steadily longer. True, the average sum available to each family of a terrorist victim has mounted to well over $1 million, while soup kitchens whose annual budget is far less have begun to close their doors. 
But rising above the debate was a clarion sympathy, hard as metal and tempered by experience, for those who suffered most keenly on Sept. 11.
If anything, visits to meal programs provided yet another testament to how few people were left untouched by the terror. "My girlfriend is out of work and one of my friends died" in the attack, said a woman in a wheelchair, who gave her name as Carol, at a weekly lunch offered by the Momentum AIDS Project at St. Paul the Apostle Church near Columbus Circle . Over stew at St. John's Bread and Life soup kitchen in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, Daphne Whidbee, 38, said that her 7-year-old son became withdrawn and fearful after Sept. 11, and is going to counseling at a nearby hospital once a week. Belinda Brown, 39, said that a woman she knows still cannot accept that her son is dead. Cherise Jones, 13, buttoned her baby sister's jacket and worried about "all those families who don't have anybody to have Christmas with."
At St. John's, responses to a routine appeal for funds are down by 50 percent this year over last. But in September and October, the kitchen served at least 100 meals more each day than it served during those months in 2000, and to more families with children. There is no meat. Instead of juice, there is water. "I can feel the cutting back already," said Jonathan Rivera, 34, who said he is unemployed and in a methadone program. "But the water, it's good quality."
When Sept. 11 is brought up, the state of charitable giving is not the first thing people talk about. And the subject of money does not prompt uniform indignation. Several people, sifting through garbage bags full of donated clothes at Part of the Solution, a pantry and kitchen in the Bronx, said they saw nothing wrong with families of World Trade Center victims receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars while people like themselves struggled to get by. "Those are different categories," said Anibal Gomez, 45, while a social worker processed his paperwork. "I think they should take care of those families. Before me."
Edward Kelly, 49, clutched a mystery novel and wore a baseball cap over his matted hair. "Their families deserve it," he said, after agreeing to come back later to have his food stamp allotment re-evaluated. "This, to me, is hopefully just a slump. My life's changed a little more gradually than in a couple of seconds."
But still, he described a widow whom he had seen on television -- she lived in a mansion, he said. He balked at the notion that families of victims could be supported at a level far above the average American income. "When my father died, we went through a lot of changes, too," he said. "It's called life."
Sally Young, 45, though, did not think anything more should change for the families. "I know, if you go to school for a number of years, you go for a reason. They were used to making hundreds of thousands of dollars a year. It's a lifestyle choice. If that's what they worked for, I think they should get it. If charity gave it for them, they should have it."
It galled Ms. Young to think that a white-collar widow might be brought down low enough to live in her neighborhood in the Bronx, near the soup kitchen. The widow would be unprepared. "I grew up there," Ms. Young said. "I know how to live there."
Later, the program director of Part of the Solution, John Hoffmann, recalled the talk over lunch in the days after Sept. 11. "Our folks live in violence," he said. "It was, 'What do you mean, the world has changed? Our world hasn't changed.' "
Ms. Young sat on a bench on a narrow landing, in line to get food for her three sons, one of whom is autistic. She sat near Joseph Figueroa, 57, who leaned close to join the conversation. "The system is so screwy," he announced, with some agitation. "I heard the kids in Afghanistan are getting Christmas presents. You have to take care of your home first," he said, to a chorus of agreements.
"I was out of work before this whole World Trade Center thing happened," concurred Tamar Watson, 35, who said she had been laid off from her job processing medical records. The families of victims should definitely receive help, she said. But when she heard the sums that some stand to receive, her eyebrows went up in surprise. "I think that's a little much," she said. Then she went in to collect her bag of canned food and cornflakes.
No one could suggest a way of determining how much was too much for the families of victims to receive. But the idea that life, even a luxurious life, should go on much the way it had before held some appeal for those struggling to maintain even the basest standard of living. 
On the other hand, a sizable portion of sympathy was reserved for the World Trade Center's deliverymen, secretaries and pastry makers. The firefighters' and stockbrokers' families would be taken care of, people at the soup kitchens were certain, even though surviving spouses have complained of onerous paperwork and the lack of help to pay bills due immediately. But what about the rest?
"I feel like, even in my church they've been neglected," said Linda Murphy, 45, a Mormon who cares for her daughter and granddaughter. "They have the nerve to say, 'For Christmas, Ms. Murphy, we're going to sing to the firefighters and the policemen.' More people got killed than the firemen and the policemen. Sing to the blue-collar workers."
Considering a hypothetical widow, Mr. Kelly said: "If her husband was a stock trader, they probably had some money tucked away. The poor busboy probably had nothing."
Ms. Murphy said that she herself is a victim of Sept. 11. She has received only two $350 paychecks from her job at a government-funded service center since the trade center collapsed, and has gone from an occasional visit to heavy reliance on Part of the Solution. She has been told not to report for work until after the holidays. 
But on a cold, rainy morning last week, on Webster Avenue and 198th Street in the Bronx, she seemed very far away from the grants and other help available for downtown workers. "Can I apply for public assistance, because my job was supplied by federal money and that money didn't come?" she asked.
Although no one said that the World Trade Center families were not deserving, many marveled at the sudden availability of money to aid them, particularly government money. "Funds came out of nowhere to help those people," said Ms. Whidbee, the mother of eight children, the two oldest in the armed forces. "My friend over there is homeless," she said, pointing across the table. "She can't get a place to live."
Ms. Whidbee was on her way to take her six younger children to a Christmas party at the hospital that provides their medical care. But first, they had stopped for lunch at St. John's Bread and Life. The children sat quietly, tray to tray, around a table in the basement cafeteria. "I tell them Christmas is not for toys. Don't be sad if you don't get nothing as long as you have a roof over your heads," Ms. Whidbee said.
People at the Momentum AIDS lunch program, which had to close two Monday meal programs last week because of city budget cuts and a decline in donations, also wondered about the distribution of government money. They said that AIDS has become almost invisible, particularly in contrast to terrorism. The media virtually ignored World AIDS Day, Dec. 1, said Dawn Bryan, the group's executive director.
A Momentum client from Kew Gardens, Queens, Warren Mitchell, 49, said: "First of all, you're talking about two tragedies. Everyone is not going to get a piece of the pie. There's no yin and yang to the two situations."
Still, in a season when many want for comfort both material and emotional, compassion has not flowed in only one direction. It is true, said the people who run Part of the Solution, that money for the hungry was siphoned off by the Sept. 11 tragedy. The charity depends, for much of its budget, on the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., which lost seven parishioners at the trade center.
But, the church still held its October fund-raiser for the little food pantry and kitchen in the Bronx. The dinner, auction and yearbook sale raised $91,000 -- a record, said Sister Mary Alice Hannan, the executive director of the soup kitchen. "There were four people there who lost family members," she said. "Three of them were widows."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some people sifting through clothing at Part of the Solution, a pantry in the Bronx, said terror victims' families deserved the money they were getting. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. B6)
