HEADLINE: Health Care Is New Darling Of Pork Barrel Spending 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Pork barrel spending used to mean roads and bridges and dams. Now it also means hospitals, medical schools and local health care projects singled out by Congress to receive tens of millions of federal dollars.
 In one of its last actions before adjourning for the year, Congress last week specified more than 600 health care providers that will receive federal largess in the coming year. The number of such directed expenditures, known as earmarks for their obvious links to the members promoting them, far exceeds the items in previous years. Congress designated hardly any health care projects in 1996, and since then the number has been well below 100. 
 President Bush and his budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., had asked Congress to eliminate most of the earmarks, saying they circumvented the usual process of awarding federal grants after thorough evaluations of the merits of proposals. But Congress ignored the White House request, producing a huge increase in the number of projects that will be financed by its command.
Republicans were just as eager as Democrats to obtain their share. Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican who obtained $3 million for health care providers in his district, said, "This is a much-needed Christmas gift to our hospitals, which are in dire financial straits."
Congress specified significant sums for some recipients, $800,000 for the University of Iowa to train nurse anesthetists, $1.2 million for a nursing program at Creighton University in Omaha, $1.7 million for a rural health care program at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, $500,000 for an emergency medical services academy at Western Kentucky University and $1.9 million for health care information technology at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.
Members of Congress said that in obtaining federal money for their districts and states they were doing what they had been elected to do. Moreover, they said, they talk to constituents all the time and are at least as qualified to make spending decisions as anyone in the executive branch.
The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, is taking home $6.9 million for West Virginia University, $2.9 million for the "mountaineer doctor" program, $2 million for a new center on obesity and $2 million to establish a "virtual medical campus" with computers.
But Congress also took a keen interest in small grants. In a $123.8 billion appropriations bill, it earmarked $80,000 for the Wausau Health Foundation in Wisconsin to study the careers of local health professionals; $50,000 for a clinic in Somerville, N.J., that serves pregnant teenagers; and $46,000 for a family psychotherapy program in Hot Springs, Ark.
Many of the programs receiving federal aid are in states or districts represented by Congressional leaders or members of the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, which wrote the legislation.
Wausau is in the district of Representative David R. Obey, senior Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee. Somerville is in the district of another committee member, Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen, a Republican.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, represents three hospitals explicitly named as recipients of federal grants. 
Ralph Regula, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Health and Human Services, obtained $2 million for Pomerene Hospital in Millersburg, Ohio; $1 million for a new biomedical research center at Ohio State University; and $1.5 million for a program to reduce medical errors at five hospitals in northeastern Ohio.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, complained that Congress had gone wild in spending money on "parochial projects." Although some may be worthy, he said, "it is distressing that these funds are specifically earmarked and not subject to the competitive grant process."
But a more common reaction is for members of Congress to boast about the money they secured for constituents. Representative David L. Hobson, Republican of Ohio, said he had obtained $1 million for an outpatient cancer center; $750,000 for a Y.M.C.A. fitness center; $250,000 for a hospital; $250,000 for a hospice; and $500,000 for a physical therapy center.
Lobbyists, lawmakers and health care officials suggest several reasons for the increase in earmarks, including these:
*Hospitals note that they are major employers and engines of economic growth in many cities and rural areas.
*Neither party has much of a numerical advantage in the Senate or the House. So an individual member of Congress has leverage in trying to extract specific projects, even if the lawmaker has little seniority.
*Medicare, a major source of hospital revenue, uses rigid reimbursement formulas that do not always take account of a hospital's special circumstances. So many hospitals have turned to Congress to meet their needs.
*Several lobbying companies like Cassidy & Associates now specialize in persuading Congress to earmark money for specific hospitals and universities. Health care providers have found that Congress is more responsive to political pressure than the civil servants who disburse federal grants in the executive branch.
Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, said, "We simply cannot afford pork barrel politics right now," at a time when the nation is at war and the federal government is again running budget deficits.
But Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, said he was "proud of the pork" going to his state. He secured nearly $16 million for 10 health care projects this year, and he said, "I can proudly justify any of the projects." 
In the past, Congress subtly urged the secretary of health and human services to direct more money to particular groups like Asian-Americans. But this year, Congress became much more explicit, saying, "The conferees include the following amounts for the following projects and activities," and it then listed hundreds of projects.

HEADLINE: A Fiscal Crisis, Paid in Credibility 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Argentina's declaration of a moratorium on repayment of its foreign debt marks the end of a failed economic experiment that has cost this country dearly. But it is also a blow to the United States and the International Monetary Fund, which had invested much of their credibility and prestige here, yet proved unwilling to help when things began falling apart.
 "I think this is going to end up being a very costly experience for the United States," Walter Molano, chief of research for BCP Securities, a brokerage firm based in Connecticut that focuses on Latin America, said today. "It was very clearly the Department of the Treasury that pushed Argentina over the edge and allowed it to collapse, so I think the issue of accountability has to come up." 
 A decade ago, Argentina decided to tie its peso to the dollar at a value of one to one, a decision that at first dramatically reduced inflation and imposed fiscal discipline, but eventually led to the current crisis. The first Bush administration had strongly urged that step on Argentina, and the United States tried to sell the same system to other doubtful Latin American countries.
There is plenty of blame to go around. But from the start, the second Bush administration found it convenient to overlook the United States's earlier role as advocate and cheerleader of that policy and to distance itself as much as possible from Argentina's growing problems. The bluntest statement of official indifference came from Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill this summer and helped accelerate the loss of capital and confidence here.
"They've been off and on in trouble for 70 years or more," Mr. O'Neill said dismissively in an interview with the British magazine The Economist. "They don't have any export industry to speak of at all. And they like it that way. Nobody forced them to be what they are."
What was missing from Mr. O'Neill's analysis, however, was any mention of the high tariffs the United States imposes on Argentine exports or of the aversion to easing those barriers to help Argentina regain its footing. Nor was the Bush administration particularly helpful in "creating some kind of framework for how the international system could respond, rather than saying, 'It's all up to you,' " said Peter Hakim, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based conference of hemisphere leaders.
As a result, "the Argentines were operating in a vacuum, without a clear sense of what the United States was thinking and what it was prepared to do to be helpful," Mr. Hakim said. "The real blame is passivity: the U.S. did not want to engage, and so it stayed on the sidelines."
Taking its cue from the Bush administration, the International Monetary Fund kept "raising the bar" on Argentina, in Mr. Molano's words -- requiring increasingly harsh austerity measures -- in return for the disbursement of money already promised. That was followed by the fund's public declaration on Dec. 18 of its lack of confidence in the Argentine authorities, which helped hasten the government's fall.
"It's clear that the mix of fiscal policy, debt and the exchange rate regime is not sustainable," said Kenneth Rogoff, the fund's chief economist. He also maintained that "everyone recognizes that to a large extent the problem lies in Argentina," a statement that did not ring true to other governments in the region.
"The fund is partly to blame for this because the fund did not sound the alarm in time and then took a very hard line when things were incredibly difficult," said Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, the finance minister of Peru, which has itself been in in talks with the organization recently.
But the abandonment of Argentina represents more than just an economic policy failure. It also has a strategic effect, because it confirms to the rest of Latin America what many leaders have always maintained: that the United States is a fickle and undependable ally.
Over the past decade, Argentina has aligned itself more closely with the United States on foreign policy questions than any other country in the region. It was the only Latin American country to participate actively in the Persian Gulf war, and in recognition of that and numerous other demonstrations of support, the Clinton administration formally designated Argentina a "non-NATO ally."
Even with its economy disintegrating, Argentina has not wavered from a commitment to send up to 600 troops as part of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan and to open a field hospital in Pakistan. That effort, which will cost Argentina up to $20 million, has been criticized here as an expenditure that would be better directed at creating jobs for the millions of unemployed.
Six months ago, Turkey's situation was very similar to Argentina's. But while Argentina has been left to fend for itself, Turkey has been showered with financial and political support, which most people here regard as proof the United States regards Turkey as vital to American geopolitical goals in a way that Argentina, despite its demonstrated support of the United States, is not.Now, other Latin American countries are likely to draw the conclusion that there is no payoff for being America's friend, at a time when the United States hopes to draw its neighbors into a Free Trade Area of the Americas.
"On the whole, I think this bodes very badly for building a long-term economic community in the hemisphere," Mr. Hakim said. "If this is what community means, it doesn't really mean much."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Whole Spectrum of Santas Emerge for Neediest Cases

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN and VINCENT M. MALLOZZI 

 BODY:
Santa Claus is a 5-year-old girl from Manhattan.
 He is a marine biologist from Queens. 
 He is the chief executive of a major toy company in New Jersey.
To the children and adults around the city who had their wishes fulfilled after they were featured in articles this fall about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Santa Claus came in many forms. But every one of those Santas had something in common. Each -- including 5-year-old Olivia Sabat of Manhattan, who sent a gift and a letter to a child whose family lost its home in a fire -- was responding to New Yorkers in need during a difficult time. 
Dear Darriel: My name is Olivia Sabat. I'm five years old, too. I'm sad that your house burnt. My Mommy read about you in the newspaper. I want to share my Barbies with you because you said you wanted a doll.
Merry Christmas
Love, Olivia
A faltering economy and an outpouring of giving to charities related to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 have contributed to what may become the largest year-to-year decline in donations to the Neediest Cases Fund since The Times began publishing articles about the Hundred Neediest Cases in 1912. The fund has received 24 percent less this year than it had at the same point in last year's appeal. That is a far larger decline than was ever recorded between any two campaigns, even the ones at the start of the Depression, when contributions declined 14 percent from 1930 to 1931.
Before Sept. 11, Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund, said he hoped to raise $10 million in this year's appeal, 25 percent more than last year. On Saturday, he said he now thought the fund would receive $6 million, and noted another declining trend. "The really meaningful figure that troubles me is the decline in the number of donors," he said, noting that there were about half as many donors this year as there were by this point last year.
Despite discouraging statistics, the spirit that moved Olivia Sabat, and others nationwide, remains as high as ever.
It is the kind of spirit that gave Darriel Hall of Brooklyn 10 new dolls, including 5 from Olivia, and a CD player to replace some of the things she lost on Thanksgiving 2000 at age 5, when a fire destroyed her family's home. Her mother, Doreen Hall, told The Times in November that Darriel had asked if her dolls had been hurt in the fire and said that all her daughter wanted for Christmas this year was a doll.
It is the kind of spirit that moved a high school science teacher to call a small community center in the South Bronx to offer computers for homework and art class.
"It's all about helping the people who can't help themselves," said James Cervino, a marine biologist from College Point, Queens, who teaches science at St. Francis Prep High School in Fresh Meadows.
Along with a colleague, Christine Van Vliet, Mr. Cervino was touched by an article in The Times in November about the impoverished children who go to Abraham House on Willis Avenue in the Bronx, and could think of no better way to part with the 10 Macintosh computers the school will soon replace with newer models. Abraham House will be receiving the computers this week, he said.
"These are beautiful, powerful computers," Mr. Cervino said. "We just wanted to make sure we got them into the right hands, and I'm sure we did."
John Eyler, the chief executive of Toys "R" Us in Paramus, N.J., who read an article about a poor young boy from Brooklyn, was also caught up in the spirit. He decided to satisfy the boy's desire for a popular video-game system, the PlayStation 2.
Mr. Eyler, who declined interview requests, had read about Edwardo Reyes, an 11-year-old whose parents had recently divorced. Edwardo had two wishes for this Christmas Day: "I want Mommy and Daddy to be together again," he had said. "Oh, and don't forget, I also want PlayStation 2."
Thanks to the generosity of Times readers, even some elderly New Yorkers in need were feeling like kids this Christmas.
A man from Florida shared the warmth of his state by sending a coat to 77-year-old Ed Felder, who holds court on a street bench near Baruch College in Manhattan. And a dermatologist from Madison, Ill., paid for a voice-activated laptop computer for Rose Ann (who would not allow her last name to be used) , 73, from Astoria, Queens, who has severe arthritis.
Earlier this month an investment manager from Greenwich, Conn., who asked that his name not be printed, read an article about a 74-year-old woman, Madeline Castellano, who is confined to her apartment. Ms. Castellano, who lives in Coney Island, had said she felt isolated from the outside world and would have liked to write to her friends, if only she had a typewriter.
So on Christmas Eve, the man stopped by her apartment with a shiny black Royal typewriter.
"It's beautiful; I never expected anything like this," Ms. Castellano said yesterday as she looked at the typewriter, envelopes and stationery that had been given to her. "This shows you that there are still loving, caring people out there."
Many readers have been putting their own thoughts on paper -- the kind with dollar signs attached.
A check for $2,000 was made out to Bill and Jeff Collins of Rego Park, Queens. The 48-year-old twin brothers, who were out of work and on the verge of being evicted, received the money from Bruce Deal, an administrative associate with the College Board in Manhattan, which sponsors college admission tests.
Offers of help came in many other forms. An acupuncturist in Southport, Conn., Jody Eisemann, offered to help Dorian Hardin, 38, a Harlem man struggling to raise seven children on a limited income. Ms. Eisemann wasn't sure whether Mr. Hardin even needed acupuncture treatment, but she offered it anyway.
"I didn't know there were so many people out there so interested in me and my family," Mr. Hardin said.
Neither did Glenn Zoll, a man who lost his job, his daughter and his apartment in the space of a week. He received $2,000 from a man who so wished to remain anonymous that he scratched his name off the check he gave. At first, the bank refused to cash the check. But when Mr. Zoll produced a copy of the article about him and a letter that the donor had sent along, a bank manager relented, gave a smiling Mr. Zoll the money, and wished him a Merry Christmas.
In addition, Mr. Zoll received a telephone call from an executive at Orion Telecommunications in Bayside, Queens, who had read that Mr. Zoll once worked in the industry and asked him to send in his resume.
Perhaps Mr. Zoll was speaking for needy people and donors alike when he said, "I'm just doing what I have to do."

HEADLINE: Plan to Let Nations Declare Bankruptcy Gains 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Argentina's chaotic political and financial collapse has given a strong push to a plan by the International Monetary Fund to allow nations to declare bankruptcy and seek legal protection from their creditors, much as people and companies can do, fund officials and private experts said.
 The governing board of the fund has given a preliminary nod to the plan, which was floated late last month by Anne Krueger, the No. 2 official. The fund is expected to prepare a formal proposal in time for a financial summit meeting in the spring, officials said today. 
 The plan would fill what Ms. Krueger call a "gaping hole" in the international financial system. It would establish a formal bankruptcy process for nations that face severe financial difficulties, allowing them to stop paying debts while they negotiate with bankers and bondholders. 
"At the moment too many countries with insurmountable debt problems leave them too long, imposing unnecessarily heavy economic costs on themselves and on the international community that has to pick up the pieces," Ms. Krueger said.
The proposal has won early support from the Bush administration, as well as financial leaders of Britain and Canada. But it would probably require the approval of Congress and legislatures of all the fund's 183 member nations because they would have to grant legal amnesty to nations that meet the fund's conditions for bankruptcy.
The plan faces stiff opposition on Wall Street, where bankers and brokerage houses warn that investors will move their money out of developing countries rather than risk having funds impounded in an international bankruptcy proceeding. 
"This is a nuclear-bomb solution that could really backfire," said Charles H. Dallara, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, who represents many banks with loans in emerging markets.
Some developing nations have also expressed unease that they might be forced into bankruptcy instead of being granted aid to help them ride out financial storms.
Though the plan was broached before Argentina announced on Sunday that it would stop making payments on its $132 billion debt, the troubles there highlighted the urgency of finding a more orderly process for resolving financial disputes.
Some experts believe that Argentina is a case study in how not to handle a debt crisis. It sought to slash government spending, freeze bank accounts and dip into state pension funds to raise money for debt payments during a deep recession -- before riots brought down the government of President Fernando de la Rua last week. Under the fund's proposal, Buenos Aires could have declared a time out, halting debt payments or other outflows while it sought to rebuild financial credibility.
The I.M.F. has historically gone to great lengths to help nations stay solvent, often by providing large loans that they can use to stay current on debts or to shore up currencies. Such loans -- including recent multibillion-dollar packages for Mexico, Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea Russia, Brazil, Turkey and Argentina -- have drawn criticism because they are seen as expensive ways of rescuing countries that make bad policy decisions, as well as protecting investors who buy risky stocks and bonds.
Major American, Japanese and European banks once accounted for most of the money invested in developing countries, and they often informally agreed to terms to settle disputes when countries ran into trouble. Today, there is more variety among bond investors, and many have been reluctant to accept anything less than full repayment.
The I.M.F. proposal is modeled on Britain's bankruptcy laws. A nation could apply to the fund for the right to declare bankruptcy. If granted, that nation would negotiate a settlement with its creditors, and a majority of them could decide terms for the whole. The fund would also allow nations to impose temporary foreign-exchange controls to prevent a rapid outflow of private funds.
Bush administration officials have signaled their support for a shift away from bailouts and toward a bankruptcy process. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has not publicly commented on the proposal, but during a meeting of the fund's executive board, the United States approved developing the plan. 
The proposal was also welcomed by some international economics experts, including Jeffrey D. Sachs of Harvard, who proposed a similar idea more than a decade ago. 
But critics like Mr. Dallara said the plan was deeply flawed because the fund wants to cast itself as bankruptcy judge even though it is often the largest creditor and seeks to protect its own loan portfolio. The interests of private investors do not rank as high, he said.
"How can the I.M.F. be a neutral judge when it is often the largest creditor?" he asked. "That would be thrown out in any court."

HEADLINE: American Investors in Argentina Mostly Taking Losses in Stride 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
As Argentina struggled to avert complete fiscal collapse with the anticipated issue of a new currency, the fallout in the United States is slowly coming to light.
 American financial markets barely shivered yesterday, even though Argentina's interim president, Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, declared at his inauguration on Sunday that he would suspend the repayment of public debt. The default had been widely expected for weeks, if not months, and investors hardly seemed surprised. 
 Prices of Argentine bonds that come due in 2008 slipped 10 percent yesterday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was unchanged yesterday in light trading.
More than 20 of Argentina's bondholders recently formed a committee to negotiate new terms with the government. "The bulk of the members of the committee are large institutional holders who either hold for their own account or manage client accounts," said Michael P. Richman, a partner at Mayer, Brown and Platt who represents the group. 
J.P. Morgan Chase and TIAA-CREF, the pension fund for educators, have been identified as members of the committee. He also said that several smaller creditors had expressed interest in joining the group.
Mr. Richman said that Argentina would have a better chance of averting legal action if its officials worked with the committee.
"Our opinion for or against an overall restructuring may help to sell other creditors," he said. "We could be helpful if we believe them to be sincere and they reach out to us. If they don't, we can't pretend to control bondholders around the world."
Institutional investors with clients in the United States had mostly deserted Argentine debt issues before the default. Wendy Shapiro, a spokesperson for Zurich Scudder Investments, said the company's managers had sold all their Argentine bonds well in advance.
A survey released last week by J. P. Morgan Securities reported that 81 percent of investors considered their portfolios underweighted in Argentine securities.
For American companies doing business in Argentina, some of them already dealing with the economic downturn in the United States, the disruptions surrounding the economic crisis were only the latest chapter in a continuing tale of woe. 
At Wal-Mart, which has 11 stores in Argentina, sales ground to a halt during the recent political unrest. The company closed its stores in the country on Dec. 21 out of concern for the safety of customers and employees, said Jay Allen, a spokesman for the company. "We did have four stores that had demonstrations of some sort outside, but there was no damage done, no injuries and no looting."
The stores have since reopened, Mr. Allen said.
The watchword was also caution at Dow Chemical, which manufactures ethylene and polyethylene in Argentina for sales locally and in Brazil and Europe. Dow closed some offices but did not halt production of chemicals last week.
"We did evacuate some employees from our offices on Thursday, because our No. 1 concern is the safety of our employees," said Holly LaRose-Roenicke, a Dow spokeswoman.
Some American companies had already started to abandon Argentina as financial and economic tensions mounted. In October, Home Depot sold its four Argentine stores to Grupo Paulmann, a Chilean conglomerate that already owned a leading home-improvement retailer in Argentina.

HEADLINE: Desperation Sales Fail to Lure Shoppers 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
The holiday shopping season opened the day after Thanksgiving with nervous merchants cutting prices 40 percent. It ended over the final weekend before Christmas with a frenzy of desperation sales with as much as 70 percent off that failed to save the season for most retailers.
 Rather than generating lots of last-minute traffic, deep sales were the minimum ante retailers had to offer merely to attract the attention of jaded customers in a dismal recession-bound economy. Bargain hunting along Chicago's Miracle Mile on Sunday north of downtown, Mary Beth Patterson summed up the sentiment succinctly: "We are trying to get 30 to 50 percent off on everything we buy. And it's working." 
 Before Thanksgiving, industry analysts had hoped that nonautomobile retail sales might grow at least 2 to 3 percent. But warm weather, the economic downturn and general malaise after the Sept. 11 attacks combined to suck the spending spirits out of the holiday. Zero-percent financing deals from Detroit's automakers also siphoned off many of the extra dollars consumers might have taken to the malls. 
Final sales and traffic for this last weekend will not be reported by most retailers until tomorrow. Yet reports from the field and scattered evidence from various merchants indicate that the crowds, while dense in certain places, were too light to offer any last-minute miracles on 34th Street or anywhere else. Economists, analysts and retail consultants now generally agree that retail sales, outside the auto sector, are not likely to increase much more than 1 percent or so for November and December.
In short, it was a long, bitter season.
"It was the worst Christmas" in a decade, lamented Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst with Lehman Brothers who follows the retailing sector. Mr. Feiner said that profit margins, already thin, could be down by as much as 10 percent across the industry.
"Retailers lowered their expectations," he said, "but when all things are added up, it will still be worse than that."
Products that encompassed the values of home -- everything from high-technology entertainment systems to old-fashioned board games -- fared the best. With a little extra cash in their wallets from skipping vacations, consumers spent big on cheap DVD players, expensive big-screen televisions, and video game consoles for their children and digital cameras for themselves. Sales of home-theater systems nearly doubled in the first weekend after Thanksgiving, compared with the comparable period last year, and then stayed consistently strong, according to a survey by NPDTechworld, a market information company.
But with much of the country experiencing temperatures this month resembling a brisk March rather than a blustery and snowy pre-Christmas, winter apparel sold particularly poorly. "I don't see how the apparel companies could be anything but down 3 to 5 percent," said John D. Morris, an analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison.
With sales at the height of the shopping season so tepid despite near give-away prices, several economists suggested that consumers may be even more reluctant to spend early next year.
"It is taking extraordinary measure of near desperation to keep consumers afloat," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley. "The question now is how much of what we are seeing now is borrowed from gains that would have come next year."
Considering how cheap things are already, it seems hard to imagine that steeper price cuts are still to come, but the nation's merchants still have plenty of goods on their racks and shelves to unload. That suggests that retailers will cut prices even more after Christmas.
"Merchandise is not like a Merlot," said Michael Gould, chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores. "It is not going to get better with time."
Mr. Gould said Federated would offer its usual post-Christmas sales, but further price cuts would come on items that had been only partially discounted so far. Men's cashmere sweaters, for example, which started the season at $198 and sold for $129 the day before Christmas will be $89 tomorrow.
And if they do not sell even then? "Oh, at $89 we will have a riot," Mr. Gould predicted.
But even before the last discounts are taken and the inventory cleared out, it is clear that the spending torpor has taken a toll on the industry. Last Friday, Moody's Investors Service downgraded Kmart's debt to junk status. The discount retailer has had trouble meeting modest sales targets despite extended hours and ferocious price cuts -- like 70 percent off its gold and diamond jewelry. 
Moody's also downgraded the outlook for the Limited, parent company of Express, and is reviewing Gap's credit. Gap, which also operates the Banana Republic and Old Navy chains, has suffered a devastating season. Just to clear unwanted sweaters, pants, and underwear, Gap's lineup of retailers has put an unprecedented amount of merchandise on sale. Even seasonal items like thigh-length hand-knit sweaters were marked down to $34.99 from $98.
The Gap's downfall has been the most spectacular of the season, but mall-based specialty clothing stores were hit hard across the board as the cathedrals of consumption did not seem to draw the usual immense crowds on the last weekend before Christmas, which has replaced the weekend after Thanksgiving as the busiest shopping burst of the year.
"Traffic was a bit off on Saturday," said Karen MacDonald, a spokeswoman for the Taubman Group, which runs 31 malls in 13 states, "although it rebounded on Sunday."
And despite an extra day of shopping when many people extended weekend breaks right through Christmas Day, malls seemed particularly empty yesterday. While shoppers reveled in the discounts, most said the price cuts were still not enticing enough to persuade them to spend more than last year.
"I am spending the same, but getting more and enjoying it more," said Barbara Kahn-Velez, who was getting in some last-minute bargain hunting Sunday on New York's Fifth Avenue.
"At Macy's it was like take 20 percent off something that was 40 percent off and take 15 percent more if you have your credit card," Ms. Kahn-Velez joked.
There were a few winners in this season of woe. The nation's biggest retailer by far, Wal-Mart Stores, reported yesterday that sales though Dec. 21 were up 4 percent over last year, a solid increase. Target said that its sales through Sunday were up more than expected.
Target did not say which was the biggest shopping day for the chain, but Dave Johnson, general manager of a Target store in Charlotte, N.C., said this year's sales on the last Friday night before Christmas were up 28 percent from the corresponding day last year. He said the store sold hundreds of George Foreman grills this year, along with electronic games like the Xbox and Nintendo GameCube. Harry Potter merchandise and "Lord of the Rings" books also have been hot, Mr. Johnson said.
Another bright spot for some retailers was the Web. Holiday purchases over the Internet -- focused on items like digital cameras -- grew 34 percent over last year, according to Bizrate.com. While that gain was substantial, Internet sales, at roughly $6.3 billion, are just a tiny piece of the overall Christmas retail pie.
Of course, the real winners in this holiday were consumers like Lisa Macias from Milwaukee, who was loaded up with merchandise from F.A.O. Schwarz, H2 0 and Gap this weekend.
"Every place it is sale, sale sale," she said. "That's the way I like to shop."

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about retail sales on the last weekend before Christmas misstated the nickname of the downtown shopping district in Chicago. It is the Magnificent Mile, not the Miracle Mile.

HEADLINE: Japan Says a Mystery Boat Fired Rockets at Its Ships 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Crewmen on a vessel suspected of being a North Korean spy boat used shoulder-held launchers to fire rockets at two Japan Coast Guard ships in a high seas battle that involved the firing of about 1,000 rounds from machine guns and other automatic weapons, Japan Coast Guard officials said today.
 "The Japan Coast Guard was attacked by rockets for the first time," Shigehiro Sakamoto, a chief of the Coast Guard's Guard and Rescue Department, said at a news conference today. "It was the most dangerous mission ever conducted by the Coast Guard." 
 The gunfire Saturday night left three Japanese sailors slightly injured and three ships damaged, including one, the Amami, that was riddled by 168 bullets. 
On the other side, 3 crew members were confirmed dead and 12 others were missing, and their 100-ton boat was resting on a continental shelf at a depth of 300 feet. With clues to the origin of the boat still limited to crew members' personal effects inscribed with Korean writing, Japan's government is considering sending divers to investigate the wreckage. 
Today, in its fullest account of the incident, the government released images from a Coast Guard plane's infrared camera that appeared to show a rocket streaking from the unidentified boat toward a Japanese vessel. 
The Coast Guard said that another infrared camera, this one mounted on the Inasa, a patrol boat, showed two or three men using shoulder-held launchers to fire simultaneously at the Inasa and the Amami. Coast Guard officials say the rockets missed the ships, but crew members recall seeing red flames passing over their boats. 
Responding to the rockets and automatic weapons fire, the Inasa and the Amami returned fire, expending 589 rounds from their machine guns in the space of a minute. Shortly afterward, a Japanese sailor reportedly watched through a night-vision lens as the boat's crewmen apparently set off an explosive device on board, perhaps sinking their own ship. 
"An explosion took place within the ship and a large amount of water poured into the hull," said Tadashi Kurogi, head of a Coast Guard rescue unit based in Kagoshima, southwestern Japan. "We cannot rule out the possibility that the ship sank by itself. It was such a large explosion." 
The sinking and loss of life are a further blow to ties between Japan and North Korea, two countries that have been estranged and last had direct talks on normalizing relations 14 months ago. 
"It is certainly one step forward in the deterioration of Japan-North Korea relations," Kazuhisa Ogawa, a defense adviser to Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, said in an interview. "Since the terrorist attack on the U.S. in September, North Korea hasn't taken an aggressive stance because they don't want to take the blame for being a pro-terrorist country." 
North Korea has had a history of sending submarines and spy ships along the coasts of both South Korea and Japan, and this latest incident added new fuel to calls by the nationalist prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, for Japan to assume more of the burden of its own defense.
Just months ago he pushed through a new law that for the first time since World War II allows Japan's naval forces to take part in operations outside territorial waters. Today Japan's cabinet approved a record $38 billion defense budget.
Hours later, Mr. Koizumi called for greater military preparedness, saying that the suspect ship "had made considerable preparations and armed itself for an attack, so the Japanese side must also think of ways to deal with such incidents in normal times, given that such reckless unidentified ships exist." 
In North Korea, there has been no comment in the state-controlled media. Instead, the state media devoted its energies today to celebrating the 10th anniversary of the elevation of North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, to supreme commander of the Korean People's Army. The Korea Central News Agency lauded the North Korean leader for his "forced march to victory with his original army-centered revolutionary leadership." 
The ascendancy of this "military first" policy in recent months is believed to be behind the stagnation in North Korea's talks with South Korea, Japan and the United States. 
Korea was a Japanese colony from 1910 to 1945. Today, Koreans on both halves of the peninsula are sensitive to any perceived revival of Japanese militarism. Some South Koreans have watched skeptically as Prime Minister Koizumi won parliamentary approval to send military supply ships to the Indian Ocean to help the American war effort in Afghanistan.
Last month, a new law went into effect allowing the Japan Coast Guard to fire at unidentified foreign vessels when they try to escape from Japanese territorial waters.
Saturday's battle took place just inside a 200-mile economic zone claimed by China. Other than saying that the boat was not Chinese, China's reaction has been muted.
But South Korea's governing Millennium Democratic Party sounded a note of worry. 
"Japan and North Korea must explain to their neighbors what happened and why it happened, without delay," Lee Nak Yon, a party spokesman said today in a statement. "We pay attention to the incident which can be seen as part of Japan's recent expansion of military power."
The Japanese have been particularly jittery over North Korea's intentions since the Communist government test fired a missile in the direction of Japan in 1998, and in recent weeks, relations have been further battered. 
In late November, Japanese police arrested half a dozen longtime Korean residents on charges that they had defrauded Korean savings banks here, probably shipping millions of dollars to North Korea.
In response, the North Korean Red Cross Society suspended efforts to locate 10 Japanese who, the Japanese government said, were kidnapped from Japanese beaches by crews from North Korean vessels in the 1970's and 1980's.
Some Japanese sensed extortion.
"North Korea may be playing a game of brinkmanship to get more food aid from Japan," Tokyo's Asahi Shimbun newspaper wrote Wednesday in an editorial. "If so, the strategy has backfired. Pyongyang's action has done nothing but tarnish the country's image among Japanese."
But the kidnapping issue ties into Japanese fears about spy boats from North Korea. In the nearly half century since the end of the Korean War, North Korea has landed about 50 spies on Japanese beaches, according to Japanese police estimates. 
The heavily armed ship that sank on Saturday fits the profile of past North Korean spy boats -- a small number of antennas atop the wheelhouse, a few token items of fishing gear, like squid lights, and powerful engines for quick getaways.
In 1999, two suspicious boats disguised as Japanese fishing boats eluded a Maritime Self-Defense Force search party and returned to North Korea.
Japanese Coast Guard officials said today that the boat that sank on Saturday closely resembled aerial photos of a North Korean boat that transferred 640 pounds of amphetamines to a Japanese fishing boat in August 1998. 
Last month, Japan's Supreme Court upheld the drug trafficking convictions of six Japanese in the case and upheld lower court findings that they received the stimulants from a North Korean ship.
According to Japan's National Police Agency, 44 percent of drugs seized in 1999 originated in North Korea. In 1999, about 1,241 pounds of drugs were seized on a coast in Kagoshima Prefecture, about 75 miles from where the boat involved in Saturday's incident was first sited. In the 1999 case, the police said that a suspect admitted that the drugs were obtained at sea off North Korea. 
In February 2000, about 550 pounds of drugs were confiscated in Shimane Prefecture, the closest part of Japan to North Korea. Japanese police said the drugs were loaded at a North Korean port. 
Today, Kyodo news agency quoted a National Police Agency spokesman as saying: "Pharmaceutical plants in North Korea are used for the production of stimulant drugs. It seems that North Korean spy vessels play a role not only in transporting agents but also drugs."

The boat sank after an exchange of fire. (Agence France-Presse) Map of Japan highlighting Kagoshima: The unidentified boat was first spotted 75 miles from Kagoshima.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Explosives Incident Adds To Airline Industry Tension
The passenger aboard an American Airlines plane who tried to ignite explosives in his shoes may have come very close to realizing the airline industry's nightmare scenario. Ever since Sept. 11, executives have worried that the downing of another jet by terrorists would reverse the industry's slow but steady recovery.
 The incident underscores simmering questions about the public's lack of confidence in stepped-up security measures since the attacks and whether American Airlines is being singled out because of its name. Page B5. 

HotJobs.com Seeks Higher TMP Bid
HotJobs.com, the Internet career site, told TMP Worldwide, the parent company of Monster.com, that it had 72 hours to top a $436 million unsolicited takeover bid from Yahoo or HotJobs would call off their six-month-old merger agreement. If HotJobs.com drops its deal with TMP, it will have to pay a breakup fee of as much as $17 million. Shares of HotJobs.com rose 26 cents, to $10.73. TMP rose 40 cents, to $41.50, while Yahoo fell 25 cents, to $16.67. C3.

Argentina Crisis Is Also Blow to U.S.
Argentina's declaration of a moratorium on repayment of its foreign debt marks the end of a failed economic experiment that has cost the country dearly. But it is also a blow to the United States and the International Monetary Fund, which had invested much of their credibility and prestige yet proved unwilling to help when things fell apart. News Analysis. A16.

As Argentina struggled to avert complete fiscal collapse with the anticipated issue of a new currency, the fallout in the United States is slowly coming to light. A17.

Stocks Settle Virtually Unchanged
Wall Street held steady, helped by buying in oil stocks on anticipation that OPEC would cut its output and oil prices would stabilize. The Dow Jones industrial average ended unchanged at 10,035.34 after an abbreviated trading session that ended at 1 p.m. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 0.24 point, to 1,144.65, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.35 points, to 1,944.48. C5.

Russia Moves to Ship More of Its Oil
Russia has embarked on an ambitious program to develop its own port capacity to ship oil, sparing it from having to pay to transport the oil through Estonia, Latvia or Lithuania. But political considerations and Russian pride have as much to do with the policy as money, analysts said. World Business, Section W.

Pearson Exits Commercial TV
Pearson of Britain said that it would sell its 22 percent stake in RTL, Europe's largest broadcasting company, to Bertelsmann for $1.33 billion. The sale represents Pearson's exit from commercial television, although the company will retain a small educational programming concern. It also furthers the strategic ambitions of Marjorie Scardino, the chief executive, who has moved to divest assets unrelated to the company's core publishing business. World Business, Section W.

Ex-Broker Is Fined $429 Million
A New York Stock Exchange panel has fined a former Lehman Brothers and PaineWebber stockbroker $429 million, the largest fine ever against a broker involving accusations of buying worthless stocks on his customers' behalf in exchange for kickbacks. C2.

Hallmark Settles a Patent Suit
Hallmark Cards settled a patent suit by the Tumbleweed Communications that had accused Hallmark of infringing on patents for sending greeting cards over the Web. C2.

AT&T Sheds Rest of Wireless Stake
AT&T, which is selling assets to reduce debt, sold its remaining stake in its former wireless unit for $1.4 billion. C4.

Markets Are Closed for Christmas
United States financial markets and most of those overseas are closed today in observance of the Christmas holiday. The American markets will reopen tomorrow; many foreign markets will remain closed.

HEADLINE: For Street Vendors With a Dream, a New Indoor Market in Flatbush 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN

 BODY:
For years, the corner of Flatbush and Caton Avenues, in the heart of Caribbean Brooklyn, has been an economic battleground, a place where enterprising street vendors went head to head with local store owners. The vendors dreamed of one day having a market all their own, while Flatbush merchants wished they would just go away.
 Now it seems the two have found a peaceful way to coexist after all, thanks in part to a new $1.6 million indoor vendors' market, the Flatbush Vendor Mart. It will open its doors early next month to 61 small-scale vendors, mostly Caribbean and African, selling hats, health and beauty aids, handmade crafts, children's clothing and everything between. 
 The mart represents a promise City Councilwoman Una S. T. Clarke made to the vendors six years ago, as they looked for an ally in their effort to survive on Flatbush. Mrs. Clarke, who is one of the 36 veteran council members forced out of office by term limits this year, called the new building a crowning moment for Flatbush. "It means jobs, economic growth and a chance to help any vendor who wants to get off the streets and get back to the dream that they came to this country with," she said.
The mart, built with city money, will operate year-round. It will be one of a handful around the city, but that is where the similarities will end, vows Roy Hastick, president of the Caribbean Chamber of Commerce, the group that will manage the new mart. Vendors will be assigned a stall for 17 months, in exchange for $25 a day. After that time elapses, a new group of vendors will come in.
No two vendors will be allowed to sell the same products. They must also agree to participate in small-business courses run by the city's Department of Business Services. Mr. Hastick said the courses were expected to include training in areas like bookkeeping, pricing, marketing and obtaining tax identification numbers and vendor licenses. 
Part of the idea, he said, is to prevent the 8,960-square-foot Flatbush Mart from suffering a fate similar to that of Mart 125 in Harlem. Vendors at that mart were eventually evicted after a lengthy legal fight with the city, in which they claimed the city never made good on promises to train them and help them purchase part of the mart. 
"Obviously, we're concerned about what happened in Harlem," Mr. Hastick said. "But we're working very closely with the city to make sure that training is in place and that vendors understand this is not a permanent home. It's a micro-enterprise incubator, an opportunity for the vendors to make some money but also to learn the skills to hopefully open their own businesses on Flatbush." 
Out on Flatbush Avenue, known for its roti shops, Caribbean grocers and reggae record stores, the mart is being welcomed by street vendors.
"Finally," said Frantz Moise, 42, a Haitian security guard who for nearly 10 years has sold Afro-Caribbean art and postcards part time. "We waited a long time, and we've had to put up with a lot." 
Under the city's "zero visibility" ordinance, street vending is illegal along busy commercial arteries like Flatbush Avenue. The police began clearing sidewalks after complaints from residents and local store owners who were frustrated that the vendors were clogging sidewalks and siphoning off customers. "Every Monday morning, vendors would be at my office asking for help because their merchandise has been taken away in a sweep or because there was a complaint from the business improvement district," Mrs. Clarke said. "To me, these were poor people trying to make a living doing an honest enterprise, albeit in a forbidden area. These are substantial stakeholders in this community; they needed a way to lift themselves up." 
So she began lobbying on their behalf, first pushing for a temporary space, an outdoor tent to be set up in part of a municipal parking lot. As that plan drew criticism from local merchants, Mrs. Clarke set her sights on a permanent mart at Flatbush and Caton. 
Her efforts have made her a hero to vendors like Selwyn Branker. "Una Clarke was the only one who listened to us, who tried to understand what it was like to be out here dealing with the crowded sidewalks, the car fumes, the police trying to enforce the law," Mr. Branker said.
Seven days a week, Mr. Branker, who is 40 and from Barbados, drags heavy bags choked full of Afro-Caribbean flags and pendants around the avenue looking for a safe place to set up.
Lately, he has found a home in front of the new mart, the place where he now plans to move closer to his dream of opening his own shop.
"Out here, the minute you make a few dollars, the person next to you starts selling the same thing," he said. "In the mart, it will be less competitive. Everybody will have a chance to make some money and learn." 
Not all the vendors along Flatbush Avenue are so convinced. Some say they are being asked to pay too much for too little in the way of accommodations. There is no storage space at the market, and some longtime vendors worry they will lose regular customers if they are not allowed to sell the same products that they have for years. 
Doreen, a Jamaican hat vendor who would give only her first name, said she was happy about the mart's arrival. "But the mart is supposed to benefit us," she said. "It ain't pretty or cheap to have to lug this stuff back and forth."
Storage would be a nice perk, Mr. Moise and others agree. But as he sees it, "You never get everything you want in life. At least we're going indoors." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Councilwoman Una S. T. Clarke, talking with street vendors outside their new indoor market in Brooklyn. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. D5)

CONTRACT MANUFACTURERSEEKS CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The contract manufacturer ACT Manufacturing said that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after its lenders refused to finance its operations under any other circumstances. 
ACT recently posted a third-quarter loss and said its business was hurt by the weak economy. The company has been cutting jobs and slowing production in a bid to save money. ACT filed its bankruptcy petition on Friday at a court in Worcester, Mass., and said a hearing is scheduled tomorrow to authorize up to $9.5 million of temporary debtor-in-possession financing. ACT said its overseas operations are unaffected by the filing.

HEADLINE: Trying to Keep Young Internet Users From a Life of Piracy 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
When law enforcement agents seized 129 computers in 27 cities recently in a coordinated assault on online piracy, they focused much of their effort on colleges like Duke, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of California at Los Angeles.
 They were probably too late. 
 As children have access to computers earlier and earlier in their educational careers, experts in piracy, hacking and other forms of Internet mischief say that any effort to tackle the illicit trade in digital goods -- including video games, computer software, music and even movies -- should be looking at a younger crowd. 
"By the time we get them, they already believe it's right," said David J. Farber, a professor of computer science at the University of Pennsylvania and the former chief technologist of the Federal Communications Commission "If you're willing to bootleg music, you're willing to bootleg anything."
In fact, America's rush to the online world has created an enormous population of ever-younger computer pirates, say experts in the field. They compare the situation with giving every student a car without providing drivers' education classes. 
"We've got to focus on preparing kids to use the Internet in a safe and responsible manner," said Nancy E. Willard, director of the Responsible Netizen Center for Advanced Technology in Education at the University of Oregon. She has prepared course materials and guides for teaching computer ethics in secondary schools to help them meet the requirements of the Children's Internet Protection Act of 2000. The law, which requires schools and libraries to use filters or similar technology to protect children from objectionable materials, also requires an "Internet safety policy" to prevent "unauthorized access, including so-called 'hacking,' and other unlawful activities by minors online."
Online, the searching and trading for wares goes on day and night. In an online discussion last week using technology known as Internet Relay Chat, the "warez" channel, or chat room, was busy. Warez is slang for software that has been "liberated" from encryption. On the channel, rapid-fire bursts of messages requesting digital goods -- games, DVD's, business software -- were interspersed among the random comments and insults: 
Queball: "Anyone know where I can a copy Sybex virtual lab . . ." 
Porrin: "@find 3d studio para *pc*."
Nellie: "Anyone here have save the last dance movie. msg me."
The patter and trading are constant, yet this is small time. Far bigger players operate quietly with vast storage and bandwidth, cracking the copyright protection that keep the strings of ones and zeroes that underlie everything from the video game Tomb Raider to the movie "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" and making them available in a limitless five-finger discount store in the ether. 
The recent raids focused mainly on the networks of hard-core traders in a handful of groups with names like DrinkOrDie, which tended to trade for fun and not for profit. Among the computers seized were ones belonging to business executives and administrators of computer networks.
Unauthorized copying and distribution of software is a global headache for the industry, which claims that more than a third of all business software used is pirated, according to an annual report commissioned by the Business Software Alliance, a trade group. In fact, the situation has improved markedly since 1995, when the figure was closer to half of all software. In the United States the figure has dropped to 24 percent, the lowest rate in the world, because of a vigorous education and enforcement efforts and until recently a strong economy. 
Over all, the cost of business software piracy alone was $11.75 billion in 2000, the group reported, although this amount assumes that any illicitly used software would otherwise have been bought by users.
The greatest incidence of software piracy, according to industry experts, occurs in business, where many employees of a firm will share a single copy of a program. Internet trading pales by comparison, said Bob Kruger, vice president for enforcement at the Business Software Alliance. But it constitutes "the biggest threat in the future," he said, "as people become more accustomed to getting digital works online."
The software industry does not break out the statistics for piracy in higher education, but "anecdotally, we see a lot of activity coming out of university areas," said Ric Hirsch, senior vice president for intellectual property enforcement at the Interactive Digital Software Association, the trade association representing computer and video game publishers.
Eugene H. Spafford, a professor of computer science and director of Purdue University's Center for Education and Research in Information Assurance and Security, said if students lack the ethical preparation when they begin using the Internet, things quickly spiral out of control when they reach college, where they have lots of free time, peers they want to impress and high bandwidth.
That is to be expected, Professor Spafford said, since college is a time for testing boundaries. "We do encourage them to try new things, meet new people," he said. "It's not that surprising that they try to break some of the bounds, and not just in computing."
But fixing the problem would be expensive and intrusive, he said. He questions whether the monitoring required might be worse than the disease.
"When you have one person who goes bad out of 40,000, do you want to watch that other 39,999 to catch that one?" Professor Spafford asked. "To find the people doing the bad things might involve violating the privacy of all those other people. As a society is that the kind of trade-off we want to make?"
Professor Farber agreed. Closely monitor students, he warned, and "pretty soon you'll be looking at what they write and what they read." 
Some experts say they wish the corporations pushing for ethical behavior among customers would show more of it themselves.
Many students bristle at the newest legal tool for protecting copyright, the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. It has been criticized as heavy handed, tipping the balance of copyright law away from principles such as fair use. 
Many also note, Professor Willard said, a federal court ruling that Microsoft had abused its monopoly power.
That is how "Incursion" sees it. The Internet name belonged to a college student from Texas, who was looking for games recently on the Warez channel. The student said he generally pays for the software he uses but does like to sample the goods before buying. "If I feel it's a quality game," he said, "I'll buy it."
Asked whether using software without paying for it is wrong, he replied, "depends what you consider wrong." Pressed for further explanation, he wrote, "A monopoly is wrong."
Taking apart rationalizations like that one are part of what Professor Willard tries to do in materials that she has prepared for teenagers.
But she added that the argument has power -- and that recklessness and rebellion are not just part of adolescence but of the American character. "We applaud the U.S. patriots," she said, "who hacked onto the British tea ship and destroyed their product."
Ultimately, time might be on the companies' side. The environment changes so quickly that even would-be pirates say they find it hard to keep up. 
Jeremy, who goes by the online name "Xelsed" and asks that only his first name be used, insisted that he did not trade software any more -- which did not explain what he was doing in the Warez channel typing "!gimme stuff," a request he saw others type and which he figured could lead to offers. Even if he wanted to, though, he was out of touch, he said, having not visited the site in several months. 
The old formula for a request for software -- typing "/xdcc" and then the name of a program -- did not seem to resonate in the current slang. "Now I really dont know what to do," he types in the hasty, error-riddled style of instant messages. "I have to face the fact that well i'm dated."
Jeremy said he was 27 and out of college and added that he feels he has outgrown the warez world. 
"To be frank," he wrote, "I think its probably alot easer to buy the game then to spend the hours neccacery to make 'friends' and get into the sceen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Education experts say that America's efforts to teach computer ethics should be aimed at younger students because the rush to the Internet has created an enormous population of ever-younger computer pirates. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: The Scrooge Syndrome 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"Bah, humbug!" cried the U.S. treasury secretary. O.K., Paul O'Neill didn't actually say "Bah." But last week he contemptuously dismissed proposals for increased aid to poor nations. And his justification -- that he "would like to see evidence of what works before making new commitments" -- was pure humbug.
 For the truth is that we already know what works. Nobody expects foreign aid to perform miracles, to turn Mozambique into Sweden overnight. But more modest goals, such as saving millions of people a year from diseases like malaria and tuberculosis, are quite reachable, for quite modest sums of money. 
 That is the message of a commission report just released by the World Health Organization, which calls on advanced countries to provide resources for a plan to "scale up the access of the world's poor to essential health services." The program would provide very basic items that many poor nations simply cannot afford: antibiotics to treat tuberculosis, insecticide-treated nets to control malaria, and so on. The price tag would be about 0.1 percent of advanced countries' income. The payoff would be at least eight million lives each year.
 This is not starry-eyed idealism. The report quotes Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard professor who headed the commission: "I can be 'realistic' and 'cynical' with the best of them -- giving all the reasons why things are too hard to change." Mr. Sachs knows that it will be hard to persuade advanced countries to come up with the money -- and that the United States, in particular, is likely to be highly unreceptive. But this is one of those cases in which leadership could make a tremendous difference. 
 Right now, the United States is the Scrooge of the Western world -- the least generous rich nation on the planet. One of the tables in that W.H.O. report shows the share of G.N.P. given in foreign aid by advanced countries; the United States ranks dead last, well behind far poorer countries such as Portugal and Greece. The sums proposed by the W.H.O. would double our foreign aid budget, not because those sums are large, but because we start from so low a base -- about a dime a day for each U.S. citizen.
 Still, doubling our foreign aid budget sounds like an impossible dream. But is it? We may be a Scrooge nation, but we are not a nation of Scrooges. Not only are Americans often generous as individuals, they are -- without knowing it -- apparently willing to give substantially more foreign aid than the nation actually does. When asked how much of the federal budget should be devoted to foreign aid, Americans typically come up with a number around 10 percent -- about 20 times what we currently spend.
 Voters are, however, misinformed: they think that the share of foreign aid in federal spending should be cut to 10 percent. And they wonder why foreigners don't show more gratitude for all the money we give them. Americans are, in other words, living in the past: the Marshall Plan ended more than 50 years ago, but they haven't noticed.
 The point is that we like to think of ourselves as generous. This suggests that a U.S. administration that really wanted to follow the W.H.O. report's recommendations would not find it hard to build political support. All it would have to do is use the bully pulpit to inform the public of the difference between America's generous self-image and the less attractive reality.
 Why bother? You might say that the United States has a selfish interest in helping the world's poor. The Sachs commission argues that there would be large collateral benefits from improved health care in the world's poorest nations. Disease, it argues, is a major barrier to economic growth, and economic growth in developing countries would make the world as a whole a richer and safer place. 
 You might also say that reducing the disconnect between America's words and its deeds would give us a better claim to the moral leadership we think we deserve.
 But the key argument here is surely a moral one. A sum of money that Americans would hardly notice, a dime a day for the average citizen, would quite literally save the lives of millions. Can we really say to ourselves, this Christmas Day, that this gift is not worth giving? --------------------

Nicholas D. Kristof's column will appear tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Next, Pavel From Irkutsk Gives Putin A Mouthful 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin did something today that might be deemed remarkable even in a robust democracy like the United States: he spent two and a half hours on national television, taking questions from ordinary Russians. 
 He got an earful, too. 
 There was Lyubov M. Sergeyeva, a single mother of a disabled child with a family income of about $50 a month, calling from Kostroma Province, north of Moscow. "Vladimir Vladimirovich, we are not living, we are subsisting," she told Mr. Putin by telephone. "When will the state show care at last for such families?" 
There was a call from Petrov -- just Petrov -- a Moscow businessman who apparently was a target for extortion. "Do you know there is a popular concept called a 'protection market' ?" he asked, and went on to suggest that representatives of law enforcement bodies top the list of those involved.
And there was Pavel Tsvetkov, a 10-year-old from Siberia's Irkutsk region, whose school was closed for lack of heat. "My question to you, Vladimir Vladimirovich, is: Is it possible that we will be asked to repeat the year if it is not our fault that our schools are not heated?"
There were 47 questioners in all, plugged into a Kremlin office via the Internet, telephone and live video feeds from 10 Russian cities. They wanted to know why their pensions were late or meager, when their villages would get natural gas lines, how a teacher and a doctor could expect to survive as husband and wife on $100 a month in government wages.
Their queries carried an undercurrent, aptly summarized by an unidentified man who appeared on a video screen from Novosibirsk, in southern Siberia. "Won't we be cheated again, Vladimir Vladimirovich?" he asked. 
Mr. Putin, imperturbable as always, answered practically every query with a dollop of facts and statistics, a display that was reminiscent of President Bill Clinton's legendary grip on the details of governing. But his answers, too, reflected an undercurrent, which surfaced early, when a student from Vladivostok complained that Mr. Putin's promises to improve housing had yet to fix the maze of leaky pipes in the region's apartment buildings.
"This is roughly the same as if one of us were suffering from a grave, chronic disease for many years, and then would go to a doctor and say, 'Tomorrow, I need to take a test for the cosmonaut's unit, so give me a pill since I need to pass the medical examination,' " Mr. Putin said. "No such miracle will happen." 
Mr. Putin repeatedly told questioners that Russia would not transform itself overnight, even as he leavened most of his answers with data showing that average incomes and pensions are rising smartly, homeless soldiers are getting more housing and aid to the disabled is on the uptick.
Whether Russians took to his blunt message remains to be seen. When the Moscow news radio station Ekho Moskvy asked callers to register their opinions in an unscientific telephone survey, two-thirds of the 1,238 callers said Mr. Putin had not reassured them about their own concerns, while a third said he had. 
The two state-run networks that broadcast the program, RTR and ORT, said that they had been swamped with more than 500,000 calls from questioners, while another 27,000 questions were submitted through the Internet. 
Only two questioners asked about foreign affairs, and both were concerned with the United States. Responding to a caller who asked about the White House's withdrawal from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Mr. Putin repeated, as he had before, that he opposed the move but that he expected relations with Washington to continue to improve. 
The other caller, harking back to cold war days, reminded Mr. Putin that in his days as a Soviet spy, America was viewed as the Kremlin's major enemy. He wondered what Mr. Putin thought about sleeping in the enemy's bed during his visit to President Bush's Texas ranch last month.
Mr. Putin had a quick and wry reply. "I was not very much excited over spending the night in Bush's dacha," he said. "I think he should himself be concerned about what was going on if he had let a former officer of the Soviet foreign intelligence into his home."

HEADLINE: Officials Race to Finish Stadium Plans For Mets and Yankees Before Year's End 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Despite the city's growing fiscal problems and the approaching departure of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, city officials are laboring furiously to complete plans for new stadiums for the Mets and the Yankees by New Year's Eve.
 It is unclear whether the work will be completed by the time Mayor Giuliani swears in his successor, Michael R. Bloomberg, in Times Square early on Jan. 1. But the city has been meeting with executives of the Mets and the Yankees in recent days, and an outline of the deals was contained in a thick environmental impact statement for a new stadium for the Mets that was completed last week. 
 The plans envision a public-private partnership, with the Mets and the Yankees making the largest private contribution toward the cost of a stadium of any Major League Baseball team. But the impact statement omits the cost of transportation improvements, and thereby understates the full cost of the projects to taxpayers by several hundred million dollars. Critics also said the report fails to provide an economic rationale for the projects. 
"Stadiums do not lead to long-term economic growth or jobs," said Ronnie Lowenstein, director of the city's Independent Budget Office. "And there's nothing in this report that would indicate otherwise."
The push to complete the work just days before Mayor Giuliani leaves office comes as the economic fallout from the recession and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center have deepened the sense that things like housing and education would have more claim on the ever-shrinking pot of public money than the stadium deal does. And the incoming mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, has been lukewarm about thesubject of stadiums and the broader topic of economic incentives to private businesses. 
Mr. Bloomberg declined to comment on the ongoing push for the stadiums. Robert Harding, deputy mayor for economic development, did not return calls requesting comment.
Contrary to most economists, Mayor Giuliani has long argued that stadiums would spark new business. In recent weeks, city officials have rushed to put the finishing details on his administration's stadium plans. The city's Art Commission approved the Mets' stadium design at a little-noticed public hearing on Nov. 12, and the Parks Department approved the team's impact statement last week. City officials have also met with the Yankees, although the team's plans are not as far along as the Mets' are.
Under the Mets' plan, the city and the team would build a 46,000-seat, $800 million stadium that would resemble the old Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, but include all the modern accouterments, including a retractable roof and 90 luxury suites, in the parking lot next to the team's current home, Shea Stadium, in Queens. The plan calls for work on the stadium to begin next month and be completed in time for the opening game in 2005.
Whatever Mr. Giuliani does before he leaves office, he cannot put any stadium plan into effect single-handedly in the days remaining in his term. Furthermore, some elements of the plan would require approval by the state and by the City Council. 
The city would issue $800 million in tax-exempt bonds, but according to the impact statement, the team would pay $25 million or more of the estimated $50 million in annual debt payments. At the same time, the Mets would be responsible for operating costs and maintenance, while the city would own the stadium and get an unspecified share of the revenue from baseball games and other events at the stadium.
Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp, a sports-consulting firm in Chicago, said that the $400 million contribution from the Mets would represent "the largest amount any team in baseball has put into a new stadium project." He also said that tax-exempt financing would save the teams millions of dollars a year.
In San Francisco, the Giants paid the entire cost of building Pacific Bell Park, but the cost was only $319 million. Taxpayers, however, covered the cost of more than $100 million in highway and sewer projects. In contrast, the Seattle Mariners provided about $150 million toward the $517 million cost of Safeco Field in Seattle, the most expensive stadium to date.
The report for "Shea Stadium Redevelopment," however, does not include more than $100 million in subway and highway improvements the Mets have asked the state to undertake for the new stadium. The estimated cost of the transportation improvements for the Yankees is even higher, more than $200 million, according to state officials. But neither the Yankees nor the Mets have met with state officials since the attack on the World Trade Center in September, when the stadium projects appeared to lose priority.
Plans for a new Yankee Stadium are still coming together, but according to one person involved in the talks, the team would receive "an equivalent deal." The Yankees project is more complicated because it involves the demolition of the team's historic home in the Bronx and the building of a new stadium at nearby Macombs Dam Park, which has generated opposition from the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, and from community groups.
Critics say it is hard to understand why New York would consider public funding for baseball stadiums when it must rebuild Lower Manhattan and has an estimated $4 billion budget gap beginning July 1 and a projected $40 billion in debt. The city already spends 16 cents out of every tax dollar to pay long-term debts, according to Ms. Lowenstein of the Independent Budget Office.
"Stadiums don't generate new hotels or office buildings," she said. "Economic activity that would have been here anyway, like restaurants and retailers, do wind up in different parts of city depending on where you put a stadium." The impact statement concluded that the Mets' stadium "would not result in substantial new development" or affect the real estate market.
The report does say that a stadium with a retractable roof would be used for up to 75 other events, including concerts, religious events, basketball games and college sports, that would bring in revenue for the city.
But Mr. Ganis of Sportscorp said that based on experience at other domed stadiums it is unlikely that the Mets could book that many events. "They're being very aggressive," he said. "I suspect that if the Mets were paying for the entire cost of the roof we might see a different economic analysis."
The report concluded by saying that, "The biggest single benefit of the proposed project to the City of New York would be the retention of jobs, earnings, and a variety of tax revenues by keeping the Mets in the city."
But the impact statement also says that if a new stadium is not built, "the Mets would presumably continue to use the existing Shea Stadium, and operations and revenue would be expected to remain."
