HEADLINE: China's Efforts Against Crime Make No Dent 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: TAIGU, China 

 BODY:
On his last night alive, Chang Dongqing responded to an emergency call about an armed robbery in progress near the police station here where he worked. Because another officer had checked out the station's only gun, a 1954 series, .45-caliber semiautomatic pistol, Officer Chang picked up the long iron rod that was the station's only other weapon.
 Less than an hour later, he was dead, killed by a shotgun blast to the heart. 
 "My husband had a glorious job," his wife, Han Xuehong, her face drawn, her eyes apprehensive and sad, said as she talked recently at the police station here about how she has coped since he died in May. 
Officer Chang is one of hundreds of policemen who have died in the line of duty since April, when China declared its latest "Strike Hard" campaign, a period of frenzied police activity meant to cow criminals and reassure the populace that the government is keeping crime in check. 
He was part of China's figurative thin gray line. Like the thin blue line of the police in the United States, it is meant to hold society's criminals back from law-abiding citizens, only this one is far thinner. 
In fact, China is one of the most sparsely policed countries in the world. Not only are there few police officers per capita here, but also as a matter of policy few of them carry guns, making them vulnerable to the country's increasingly well-armed criminals, like the highway robbers that shot Officer Chang. 
To hold the line against crime, the government relies on draconian campaigns that periodically sweep up tens of thousands of suspects, rush them through abbreviated trials and send thousands of them to death -- regardless of the likelihood that some are innocent. 
Though the official number of those executed is a closely guarded government secret, this year alone more than 5,000 people are believed to have been put to death. They include the two men involved in Officer Chang's death.
The periodic crackdowns have become the policing strategy of choice for a Chinese government lacking the reach and resources to provide more police officers who are both better armed and better trained. 
But while tens of thousands of people have been executed since the country's first nationwide campaign in 1983, Chinese academics say government statistics show that the Strike Hard campaigns have no lasting impact on crime, belying the effectiveness of a policing strategy whose central feature is forced confessions and death.
The anticrime drives invigorate and define the darkest corner of China's formidable system of social control, a corner, largely unseen by the broader population, where police brutality is tolerated, even encouraged. For the vast majority of Chinese, the campaigns are reassuring and right. But for others, they bring terror and despair. 
With an average of six policemen for every 10,000 residents -- a quarter the ratio in the United States -- China relies on its citizens, particularly Communist Party neighborhood committees, to act as watchdogs against crime. 
Local police forces operate on shoestring budgets, which they supplement during normal periods with money collected through fines imposed for a wide range of illegal behavior.

Corruption Aids Criminals
But the line between fines and payments by criminals for protection from prosecution is easily blurred in a country where the political system has remained closed even as the economy has opened. 
Emboldened by such protection, criminals in many parts of the country have been able to take revenge on witnesses and informants with impunity. 
The government fears that people will be afraid to report on suspected felons and that the citizen network will break down, leaving the police overwhelmed. 
"When the press talks about the campaigns 'puncturing the puffed up arrogance of the criminals,' they are trying to reassure the populace that the police are in control," says Murray Scot Tanner, an associate professor of political science at Western Michigan University who has written extensively on China's anticrime drives. 
In many ways, Officer Chang was as much a victim of this understaffed, underfinanced police force and the campaign-style policing on which it depends as he was of crime. 
When the station received the call from the county's emergency dispatcher, Officer Chang raced to the scene and found the victim along the roadside, but the robbers were nowhere to be seen. His bosses say his job was to give emergency assistance to the victim and secure the crime scene for investigators who were on their way. But he was intent on doing more. 
He parked his unmarked car on the stretch of road where the robbery had taken place and opened the hood, feigning engine trouble. The robbery victim waited with him at the front of the car, while a part-time employee from the police station stood guard at the back. It was not long before they spotted two crouching figures who ran toward the car from a ditch beside the road. The robbers had apparently returned. 
Officer Chang stepped around the front and swung the iron rod he had take from the station house. One of the masked men fired a shotgun, hitting him in the arm. Officer Chang swung again, and the man fired the gun's second barrel into his chest. He died in the car on the way to the hospital. 
It is not clear that the Strike Hard campaign, which had begun a month earlier and was then at full pitch, pushed Officer Chang to take unreasonable risks, but the campaigns do put pressure on police officers to make arrests and close cases quickly in an environment of fervid competition. 
Like everywhere in China, Taigu's police chief is appointed by local Communist Party officials whose careers depend on how well their area performs during such politically directed campaigns. Many police stations are given arrest and conviction targets that they are expected to meet.
"The central government does not set quotas, but county-level officials do," says Liu Renwen, a lawyer who studies the campaigns at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences' Institute of Law in Beijing.
When asked whether the spirit of Strike Hard helped drive Officer Chang beyond the call of duty, the local deputy police chief did not hesitate. "Undoubtedly!" he replied.
Hu Xiaoguang, who had come from the Shanxi Public Security Department in the provincial capital to oversee a reporter's meeting with the slain officer's wife, said, "There's a strong sense of pride between provinces, and we compare ourselves to each other."
The percentage of policemen killed in the line of duty in China, already several times higher than the United States and as many as 10 times the rate during the Mao era, has surged during the current campaign. 
Presenting a looming challenge to the authorities, criminals in China are increasingly well-armed with guns either smuggled from Vietnam and other Southeast Asian countries or manufactured in illegal factories at home. But China remains reluctant to arm its poorly educated, poorly paid police force, fearing more guns in its hands would lead to a rise in extrajudicial killings and other crimes by policemen with ties to local mafias. There is also concern that police officers could side with their communities against the central authorities in cases of local unrest.
Instead, weapons are reserved for the People's Armed Police, a national paramilitary force charged with guarding government offices, patrolling its borders and quelling riots or uprisings. Even counting the People's Armed Police, the number of police officers per capita is still only half that of the United States. The regular military does not ordinarily involve itself in routine police matters.

First Crackdown by Deng
The late Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, who steered the country into a social and economic transformation that continues today, called for the first Strike Hard campaign in 1983 to reassert government control over society as the pervasive network of party members and zealous resident committees began to lose its grip over the country's vast and increasingly mobile population.
At that time, droves of convicts were executed in cities across the country, often dozens in a single city in a single day. Scholars estimate that during the three years of the campaign, more than 30,000 people were sentenced to death.
Since then, there have been dozens of local and regional campaigns, sending judicial executions to annual levels that far exceed even those during the three centuries of the Ching dynasty. This year's is the third national campaign, following one in 1996.
Many people in China argue that the threat of severe punishment and the likelihood of arrest during Strike Hard campaigns keeps would-be criminals in line. But government statistics studied by Chinese academics suggest that career criminals have learned to lie low until the campaigns are over and the police, worn out, relax back into old patterns.
Almost immediately after the 1996 campaign ended, criminal cases began to climb, and by September 1997, monthly crime rates were back where they had been when the campaign began, according to Mr. Liu, the lawyer who studies the campaigns. 
"The same will happen after this campaign," he said. "If you expect the crime rate to go down after such a campaign, it won't work. Crimes have social causes."
The campaigns often result in abuses of power, particularly in forcing confessions from suspects in order to satisfy the bureaucracy's statistical hunger.

Torture and Conviction
In a private room of a hotel restaurant in Dashiqiao, the gray northeastern industrial town in which he was born, Li Huawei, 38, pulls aside the thick black hair atop his head to reveal a hairless divot left in his scalp by a policeman's truncheon. It is an enduring reminder of the three days of torture that ruined his life. 
Mr. Li had returned home from work on a cold afternoon in October 1986 to find his 21-year-old wife dead, her head nearly severed by a butcher knife. He briefly held her in his arms and then rushed to find help.
Almost three months later, at the end of the country's first major Strike Hard campaign, he was suddenly seized, handcuffed and taken to the local police station. Wang Chengyou, the local police chief at the time and now a judge, told a Liaoning newspaper this year that the police had arrested Mr. Li because "the case needed to be solved by the end of the year." 
He was made to stand for hours while he was interrogated. "When I wouldn't confess, they made me lean my head against the wall with my hands cuffed behind me," Mr. Li said, demonstrating how he was forced to stand two feet from the wall so that much of his weight was concentrated on his head. He said sweat ran from his face and puddled beneath him despite the winter cold in the room.
Occasionally, when he was on the verge of collapse, the police would allow him to sit, handcuffed to a chair, and his interrogation would begin again. 
Finally, in the middle of the third night, when he could bear it no longer, he pushed away from the wall to stand up. He was immediately felled by the crack of a truncheon that left him dazed on the ground.
Such police behavior is nominally illegal in China but widely tolerated because prosecutions here have long relied more on confessions than on physical evidence. The use of DNA analysis to solve crimes, for instance, is still extremely rare.
"As far as we can tell, confessions from torture spike higher during anticrime campaigns as lower level officials are compelled to generate criminals on short notice," says Mr. Tanner, the scholar.
According to a report by the Supreme People's Procuracy, torture cases surged to their highest level in six years during the 1996 Strike Hard campaign.
When Mr. Li had recovered from the blow, the chief investigator threatened him again, telling him that his mother had testified that he had confessed to her and that if he did not confess, his family would be arrested as accomplices to the crime. Not having slept for three days and allowed to eat only some bread and soup during that time, he decided that he should at least save his family if he could not save himself.
"I decided this was my fate," Mr. Li recalled, "and to live had no meaning. My family was already broken, my wife dead, and if I confessed, nothing more would happen to my family."
He sat, dispirited, answering "yes" to the investigator's account of how Mr. Li had stabbed his pregnant wife and sliced at his unborn child. He was then sent to a detention center, where his feet were locked into 10-pound shackles for the next three years.
Mr. Li was found guilty and sentenced to death in late 1989, even though the police had found fingerprints on the knife and a footprint on a bedsheet in the room clear enough to identify the brand of shoe, neither of which matched those of Mr. Li. As tacit acknowledgment that the case against him was flawed, the court suspended his sentence for two years, a reprieve that normally means the sentence will later be commuted to life in prison.
Then, in July 2000, a man arrested for a separate murder confessed to killing Mr. Li's wife. He had been a 17-year-old high school student living next door to Mr. Li at the time. The man's fingerprints matched those still on file from the knife used to kill Mr. Li's wife. 
It took eight months more before Mr. Li was released on bail. He will not have a chance to clear his name until after his wife's murderer is executed, as is expected sometime in the next few months.
Despite such cases, suggestions that innocent people are being sentenced to death in the current Strike Hard campaign leave many people unmoved, particularly given the absence of public debate in the state-controlled news media. Most Chinese are more concerned with seizing new economic opportunities than reflecting on possible injustices.
"I think there are very, very few cases of innocent people who are executed, and, anyway, that's better than letting some criminals get away to harm other people," said Li Boyu, a 19-year-old college student sipping a cup of tea at a fashionable cafe in the university district of Shanghai. "In China, the interests of the nation or the community are always more important than the interests of the individual."
On the contrary, she says, there are cases, like corruption and embezzlement, in which people have been given life imprisonment when she thought they deserved the death penalty.
"They are the termites of society," she says, her voice soft and high. "They deserve the death penalty."
Such conservative sentiments are easy to find in China, where there is a deep, historically linked fear of social chaos and a Confucian yearning for governance by a strong central authority. The sentiments are not surprising in a country where the vast majority of people are undereducated and poor and represent a latent threat to order. Ms. Li (no relation to Mr. Li) says her greatest concern about safety, in fact, is the tides of migrant workers that flow from the countryside into the cities and are blamed for much of China's crime.
For her and her peers, who have known only economic expansion, China is a country of opportunity, not oppression, and the Communist Party is responsible for having created the space in which they thrive. 
"If public security is good, ordinary people can live peacefully," she said, then cited an ancient Chinese adage: "Kill one to warn a hundred."

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
Workers Get More Bang for Their Bucks in Surprising Locations

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Where should police officers, registered nurses and truck drivers move if they want to earn a good living? Reno, Nev., might be a good choice. 
 Reno ranked No. 1 in the United States in pay for police officers and No. 2 for nurses and truck drivers, when calculated as a percentage of the average income in the city, according to an analysis of compensation data collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for 1999, the most recent available year. 
 Salinas, Calif., also did well, placing second and third, respectively, for police officers and registered nurses.
 For truck drivers, Reno was one of the few bright spots. In most places, the average hourly salary of truck drivers was less than the average for the area. In Rochester, for example, drivers earned an average of just 59 percent of the average for all workers. In Austin, Tex., drivers earned 61 percent, and in Los Angeles and Orange County, Calif., 69 percent. 
 Not surprising, computer programmers did well in technology hotbeds like San Francisco and North Carolina. But, reflecting the increased role of technology in recent years in the design and construction of automobiles, the most remunerative part of the country for them was Detroit and nearby cities. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Japan Wants to Salvage Boat It Says Fired on Its Coast Guard 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 26 

 BODY:
Japanese officials on Tuesday advocated salvaging a sunken boat believed to be from North Korea, a move that could give new insight into the electronic eavesdropping ability of that secretive nation.
 "Salvaging the sunken ship is technically possible," Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said of the boat that went down Saturday night in the East China Sea after an intense firefight with the Japanese Coast Guard. "The area is outside Japan's territorial waters, so we should look into the situation carefully and salvage it if possible." 
 In the battle Saturday night, occupants of the mystery boat fired RPG-7 rockets, Soviet-era armaments that are often used as antitank weapons, Japanese Coast Guard officials have concluded. The officials say that at least two of the rockets flew over their ships, landing harmlessly in the water.
Although 12 Coast Guard vessels continued to search the area on Tuesday, the 90 pieces of debris recovered do not definitively identify the 100-ton ship as North Korean. Of the 15-member crew, only 2 bodies have been recovered, both wearing life jackets inscribed with Korean writing.
Japanese news media reported today that Japan's Defense Agency monitored radio communications last week from the mystery ship on a radio frequency used by North Korea's ruling Workers Party of Korea. Sankei Shimbun newspaper said the communications suggested that the ship was smuggling drugs. Kyodo News Service reported that Japanese defense officials focused on the ship after United States military satellites detected the unknown ship in Japanese waters on Dec. 18.
"I hope to salvage the sunken ship for investigations," Japan's land, infrastructure and transport minister, Chikage Ogi, said on Tuesday. "Unless we find out the nationality and the goals of the unidentified ship, we cannot take any steps."
The ship sank within waters claimed by China as its economic zone.
In Beijing on Tuesday, Zhang Qiyue, a spokeswoman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, said: "China is seriously concerned about the Japanese side employing arms while pursuing the boat, and about the fact that it sank in China's exclusive economic zone. We are requesting the Japanese side to brief us further on relevant situations. The Japanese side should fully respect China's rights, interests and concerns."
Kazuhiro Sugita, a Japanese deputy chief cabinet secretary, recognized China's authority at the site of the sunken boat, saying, "There are options such as salvaging the ship or sending divers, but we would need the consent of China."
Three days after the sinking, North Korea has remained silent on the episode.
Japanese public opinion seems to be hardening against North Korea. Over the last two days, Japanese television has shown videos taken by the Coast Guard of the intruder ship firing rockets, and of bullets slamming into Japanese ships.
Much of the tension comes from widespread suspicions that in the past North Korean boats have delivered drugs to Japan and have taken to North Korea about 10 Japanese citizens kidnapped from beaches.
On Tuesday, the Coast Guard quickly mobilized a search party of 10 boats and 9 airplanes to respond to a Japanese fisherman's report an unidentified boat off a section of coast directly across the Japan Sea from North Korea. This mystery vessel now appears to have been a Japanese fishing boat.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Magnet School in Westchester

BYLINE:  By Merri Rosenberg 

 BODY:
 A magnet high school open to students from three Westchester County school districts will begin classes at the State University of New York's Purchase campus at the end of January. The high school, known as the Westchester Magnet Academy, hopes to bring together students from different ethnic and economic backgrounds who live in Irvington, Harrison and the Greenburgh Central Seven School District, based in Hartsdale. A major lure is Purchase College's intense arts courses and its professional faculty and studios. The magnet school, financed by a $2 million, three-year federal grant, is starting with 60 ninth graders and will add a grade successively until the current freshmen graduate. So far about three dozen students have applied. 
 Merri Rosenberg

HEADLINE: Law Firms Put Less Money Into Bonuses for Associates 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Last year it seemed as if New York law firms tripped over themselves to dole out unprecedented year-end bonuses to their high-billing associates. This year it is with grave reluctance and not much fanfare that they are paying out half, at most, of what they paid last year.
 First-year associates appear to be getting a bonus this year of up to $20,000, compared with $40,000 last year, according to an unofficial poll of several large firms that are usually industry bellwethers. The amount of the bonus increases by $5,000 for each year of experience, topping out at $50,000, down from last year's top level of $100,000. 
 The leader in setting bonuses this year was Cravath, Swaine & Moore. That firm has been matched by Sullivan & Cromwell, which kicked off a bonus competition among firms last year; Davis Polk & Wardwell; Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton; and several others.
The lower bonuses are evidence that although law firms are generally viewed as buffered against economic conditions by the different kinds of work they do -- when mergers slow down, bankruptcies usually pick up -- they are feeling the effect of a slowdown over the last year. (Bonuses at law firms are generally far smaller than those received by investment bankers and other Wall Street professionals, whose take-home pay may increase by 50 percent or more as a result of bonuses.)
The overall drop in bonuses "reflects the fact that last year was truly an extraordinary year, and we felt that associates were entitled because they contributed a lot to that," said one partner at a large firm. "This year will probably not be an extraordinary year," the partner added.
But there is still bonus competition. Partners at Davis Polk told their associates in October that the firm would not pay bonuses at all because of the economic slowdown, but they assured associates at the same time that the firm would continue its no-layoff policy. The move was widely viewed as an effort to forestall a costly bonus war, like the one that occurred last year.
At the last minute, the Davis Polk partners changed their minds. On Friday they informed lawyers that bonuses would be given after all. 
The pressure to pay bonuses is the result of the "constant competition among the firms for talent," said Stephen Gillers, a law professor at New York University. "A bonus has both real and symbolic value," he said, explaining that besides their monetary value, bonuses symbolize both the willingness of partners to share the wealth with junior lawyers and the confidence of partners in the financial health of the firm.
"Every second- and third-year law student and every associate is watching to see who gets paid what," he added.
Weil, Gotshal & Manges, which is representing the Enron Corporation in its bankruptcy proceedings, will pay first-year associates up to $20,000, as will several other firms. It will also pay retention bonuses of $11,900 to $19,800, based on lawyers' seniority.
What is most disturbing to young lawyers in the world of big firms is the number and the size of some of the law firms that are paying less, even slightly less. Debevoise & Plimpton is paying both first- and second-year lawyers bonuses of $20,000, for example. The bonuses increase only for every two years of experience, rather than for every year.
At Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, whose $140,000 starting salaries are significantly higher than the $125,000 paid by other big firms, bonuses will much smaller, ranging from $2,500 to $10,000.

Marsh & McLennan Revises Health Benefits for Families
Soon after Sept. 11, Marsh & McLennan announced that it would provide the families of 295 employees killed in the attack with a year of full health insurance benefits. Senior executives considered the offer generous, but family members argued that a company with $10 billion in annual revenues could surely do more.
 Marsh & McLennan has decided to extend health coverage to the families for three years. But it will pay for the coverage not from corporate accounts, but from the MMC Victims Relief Fund, a charity established by the company to help provide for the families of the 295 employees who died. Page A1. 

Law Firms Reduce Some Bonuses
New York law firms will pay first-year associates year-end bonuses of up to $20,000, down from $40,000 last year, according to an unofficial poll of several large firms that are usually industry bellwethers. C2.

All You Need to Know About the Euro
A dozen European countries will start using the euro on Jan. 1, but international business travelers have found that information on the euro has been relatively sparse. One exception is the euro Web site of the European Central Bank. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C3.

Many people believe euro notes and coins will reduce the popular skepticism. A3.

Supporters of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi like to compare him to Ronald Reagan or Margaret Thatcher. But others see him more as Mikhail Gorbachev, who said all the right things but could never get his own party to do them. News Analysis. C2.

Robert A. Watson, retired national commander of the Salvation Army, recalled attending a Salvation Army activity when he was 9. The teacher had the children put together a Bible verse. He believes "it was kind of a heart-warming moment when God took interest in a scrawny kid from a struggling family, in an after-school activity in the Salvation Army." The Boss. C5.

HEADLINE: In Tumultuous Year, Con Ed Basks in ItsQuiet Success 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
It was among the many small, improbable scenes in the days after the Sept. 11 attacks: A blue Consolidated Edison Inc. truck rushed down West Street toward the disaster site, an American flag streaming from its roof, and the roadside crowd, which had gathered to cheer firemen and police, shouted, "Yaay! Con Ed!"
 Con Ed is basking in a season of redemption. A company that New Yorkers love to hate -- their ire stoked by blackouts, accidents and monthly bills that persistently reflect some of the highest rates in the country -- has won a new measure of respect. 
 Politicians and regular New Yorkers applauded the utility for dispatching legions of workers to restore power to the wounded financial district in time for the reopening of the New York Stock Exchange less than a week after the attacks.
Investors who long shrugged off Con Ed have embraced it, happy to own a stock market wallflower. With Enron collapsing and the share prices of deregulated power companies like Dynegy and Calpine swinging wildly, Con Ed has been a safe harbor, its stock hovering just under $40 since mid-November. 
While other utilities charged off in new directions, Con Ed stuck to its core business of delivering power to homes and businesses. It did not seize on electricity deregulation to start building power plants all over the country, only to watch electricity prices fall. It did not develop a sizable power trading operation, only to be vulnerable to Enron's collapse.
Con Ed's glow is mainly in relative terms, and no one can say how long it will last. But even when it fades, Con Ed will probably not veer from its conservative track.
"The company is intentionally risk-averse," said Barry Abramson, senior utilities analyst at the investment bank UBS Warburg. "Not missing opportunities isn't the goal at Con Ed. The goal is to miss foul-ups."
When the World Trade Center was attacked, Con Ed scrambled to minimize damage to the grid downtown.
Dozens of Con Ed workers rushed to the World Trade Center after the first plane hit, along with Richard Morgan, a former company executive who was working as a consultant on emergency response. Mr. Morgan was there to help firefighters navigate the electrical system and to keep an eye on two Con Ed substations in Building 7 that were part of the financial district's electricity grid.
Mr. Morgan died in the towers' collapse, and the substations were destroyed. Since Sept. 11, Con Ed crews have jerry-rigged an above-ground electrical network that skirts the disaster site and powers the rest of Wall Street.
The company is now digging nearly seven miles of trenches through the financial district to create a permanent grid, which it expects to have operating by May. The substations were insured for about $70 million; Con Ed estimates that the work will cost a total of about $400 million. 
While that is not a crippling sum for a company that routinely spends more than $1 billion a year on capital improvements, Con Ed is appealing for government aid, which is being disbursed through a number of state agencies. It does not expect to be fully reimbursed, and would fill the gap with borrowing, said Hyman Schoenblum, vice president for corporate planning. 
Con Ed probably could get reasonable terms, because its debt is low and its balance sheet strong, Mr. Schoenblum and industry analysts concurred. In any event, the company would probably seek to recover the costs from ratepayers in 2005, when its prices for transmitting and distributing power will be re-negotiated with New York state regulators. For now, Con Ed expects that any rate increase would be small, and Mr. Schoenblum said that the company does not plan to ask for an emergency rate increase in the meantime.
The strong balance sheet that has allowed Con Ed to weather attack-related costs is a product of the company's entrenched conservatism. And that worldview, in turn, was shaped by several tumultuous decades of corporate history.
For a time, Con Ed lurched from one crisis to another: blackouts in 1965 and 1977, with a near-bankruptcy in between; an explosion in 1989 in Gramercy Park that killed several workers and spewed asbestos onto homes; a string of accidents and mishaps at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, which was sold in September to the Entergy Corporation.
Managing its way through those problems, Con Ed became financially cautious. 
It stuck to its traditional businesses in the 1980's when other utilities diversified into real estate, to their near ruin. More important, in the late 1990's, when utilities rushed to embrace deregulation -- developing businesses that built power plants and traded in electricity to cash in on the volatility of the newly liberalized power markets -- Con Ed only dabbled in energy's new world.
When New York deregulated, Con Ed sold most of its power plants and focused on delivering power. And the company won the right to pass its power costs through to consumers, becoming the only utility in the country that managed to shift the risks of a newly deregulated market onto ratepayers from the start. By contrast, the nation's largest utility, California's Pacific Gas & Electric, sought bankruptcy protection precisely because it was unable to pass those costs along.
As unpopular as the pass-through has been among consumers -- especially in the summer of 2000, when prices spiked sharply -- it has left Con Ed strong enough to cope with the aftereffects of the World Trade Center attacks and the Enron meltdown.
Most analysts still yawn at the mention of the company, but investors with portfolios of power industry stocks are clearly picking it as an anchor; that is what analysts make of the stock's steady performance while the power sector swoons.
Con Ed's earnings are expected to grow by only 3 percent to 4 percent a year, but unlike power companies that use profits to finance rapid expansion, Con Ed pays dividends. At 55 cents a share per quarter, the stock's indicated yield is 5.63 percent, versus 4.22 percent for stocks in the Dow Jones utilities average, or 1.36 percent for the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500.
Con Ed knows its luck might sour. The local economy is sputtering, and the utility's health depends in large part on that of the city. It expects the city's power supply to be adequate next summer, but just barely, a slim margin of error that Con Ed came up against this year, when it narrowly averted blackouts during an extremely hot week in August. 
The company is still mired in litigation with Northeast Utilities, the big New England power company that Con Ed tried to acquire last year. The merger fell apart, and the two sides are now suing each other.
Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman of Con Ed, said earlier this year that the company is open to acquiring another concern, and that some executives have been assigned to look for opportunities. 
And while Con Ed would entertain a buyer, Mr. McGrath said, any takeover would face serious hurdles, from intense regulatory scrutiny to Con Ed's insistence on getting the right price.
"I continue to see Con Ed as more of an acquirer than an acquiree," said Jay Dobson, senior energy analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "They have a very conservative management team, and I don't know if they would want to sign on with another company."
But Mr. Dobson does not expect the company to make a move on another utility anytime soon, either. "Right now, they are focused on restoring the electricity system, so any move toward an acquisition is on hold," he said.
Con Ed, having grown more sensitive to criticism about the cost pass-through it fought so hard to arrange, is trying to make sure its rates do not rocket. It is arguing hard for the construction of new power plants and transmission lines to supply the city. It plans to bring more power online at its East River plant by the summer of 2003. It convinced the federal government to compel the state to intervene to keep prices from spiraling in the New York City wholesale markets. And it says that its work in the financial district will not trigger delays of other badly needed maintenance in the city. 
Next summer, of course, will be the real test, and Mr. McGrath vows to pass.
"Because we send the bills out to people," he said, "it's our responsibility to keep the lights on."

HEADLINE: Small Cable Operators Worry About Life After Big Mergers 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
The stakes in the battle for the nation's televisions are gargantuan -- subscription TV generates revenue of $60 billion a year. So the players need to be gargantuan as well, some industry executives argue.
 Thus the big are getting bigger in order to prepare for a clash of the titans. The two big satellite television companies, EchoStar Communications and DirecTV, are trying to consolidate to create a single company with nearly 17 million subscribers. At the same time, the Comcast Corporation has agreed to buy the cable television unit of AT&T, a move that would make it the largest cable company with more than 22 million subscribers. 
 The two new companies that would emerge, AT&T Comcast and EchoStar, would control 40 percent of the television households in the United States. 
Nervously watching on the sidelines of battle between big cable and big satellite are the 1,200 smaller independent cable operators that serve 12 million homes, about 17 percent of cable subscribers. 
The independent operators, many in small rural markets, say the talk about convergence and national competition neglects a fundamental fact: competition is local. They fear that federal regulators are missing the trees for the forest.
"What we fear is policy makers are going to take their eye off the ball because they are going to be focused on these high-profile media mergers and not the smaller markets," said Matthew Polka, president of the American Cable Association, an organization of independent cable operators that opposes the EchoStar and DirecTV merger.
The chief executive of EchoStar, Charles Ergen, has been trying to paint the competitive landscape as one of convergence -- the convergence of cable and satellite markets, the convergence of television and Internet, and a convergence of fractured local markets into one national market. But state officials agree that television, like politics, is local. Attorneys general from several states have joined the debate, discussing how to block the EchoStar and DirecTV merger.
Small cable companies cast themselves as mom-and-pop stores that come under siege when Wal-Mart rolls into town with lower prices and better distribution networks. In this case, the Wal-Marts are DirecTV and EchoStar, which distribute pizza-size satellite dishes that can receive hundreds of channels. 
But unlike the retail industry, the telecommunications realm is closely regulated. The Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission are also weighing the merits of the satellite deal.
The satellite companies say size will make them more competitive and allow them to build the infrastructure for high-speed Internet access and interactive television, all of which require extensive initial investment. They also say that rural customers will benefit from competition in urban areas through a nationwide pricing plan.
But small cable operators say the cost-effectiveness that makes satellite operators better able to compete with the likes of AT&T Comcast and AOL Time Warner's cable operation will undermine small cable companies. 
Despite the local nature of competition, satellite operators can leverage their national reach and size in ways local cable operators say they cannot. EchoStar, for example, offers one promotional package of 100 channels for $9 a month to new customers, compared with its regular rate of $30.99. 
"They are competing at a price below the cost," said Ben Hooks, chief executive of the Buford Media Group, a cable company with 7,000 subscribers that is based in Tyler, Tex. "How can they do that? Tell me what is going on."
Mr. Hooks said his programming fees alone, without taking into account the costs of the infrastructure, exceed $9 a month. "If you are going to advantage satellite operators to the point where it wipes out competition, what has it accomplished?" he said. 
In all of this, customers do not seem to be suffering, at least not yet. The quality and variety of satellite television has forced cable operators to scramble to upgrade their systems by installing digital networks. Customers are getting more channels, more diverse programming and more choices. Satellite operators have also put pressure on the cable rates in the markets where they compete.
But rural cable operators say the long-term consequences of consolidation will create a landscape where smaller players will be squeezed out and viewers will be left with fewer choices. 
Many are already feeling the pinch as satellite television has eaten into cable subscriber bases.
Small operators are confronted with a choice of losing subscribers or upgrading their equipment. But they say small and sparse subscriber bases in the rural areas make it hard to recuperate the upfront costs of upgrading. A rural operator may get only 30 or so households for each mile, compared with 150 or more households in an urban area.
In addition, small cable operators say they are feeling the brunt of the sharp increases in programming costs. The cost of the ESPN channel, for example, has nearly doubled in five years, to nearly $2 a subscriber, making it one of the most expensive basic channels. 
In addition, most national television channels are controlled by a handful of companies -- AOL Time Warner, Walt Disney, Viacom, General Electric, Vivendi Universal and the News Corporation -- many of which have financial ties to pay-TV companies.
The largest cable and satellite companies also have enough clout to get discounts from programmers. Smaller operators say they cannot get the same discounts, and as a result, they pay as much as 40 percent more for programming. 
Cable rates have jumped an average of 35 percent since 1996, so some of the costs have been passed on to the customers. But the cable companies say they have also had to absorb the higher fees, which has eroded profit margins.
The Comcast-AT&T merger will only make it worse, the rural operators contend. Small rural cable companies rarely compete head-on with the large companies because they are in different geographical areas. 
But the economics of the industry can be affected by the actions of the industry leader. Comcast executives say their programming costs will go down after the merger since they can take advantage of AT&T's better rates. Small cable companies say in turn, their fees will be increased to make up the difference.
The squeeze of increasing programming costs and an eroding subscriber base is getting to be too much for some operators. Many rural operators have sold out in the last several years. Independent Brokerage, a Denver company that focuses on selling rural cable companies, has seen the number of clients trying to sell their cable systems double this year compared with last year.
"We've had more listings of rural cable systems than we have ever had," Cindy Lyle, a partner at Independent Brokerage, said. 
"They are losing subscribers monthly," Ms. Lyle said. "They have come to a crossroads. They either need to upgrade and become digital to compete. They can stay and run the company. Or they can sell."
A cable system in Arkansas lost 100 of its 1,200 subscribers in one month. That prompted the owner to sell the business a year ago.
One trend may be for rural cable operators and satellite broadcasters to join forces. A weakness of satellite broadcasting is its lack of local channels. Limited satellite spectrum means that currently EchoStar and DirecTV broadcast local channels in about 40 of the 210 defined television markets nationwide, covering about 60 percent of the nation's population.
But local programming is important in winning subscribers, executives say, particularly in rural areas. Some businesses are creating hybrid systems of satellite television and local cable. Cable Direct, in Sikeston, Mo., has purchased rural systems over the last year and offered a combination of a satellite dish complemented with local channels. 
"This is the wave of the future," Ms. Lyle said. "If you can't beat them, join them."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New Jersey: Newark: Insurer To Drop High-Risk Drivers 

BYLINE:  AP (Compiled by Yilu Zhao) 

 BODY:
 The Eagle Insurance Company, which covers about 12,000 high-risk drivers, will no longer handle them for other companies. These customers will be handled by an affiliate of the insurance giant A.I.G., according to the State Department of Banking and Insurance.

In the last several weeks, the regulators have approved increases for several companies, including State Farm and A.I.G. New Jersey already has some of the nation's highest rates for auto insurance.

HEADLINE: Hoping a Euro in the Hand Will Be Worth More 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 25 

 BODY:
For three years now, the euro has been a "virtual" currency, existing only in the ether-world of electronic transactions and bookkeeping but almost undetectable in daily life.
 That is about to change. On Jan. 1, if all goes as planned, automated bank tellers in 12 European countries will start dispensing crisp new euros and stop issuing national currencies like the Spanish peseta, German mark, French franc and Dutch guilder. It will be the last step in an effort that began more than 30 years ago, crowning Europe's boldest achievement yet in becoming a seamless union. 
 But even on the eve of that momentous transformation, affecting more than 300 million people, the euro is dogged by a credibility problem that has not been helped by its invisibility to date. Even before its introduction, it has fallen shy of some of the grander ambitions that European leaders had envisioned for it. 
Defying predictions that it would create the monetary equivalent of Airbus's rivalry with Boeing, the currency has not eroded the global dominance of the American dollar. In fact, it has lost about one-fifth of its value against the dollar since 1999. 
More important, it has failed to insulate Europe from outside economic shocks, like the blow provided by the slowdown in the United States, and its value has failed to bounce back even since America plunged into a recession.
The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, knows better than anyone these shortcomings and the lack of apparent enthusiasm that the currency has generated. 
Indeed, Mr. Duisenberg suggested in a recent interview that one of the barriers to the euro's acceptance has been the absence of cold, hard cash. "I regard not having the notes in the hands of people as maybe the greatest handicap the E.C.B. has had in gaining confidence of the people at large," Mr. Duisenberg said in an interview. "Although the euro is already with us, the people at large still think of it as a thing that is coming."
Neither Mr. Duisenberg nor any other economist expects the arrival of cash to boost the euro's exchange rate. But many people believe euro notes and coins will reduce the popular skepticism. The practical advantages, such as not having to change money at most borders, will finally become apparent in real life.
Except for Britain, Denmark and Sweden, every country within the European Union will be setting prices and accepting payment in the same currency. Small states like Monaco and Vatican City will be minting euros as well, while Balkan territories like Kosovo and Montenegro are adopting the euro by converting the German marks that serve as their de facto currencies now.
It is an achievement that many people thought would never happen, a dream that dates back almost to the end of World War II and was championed in the late 1970's by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France and the German chancellor, Helmut Schmidt.
But while the euro has already disappointed certain aspirations and has not been popularly embraced, it has hardly been a failure.
Most economists and business leaders say the single currency is a healthy step toward openness and more vibrant competition across Europe. Eliminating currency fluctuations between member countries reduces the expense and risk of cross-border business. Prices become easier to compare, for consumers as well as corporate buyers. Profit becomes easier to compare as well, putting pressure on companies to become more efficient.
"It is, on many levels, a catalyst and a driving force for reform," said Ernst Welteke, president of Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank. "It will have an effect on the unified growth of Europe."
Economists note that the arrival of a tangible European currency is merely the visible tip of a deeper transformation. Because countries joining the monetary union were required to reduce their budget deficits and bring inflation under control, Europe has attained a much higher level of economic stability.
Inflation is as low in Greece as it is in Germany, slightly above 2 percent. Interest rates on home mortgages in Italy, which routinely reached double-digit levels in the past, are about 5 percent. Spain and Portugal now have budget surpluses, though the current slowdown is producing budget deficits in countries like Germany and Italy.
Eric Vergnaud, economist at BNP Paribas in Paris, notes that Europe has weathered this downturn much more smoothly than the one in the early 1990's. In 1992, the currencies of Italy and Britain shifted so wildly that both countries had to drop out of Europe's currency-exchange stabilization system.
Why, then, does the euro generate so little enthusiasm? And will that really change once people have the notes in hand?
In the European Commission's most recent monthly poll of popular attitudes toward the new currency, only 48 percent of those asked thought the euro would mean more advantages than disadvantages for them. Only 50 percent said that using the new notes and coins would make them feel "a little more European."
"The coins look beautiful," remarked Christian Pavic, 20, a steelworker in Frankfurt, as he contemplated the handful of coins in one of the "starter kits" that went on sale earlier this month. But he added: "I find it difficult because of the conversion. I would have preferred to keep the mark."
Part of the euro's problem stems not from the currency itself but from the gauzy mixture of political expectations that surrounded its creation. When the euro was formally adopted on New Year's Eve 1999, Jacques Santer, then president of the European Commission, declared that "in one single blow, Europe is imposing itself on the world's financial and monetary map."
There were also widespread expectations that the euro would unleash a new era of economic growth, as companies took greater advantage of pan-European opportunities and greater stability. Those predictions were not entirely wrong: Europe experienced a big surge in cross-border corporate mergers and European companies began raising much more money than before through international stock and bond offerings.
The real problem is that Europe continues to fall behind in other areas. Job-protection laws remain rigid and taxes are high in many countries. Europe has lagged behind the United States in economic growth throughout the past decade, as homegrown companies like Siemens have shifted jobs overseas and international investors have flocked to the United States.
"The weakness that the euro has shown over the past two years, which we had not expected, obviously reflects the weakness of Europe as a place to do business," said Rolf Breuer, chairman of Deutsche Bank.
Frits Bolkestein, the European Commission official in charge of developing common rules for business within the European Union, provides a vivid insight into the difficulties of pushing through broader economic change.
The European Union already enjoys free trade between member countries, and citizens of one country have an automatic right to live and work in any of the other 14 countries. But companies remain bedeviled by different rules for setting up businesses, raising capital and carrying out seemingly mundane jobs like running a pension fund.
Earlier this year, German leaders torpedoed a 12-year effort to reach agreement on a Europewide set of rules governing corporate takeovers. 
Similarly, European banks are still charging fees as high as 17 percent on cross-border money-transfers. Only after a stormy battle this fall did Mr. Bolkestein finally win approval for a measure to prohibit such fees as of next summer.
Mr. Bolkestein counts that as one of his successes. But the list of stalled reforms is long: huge battles over a standard European prospectus for raising money from investors; bitter feuds over rules to let pension funds operate across borders; even a months-long logjam over reducing the number of languages required for filing a European patent.
"We spent about nine hours discussing linguistics," fumed Mr. Bolkestein, recalling a meeting in late November at which European cabinet ministers failed to agree on the patent issue. "It's three steps forward, and two backward."
Against that backdrop, the ability of 12 European countries to surrender their national currencies is a stunning achievement. But it is also one whose impact will be indirect and only become apparent over time, even once euros are in hand.
Daniel Gros, deputy director of Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels, once compared the euro to a glacier that moves too slowly for most people to notice.
But wait, he predicted. "After 10 years, Europe's landscape will be transformed."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Courtesy and Decency Play Sneaky With a Tough Guy

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
Hank Grotowski (Billy Bob Thornton) is, like his father and his son, a Georgia corrections officer. Leticia Musgrove (Halle Berry) is a waitress struggling to make ends meet and to raise her 12-year-old son. She is also the widow of a man whose execution Hank helped to conduct. The relationship between Hank and Leticia, a relationship born of chance, moral reflex and desperate need, is at the center of "Monster's Ball," a tough, heartfelt new film from the young Swiss-born director Marc Forster. 
 In outline, the story of Hank and Leticia's entwined lives might seem implausible, and the events that surround it -- three deaths, including the unblinkingly filmed electrocution of Leticia's husband, Lawrence (Sean Combs) -- could have smothered the movie in melodrama. "Monster's Ball" could easily have been an exercise in liberal high-mindedness, a cinematic lecture on the inhumanity of the death penalty or the legacy of Southern racism. But Mr. Forster and the screenwriters, Milo Addica and Will Rokos (who is a native of Georgia), are more interested in the details of character and milieu than in deducing right-thinking morals. 
 Hank and Leticia are not easy people, and much to its credit, "Monster's Ball" is not an easy picture. Mr. Forster's deliberate pacing and the gritty, smudged look that Roberto Schaefer, the cinematographer, brings to the workaday modern South create an atmosphere heavy with the buried emotions of grief, rage and terror. Hank lives in the shadow of his bullying, bigoted father (Peter Boyle) and a brutal code of masculine behavior that blocks all access to feeling. But if Hank feels at all sorry for himself, he does not show us, and Mr. Thornton earns our sympathy the hard way, by showing us Hank at his unvarnished worst. "You've always hated me, haven't you," demands his son, Sonny (Heath Ledger), a sensitive, troubled soul who is clearly not cut out for death row duty. "Yes, I have," is Hank's even-toned reply.
The night before, Sonny had incurred his father's wrath by showing intolerable weakness during Musgrove's walk to the electric chair. As one of his African-American colleagues tried to pull him off his son, Hank exploded in an obscene, racist tirade. "This is not you, Hank," his co-worker insisted, trying to calm him down. "This is me," Hank yells back. "This is me."
He's right. Hank's prejudice and suspicion are not simply mistaken attitudes in need of correction; they are integral to his character. But so is a habitual courtesy -- the writers catch the quiet politeness that inflects even the most tense or hostile exchanges -- and a reluctant sense of decency. These qualities overtake the others in a way that surprises Hank himself, and his transformation -- in Hollywood, as in the Baptist church, they like to call it redemption -- is all the more astonishing for being almost surreptitious.
Mr. Thornton, one of the most gifted screen actors working today, outdoes himself. For her part, Ms. Berry proves herself to be an actress of impressive courage and insight. Like Hank, Leticia is a character who could have been simplified, turned into a one-dimensional victim or a saint. Ms. Berry emphasizes the character's temper, and also the vulnerability beneath her toughness. 
What she has in common with Hank is an alienation from her finer emotions. She loves her son, Tyrell (well played by 10-year-old Coronji Calhoun in his first film role), but he is also the target of her anger and shame. In the last minutes of the movie, the burden of dramatic resolution falls squarely on Ms. Berry, and she soars. The film's conclusion is an enormous gamble for the filmmakers, as well as for Leticia and Hank, and it is above all Ms. Berry's fearless concentration that converts potential sentimentality into honest, complex emotion.
The characters and the bond that develops between them are too complex for words, and the writers use very few. Their economy and the eloquence of Mr. Forster's unshowily beautiful images give "Monster's Ball" the density and strangeness of real life. The raw intimacy of some of the scenes -- whether they take place at a diner, in the death house or in the bedroom -- is breathtaking. In the end, the movie belongs to the actors -- to Ms. Berry and Mr. Thornton, principally, but also to the large supporting cast, including Mr. Combs, Mr. Ledger and the hip-hop star Mos Def (as Hank's neighbor down the road). This is one of those rare movies in which even people glimpsed only for a moment or two seem to have lives that ramify beyond the screen, as if the story were being witnessed rather than dramatized.
"Monster's Ball" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has scenes of brutal violence and realistic sex.

MONSTER'S BALL

Directed by Marc Forster; written by Milo Addica and Will Rokos; director of photography, Roberto Schaefer; edited by Matt Chesse; production designer, Monroe Kelly; produced by Lee Daniels; released by Lions Gate Films. Running time: 108 minutes. This film is rated R.

WITH: Billy Bob Thornton (Hank Grotowski), Halle Berry (Leticia Musgrove), Heath Ledger (Sonny Grotowski), Peter Boyle (Buck Grotowski), Sean Combs (Lawrence Musgrove), Mos Def (Ryrus Cooper) and Coronji Calhoun (Tyrell Musgrove).

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says He's Not Rushing to Close Deals on Stadiums 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended his plan to complete negotiations for two new baseball stadiums in his last days in office, adding that he was working with the incoming administration of Michael R. Bloomberg to do so.
 But Mr. Giuliani, who leaves office on Jan. 1, said that, contrary to news reports suggesting that he was trying to close the deals, he was trying only to reach tentative agreements with the Mets and the Yankees that would provide a framework for future deals. 
 Mr. Giuliani, who had an unusually busy Christmas schedule, extolled the economic virtues of his plan, saying that it would provide jobs and an economic boost to the city at a minimum cost. 
"We think this is an innovative deal," Mr. Giuliani said, adding that the city paid the entire cost to build Shea Stadium and to rebuild Yankee Stadium in its present form.
The Giuliani plan envisions a public-private partnership, with the Mets and the Yankees paying half the building costs, which in each case would be more than any major league baseball team has contributed to the construction of a stadium.
The estimated price tag for the Mets' stadium is $800 million, not including $100 million in road and subway improvements that the team has asked the state to make. The estimated cost of the Yankees' stadium, which is in a much earlier stage of planning, has not been disclosed.
The city's Arts Commission approved the design for a new Mets stadium on a parking lot beside Shea. Mr. Giuliani said that while the deal he was working on involved building the new Yankee Stadium in Macombs Dam Park in the South Bronx, he did not dismiss the possibility that that it would be built on Manhattan's West Side, a proposal that has drawn heavy opposition from area residents and Bronx politicians.
In the last two years, Mr. Giuliani has advocated using a West Side site owned by the state for either a baseball stadium for the Yankees or a football stadium for the Jets.
Mr. Giuliani's push to complete the negotiations just days before he leaves office comes as the economic fallout from the recession and the damage to Lower Manhattan caused by the attack on Sept. 11 has raised questions about whether building new stadiums would be money well spent.
At a news conference at a firehouse on East 75th Street in Manhattan, Mayor-elect Bloomberg, who on Monday declined to comment on the stadiums, said that he had spoken with Mr. Giuliani about the stadium plans and approved of the negotiations. Still, Mr. Bloomberg said that he would have a better idea once he appointed a deputy mayor for economic development later this week.
"We want to have the best facilities for cultural events, athletic events," Mr. Bloomberg said. "We also have to understand that we are going into some very tough economic times, and we are going to have to find some ways to balance that."
When asked whether he expected to complete the negotiations before Mr. Bloomberg was sworn in, Mr. Giuliani said, "Yeah," and then turned to Merrill Lynch's senior vice president and general counsel, George Schieren, and said: "Most deals get made at 4 or 5 or 6 in the morning, right, George?"
The last few days have been different for Mr. Giuliani, a man who has become accustomed to holiday routines as mayor.
Each Christmas Eve for the past eight years as mayor, Mr. Giuliani took gifts collected by the city to children, generally those living in public housing in low-income neighborhoods. On Christmas, Mr. Giuliani participated in Merrill Lynch's annual Christmas Calls program, which allows senior citizens to use the firm's telephones free of charge to call their loved ones around the world.
This Christmas Eve, Mr. Giuliani found himself giving out toys to children. But this time it was to the children of Scott Larsen, a firefighter who was lost in the World Trade Center attack. Firefighter Larsen's wife, Carol Ann, gave birth to a boy on Sept. 13. Mr. Giuliani went to the family's Queens home and took presents for that boy, August, as well as the other children, Marisa, 9; Brenda, 8; and Scott, 4.
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani went to the Christmas Calls event. But instead of being held at Merrill Lynch's headquarters in the World Financial Center, it was held in temporary offices on Fifth Avenue where Merrill Lynch officials moved after the terrorist attack damaged their headquarters.
"This is a wonderful, special holiday for everyone," Mr. Giuliani said while at the temporary offices. "The joy of it transcends what happened on Sept. 11."
Instead of going home early on Christmas, Mr. Giuliani's entourage headed south on the West Side Highway to a tent on the edge of ground zero, within sight of Merrill Lynch's shuttered headquarters. There, Mr. Giuliani served Christmas meals to rescue workers laboring around the clock recovering corpses and removing debris.

HEADLINE: White House Aides Trying to Balance Attention on Terrorism, the Economy and Politics 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 

 BODY:
Shortly after Sept. 11, President Bush instructed his aides that he would not tolerate discussions about politics during the emergency.
 "He just said, 'Politics has no role in this,' " recalled Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser. " 'Don't anybody talk to me about politics for a while.' " 
 But the White House and the Republican Party are persistently, if quietly, venturing back into the realm of politics. Officials are paying careful attention to how the war is proceeding -- and how it might affect the president's standing in the polls. In drawing up Mr. Bush's remarks about the war, the aides are ever mindful of how his words will play with particular constituencies. They are dispatching surrogates, including Vice President Dick Cheney, to give speeches that take on Democrats. 
Beyond the war, the most consuming debate in the White House is a political one: how to strike a balance in the State of the Union address next month between a discussion of the war and the nation's economic strains.
Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor, said the president had recently held his first meeting to discuss the speech with aides, who have been meeting frequently among themselves.
"Our thinking right now is clearly, there are two key issues, and they are related," Ms. Hughes said. "One is the war, and one is the recession. Those two will obviously be major components of the speech."
No firm judgments have been made calibrating between the two.
"The country is going to want to hear from him about the conduct of the war," Mr. Rove said. "And they're going to want to know what his agenda is."
The offices next door to the White House of the vaunted group of aides that sets long-term political strategy, nicknamed the "strategery" team, repeating a joke from a "Saturday Night Live" parody of Mr. Bush, had been supplanted by the new Office of Homeland Security, which needed a "secure" first-floor location.
But White House officials said the group was back in full operation and focusing intensely on planning for the State of the Union address.
Beyond the Oval Office, White House advisers said, they have had extensive discussions about how long Mr. Bush can sustain his impressive popularity ratings. Several said that they were bracing for Mr. Bush's standing to begin declining early next year and that they viewed that State of the Union address as a fortuitous opportunity for the president to reassert himself -- and retain his popularity. 
There has been no such chance since his address to a joint session of Congress shortly before the bombing of Afghanistan began.
"It's a window where the American people are watching, and you don't get a lot of those," said Matthew Dowd, an adviser to the Republican Party who is in charge of polling for the White House. "You remember, in the speech he gave to the joint session his numbers went up."
"Obviously, the fact that he's got approval ratings in the 80's that have sustained themselves for three months is a huge thing," Mr. Dowd said. "Nobody since F. D. R. has had this situation. The question is, How does that translate into how much of your agenda you can get through?"
One White House official was blunter, saying: "The political viability or support behind the president's actions is always on everybody's mind. It's naive to think that that's not what every White House is constantly thinking about."
White House advisers said they were always seeking openings to score political points without appearing to be overtly political. 
Officials said they were pleased this month when Representative Nita M. Lowey of New York, chairwoman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, ridiculed the administration for the "Bush recession." 
That gave Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, an excuse to fire back, asserting that the president "thinks the job of leaders in Washington is not to point fingers, but to find solutions."
White House advisers also said they had considered the political benefit of initiatives like reaching out to women in Afghanistan.
"It will do nothing but help them with female voters," an adviser said.
Mr. Dowd said the effort would do more than simply appeal to women.
"It could have a broad effect on independents and soft Democrats," he said, by softening the president's conservative image.
Every word's nuance is weighed. White House officials said they had urged Mr. Bush to refrain from using the word "stimulus," because it sounds academic and inaccessible. They have implored him to favor terms like "economic security" that relate to ordinary people and could connect the economy to the war.
"You can pick up the Washington vernacular quickly," Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, said. "But that doesn't mean a lot to the guy sitting in Paducah."
There have also been discussions about whom to put before the cameras to relay the message. White House advisers said they were mindful that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was effective with the news media in his frequent briefings and that Attorney General John Ashcroft was helpful because, in the view of one, "he is a willing lightning rod to take the heat off the president on these very difficult criminal justice decisions."
Some aides said they had been less satisfied with the performances of Tom Ridge, who heads the Office of Homeland Security. But they said Mr. Ridge had been less visible lately, in part because the anthrax scares and other domestic threats have receded.
White House officials are also partial to having Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, as a high-profile surrogate on television.
"The initial response is always to put Condi out first," one White House official said. "She always has the exact tone and response the president wants. She's someone everyone feels entirely safe with."
The drive to intensify political efforts has not been entirely behind the scenes. The White House has significantly intensified its public political activities in recent weeks. The strategy is for Mr. Bush to continue to present himself as bipartisan as long as he can while his representatives, notably Mr. Cheney, become more partisan. Since late October, Mr. Cheney's fund-raising appearances have included stops in Pierre, S.D., Dallas and Oklahoma City.
This month, Mr. Rove ventured from Washington to be the marquee attraction at fund-raising events for Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Representative John Thune of South Dakota, who is running for the Senate next year. Mr. Rove was not bashful about delivering partisan comments about the economic stimulus, words that Mr. Bush would dare not repeat himself.
Mr. Rove insisted that Mr. Bush had so little interest in his standing in the polls that he did not dare mention it to the president until two weeks ago.
"You say, 'Mr. President, there was an interesting poll out last night,' " Mr. Rove said, "and he'll cut you off and say, 'Let's move on to something consequential.' "
But, Mr. Rove said, Mr. Bush will "absolutely" campaign for Republican candidates next year. The question is when.
In an interview last week with news agencies, Mr. Bush said, "I'm really just not thinking about politics right now, although I readily concede I will have to here pretty soon. If I do the job the American people expect me to do, not only the job in foreign policy, but also have a domestic agenda that will help people in need, my guess is I'll be in pretty good shape politically."
An illustration of White House success in public relations was in building the drama that led up to the release of the videotape of Osama bin Laden. At a time when impatience was growing over the hunt for Mr. bin Laden, the anticipation over the tape filled the void. Mr. Bartlett insisted that there was no orchestrated effort to leak information about the tape, but he acknowledged that it had been favorable public relations.
"I wish we could take credit for the buildup," he said.
Other advisers said the administration had painstakingly choreographed its handling of the war message.
"They're not manipulating the military operations," a strategist who advises the White House said. "But there's a manipulation of the environment. They take advantage of the situation to achieve some political objectives."
Former Speaker Newt Gingrich said the White House, after a shaky start, had been effective in orchestrating public opinion behind the war. Mr. Gingrich singled out Ms. Hughes for establishing a "rapid response" team with offices here, in London and in Islamabad, Pakistan, to wage the propaganda war against Mr. bin Laden.
"We are much more on the offensive," Mr. Gingrich said, "and I think Karen Hughes and Karl Rove are central to it. We've gone from Osama bin Laden being a martyr to Osama bin Laden being a mindless terrorist. And that's a very significant shift."
