HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 New Plan, New Captives

SEARCH IS ALTERED -- The United States military has revised a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is once again urging local forces to take the lead. Just last Friday, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he was ordering hundreds more American troops to join Afghan militia in the hunt. A1

MORE DETAINEES -- The Marine-led force in Afghanistan took custody of 20 more Arab fighters, accelerating the hand-over of Al Qaeda prisoners from the new government. B2

GENERAL'S BOAST -- General Abdul Rashid Dostum, the newly appointed deputy defense minister for Afghanistan, made clear that he believed that nobody could govern the country without his support. B1

Leaders' Voices

BIN LADEN TAPE -- A new videotaped statement from Osama bin Laden, purportedly made in late November or early December, shows him looking tired and gaunt but alive. If, as Mr. bin Laden suggests, it was filmed three months after the Sept. 11 attacks, the tape offers proof that he survived the first waves of the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan. A1

SECURITY IN FOREFRONT -- President Bush will emphasize domestic security in his State of the Union speech next month and propose billions of dollars in security initiatives in his new budget, officials say. To underscore the new priority, the budget will include a separate section on domestic security, including aid for police and fire departments and for the public health system. B1

PEACEKEEPING FORCE -- Afghanistan's foreign minister, Dr. Abdullah Abdullah, said that negotiations over the shape and duration of an international security force were nearing their end. So far only a few dozen peacekeepers have arrived in Kabul; the size of the force could reach 5,000. B3

The Saudi Paradox

SOURCE OF FIGHTERS -- Thousands of young Saudis have left their country to wage Islamic holy war in the last decade, and Saudi leaders have let them go, aware of the danger they may pose to the United States but more focused on the danger they may pose at home. At least four times in the last six years, Saudis have been among the terrorists who bombed American targets. But not until October, after the American military campaign in Afghanistan began, did Saudi Arabia detain young men trying to join that fight. A1

AL QAEDA'S SHIPS -- Osama bin Laden's organization is said to control at least 20 ships, mostly purchased years ago, when Mr. bin Laden was not yet mixing commerce with terror and neither he nor his lieutenants were recognized for what they were to become. B1

TEMPERED DISSENT -- After spending five years in a Saudi prison, the religious scholar Sheik Salman al-Awdah is again playing an influential role in that nation's political opposition. In lectures broadcast by telephone and accessible on the Internet, he has renewed tempered calls on the government to consider reforms while also admonishing young Saudis against heeding calls for jihad. B4

The Shoe Bomb Suspect

INSIDE FLIGHT 63 -- The passengers and crew members who subdued the man known as Richard C. Reid on Flight 63 thought he was unruly and possibly drunk, but they had no inkling of the possible disaster they had just prevented -- that the man's shoes contained explosives powerful enough to bring down the plane. A1

A CRIMINAL PAST -- Mr. Reid, also known as Abdel Rahim, is a British small-time criminal who converted to Islam in prison and then was lured to radical action by Muslim extremists, the head of a London mosque he attended confirmed. B6

CHAGRIN IN FRANCE -- The failure of the French police to realize that a man they were questioning was a human bomb and their efforts to explain how he made it onto Flight 63 to Miami turned into finger-pointing and public defensiveness. B6

AGENT DENIED FLIGHT -- An Arab-American member of President Bush's security detail was denied passage on an American Airlines flight Tuesday evening after the pilot questioned his credentials. B6

Aftermath in New York

REBUILDING PLAN -- Governor Pataki unveiled a $700 million plan to distribute the first installment of federal aid designed to revive the economy of Lower Manhattan. Funds will go to small businesses and retailers crippled by the Sept. 11 attacks and to corporations that the city hopes to keep in the downtown area. D1

FOOD BANKS STRUGGLING -- Perhaps 1.5 million New Yorkers now rely on food pantries, which offer free provisions. But with donations sinking since the terror attacks and the need for food increasing, the system is in danger of collapse. D1

SOLACE IN CULTURE -- While the Sept. 11 attack has frightened hundreds of thousands of visitors from most of New York's cultural centers, New Yorkers have been more eager than ever to visit parks, zoos and botanical gardens. D3

The Arts

A BAND'S NEW FAME -- No new cases of anthrax have been reported for weeks, and that is good news for everyone, including Anthrax, the metal band from Bayside, Queens, that has become more famous for its name than its music. E1

Business

AID TO AIRLINES -- America West Airlines, which is the country's eighth-largest carrier and one that was struggling even before the terror attacks, has asked for help under a $10 billion federal loan program created to bolster the airline industry. The country's other airlines, which together have lost billions of dollars since Sept. 11, are watching the process closely. C1

HEADLINE: Mayor Defends His Planning To Build New Sports Stadiums 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
With less than a week remaining in his term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani again defended the idea of building two new baseball stadiums and lashed out at critics yesterday who suggest that the city should be putting its strained resources elsewhere.
 "Baseball is a tremendously big business," Mr. Giuliani said. "It's like keeping the Stock Exchange here. This is by far, without any doubts, one of the best deals in sports." 
 Those who criticize the spending of public money on building stadiums while the city is suffering from the economic fallout from a recession and the damage to Lower Manhattan "haven't the foggiest idea of what they're talking about," he added.
The mayor also said it was important to show the committee making selections for the 2012 Olympics that the city was committed to construction, because the city would need to build an arena to accommodate the Games. Later, on the related matter of building an arena on the West Side of Manhattan that could be used for football games and 100 to 200 indoor events a year, the mayor said that without it, the city would jeopardize its chances of landing the Games.
Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg, whose administration would have to carry out the stadium plans, said yesterday with Mr. Giuliani by his side that he thought it was good that the current mayor was trying to ensure that the city and its facilities remained "first class."
"Even though we have a current budget problem, we should not forget the future," Mr. Bloomberg said. "This is a city of big ideas, and big projects and a big heart, and things that take many years to do, you have to continue to work on, even when you happen to have tough times short term."
Under the Giuliani plan, the Mets and the Yankees would each pay half of the building costs. A new stadium for the Mets is expected to cost about $800 million to build, while the estimated cost for a new Yankees stadium, which is at an earlier planning stage, has not been disclosed. But officials suggested that it would be a comparable amount. In addition, the mayor said, the state would contribute $300 million to $350 million to help with infrastructure, like new or repaired parking facilities and train stations.
"The state is going to do all the things that they promised to do some time ago, which is to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on infrastructure," Mr. Giuliani said of his plan.
Gov. George E. Pataki reiterated yesterday that the state would help with the infrastructure, but not the direct building of the stadiums. "That's between the city and the private owners," he said, "but we will keep the commitment that has been made to help with infrastructure."
Mr. Giuliani said rent payments would be determined according to a formula, depending on how well the teams performed each year, that would substantially increase what the city earns now. "We stand to make an enormous amount of money if they have great seasons," he said. "And in weaker seasons, we would do O.K."
The mayor also said that the deals, whose final details are still under negotiation, would keep the teams in the city for 35 years and save millions in upkeep on the present stadiums. To maintain the teams' present stadiums for a decade or more, Mr. Giuliani said, "could cost all of the rent that we get and then some." 
The plan for the Yankees, in which a new stadium would be built in Macombs Dam Park in the South Bronx, would require the approval of the State Legislature of a plan to substitute parkland for what would be lost in the construction, he said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: DOMESTIC SECURITY; 
Security Issues Called a Focus Of Next Budget

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 

 BODY:
Addressing the challenge of strengthening the nation against terrorist threats, President Bush will emphasize domestic security in his State of the Union speech next month and propose billions of dollars in security initiatives in his new budget, White House officials say.
 To underscore the new national priority, the budget will include for the first time a separate section on domestic security, including aid for local police and fire departments, assistance for the public health system and money for upgrading technology and for agencies at the front lines of the struggle to protect the public. 
 "We will multiply our investments in what we now call homeland security," Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, said in an interview.
The final figure would be "dramatically" above current spending levels for domestic security, Mr. Daniels said, adding, "This is real money." 
Mr. Daniels did not use specific figures. Other administration officials said that while the budget for the 2003 federal fiscal year was still being assembled, it was likely to contain as much as $40 billion in measures for security and fighting terrorism.
It was not clear just what programs officials were counting. But the amount would compare to roughly $25 billion in similar security measures in the current budget.
The budget will highlight and bring into sharper focus the first efforts of Mr. Bush's fledgling Office of Homeland Security, run by Tom Ridge, the former governor of Pennsylvania, who stepped into the new job in October.
While lawmakers have given Mr. Ridge time to establish himself, some critics in Congress say they remain unconvinced that he has enough power as an adviser to the president to do his job. They argue that Mr. Ridge should have cabinet status and his own agency outside the White House.
"Right now, the war effort abroad is highly organized and highly effective," said Representative Jane Harman of California, the senior Democrat on a House terrorism subcommittee, "and the homeland security effort is not highly organized and not highly effective."
The focus on securing the nation is also sure to set off a debate about how large a federal government is needed to safeguard everything from air travel to public health to the nation's borders. Democrats -- traditionally more comfortable with a larger governmental presence than Republicans -- are expected to push to enlarge the security effort beyond what Mr. Bush will propose.
"Like it or not, the federal government is going to have to expand," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, "and the American people are going to demand that it expand."
Two Democratic senators, Harry Reid of Nevada and Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, for example, are calling for a federal security force to guard the nation's nuclear power plants.
Perhaps the most difficult question for Mr. Ridge and the Bush administration is how much security is enough. Experts say that in a nation as open as the United States, with a million people on average entering the country daily, the vulnerabilities are almost limitless.
"They've got the whole waterfront," said Dr. Amy E. Smithson, an expert on biological and chemical weapons at the Henry L. Stimson Center, a private group in Washington, referring to the homeland security office. "And there's not a single aspect of that panoply of terrorism prospects, whether it's cyberspace or bioterrorism, that they can be seen as not paying utmost attention to."
States and localities, too, will be putting billions of dollars into security and are lobbying for more federal assistance.
The United States Conference of Mayors has called for a new federal block grant program to localities to help pay for security measures. Local officials say they also want to make sure that new money for security is not offset by cuts in other programs.
"We think a homeland security block grant is essential," said Mayor Marc Morial of New Orleans, the president of the conference. "But in a climate of economic downturn, increases in homelessness and against the progress cities have made, it is not the right approach to rob Peter to pay Paul."
Mr. Ridge's office has a staff of about 50 people, about half its eventual planned size, and the budget proposals are just the first step in creating a comprehensive national security strategy. The effort, his aides say, is related to counterterrorism, which seeks to identify threats posed by shadowy enemies and the motivations, abilities and whereabouts of their terrorist networks.
Yet the analysts are focusing not just on threats, but also on where the United States is weak, where it is unprepared to respond to a catastrophic attack, where the complex, overlapping relationship between federal government and states has the potential to leave no one in charge should terrorists strike.
"How do we want to button up America?" Mr. Ridge asked recently. "How do we want to harden America? How do we want to reduce the threat?"
Or, as one of Mr. Ridge's senior aides said, "I think about it as vulnerability reduction."
Some of the country's most glaring weaknesses were ones that government officials scrambled to deal with after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Combat jets flew patrols over cities. Airspace was closed over nuclear power plants, and the plant operators were ordered to their highest level of security. National Guard troops took up arms in airports. And Border Patrol agents along the thinly policed border with Canada worked double shifts. 
Now Mr. Ridge's aides and officials across the government are coming up with new lists of security priorities, to be addressed in this budget and subsequent ones.
The officials cite a national health care system that would not be able to cope with the casualties that could be caused by a mass biological or chemical attack after a decade when managed care and cost containment caused it to shrink. They speak of the containers full of cargo that pour into American ports and get only spot-checks.
They point to the inability of the numerous government agencies to communicate intelligence to each other or get access to different databases, and they say there will be initiatives to deal with such problems in the president's budget. They speak of shortages of equipment and training among first responders and promise an infusion of money for those police and firefighters.
To help set priorities, Mr. Ridge has divided his staff into 13 policy coordinating committees reviewing issues including surveillance and intelligence; terrorism training exercises and evaluation; weapons of mass destruction; border, territorial waters and airspace security; research and development; and medical and public health preparedness.
The committees report to Adm. Steve Abbot, who was deputy director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff and commander of the sixth fleet before he retired.
Admiral Abbot returned to the government in May at the request of Vice President Dick Cheney when the president assigned Mr. Cheney to review national preparedness for responding to weapons of mass destruction. He is now deputy director to Mr. Ridge.
"I'm a former military officer and grew up looking at the Soviet threat in the cold war era," Admiral Abbot said. "That's time gone by now."
Acknowledging that the terrorist threat is more diffuse, he said, "You can still take a complex problem and one that perhaps is fuzzier at the edges in some respects than that nice crisp cold war experience and attack it in a systemic manner."
Reporting to Mr. Ridge and Admiral Abbot is a growing corps of individuals who have studied terrorism or have hands-on experience in disaster management. Michael Byrne, a 20-year veteran of the New York City Fire Department and a high-ranking official of the New York City region of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, is senior director of response and recovery.
Dr. Richard A. Falkenrath, a faculty member at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, has moved over from the National Security Council to be senior director of policy and plans. A co-author of "America's Achilles' Heel," about the nuclear, biological and chemical terrorist threats, Dr. Falkenrath has criticized the federal domestic preparedness program as disorganized and lacking a guiding strategic concept.
Gen. Bruce Lawlor, the first commander of a new military operation called the Joint Task Force Civil Support that would respond if the United States experienced a chemical, biological or nuclear attack has been appointed senior director of protection and prevention.
And Frank J. Cilluffo, an analyst of counterterrorism and information warfare at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, has joined the staff as a special assistant to the president.

HEADLINE: Office Pool, 2002 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
If you correctly predicted everything that happened in 2001, you belong in jail. Here is the office pool for the bounceback year; "All" and "None" are options. 
 1. Next nation to be hit for harboring terrorists is (a) Iraq; (b) Somalia; (c) Sudan; (d) North Korea; (e) Syria. 
 2. An on-to-Baghdad campaign will result in (a) a quagmire; (b) use of Iraqi biowar and nukes against U.S. forces; (c) swift victory by alliance of invading Turks, freshly armed Iraqi Kurds and U.S. troops staged in Kuwait; (d) unwise alliance with Iran's theocrats suppressing Iranian youth. 
3. Corporate giantism news will be (a) AT&T Comcast marries Disney to form "Discomatt"; (b) Satellite Echostar merges with DirecTV to create a cable-satellite duopoly with aforementioned Discomatt; (c) European regulators reject Bush administration's surrender to Microsoft; (d) Justice Department establishes Pro-Trust Division. 
4. The Best Picture Oscar goes to (a) "The Lord of the Rings," elbowing aside "Harry Potter"; (b) Ron Howard's "A Beautiful Mind"; (c) the French comedy "Amelie"; (d) "In the Bedroom" (actress Sissy Spacek's comeback); (e) David Mamet's hard-hitting "The Heist"; (f) David Lynch's hall-of-mirrors "Mulholland Drive." 
5. Novel to watch for best-sellerdom is (a) Jasper Fforde's "The Eyre Affair"; (b) Stephen Carter's "Emperor of Ocean Park"; (c) Jane Stanton Hitchcock's "Social Crimes." 
6. Sleeper in nonfiction will be (a) Bernard Lewis's "What Went Wrong?" about Islam; (b) Patricia Heaton's "Motherhood and Hollywood"; (c) Jack Valenti's updated "Speak Up With Confidence"; (d) the conclusion of Robert Caro's L.B.J. trilogy, "Master of the Senate." 
7. If Chief Justice Rehnquist steps down and Justice Scalia is nominated to replace him, Bush's nominee to replace Scalia will be (a) Associate Justice Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court; (b) Chief Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III or Judge J. Michael Luttig of the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals; (c) White House Counsel Alberto Gonzales.

9. The current recession will (a) see unemployment reach 8 percent by fall and be blamed on Bush-league economics; (b) end by summer as Dow average booms above 12,000; (c) linger mildly through the winter despite ever-rising deficits and ever-sinking interest rates.

13. The anthrax mailing will be (a) traced to Iraq; (b) solved by catching a U.S. unabomber; (c) a continuing mystery. 
14. The positive aftermath of Sept. 11 and the anthrax scare will be (a) the example to the world of the use of power permitted by an aroused U.S. public; (b) the wellspring of fellowship inspired by a national wound; (c) the awakening of the need to advance immunology research and build public health facilities. 
15. Winner of the policy power struggle within the National Security Council will be (a) Secretary of State Colin Powell's "smart multilateralism"; (b) Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld's "compassionate unilateralism"; (c) National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice's "inscrutable Mona Lisa-ism." 
My picks: 1 (a), 2 (c), 3 (all), 4 (b), 5 (c), 6 (a), 7 (c), 8 (d), 9 (a), 10 (a), 11 (none), 12 (c), 13 (c), 14 (all), 15 (b). Only those who play get hooting rights.

HEADLINE: Homelessness in New York 

 BODY:
Mayor-Elect Michael Bloomberg faces all sorts of daunting challenges when he takes office in New York City next week. High on the list are the twin problems of hunger and homelessness that have taxed soup kitchens to the limit and jammed the city's homeless shelters with record numbers of men, women and children. In a city where so many people are needy, the problem of what to do for the very neediest has bedeviled mayors for the last two decades. We hope Mr. Bloomberg can bring a new energy and determination to the issue. 
 The crowds at the soup kitchens and homeless shelters were already growing before the Sept. 11 terrorist attack in Lower Manhattan rocked the local economy, costing the city nearly 80,000 mainly low-income jobs in October alone. Many of those thrown out of work are still receiving unemployment benefits or emergency disaster aid. But the state has nonetheless reported that welfare caseloads grew between September and October. After six years of dramatic reductions, New York may be facing the beginning of a new surge in the welfare population. 
 Local food pantries are reporting a startling increase in the number of New Yorkers who seem to be putting what money they have toward the rent and turning to charitable organizations to feed their families. People who somehow found ways to support themselves in the booming 90's have begun to reappear on the streets and subways. As of the November census, the city's homeless shelters housed about 30,000 men, women and children. Homeless-rights lawyers describe this as the largest number since the city began keeping records in the early 1980's.
The state provides a welfare family of three with a rent subsidy of just $286 a month -- far short of the nearly $700 it would cost that same family to find a two-bedroom apartment in a low-income neighborhood. However, that is still far less than the $36,000 a year it costs to house a family in a hotel- style shelter.
Mr. Bloomberg should begin his administration by vowing to ensure that every New Yorker who is eligible for federally funded food programs is enrolled to get help as soon as possible. Beyond that, he should work with Albany to redirect the state's homeless dollars toward housing subsidies. Common sense calls for a policy that keeps as many people as possible in their own homes instead of driving them into homeless shelters that cost the city and state a fortune.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Late Surge in Holiday Sales May Have Lifted Retailers
A surge of last-minute shopping may have given the nation's retailers and the economy a small boost, according to several reports on holiday sales.
 The late sales gains will not add much to retailers' profits because most of the increases came after deep price cuts. Still, analysts said the discounts that moved merchandise out of the stores should be good for the overall economy. Page A1. 

Price, simplicity and a desire to weave tighter bonds with family and friends have combined to make sales of cameras, particularly digital cameras, soar this season. C4.

Scenes From Post-Holiday Malls
The day after Christmas, traditionally the time to return gifts that are either ill-fitting or ill-suited, has a different purpose for bargain-hunters, but they were not out in force. C4.

Wal-Mart and Yahoo Lift Stocks
Stocks rose on light volume after Wal-Mart Stores and Yahoo rang up better-than-expected holiday sales. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 52.73 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,088.07. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 4.72 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,149.37. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index finished up 16.22 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,960.70. C6.

Web Site Discloses Farm Subsidies
A Web site has made public for the first time every farm subsidy payment received by every farmer since 1996, touching off talk of rage and recrimination across rural America. A1.

Nestle to Buy Out Ice Cream Venture
Nestle agreed to pay $641 million to General Mills for the 50 percent it does not own in a venture that sells Haagen-Dazs ice cream in the United States. C4.

Belgian Court Rejects Sabena Plan
A Belgian court rejected a crucial component of a government-backed plan to create a successor airline to Sabena, Belgium's bankrupt flag carrier. World Business, Section W.

Air Travel Still Strong in Russia
Russian airlines have been relatively untouched by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States that has brought so many Western carriers to their knees. Amid a global collapse in air travel, in Russia it actually rose by 12 percent from September through November of this year versus the comparable period last year. World Business, Section W.

Buffett Buys 5.1% Stake in REIT
Warren E. Buffett has taken a 5.1 percent stake in Burnham Pacific Properties, a real estate investment trust based in San Diego, which is liquidating its holdings after an effort to sell the company failed. Mr. Buffett holds almost 1.7 million shares in Burnham Pacific, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett is the chairman of the investment company Berkshire Hathaway. C4.

Machinery Maker to Miss Goals
The slump in civil aviation after the Sept. 11 attacks and the reluctance of the Japanese government to spend more money on public works projects to stimulate the economy are clouding the future for Mitsubishi Heavy Industries. The company said that it would eliminate 2,000 more jobs by 2006 and take other steps to cut costs. World Business, Section W.

Bioterrorism Threats Spur Ads
Responding to the increase in reports of anthrax, both real and perceived, the Association of Medical Publications is introducing a public service campaign intended to encourage medical professionals to know how to recognize, diagnose and treat diseases associated with bioterrorism. Advertising. C6.

Layoffs Reach 1 Million in U.S.
United States companies, led by Motorola and Boeing, laid off about a million workers in 2001 as the economy lapsed into recession. It was the largest reduction in a dozen years. C6.

Study Raises Inflation Questions
A new comprehensive study raises serious questions about just how much anyone knows about the true rate of inflation in the United States. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Harvard Is Seen Gaining In Economics Game; 
Top Graduates No Longer Favor M.I.T.

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL STEINBERGER 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Last March, when Lawrence H. Summers, a former Treasury secretary, was named the 27th president of Harvard University, nowhere was the popular choice greeted with more enthusiasm than on the second floor of Littauer Center, home to the economics department.
 "People were delighted," said Oliver Hart, the department's chairman. "Larry has a lot of friends here." 
 It's no wonder. Mr. Summers, 47, is almost a pure product of Harvard's economics department. While he attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as an undergraduate, he received a Harvard doctorate in 1982, became the youngest tenured member ever of its faculty at age 28 and taught there for eight years before leaving for Washington in 1991. 
More important, Mr. Summers -- whose sharp rise has given him enormous influence in policy and scholarly circles -- epitomizes the increasingly important position that Harvard now holds in the world of academic economics.
Harvard's economics department is on a roll these days, attracting a disproportionate number of the most coveted graduate students and turning out an equally hefty share of the most promising young economists. Making it all the sweeter is that Harvard's success is helping it eclipse the profession's traditional lodestar, the economics department at crosstown rival M.I.T.
"We feel we are currently winning the competition," Mr. Hart said. "Over the past five to eight years, things have moved in our direction."
Ben Bernanke, who is now the chairman of Princeton University's economics department, recalls that M.I.T. was long the premier incubator of economists and an intellectual hothouse that thoroughly overshadowed Harvard. Indeed, when he was an undergraduate at Harvard in the 1970's, even Mr. Bernanke's own Harvard adviser recommended M.I.T.'s doctoral program.
"He told me that's where all the best students went, and he was right," Professor Bernanke said.
That's no longer true. "Now, things aren't so clear-cut," he said.
One reason the balance of power in Cambridge has shifted is because Harvard has made itself a much better teaching institution. At the same time, M.I.T. has become, relative to Harvard at least, a less attractive place to study economics, in large part because it has suffered a number of prominent defections from its faculty over the past decade. The altered competitive landscape represents another twist in a long, storied rivalry, but it also reflects the changes that have swept the field of economics generally.
In a sense, M.I.T.'s department is being victimized by its own success. It has remained a small shop as the profession it led to prominence has become a sprawling subject. Moreover, the discipline's biggest names are now virtually celebrities, with opportunities extending beyond the lecture hall. Yet M.I.T. clings to the egalitarianism that has always been its trademark; one former faculty member jokingly calls it "the last kibbutz in economics."
Whatever their comparative strengths and weaknesses, M.I.T. and Harvard, which each admit around 25 doctoral candidates annually, still boast what are widely acknowledged to be the two finest graduate programs in economics.
The rivalry between Harvard and M.I.T. is fueled nowadays primarily by proximity and ego. "It's the narcissism of small differences," said Michael Kremer, a specialist in issues of growth and development who jumped from M.I.T. to Harvard two years ago. And while Harvard is a more politically active department, there is no real ideological divide.
Both departments lean to the left politically, though Harvard is more catholic in its composition: its faculty includes two leading conservative economists, Robert Barro and Martin Feldstein. Each school practices what is known as Cambridge-style economics, which, while heavily mathematical, is less formalistic and theoretical than the economics done at the University of Chicago, which has long been at the forefront of the free market school of economics championed by Milton Friedman, who taught there for many years.
Many of the professors and students in Cambridge have taught or studied on both campuses, and there is frequent collaboration among faculty members. Except during recruiting season. "Recruiting is a good old-fashioned fight," said Olivier Blanchard, M.I.T.'s chairman."It usually takes a few weeks for friendships to be restored. Apart from that, it's a state of generalized incest."
It's a rivalry, however, that was conceived in bad blood. In October 1940, a remarkably gifted 25-year-old economist named Paul Samuelson, then an instructor at Harvard, was offered a professorship by M.I.T., which at the time had a threadbare economics department. Harvard was expected to eagerly match the offer, but it did not.
It was widely understood that Mr. Samuelson was snubbed because he was Jewish. Even those who saw it differently acknowledged that anti-Semitism was a factor. The renowned Austrian economist Joseph Schumpeter, who was then teaching at Harvard, remarked: "I could understand if they didn't want to hire him because he is a Jew. But that wasn't it. he was just too brilliant for them."
From his perch at M.I.T., Mr. Samuelson revolutionized economics. Although firmly in the Keynesian camp, his foremost achievement was to unite a century of economic insights, many of them seemingly at odds, into a single, coherent theory -- the neoclassical synthesis, as it was called -- that would dominate economic discourse for some three decades. He also wrote a primer on economics that, 50 years later, remains a popular introductory textbook around the world.
In the early 1950's, he was joined at M.I.T. by another talented young refugee from Harvard, Robert Solow. Together, Professors Samuelson and Solow turned M.I.T. into the institution that best embodied mainstream economic thought. They were distinguished not just for their path-breaking work, but also for their dedication to nurturing their students.
From the 1950's through the 1980's, Harvard's economics department was no match for M.I.T.'s. While it had a fine faculty, professors were not particularly interested in teaching either undergraduate or graduate students, who often received little guidance. "One was hesitant to send students to Harvard," said David Colander, an economist at Middlebury College. "You knew they would receive a good education at M.I.T.; at Harvard, they would have to educate themselves."
Consequently, M.I.T. almost always beat Harvard for the most prized doctoral candidates.
In the early 1990's, however, the first signs of shifting fortunes emerged. Professors Samuelson and Solow, along with other members of the old guard, began to retire even as M.I.T. lost some younger stars as well. In 1993, Mr. Hart and Drew Fudenberg, two leading microeconomic theorists, bolted for Harvard. Shortly thereafter, Jean Tirole, another microeconomic theorist, returned to his native France.
Meanwhile, Harvard was becoming a more user-friendly place, thanks mainly to an influx of M.I.T. economists who had been reared on the Samuelson-Solow ethos.
"In the past, if you were a graduate student, you really took your chances coming here," Mr. Hart, the department's chairman, said. "But the culture has changed. We're able to compete with M.I.T. now because we have people who were taught in the M.I.T. tradition and believe in treating graduate students well."
In the meantime, M.I.T.'s faculty exodus has continued. Besides losing Mr. Kremer, the department could not prevent Susan Athey, a highly reguarded young microeconomist, from going to Stanford University. It also suffered an even bigger defection when Paul Krugman, arguably the world's most influential trade theorist and also a columnist for The New York Times, left for Princeton.
M.I.T. now finds itself at a disadvantage on several fronts. Over the last few decades, economics has flowered into a broad, yet highly specialized, field. With some 60 full-time faculty, Harvard can blanket the subject. M.I.T.'s economics department is half that size.
"It seemed to me that Harvard is a better place if you don't know exactly what you want to study," said one first-year student there, who chose Harvard's economics program over M.I.T.'s. "It's got almost every area covered, and in almost every area it has people who are at the top of the field."
Small was once beautiful for M.I.T., but the department also made a virtue of necessity. For all its influence on the outside world, economics has never cast a large shadow within the university itself. "No one comes to M.I.T. as an undergraduate with the intention of pursuing a degree in economics," Professor Blanchard said.
Engineering and computer science are M.I.T.'s bread and butter; as a result, more resources flow in that direction. "The administration has always been accommodating and generous," said Peter Temin, who has taught economics at M.I.T. since the mid-1960's, "but it prefers to put money into labs than give it to people who just sit there with PC's."
While M.I.T. pays top dollar for faculty, it has trouble matching Harvard's generous housing allowances. Likewise, there is less money floating around for graduate students; some M.I.T. doctoral candidates even serve as Harvard teaching assistants.
M.I.T. is also being punished for remaining true to its teaching mission. The field, notes Princeton's Mr. Bernanke, is now in a "race to the bottom" in terms of teaching loads, with major departments requiring fewer and fewer hours of instruction from faculty. Princeton economists are obligated to teach two course a year. The same applies at Harvard. M.I.T. insists that its faculty teach two and a half courses.
That may not seem like a big difference, but M.I.T. is also less willing to sanction the kind of outside activities that are now commonplace for heavyweight economists.
"There are people who have left who I would have loved to have kept, but we couldn't offer them what other places might," Mr. Blanchard conceded. "There are departments that are willing to bring in big names, pay them lots of money, and let them teach one introductory course a year and to spend four days a week on the road. That is something we will not do."
But for all its comparative difficulties, M.I.T. continues to attract plenty of the best and the brightest: Princeton, Stanford, and Chicago still lag in the battle for graduate students. "When I think about these challenges in the abstract, I think to myself, gee, this is a real problem," Mr. Temin said. "But then, when I look around and see all the talent we have here, things don't look so bad after all."

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND; 
Noir Indeed Is the Night, So Very Dark and Stormy

BYLINE:  By Anita Gates 

 BODY:
Adam Goldberg's good-looking black-and-white movie "Scotch and Milk" knows its Sam Spade; its Mickey Spillane; its all-noir vocabulary, visual and verbal. The film begins with shots of big-city building exteriors, a taxi roof light, a cigarette in close-up. Mr. Goldberg's voice-over sets the mood, to say the least: "There wasn't particularly anything to do that week, but then there never was in the city that's always sleeping. A familiar voice was telling me a story, one I had heard too many times before." 
 The viewer has to assume that Mr. Goldberg is having a little fun with the genre by recreating it, but it's an imitation without impact. The only point made by "Scotch and Milk," which has its television premiere tonight on the Sundance Channel, is that American ennui is alive and thriving among youngish, white, chronically unemployed males. As a film-school exercise in noir camera work, "Scotch and Milk" is expert. As an entertainment, it's mostly unsatisfying, despite the appeal of Mr. Goldberg, whom audiences know as an actor in films like "Saving Private Ryan" and the current drama "A Beautiful Mind." 
 The film takes place during one man's aimless ride in a New York taxi ("Just drive around downtown") on a rainy night. Our protagonist, Jim (Mr. Goldberg, who also wrote and directed the film), spends the trip reflecting on his life in a series of short, scattered flashbacks. Jim's life seems to consist of being rowdy with his male buddies (among them Giovanni Ribisi, Robert Pastorelli and Mr. Goldberg's old co-stars on "Dazed and Confused" Nicky Katt and Cole Hauser) when he isn't busy failing at his relationship with Ilsa (Clea Lewis), a pretty, soft-spoken woman who has read Nathanael West. ("You're a smart chick," he tells her admiringly.)
The men dress and behave in a style somewhere between Jack Kerouac and the Rat Pack, but they talk -- in their own superficial way, heavy on the R-rated adjectives -- about the big issues. "Time either runs out too fast or it takes too long," Jim observes just before three of the guys decide to spend an evening out on the town. At a bar Mr. Pastorelli says in a voice slurred with drink, "You can't think too much, because the mind is for more than just thinking." There is even a discussion of the afterlife, with the observation that in hell at least you'd be among old friends. And once in a while insight appears. When Ilsa accuses Jim of loving the sound of his own voice, he tells her that's impossible because he truly hates himself. "It's the same thing, Jimmy," she says.
Jim seems to be an aspiring poet. That is, he owns a typewriter and talks a lot about his inability to write. It may be just as well, based on the originality of much of the script. "It was night already -- again," Jim thinks in voice-over, looking out a city window. "But it was warm, and there was a faint smell of lilacs." The lines dividing homage, parody and accidental comedy are dangerously thin.

SCOTCH AND MILK
Sundance Channel, tonight at 9

Thomas Haden Church, executive producer; Robert Bauer and Francesca Silvestri, producers; Adrienne Gruben, co-producer; Mary Vernieu, associate producer; written and directed by Adam Goldberg.

WITH: Adam Goldberg (Jim), Nicky Katt (Ray), Clea Lewis (Ilsa), Giovanni Ribisi (Marty), Robert Pastorelli (the Skipper) and Cole Hauser (Johnny).

HEADLINE: What's New at Ford? Try the 2003 Model T 

BYLINE:  By TONY SWAN 

DATELINE: REDFORD, Mich. 

 BODY:
THEY say that history repeats itself, and in one quiet corner of the sprawling Ford Motor Company empire, that aphorism is literally true.
 Ford has resumed production of its legendary Model T, the car that put America on wheels, though the factory consists of a single large bay in one of the company's engineering buildings here, and the final assembly crew is just two workers. 
 The hiatus has been a long one.
Model T production began in October 1908 and ended on May 31, 1927. Ford built more than 15 million of the cars, a single-make record that stood for decades until it was surpassed by the Volkswagen Beetle. 
Although the Model T was thoroughly obsolete by the end of its long run, it was tough, durable and -- its chief virtue -- cheap.
In 1908, the list price for a basic two-seat runabout was $860. By 1925, thanks to economies of scale that followed the 1913 introduction of the moving assembly line, the same car cost just $250.
At one point, half the cars on the planet were Model T's.
Ford has made just half a dozen of its latter-day T's, though it could possibly build more. The new cars were commissioned by Ford for the company's 2003 centennial celebrations.
If you could buy one, which you can't, the new cars would be a lot more expensive than the originals, since economies of scale certainly don't apply. The limited production stands in sharp contrast to output at the Model T plant in Highland Park, Mich., where as many as 8,900 cars left the line in a single day.
To be fair, ramping up for production took a lot of time because the team -- Bill Leland, an engineer with Ford's advanced vehicle engineering group, and Guy Zaninovich, an independent auto restorer and Model T expert -- started with a well-restored 1914 Model T touring car and little else.
But the project seems to have had an ample budget -- enough to call on outside suppliers for items like new body shells, engine block castings, cylinder heads, transmissions, rear axles and more.
It was a complicated process. The original engineering drawings, which had been executed on linen, had long ago crumbled to dust. So to get precise specifications for the castings for the four-cylinder engine block, Mr. Leland and Mr. Zaninovich submitted an original block for a CAT scan at Hill Air Force Base, near Ogden, Utah. The scan generated a three-dimensional computer model, which was used, in turn, to create the castings.
A woodworking team -- Sture Lundin and Sven Hansson -- was brought in from Sweden to hand-craft the bodywork (sheet metal supported by wood) for the new cars.
Other replica parts were easier to obtain.
With so many Model T's still running -- Mr. Zaninovich estimates that there are some 300,000 out there -- there are several sources for replacement items like ignition coils, magnetos, carburetors, brakes, lamps, wheels and the like.
And the partners do acknowledge some departures from the original. For example, the pistons are aluminum and the valves are stainless steel, instead of the cast iron originally used. The substitutes are more durable and efficient.
Even with so many parts ready-made by outside companies, this is an expensive way for Ford to acquire Model T's for its centennial. No one connected with the program will discuss costs, but there is no doubt that building one of these all-new T's exceeded the $25,000 or so that it would have taken to buy a well-restored original.
So what was the point? "Well, what we really wanted to do here," Mr. Leland said, "was say we'd made a new Model T."
Ford has not decided exactly how the cars will fit into its centennial plans, but four have already been donated to the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich. If in 2003 you visit Greenfield Village, a historic park affiliated with the museum, you are likely to see -- and possibly ride in -- one of the painstaking replicas.
And if you can distinguish the new ones from the old, your eye is sharper than most.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
When a Year Becomes An Old Acquaintance

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Soon it will be over. That may be the best thing left about 2001. No one needs to be reminded of the devastation of Sept. 11, of the recession that was already under way, of a war with no immediate end in sight. And it would hardly be surprising if New Year's Eve events were more muted than they have been in recent years, and filled with mixed emotions: relief, sadness, determination, uncertainty, hope.
 The rituals of New Year's Eve, observing the change of calendar in a blur of noise and intoxication, have always tied good riddance to stubborn optimism. Fireworks, confetti, "Auld Lang Syne," shouts, kisses, honking horns and popping corks expunge the past year while making the next one joyful for at least as long as the party lasts. Like most rituals, they provide the reassurance of familiarity and continuity. For a few escapist hours, they may even hold this year's sobering realities at bay. 
 The public and media events this wartime New Year balance pleasure and duty. The glittering ball will drop at midnight in Times Square, but New York City's new mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, will also be sworn in there as a symbol of civic stability. Perennial New Year's events, like the concert and Mass for world peace at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and the Poetry Project's Jan. 1 marathon at St. Mark's Church, are likely to be especially charged.
Television suddenly grew in importance on Sept. 11, and many more stay-at-homes are expected this year. MTV will proceed with its annual New Year's Eve show, including the punk-pop of Sum 41 and the hip-hop of Ja Rule, but on New Year's Day at 2 p.m., it will have a counterpart: a U.S.O. special from Rammstein, Germany, interspersing performances by Jennifer Lopez and Kid Rock with conversations with the troops. 
Meanwhile, Turner Classic Movies is playing Dec. 31 for laughs with a marathon of 13 Marx Brothers movies. Dick Clark's 30th annual "New Year's Rockin' Eve" special on ABC-TV, with Blink 182, Aerosmith and Barry Manilow, will be preceded by its counterbalance: a three-and-a-half-hour news special combining a retrospective of 2001 with New Year's events from Afghanistan, Jerusalem, Tokyo, Edinburgh, Moscow and Rio de Janeiro. It will also have music from U2, Sting and Arlo Guthrie, who will sing "This Land Is Your Land," written by his father, Woody Guthrie.
"I can't imagine anyone celebrating the new year without some sense of commemoration as well as challenge," said Peter Jennings, the ABC anchor. "But people still think we have an awful lot to celebrate. There is a quite remarkable resilience in this country."
Polls taken by ABC News for the program show optimism, Mr. Jennings added. "Eighty percent of folks were more hopeful rather than fearful about what the coming year holds for them personally," he said. "It probably reaffirms the great notion that the country is able to withstand so much pain and to still be a beacon for the rest of the world."
In 2001, simply going to work turned people into victims and heroes. And for the last few months, consumption, even self-indulgence, has begun to be touted as tantamount to a public service. Add a heightened sense of mortality, a longing for frivolousness to seem as compelling as it was earlier this year, and the result is something like a government-approved suspension of the Puritan ethic. It's the antithesis of World War II, when rationing and austerity were the duties of the home front.
"One thing I find everywhere," Mr. Jennings said, "is a confusion about whether the leadership, principally the president, is going to ask people to sacrifice over the long term. We haven't been asked to do that yet." And New Year's Eve is traditionally a night when gratification is not to be delayed.
At least, events promoters hope so. Clubs are just beginning to recover from their empty weeks after Sept. 11 and still face the effects of decreased tourism. As always, the city has events for every musical taste, from the Metropolitan Opera's "Boheme" gala to hipster rock of the Strokes and Guided by Voices at the Apollo Theater to the drum-and-bass marathon at the Limelight. But many of the headliners are locals rather than touring musicians, perhaps reflecting musicians' reluctance to travel or promoters' lower budgets.
Michael Dorf, the founder and chief executive of the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa, has seen audiences return after a two-month lull, but he has also noted a change. "People are drinking more and maybe have a slightly more zealous approach to life," he said. "They would rather not spend a lot of money on a ticket and spend more on beverages."
Running a club that has always prided itself on its experimental side, he has run into a paradox. "I've had some of the most intense conversations with musicians about what's important in this world since Sept. 11," Mr. Dorf said. "On one hand I think things have gotten deeper as the creators of music think hard about why they are in it. But as a business proposition, right now we have to present what people are wanting to pay for rather than having more visionary aspirations."
In a 21st century that was touted as the era of easy global interchange and of the instant mobility of cyberspace, the attacks were a brutal reminder of physicality, of the stubbornness of place and time. New York City night life, concentrated in the city where virtually every culture has an outpost, has always defined the happier flip side of that physicality. Site-specific and ephemeral, it brings together self-selected strangers -- 24 million a year in live music and cabaret-licensed clubs alone, according to 1997 research by the New York Nightlife Association, a club owners' group -- in, as the old-school rap line goes, "the place to be."
The rocker, poet and bandleader Patti Smith has become a staple of New Year's Eve in New York City. This year, as usual, she is performing at the Bowery Ballroom. "I really thought it was more important than ever to do this job and to do it in New York," she said. "I had all these great offers to play New Year's Eve in all these different places, and I thought: 'I don't want to go anywhere. I want to be home here in the city. I want to gather with the people and find out where they're at and where I'm at."
For Ms. Smith, it's not just a recurring gig but an annual milestone. "The 30th of December is my birthday and the 31st is New Year's Eve, and they're both deeply reflective days," she said. "I figure, either celebrate it like a monk, alone and writing, or as a happy warrior, and I'm still in happy warrior mode. I think it's important to address what happened on 9/11, to remember the people who have passed, to consider the plight of Afghan civilians and the refugees, to consider what our government policy is, to comprehend how our civil rights are being tampered with. I'm looking to addressing all of these things as best as I can through our music."
Ms. Smith has written a new song, with the working title "Have a Heart," about John Walker, the American who joined the Taliban. "I find his story to be a microcosm of everything," she said. "It's one human story. Someone who as an American, having freedom to do so, searching for a pure state of expression, whether religious philosophy or some kind of philosophy, going from that search to being where he wound up."
"I'm not thinking that people are going to come and get a world history lesson," she said. "But we're not going to avoid it, and we're not going to avoid different aspects of it, whether sorrow, grief or anger. But I'm very aware that people also need some respite. I'm also going to do some songs that I haven't done in over 20 years, because I know they'll be a lot of fun for people."
"With all that there'll be some out-of-tune singing and a couple of bad guitar chords," Ms. Smith added. "It'll be, hopefully, a raucous, flawed night. I always remember one thing, which is that anybody who's there will have made it, will have gotten through another year. Every year we lose some friends, and a lot of people got lost this year. But anybody's who's there will be alive. In that little Bowery Ballroom, we're what I would like to see us as -- trying to radiate as much positive strength as possible so people can go out in the world and feel strengthened and feel like we're not alone."

HEADLINE: JDS Set the Record, but It May Not Be 2001's Biggest Loser 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
CALL it the year of good will gone bad. Never in history has so much in intangible assets been wiped off balance sheets as companies were forced to acknowledge that they had made some very bad acquisitions.
 But records are made to be broken, and accountants and appraisers say that companies are lining up to announce huge write-offs in 2002. 
 Until this year, the worst annual performance for an American corporation was the $23.5 billion loss posted by General Motors in 1992, largely because of an accounting change that forced it to recognize the costs of health care for retired workers. But that record was smashed by JDS Uniphase, which lost $56.1 billion in its fiscal year that ended June 30. Of that, more than $51 billion came from writing off the costs of bad acquisitions and investments. 
As a symbol of the age, that was perfect. When G.M. set the record, it was an American icon, and its net loss that year came to just one-sixth of its annual revenue. JDS Uniphase, a maker of telecommunications equipment, is not known to most Americans, and for good reason. Its 2001 loss was about 10 times as large as its lifetime revenue.
JDS never saw $50 billion in cash, but it could lose that much because it was blessed, for a time, with an overvalued stock, which it used to buy overpriced companies. After the bubble burst, the accountants acted as if JDS had spent real money.
Another 2001 record breaker, Enron, did spend real money. Its bankruptcy set the record as the largest in American history in terms of assets. It managed to go broke without ever reporting a bad quarter, at least not as measured by the "pro forma" earnings that Wall Street relied upon until it was too late.
Enron will now report huge losses. And, reports Alfred King, the co-chairman of the Valuation Research Corporation, it will not be alone.
"A lot of write-downs are coming" early in 2002 and will involve hundreds of billions of dollars, Mr. King told a recent New York University seminar on the new merger accounting rule that has just taken effect. Appraisal firms like his have been inundated with business from companies seeking advice on how much to write off.
The rule says good will from mergers must be written off if the business unit containing the acquired company is worth less than book value, including the good will taken on as part of the acquisition. Companies have some leeway in determining whether a write-off is needed, but it appears that many of them want to take their write-offs quickly, when they can blame a change in accounting rules.
After the 2002 baths are taken, the usefulness of the new merger rule for investors will depend on whether it forces companies to take losses quickly when a deal goes wrong, or whether companies can postpone the bad news until years later, after problems are clear to all.
There is a sense in which JDS did not suffer 2001's largest loss, nor did Enron. The biggest loss of good will may have been suffered by the accounting profession. The Big Five accounting firms are clearly worried, and they are scrambling to come up with a quick fix to improve disclosures of off-balance sheet debts, related-party transactions and market risks relative to commodity prices. In other words, all the things that Enron hid until it collapsed.
The worry among accountants is that investors who were willing to shrug off accounting scandals during the bull market may now be less tolerant. Whether that proves to be the case will be one thing to watch in 2002.

HEADLINE: Barrick Gold Joins Battle For a Rival 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 27 

 BODY:
Citing the need for a long-overdue rationalization in the gold mining industry, Barrick Gold of Toronto has waded into the takeover battle over Normandy Mining of Australia, with plans for closer cooperation with AngloGold of South Africa if AngloGold's bid for Normandy succeeds.
 AngloGold is vying with Newmont Mining, based in Denver, for control of Normandy. AngloGold, 53.4 percent owned by the Anglo American Corporation, disclosed Barrick's involvement today when it announced a second sweetening of its offer for Normandy. 
 Confirming the talks with AngloGold, Vincent Borg, Barrick's vice president for corporate communications, referred to "layers of potential opportunities" for cooperation, especially in Tanzania and in Australia, where Normandy is the biggest producer. 
Specifically, AngloGold said that if it won Normandy, it would offer Barrick operational control of Kalgoorlie Consolidated mines in western Australia. Kalgoorlie is now a joint venture between Normandy and Home stake Mining of Walnut Creek, Calif., which Barrick recently acquired.
Adding Normandy to Newmont would vault the combined company to No. 1 among world gold producers, with 22 mines on five continents producing 8.2 million ounces of gold a year, compared with AngloGold's 7.2 million ounces and Barrick's 5.7 million ounces. Newmont's bid also includes an offer for Franco-Nevada Mining of Canada, Normandy's biggest single shareholder, which is free of debt and flush with cash.
This would put Newmont in a position to rival Barrick as investors' favorite gold stock. Barrick now has the highest market value and the strongest balance sheet of any major gold producer, and its average production costs are lower than Newmont's.
AngloGold said its new cash and stock bid valued Normandy at 1.84 Australian dollars (93 cents) a share, or about 4.1 billion Australian dollars ($2.08 billion). That would be slightly short of Newmont's latest offer of 1.87 Australian dollars a share, and the gap widened a bit today when AngloGold's American depository receipts fell 1.5 percent in New York trading to $17.80 each, while Newmont slipped 0.7 percent, to $19.24.
Newmont said it was reviewing AngloGold's offer and would respond "in due course." Several analysts predicted that Newmont would again raise its offer and hope to knock AngloGold out of the bidding.
Normandy's board recommended the Newmont bid earlier this month but advised shareholders on Wednesday to "do nothing" for the time being while the bidding played out.
Georges Lequime, an analyst at HSBC Securities in Toronto, said AngloGold's latest offer "smacks of desperation." "They don't have the balance sheet to cough up that extra bit of cash," he said.
But AngloGold said its offer had the advantage of being unconditional and open for immediate acceptance, while Newmont was not expected to make payment before mid-February. "A lot of arbitrageurs and hedge funds might be more inclined to take their money and run," said the manager of an American gold fund that owns shares in all the companies involved.
That Barrick would be involved with AngloGold is not surprising. Barrick sees Newmont as a bigger threat to its investor appeal than AngloGold, and Barrick's chief executive, Randall Oliphant, is close to Robert M. Godsell, his counterpart at AngloGold.
Speaking by telephone from Chile, Mr. Borg said that talks about cooperation between the two companies' mines in Tanzania had been taking place for some time but had been widened in the last few weeks to include Australia. "There are too many companies running too many mines," Mr. Borg said. "This is an attempt to discuss how we can put Humpty Dumpty together again."
The discussions include not only control of specific operations, but also economies of scale through joint procurement and training.
Mr. Borg said Barrick would be willing to pay AngloGold for the Kalgoorlie management contract, saying, "If one management team was operating it, you could extract greater value."
AngloGold said it also intended to offer Barrick participation in a planned expansion of the Boddington mine in southwestern Australia. The project would extend the life of the nearly depleted mine about 15 years and bring annual output to 600,000 ounces.
AngloGold described the talks as "exploratory," with no agreements likely until it landed Normandy. Analysts said there was no reason Barrick could not reach similar arrangements with Newmont.

HEADLINE: Home Loan Applications Climb 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 

 BODY:
Record numbers of Americans applied for loans to buy houses in the week before Christmas, a sign housing may lead the country out of recession, a mortgage banking group reported today. 
 Warm weather and a desire to lock in rates that are on the upswing fueled a 16.5 percent rise in the purchase index kept by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. 
 The reading of 373.5 for the week ended last Friday was the highest ever. Applications to refinance mortgages plummeted. 
Home sales are likely to approach record levels this year, and companies like Pier 1 Imports and Lowe's, which sell furnishings and home-improvement items, are projecting increasing profits next year. That may help underpin the economy's return to growth after slipping into recession in March.
"We are looking for a very positive real estate market," Maureen Passerini, president and chief operating officer of Coldwell Banker, a real estate brokerage firm, said in an interview last week. "There's still great demand." 
A total of 888,000 new homes will probably be sold this year, eclipsing the record of 886,000 in 1998, according to a forecast from the National Association of Realtors. Sales of previously owned homes this year are likely to reach 5.2 million units, second highest on record, the group said. 
Housing "is shrugging off the disruptions that occurred to the rest of the economy after Sept. 11," said Henry Willmore, chief United States economist at Barclays Capital in New York. He said its resiliency would contribute to the economy in the new year. 
Mortgage refinancing is well past its peak even as purchase applications soared, the mortgage bankers figures showed.

HEADLINE: Help-Wanted Index Was Flat in November 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
An index measuring the number of jobs being offered across the United States was flat in November compared with October, but it was nearly half its level in November 2000, the Conference Board said yesterday.
 The private research group's help-wanted advertising index dipped to 45 in November from 46 in October, as the recession continued to affect the already weak labor market. 
The index stood at 75 in November 2000. 
 "Even if the economy is slowly starting to turn around, the labor market is still in retreat," said Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board. 
"In more than half the country," Mr. Goldstein said, "help-wanted ad volume is about half of what it was a year ago."
The number of Americans claiming initial unemployment benefits dipped to 384,000 in the latest week, but the number of claims is expected to climb above 401,000 in a Labor Department report today. 
The Conference Board surveys 51 newspapers across the country about their patterns of help-wanted ads every month to determine the index.

HEADLINE: In Spain, Political Gains of Euro Outweigh Nuisances 

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY

DATELINE: MADRID, Dec. 27 

 BODY:
It is merely a TV advertisement but it captures a national turning point. 
 Doctors and nurses gather around a life-support machine, wires connected to the bed-ridden patient. On its death bed, it seems, is a tiny aluminum coin, the Spanish peseta. A phone company is advertising itself by bidding farewell to the 133-year-old currency and offering a goodbye bargain: phone calls that cost just one peseta a minute, about half a cent. 
 Spain is swapping its currency for the euro, and the country is paying homage to the peseta, adopted officially in 1868 for an earlier (failed) monetary union. An exhibition at the Bank of Spain in Madrid shows dozens of old bills and coins, with a video commentary on the country's road to the euro, which makes its debut in cash registers and automated teller machines on Tuesday.
Over the years the look of the peseta has reflected the nation's gallery of heroes -- Spanish writers, explorers and artists. 
One 19th-century banknote, worth 100 pesetas and printed by the American Bank Note Company of New York, depicts a comely maiden flanked by two storm-tossed ships. Miguel de Cervantes (who also appears on Spanish euro coins), along with his creations, Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, appear on bills from the 1870's, as do the painters Velazquez and Murillo.
"Traditionally Spanish coins and bills had some very pretty designs, because they used very good painters and engravers, above all before the Civil War, and that's what we will miss," says Teresa Tortella, the curator of the exhibition.
Spaniards, who long suffered in isolation because of Francisco Franco's four-decade dictatorship, have embraced everything European with alacrity, and surveys now show the country to be keenly awaiting the euro, which will have a fixed value of 166.386 pesetas.
"We Spaniards have been using pesetas for many years, but with today's economic advances, we need a strong currency," says Manuel Lazaro, 65, who retired from an insurance company. "I think the euro will be very positive." 
The peseta replaced the real, created by King Pedro of Castile in the 14th century. (The American quarter was born when colonists made change by cutting reales and other European coins in fourths.) 
"The history of Spain has been reflected in these bills, from a political, historical and cultural point of view," said Ms. Tortella. Banknotes from the 1936-39 Civil War, for example, reflect the battle between the Republicans and the Nationalists. The Republican bills show scenes of muscular workers alongside steaming factory chimneys executed in bold reds and blues, while Franco's Nationalists used conservative etchings highlighting cathedrals, battles and Castillian landscapes.
The most recent peseta bills, re-issued in 1992 to coincide with the 500th anniversary of Columbus's first voyage to the Americas, bear his face along with those of the Conquistadores Francisco Pizarro and Hernan Cortes.
One rarely seen bill, the 10,000-peseta note, with a portrait of King Juan Carlos, suddenly made a comeback in recent months, thanks to the euro. Spaniards who once stashed their "mattress money" in large bills seem to have gone on spending sprees, knowing the peseta will vanish as a currency early next year. Property prices have soared, as have purchases of luxury cars and artworks. 
This consumption has helped to offset Europe's economic slowdown, economists say.
The government has backed a major campaign to familiarize citizens with the new coins and bills, and revelers gathering on New Year's Eve in the central squares in Madrid, Cordoba and Las Palmas will see a sound-and-light show celebrating the end of the peseta and the public introduction of the euro. The show will be broadcast on national television, when millions of Spaniards tune in to hear the clock strike midnight.
Modern Spaniards, who are unaccustomed even to using the 1-peseta coin (known as the lentilla, or contact lens, because it is so flimsy), grumble that they will now have to learn to deal in euro cents. But the main concern here is so-called euro-inflation: that retailers will be tempted to round up the prices when they convert to euros from pesetas.
A cartoon for the daily El Mundo captured the public's fear: a mugger approaches a prosperous couple and shouts, "Stop, this is a rounding up!" To which the fur-coated woman replies, "Oh, damn that euro!"

GRAPHIC: Photo/Chart: "IN A MONETARY UNION LONG AGO, THERE WAS THIS PESETA . . ."First Introduced: 1868. Trivia: Spain officially adopted the peseta to join a 19th-century monetary union that grouped the currencies of France, Italy, Belgium, Switzerland and, eventually, Greece. Though Spain never joined the union, the peseta was established at five grams of silver and divided into 100 cents. Peseta-to euro value: 166.3866.

HEADLINE: Could've Been Worse 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
It has not been a good year for economic policy, at home or abroad. The best you can say is that things could have been worse.
 The bad news was legion. The U.S. went into recession, and the collapse of Enron raised questions not only about our economy but about the state of business ethics. We squandered our hard-won budget surplus, and with it our best chance to do something about the fiscal burdens of an aging population, on an ill-conceived tax cut. Overseas, Argentina melted down -- something I had long predicted, but the actual events were still shocking. And Japan's prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, looks less like Franklin Roosevelt and more like Herbert Hoover every day. 
 The good news all takes the form of things that didn't happen.
 The good news about the U.S. economy is that it fell into recession, but it didn't fall off a cliff. Most of the credit probably goes to the dogged optimism of American consumers, but the Fed's dramatic interest rate cuts helped keep housing strong even as business investment plunged. The pain is far from over -- unemployment looks set to keep on rising, even if the G.D.P. starts growing again -- but our worst fears have not been realized.
 It was good news that the World Trade Organization didn't collapse. Trade is one area in which the Bush administration is right and the Democrats are wrong; but there was a real risk that the 1999 debacle in Seattle, where an attempt to start a new round of negotiations collapsed in disarray, would be repeated this year. In fact the meeting, in Doha, Qatar, went off fairly well. Alas, I cannot take any satisfaction in the passage of "fast track" trade authority: as Lael Brainard pointed out on this page yesterday, the Bush administration purchased fast-track at the cost of appalling concessions to special interests, concessions that hurt the very countries free trade is supposed to help. 
 It was good news when California's energy crisis evaporated, thanks to price controls and conservation. The Bush administration was all set to use the crisis to push through an environmentally destructive program of corporate welfare, which had nothing to do with the actual problem; the sudden surplus of power put that plan on hold. 
 Really big good news: To my immense relief, the absurdity of Social Security privatization became manifest before the system had been dismantled. I had been really worried about that; the Bush administration's claim that private accounts would improve rather than worsen the system's finances made no sense at all, yet it got a free pass from most commentators. 
 Fortunately, the commission that was supposed to propose a detailed plan came to a farcical end. Its final report declared that private accounts would indeed strengthen Social Security, if they were accompanied by sharp benefit cuts and huge financial injections from unspecified sources. Yes, and eating a jelly doughnut every morning will help you lose weight, if you also cut back sharply on other foods and do a lot of exercise; otherwise the doughnuts will make you fatter. Again, aren't you glad the absurdity of the Bush proposal came to light before $1 trillion was diverted into private accounts?
 And one more thing to be grateful for: We didn't get a stimulus bill. That doesn't sound like good news, unless you look at the content of the bills that were actually on the table: huge further tax breaks for corporations and the wealthy, doing little for the economy but further worsening our already dreary fiscal outlook.
 But what about the year ahead?
 For me the gloomiest moment was probably around mid-October. That's when the straight economics looked worst -- when the impact of Sept. 11 on confidence seemed all too likely to turn the recession into something truly nasty. It was also the moment when some politicians decided to abandon all restraint, and throw their weight behind huge special-interest giveaways. But guess what? Confidence didn't collapse, and the special interests didn't get what they wanted. It turns out that there are still decent politicians, in both parties, and so far they have had enough power -- just -- to prevent the worst.
 In short, things could have been worse, and there is still reason to hope. Happy New Year.
