HEADLINE: A Turbulent First Year 

 BODY:
George W. Bush is spending the days before New Year's at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., enjoying the kind of informal, secluded weekend he has probably envisioned having many times during his presidency. And the public, much of which was once prepared to resent Mr. Bush's desire to get away from Washington as much as possible, now simply hopes he gets to catch up on his sleep. It has been a far different first year than the one the president, or the country, anticipated.
 Mr. Bush heads toward his second year at the White House with his presidency transformed by crisis and the nation propelled by a renewed sense of purpose. He hardly seems like the same chief executive who squeaked into office thanks to a badly designed ballot in some Florida counties, let alone the candidate who was embarrassed by his inability to name the general running Pakistan. Mr. Bush, whose critics worried that he would never be able to conduct foreign diplomacy, has proved himself a strong wartime leader who gives the nation a sense of security during a period of crisis. 
 Among the many things America learned this year about its new president is that Mr. Bush sometimes responds uncertainly when he is taken by surprise, as he did in the hastily arranged appearance he made on Sept. 11, as he was being flown from one air base to another in search of security. But he recovers quickly. Since the terrorist attacks, Mr. Bush has approached the war against Al Qaeda in much the same way he ran his campaign for president -- by giving the people a series of clear, simple messages repeated with the firm discipline of a man who lives for his hourlong gym workouts. He picks subordinates he trusts and lets them do their jobs. 
As America approaches a new year, the lingering horror over Sept. 11 has been somewhat ameliorated by the success with which Mr. Bush and his team have prosecuted the war in Afghanistan, and the president's popularity is at historic highs. But there is no piece of history Mr. Bush is more familiar with than what happened to his father in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war. Economic problems at home turned the American mood sour, with fatal results for his re-election campaign.
The lesson the current President Bush takes from all that is the importance of maintaining the loyalty of his right-wing base, and showing the public he cares about their distress. In the new year he should reconsider the moral of his father's story. The American people want neither sympathy nor ideological purity. They are concerned with getting the economy back on its feet, and if that does not happen quickly, history suggests they may begin looking worriedly at federal deficit spending, which was made inevitable by Mr. Bush's huge tax cuts for wealthy Americans.
As the nation moves into 2002, we no longer worry about whether George W. Bush has the gravitas to lead the country in time of crisis, or whether his foreign policy team has the skill to protect the nation's interest in a global conflict. But there are many other things we still cannot be sure of. We do not know whether the president has the ability to trim his early impulse toward unilateral thinking and conservative ideology in ways that will allow him to maintain an international alliance against terrorism. The wheels are already coming off the cooperation between India and Pakistan. More ominous, Mr. Bush is needlessly challenging Russia and undercutting its president, Vladimir Putin, by insisting on scrapping the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The administration has dismayed allies by its hostility to international treaties on the environment and nuclear proliferation.
We do not need to wonder, as we did a year ago, whether the president is capable of using his famous people skills to create bipartisan alliances in Congress as he did in Texas, where the parties are far closer together than they are in Washington. Mr. Bush demonstrated through his work on the education testing bill that he has the talents to fashion a strong legislative agenda that can be passed into law. 
What we still do not know is whether he has the will to put all these talents together and create the sort of bipartisan, moderate domestic agenda that the voters were clearly demanding in that inconclusive presidential election a year ago. Finishing up his first year in office, George W. Bush is a larger, graver figure than the one we met during the 2000 election. He sees himself as a man wrestling with history, and he is right. The only question is whether he will learn the wrong lessons.

HEADLINE: Playing the 'Jersey Card,' Firms In Manhattan Compare Incentives 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In the summer of 1997, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani hailed the decision by a securities firm called Exco P.L.C. to move hundreds of employees from Jersey City to the World Trade Center as a breakthrough and rewarded the company with millions of dollars in tax breaks and other incentives.
 "For the first time in years," Mr. Giuliani said at the time, "companies like Exco are realizing the advantages of doing business in New York City and are making sure they have a major presence here." 
 But in the latest example of the cross-border war for jobs, the company announced yesterday that it was moving back across the Hudson River to Jersey City, to a new office tower at the Harborside Financial Center. Now known as Garban Intercapital, the company was lured there with at least $8.3 million in subsidies from New Jersey after its offices at the trade center were destroyed. 
The Garban deal surfaced two days after Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a plan to use $285 million in federal aid to offer tax incentives to companies that remain in Lower Manhattan, or move there from elsewhere.
While a lawyer for Garban says the company plans to pay back the city, the growing bidding war for companies like Garban has prompted critics to question the wisdom of the incentive strategy.
"It would be wiser for the city to concentrate on strengthening entire industries, not just a few large corporations, and making the city more attractive for the indispensable employees and executives of these companies," said Jonathan Bowles, research director for the Center for an Urban Future.
Garban is far from alone in pressuring New York in a weak moment. Euro Brokers, another financial firm that had offices in the trade center, is "playing the Jersey card big time," said one New York official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Euro Brokers is threatening to move its 303 employees to Jersey City unless New York officials provide tax breaks comparable to the $24 million package New Jersey is offering, according to officials on both sides of the Hudson.
Euro Brokers could not be reached, but two real estate brokers familiar with the company's plans said Euro Brokers planned to move to 199 Water Street in Manhattan and was merely using the Jersey card as leverage.
Eight other companies, including Lehman Brothers, Fuji Securities, CIBC Oppenheimer and Dow Jones, have moved thousands of workers to New Jersey since Sept. 11 in exchange for millions in tax breaks.
Glenn J. Phillips, a spokesman for the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, said the state had not taken advantage of New York City's vulnerability, as many state and city officials in New York suspect.
"We've been very sensitive to that charge," Mr. Phillips said. "Since Sept. 11, it's been business as usual. There's no attempt to take advantage of the situation, but we're here if companies call us."
Over the past six years, he said, Goldman, Sachs, Merrill Lynch, U.S. Trust, Cigna Healthcare and other companies have moved employees to New Jersey from New York and taken advantage of the state's business incentive program. Many others simply threatened to relocate.
Whether or not the corporations truly intend to leave Manhattan, real estate brokers and urban planners say the executives have become adept at playing off New Jersey against New York to obtain special tax breaks, low-cost electricity or cash grants. In the last eight years, the Giuliani administration has provided more than 50 companies with a total of $2 billion in tax breaks and other incentives.
State and city officials are more worried than ever that investment banks and others will move their headquarters, or part of their operations, outside the city.
Earlier this month, New Jersey's governor-elect, James E. McGreevey, met with Mr. Giuliani at City Hall and pledged to not try to lure companies across the river. "Poaching is wrong," he said. But he did not vow to eliminate the incentive programs intended to attract out-of-state employers.
A decade ago, economic development officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut endorsed a no-poaching agreement at a news conference in Manhattan, and then promptly forgot about it.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said New Jersey officials had told him that they were not working overtime to benefit from New York's current problems.
As for Garban, Mr. Gargano said he intended to sue the company to recover more than $1 million in grants, charging that Exco did not live up to its 1997 agreement with New York to keep 460 jobs in the city. "We're going after them," he said.
But Jay Biggins, a lawyer who worked for Garban in obtaining the tax incentives in New Jersey, said the company intended to pay back both New York State and the city for the $6.3 million incentive package it received in 1997.
"This is not a dispute," Mr. Biggins said. "It's a nonissue."
The history of the Exco deal illustrates the pitfalls of tax incentives. In 1997, Exco promised to move 460 employees into the World Trade Center, including 219 from Jersey City. But within two years, Exco was losing business and cut its payroll in half, forfeiting any future benefits from the city and state. It was acquired by Intercapital, which later merged with Garban. Garban, in turn, moved into Exco's office space at the trade center.
Last summer, Garban executives said they wanted to expand Exco's original incentive deal to cover 700 employees who would remain in New York. The city refused the offer, Mr. Biggins said. Wracked by competition and problems after the trade center attack, Garban is now moving about 250 employees to Jersey City.
"They made the deal because the New Jersey economic benefits were so attractive," said John Picco, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, a brokerage firm that represented Garban. "There was no comparison with New York."

HEADLINE: U.S. Drops Threat to Cut Aid to Russia For Disarming 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Dec. 27 

 BODY:
After nearly a year of threatening to end programs aimed at helping Russia stop the spread of nuclear weapons, the White House announced today that it remained committed to an effort to help Russia dispose of hundreds of tons of military plutonium.
 The Bush administration, its concerns about the availability of nuclear weapons heightened since Sept. 11, said it would also continue a program to reduce the dependence of some Russian cities on nuclear weapons development and to provide alternative jobs for nuclear scientists. 
 In addition, the White House said that the Pentagon would seek to speed up the Cooperative Threat Reduction project to construct a chemical weapons destruction facility at Shchuchye, 1,000 miles southeast of Moscow, allowing for its earlier completion.
The announcement marked the culmination of the Bush administration's yearlong review of Clinton-era programs, designed to work with Russia to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, and essentially left all of them intact. Early in the administration, Bush administration officials criticized many of the programs as expensive and ill conceived, and had threatened to eliminate them or greatly reduce their funding. 
"I think it shows a fairly profound evolution of Bush administration views over the past year," said Rose Gottemoeller, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and a senior Energy Department official during the Clinton administration. "They raised huge expectations early in the administration that they were going to slash and burn. I think they began to see the national security implications, and then after Sept. 11 it became untenable to cut the programs radically."
The administration released the announcement in a brief e-mail to reporters from the White House office in Crawford, Texas, where President Bush is vacationing on his ranch. Officials on the National Security Council oversaw the yearlong review of the programs.
The e-mail included only a short statement from Mr. Bush, taken from a speech he gave on Dec. 11 at The Citadel, the military college in Charleston, S.C. In that speech, Mr. Bush said that "together, we must keep the world's most dangerous technologies out of the hands of the world's most dangerous people. A crucial partner in this effort is Russia -- a nation we are helping to dismantle strategic weapons, reduce nuclear material, and increase security at nuclear sites."
The White House review covered 30 programs with a combined annual budget of $750 million. Arms control advocates consider them a cornerstone of America's scientific and military relationship with Russia. The programs involve mostly the Pentagon, the Energy Department and the State Department, and pay for the dismantling of weapons facilities and the strengthening of security at sites where nuclear, chemical and biological weapons are stored. 
Bush administration officials have said that their review, parts of which were made public by senior officials over the summer, does not endorse the Clinton approach. Rather, they say, the administration is trying to make the programs more cost-efficient and better-managed.
To that end, the administration has said it will pursue a less expensive approach in its effort to help Russia dispose of plutonium. The administration favors using plutonium in reactors as "mixed oxide fuel," as opposed to a more expensive method that mixes plutonium with glass and nuclear waste materials. 
In addition, the White House has sought more financing from Russia and European nations to help build the chemical weapons destruction facility at Shchuchye. Critics said the original program was too costly and was not moving forward, and that Russia had not put up enough of its own money for the project. 
Under the Bush review, the program to provide alternative jobs for nuclear scientists, called the Nuclear Cities Initiative, will be consolidated with another program, called Initiatives for Proliferation Prevention. The combined program will be restructured, the announcement from the White House said, "to focus more effectively on projects to help Russia reduce its nuclear warhead complex."
The Nuclear Cities Initiative was started in 1998 to help create nonmilitary work for Russia's 122,000 nuclear scientists and to help Russia downsize geographically and economically isolated nuclear cities, where 760,000 people live. 
The aim of the program was to prevent nuclear scientists from leaving for Iraq, Iran and other would-be nuclear powers.

HEADLINE: IN FINAL ADDRESS, GIULIANI ENVISIONS SOARING MEMORIAL 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL

 BODY:
In his official farewell address to New Yorkers after eight years in office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promised yesterday that he would push for a "soaring, monumental" memorial to be built at the World Trade Center site. He also said he felt that he and others were obligated to make sure that ground zero was sanctified and not controlled by economic development.
 Stepping from behind the lectern of St. Paul's Chapel, just a stone's throw from the gigantic cranes still sifting through the rubble, Mr. Giuliani walked, with microphone in hand, toward his audience of supporters and promised that all the families who had lost their loved ones would always receive assistance. 
 "I really believe we shouldn't think about this site out there, right behind us, right here, as a site for economic development," Mr. Giuliani told the assembled crowd of about 300. "We should think about a soaring, monumental, beautiful memorial that just draws millions of people here that just want to see it." 
"We have to be able to create something here that enshrines this forever and that allows people to build on it and grow from it," he added. "And it's not going to happen if we just think about it in a very narrow way." Excerpts, Page D6. 
If the memorial was done correctly, he said, "millions of people would come here. And you'll have all the economic development you want, and you can do the office space in a lot of different places." 
The departing mayor's support for letting the memorial govern the redevelopment of the trade center site could make things more complicated for the administration that succeeds him. Page D6. 
The incoming mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, gave a lukewarm reception yesterday to the notion of turning the entire 16-acre site into a memorial, which Mr. Giuliani has suggested as an option in recent weeks. 
"Everybody thinks we will have a memorial and should have a memorial," Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday, "and that is what we have the committee for: to look and see what's the appropriate use of that space, and I think I'll sit back and let them come up with suggestions and give them my input. I think that I'm in favor of more of a mixed-use thing."
As City Hall was being festooned with red-white-and-blue bunting in anticipation of Mr. Bloomberg's inauguration on Tuesday, Mayor Giuliani took the unusual step of saying goodbye from the 18th-century chapel where George Washington prayed after being inaugurated president.
He became slightly emotional during his 55-minute speech as he talked about fleeing the scene of the attack on Sept. 11. Mr. Giuliani jokingly referred to his cranky reputation before then and his image afterward as the old Rudy and the new Rudy, while he read newspaper clippings as a way of answering his critics. At times he reminisced about his family and his life, while at others he borrowed from the script of his annual State of the City speeches to credit his administration for the sharp declines in crime, lower welfare rolls and other achievements.
But the speech, by turns playful, technical, religious and patriotic, was also notable for the ground it did not cover, which included subjects like children's services, parks and recreation, education and public health, even though they were outlined in a handout about what the administration considers its successes, which was given to reporters.
At times, Mr. Giuliani's language and tone reverted to his familiar scolding voice, as he settled old scores and found fault with those who disagreed with him on crime, budget policy and treatment of the homeless.
He once again defended his policing policies and said places that used other approaches like community policing had had recent spikes in crime. And apparently stinging from recent criticism regarding the debt the city carries in a weakened economy, he digressed into a lecture about long-term debt and the city's fiscal responsibility.
The mayor began his speech by saying, as he has many times, that he drew his strength from New Yorkers and places like the chapel, its pews plastered with messages of thanks and encouragement to the recovery workers and its balcony lined with beds where those workers have rested alongside stacked boxes of paper towels and hot chocolate mix.
"Although I have to leave you as the mayor soon, I resume the much more honorable title of citizen," Mr. Giuliani told his audience, mainly former and current members of his administration, supporters, friends and family. "And the people of the city should understand that all of the sources of my strength absolutely endure because you have it, and you have that strength and you've displayed it."
Around the time he took office in 1994, Mr. Giuliani said, the city had been labeled a rotting apple on the cover of Time magazine and was the subject of terrible publicity, including 2,000 murders a year, the decline in jobs, the departure of Fortune 500 companies in record numbers and the flight of residents to other locations.
"I didn't know if I would succeed or not, but I felt that my job as the mayor was to turn around the city," he said. "Because I believed rightly or wrongly that we had one last chance to do that, to really turn it around in a totally opposite direction from the direction it was going in. And that created a lot of hostility and a lot of anger."
Mr. Giuliani gave a lengthy discourse on the city's accomplishments in reducing crime through what he called the application of rational strategies rather than emotional and political responses. He moved on to defend, as he frequently has, the city's dealings with welfare recipients and the homeless, casting those efforts as ideological shifts in social policies that critics were incapable of understanding.
Taking a swipe at a recent federal court decision that ordered the police to stop ejecting homeless people from the grounds of a Manhattan church, the mayor said that none of the problems of the homeless were solved "by doing the kind of thing that the judge allowed last week."
"That's cruel," he continued. "He doesn't think it's cruel. But he's having a hard time thinking through the ideology that he brings with it to analyzing his decisions."
On welfare, displaying his penchant for using numbers in speeches, Mr. Giuliani said that the city had nearly 700,000 fewer people on welfare than it had when he came into office, and that it was on track to having created 250,000 jobs in the last two years. He also praised the city's fiscal policies, saying that Mr. Bloomberg would take office with a budget surplus of more than $1 billion, whereas Mr. Giuliani came into office with a $2.3 billion deficit.
The mayor credited his administration with having accomplished more development in the last 8 years than had occurred in the city in probably 30 or 35 years. He cautioned against a return to an "anti-development, high-tax philosophy" as the national economy sags.
Despite his often frosty relationship with some of the city's minority populations and representatives, Mr. Giuliani also took time to say that the city's greatest strength was its diversity. He added, "I remember after the attack on the World Trade Center, it just came very naturally for me to say to people, do not engage in group blame. Do not go single out people who are Arab-Americans and blame the attack on the World Trade Center on them."
Indeed, all roads, it seemed, led back to Sept. 11. In one of the more emotional parts of his speech, the mayor called himself "a survivor like the church," along with many of the officials seated in the front row of pews. There, flanking his friend Judith Nathan, were many of the people who had been with him that morning, he said, including Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen, and Deputy Mayors Joseph J. Lhota, Anthony P. Coles and Robert M. Harding. The fourth deputy mayor, Rudy Washington, although mentioned by the mayor in the lineup, was not seated among them.
Mr. Giuliani said he owed it to those who perished to ensure a proper memorial at the World Trade Center site and promised to make it his mission. The area, he said, will be remembered 1,000 years from now for "the sacrifice of our patriots and their heroism."
"This place," he said, "has to become a place in which when anybody comes here immediately they're going to feel the great power and strength and emotion of what it means to be an American."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Talks of a City's Spirit, and a Grand Monument to Those Who Died 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's farewell address at St. Paul's Chapel in Manhattan yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 . . .The reason I chose this chapel is because this chapel is thrice-hallowed ground. This is a place of really special importance to people who have a feeling and a sense and an emotion and an understanding of patriotism. This is hallowed by the fact that it was consecrated as a house of God in 1766. That's a long time ago. And in 1789, in April of 1789, George Washington came and after he was inaugurated as the first president of our republic he prayed right here in this church, which makes it very sacred ground to people who feel what America is all about. 
 But then it was consecrated one more time, in 2001 on Sept. 11. When I walked in here from the back, I looked up because every time I've walked in this church when I looked up I saw the twin towers just way, way above. . . . And on Sept. 11 when the twin towers were viciously attacked and came crashing to the ground in the worst attack on America, destroyed buildings all around, did damage as far away as City Hall all the way south in the southern part of Battery Park City and covered this whole area with debris, body parts and in many, many ways damaged buildings, this chapel remained not only not destroyed, not a single window was broken, not a single thing hurt. And I think there's some very, very special significance in that. The place where George Washington prayed when he first became president of the United States stood strong, powerful, untouched, undaunted by the attacks of these people who hate what we stand for. Because what we stand for is so much stronger than they are.
So this chapel stands for our values. And it's a very important place. And I hope you return here often to reflect on what it means to be an American and a New Yorker.
When I became mayor of New York City in 1993, with the help of many of you that are here, it seemed to me that I had to do something different than other mayors. It seemed to me that what I had to do was to totally change the direction and course of New York City. Maybe I was right about that, maybe I was wrong about it, but that's the way I felt I had to operate. I saw this city deteriorating. . . . I saw the city on the front page of Time magazine in 1990 in which the front cover said "New York City: the Rotting Apple." 
And then several years worth of terrible, terrible publicity about the city: 2,000 murders a year; people fleeing; 320,000 fewer jobs; Fortune 500 companies leaving in record numbers. A poll in 1993 said that over 65 percent of New Yorkers wanted to leave the city if they could afford to do it. When I saw that poll I became really concerned about the future of the city. And then another one that said that the overwhelming majority of New Yorkers believed that although we would survive as a city, our best days were behind us, our best days were history, that our future would not be nearly as bright as our past. . . . 
So I felt that my job as the mayor, I didn't know if I would succeed or not, but I felt that my job as the mayor was to turn around the city. Because I believed rightly or wrongly that we had one last chance to do that, to really turn it around in a totally opposite direction from the direction it was going in.
And that created a lot of hostility and a lot of anger. I knew it would. Because the city was headed in the direction it was in because of ideas. There were people who had political philosophies and political creeds and ideologies and those were the reasons behind all of the things that had the city headed in the wrong direction, in my view. And I had a different group of ideas about what should lie behind where the city was going. . . .
The physical structure of the city has to be rebuilt like the human structure of the city is rebuilt. And the city should never again go back into the antidevelopment philosophy. We did more developing in the last eight years than in probably the last 30 or 35 years combined. I won't list all the projects. You know them: Times Square, 125th Street, the first hotel in Brooklyn in 50 years. 
Nobody had built a hotel in Brooklyn in 50 years. I don't know what they were doing in Brooklyn in 50 years . . . But no hotel in Brooklyn in 50 years. We brought baseball back to Brooklyn and Staten Island. 
And the one that I'm the most proud of now and keep going to look at is the AOL Time Warner headquarters on Columbus Circle. That's a grand new project that was mired in the antidevelopment philosophy and letting it rule for 15 or 20 years. And I can give you all kinds of examples like that. Hotels that were built, office buildings that have gone up, courthouses, Judge Kaye, courthouses in every borough with the very, very strong support and help of Chief Judge Kaye. Thank you.
But you have to fight the antidevelopment philosophy. Because it's there and it can be very, very harmful, particularly now, when the city has to work its way out of two things. And I think it's the second more than the first, actually. The attack on the World Trade Center and the impact that that has had on our economy. I'm not sure that some of that wasn't exaggerated now that I look at our tax receipts, the impact of the World Trade Center. 
But the second part, and that is the national economy. No matter how we try to outperform it, and we do nowadays, it's still going to affect us. So given that, this would be the worst time to go back into an antidevelopment, high-tax philosophy. . . . 
There are just too many things to talk about and too many people to thank. But there is one big change that has taken place that's the most important and the one that I wanted to bring about. And that one I'm really sure of. It's a change in the spirit of the city. That city that used to be the rotting apple, that 60, 70, 80 percent of the people wanted to leave and nobody wanted to come to, that city now is very strong and it is a confident city. It's a city that has withstood the worst attack of any city in America or in the history of America and people are standing up as tall, as strong and as straight as this church. . . . 
So I really believe we shouldn't think about this site out there right beyond us right here as a site for economic development. I think we should think about it this way: we should think about how we can find the most creative minds possible who love and honor America and can express that in artistic ways that I can't, but they can. And we should think about a soaring, monumental, beautiful memorial that just draws millions of people here that just want to see it and then also want to come here for reading and education and background and research.
Long after we are all gone, it's the sacrifice of our patriots and their heroism that is going to be what this place is remembered for. This is going to be a place that is remembered 100 and 1,000 years from now, like the great battlefields of Europe and of the United States. And we really have to be able to do with it what they did with Normandy or Valley Forge or Bunker Hill or Gettysburg. We have to be able to create something here that enshrines this forever and that allows people to build on it and grow from it. 
And it's not going to happen if we just think about it in a very narrow way. How do you replace the offices? And how do you get the jobs? There is plenty of -- we can do all that. We've got to think about it from the point of view of a soaring, beautiful memorial. And then if we do that right, if we do that part right, then the economic development will just happen. And millions of people will come here. And you'll have all the economic development you want. And you can do the office space in a lot of different places. And I feel very, very strongly about this. And it is something I'm not going to forget and something I'm going to continue to speak up on because I feel I owe that in a very, very personal way. Thousands of people died there. And hundreds of them died as rescue workers. They didn't have to go there. They walked in to try to pull people out. Some of them are very close friends of mine. And some of them are very close friends of people that I love and care about and are related to the people that I love and I care about. . . .
So I think we have an obligation to the people who did die to make sure of two things about which there can be absolutely no compromise: Their families need to be protected just as if they had been alive, financially and in every other way that we can help and assist their families, there should be no compromise about that, ever; and second, this place has to be sanctified. This place has to become a place in which when anybody comes here, immediately they're going to feel the great power and strength and emotion of what it means to be an American. We have to do that and not worry about other things. Because this is too important a place. In their memory we have to do that. . . .

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he felt it was his job as mayor to turn the city around. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Tokyo Weighs Pouring More Public Money Into Banks

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 28 

 BODY:
Japan's government, in a bid to stave off another banking crisis, said it was considering pumping public money into the nation's beleaguered lenders for the second time in three years.
 Taku Yamasaki, secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, told Japanese reporters that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi supported using taxpayer money if needed to bail out the banks, which are sinking under at least 150 trillion yen ($1.1 trillion) of outstanding loans that are not being repaid. 
 Yasuo Fukuda, the chief cabinet secretary, and several other high-ranking government officials echoed that stance today in separate remarks.
Although investors have talked about the need for additional financing, the comments were the first direct acknowledgment by Mr. Koizumi's inner circle that Japan's banks cannot solve their own problems. With the economy mired in recession, the stock market trading near three-year lows and widespread deflation making it harder for companies to repay loans, Japan's four largest bank groups expect to lose 1.6 trillion yen ($12.15 billion) in the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, 2002. 
Making matters more difficult, the government will end its blanket guarantee on deposits in April next year and will instead limit deposit insurance to 10 million yen ($75,953) in each savings account. In anticipation, depositors are withdrawing money from smaller, weaker banks and moving it to safer institutions. The loss of deposits has driven several banks into bankruptcy.
On Friday, Ishikawa Bank, based in western Japan, filed papers with the Financial Services Agency to start bankruptcy proceedings, according to Kyodo News. Financial regulators and the bank refused to comment.
Though government officials offered no specifics on how much money they were prepared to inject into the banking system or which banks would be eligible for aid, they signaled an awareness that conditions in the industry will deteriorate further in the first quarter of 2002.
"We will not let an economic crisis occur in February or March, and to do this we will take emergency measures when necessary," Mr. Yamasaki said, referring to comments by the prime minister.
The government's tacit admission that the banks need more money to stay afloat comes three years after it funneled 7.5 trillion yen ($56.96 billion) into the country's 15 largest banks to help them meet international capital adequacy standards. The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi has since repaid the aid it received; most others have not.
Although the biggest banks are still solvent as Japanese law defines it, investors and analysts say the economic downturn will expose even larger losses on the banks' balance sheets as more companies are forced into bankruptcy.
"Everyone knows this situation is coming sooner or later," said one banker at a major Japanese lender, referring to the need for another infusion of public money. "The question is really the timing."
Japanese bank shares on average lost 40 percent of their value in 2001, and are now trading at lows not seen since 1984. But the news that the government is mulling another bailout pushed them up 3.5 percent higher on Friday, the last day of trading for the year in Tokyo. The yen also got a lift from the reports, posting its largest gain in a month to settle at 131.24 yen to the dollar.
On the stock market, major gainers for the day included Mizuho Holding and UFJ Holding, two banking groups believed to be especially in need of aid because of their exposure to some of Japan's most troubled companies. The four major banking groups, including Mizuho and UFJ, have promised to write off $44 billion in nonperforming loans this fiscal year, but additional large-scale failures could drive that amount higher, analysts said.
The banks also face losses stemming from their stock portfolios, which have fallen in value along with the broader market and offer little scope for offsetting lending losses, as they commonly have done in the past. New accounting rules forcing the banks to carry stocks on their books at their current market value, not their original purchase price, have further eroded the portfolios' value. In all, the banks are likely to lose $25 billion on their stock holdings, according to bank analysts.
At the same time, the largest banking groups -- products of mergers planned two years ago -- are struggling to integrate their operations, another financial burden. Estimates of the amount of public money that will be needed to prop up the banks this time range from 5 trillion to 10 trillion yen ($39 billion to $78 billion).
Mr. Koizumi, who is pushing a program of government austerity and reduced regulation, has been reluctant to say that another bank bailout is needed. But the economic slump is forcing his hand.
On Thursday, the government said the country's unemployment rate, already at postwar highs, rose to 5.5 percent in November while consumer prices fell 0.8 percent. Reports earlier this week showed declines in industrial production, retail sales, home starts and construction orders.

PERSON: Edward G. Jordan 

HEADLINE: Edward Jordan, Chief of Conrail, Dies at 72 

BYLINE:  By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 

 BODY:
Edward G. Jordan, who helped to lift the remnants of several railroad freight lines out of bankruptcy as the first chairman and chief executive of Conrail, died on Wednesday at his vacation home in Bend, Ore. He was 72.
 Mr. Jordan, who also had a home in the San Francisco area, had suffered from esophageal cancer, his family said. 
 A native of Oakland, Calif., Mr. Jordan graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1951 and earned a master's in business administration from Stanford University. He worked for several corporations, including the Ford Motor Company and Procter & Gamble.
He was a Los Angeles insurance executive when President Gerald R. Ford selected him in 1974 to be president of the United States Railway Association, the federal agency formed to develop a plan to take over most properties of ailing freight carriers in the Northeast and the Midwest.
After he had been president of the association for 17 months, its board picked him in mid-1975 to head the new line created by the association: the Consolidated Rail Corporation, known as Conrail. Although he had no experience with railroads, Mr. Jordan was confident he could do what earlier train executives could not. His credo was, the fewer managers, the better.
"One of the real problems with American industry, in large organizations such as the railroads," he said at the time, "is that you get such incredible depth in management that the nature of a real problem and the man dealing with it never gets to the decision maker."
But Mr. Jordan was battling more than management problems, however intractable they may have been; he was also up against the tide of history. For much of the 19th century, there were scores of thriving railroad freight lines. But by the middle of the 20th century, there were only six: the Penn Central, the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the Erie Lackawanna, the Lehigh and Hudson River, the Lehigh Valley and the Reading.
Buffeted by competition from trucks using the Interstate highway system, hobbled by federal requirements to run money-losing passenger service, the six railroads deferred maintenance on trains and tracks. As their service deteriorated, more freight business went to the trucks in what seemed to be a death spiral for the rail lines.
One by one, the six lines entered bankruptcy in the early 1970's, weakening a national economy already in recession. The federal government responded by creating Conrail and appropriating money to rebuild tracks, locomotives and freight cars. Congress also loosened some regulations, making it easier for trains to compete with trucks, and created Amtrak to take over intercity passenger service from the freight railroads.
Mr. Jordan confidently predicted a quick turnaround, with engines in mint condition hauling more freight for more customers on smoother tracks. But despite his efforts to modernize the operation and bring costs under control, Conrail ran at a loss and was troubled by problems and complaints for many months. Mr. Jordan and other Conrail executives said that the equipment they had inherited was even worse than they had expected and that harsh winter weather and a prolonged coal strike had made things worse.
In 1980, after Conrail had finally recorded two consecutive profitable quarters, Mr. Jordan resigned. He was dean of the Cornell University business school for nine months, then for several years was president of the American College, in Bryn Mawr, Pa., which provides instruction to insurance and financial services professionals. He also sat on the boards of several corporations.
He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Nancy; two daughters, Susan Thomas of Accra, Ghana, and Kathryn Ragan of Fair Oaks, Calif.; two sons, Jonathan, of Rohnert Park, Calif., and Christopher, of Lake Oswego, Ore.; and 11 grandchildren.
In 1981, Conrail had its first profitable year and no longer required federal subsidies. On March 26, 1987, the government's 85 percent share of the corporation was sold to private investors for $1.65 billion, then the largest stock offering in Wall Street history, a transaction that completed one of the more successful federal bailouts. (The remaining 15 percent of the railroad was owned by concurrent and former Conrail employees.)
In 1997, Conrail was bought by the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation in a deal worth more than $10 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward G. Jordan (1980)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Arabs, Spurred On By Inquiry, Set Museum 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. 

 BODY:
The nation's first Arab-American museum will be built in a gutted and leaking furniture store in this city, known both as home to the Ford Motor Company and the most concentrated community of Arab-Americans. 
 Though the museum project has been under way for more than a year -- and will not be completed for several years -- the sense of purpose among its organizers has been elevated since Sept. 11. 
 "This is a real watershed event for us and we'd better try to capture it," said Ismael Ahmed, executive director of the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services, known as Access. The group, which is organizing the museum, provides a host of social services to Arab-Americans in Dearborn and nearby Detroit. 
Mr. Ahmed says the domestic terror investigation and its focus on people of Arab descent should be reflected in the museum. That inquiry has included interviews with people here on recently issued visas from Middle Eastern countries. 
"We've moved from what was an investigation of a crime to creating a suspect class," Mr. Ahmed said. "I think we should start documenting this." 
There is time to mull over how to do that. Last year, Access bought the 36,000-square-foot, three-story building for $750,000, but it does not plan to open the museum until 2004, after an $8 million to $10 million fund-raising campaign. 
At present, the building is a dusty space littered with cabinets, woodpiles and a few fluorescent lights casting long pockets of shadow. Access has considered building the museum for years, but has always seen the immediate social services needs of immigrants as its top priority. 
"We realized that every 10 years we have a new wave of refugees so we can't keep putting it off," said Anan Ameri, the group's cultural director. "I'm just sorry that we weren't closer to opening by Sept. 11." 
Cultural officials from around the country met here recently for a planning session sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities. 
One of the participants was Irene Hirano, the executive director of the Japanese-American National Museum in Los Angeles. She says that the Arab-American museum can serve as both a resource for the community itself and a window for other Americans. 
"It can be a positive byproduct of a terrible time," Ms. Hirano said. "Current events spotlight this as an important community that we need to know more about."
The Japanese-American museum was created largely through the efforts of both Japanese-American veterans of World War II and citizens who were put in internment camps. Both groups were interviewed when the museum was being developed in the 1980's and early 1990's. But these people were "looking back 50, 60 years and interpreting events they remembered," said Ms. Hirano, noting the Arab-American museum has a more immediate opportunity. 
"Recording the first-person perspective -- the fear, the uncertainty, the questions that are being asked of people -- I think the current feeling is that there is an important opportunity to capture that," she said. 
But how big a role Sept. 11 will play in the museum is unresolved. 
"When writing the history of a community in a museum, the question is whether to highlight these events or hide them, or say this is just part of what has happened to the community," said Michael Suleiman, a political science professor at Kansas State University. "My own preference is that there isn't too much politics, but you can't talk about a community and leave out the challenges."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anan Ameri is cultural director of a group that is working to develop an Arab-American museum in a former furniture store in Dearborn, Mich. (Jim West for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
OPEC to Cut Back Production By 6.5% for at Least 6 Months

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 28 

 BODY:
Hoping to prevent the global economic slowdown from further eroding world oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries finalized an agreement today to cut back oil production by 6.5 percent, or 1.5 million barrels a day, for at least six months starting Jan. 1.
 The decision, made at an emergency meeting of OPEC ministers here, followed a pledge by non-OPEC oil producers -- principally Russia, Norway and Mexico -- to reduce their exports by 462,500 barrels a day. OPEC officials prompted the non-OPEC nations to act using barely veiled threats of a price war. 
 Oil prices had been rising in recent weeks in anticipation of the action by OPEC, and did not move much in reaction today: the benchmark price for crude fell slightly, to $20.41 a barrel. 
OPEC's total daily production is now scheduled to reach its lowest level in 10 years, but oil prices remain well below OPEC's target bands set in 1999 of around $24 to $31 a barrel, depending on grade. Informally, OPEC now hopes for prices in the $20 to $25 range.
"The first objective is to stop the fall," said Ali Rodriguez, OPEC's secretary general. "We'll see some recovery in coming days, but the main recovery will be in the second half of next year."
In the short term, oil experts do not expect OPEC's production cuts to have a significant impact on the cost of heating oil or gasoline at the pump in the United States. "I don't think this will cause a major spike in prices," said Thomas Bentz, senior energy analyst for BNP Paribas in New York. "Prices will go a little higher, but we're not looking at a major rally."
One immediate variable may be the winter weather in the United States, which so far has been mild. More significant, though, is the impact of the global economy on demand for oil.
"The demand situation is difficult," said John Kilduff, senior vice president at Fimat USA Inc., the commodities trading arm of Societe Generale. "With the United States, Japan and Germany in contraction, if not in recession, the forecast is for lower oil prices."
Having already met seven times this year, OPEC ministers today agreed to another conference, on March 15 in Vienna, to review the impact of the new cuts. Mr. Rodriguez refused to speculate on whether further cuts were likely then, although he noted that global demand for oil usually falls in the second quarter of every year.
Analysts said it remained to be seen how closely both OPEC and non-OPEC producers would comply with the announced cutbacks. "Compliance by OPEC members is voluntary," Mr. Rodriguez said. "It's a question of honor for countries. Sometimes, for different reasons, compliance is not satisfactory. But we have a mechanism for monitoring the situation."
The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, said he preferred not to cast doubts on the response of other producers. "I think it is much more important to focus on what the leaders of these countries have said, and that's enough indication that they are serious," he said.
OPEC has already cut its production by 3.5 million barrels a day this year, but oil experts believe its members are now producing at least 600,000 barrels a day over quotas, half of that from Nigeria alone.
"OPEC needs to cut 1.5 million, plus the 600,000," said Leonidas Drollas of the London-based Center for Global Energy Studies, referring to the overage. "That is a huge cut that we will never see. So we at the center think we'll get a maximum of one million from OPEC and token amounts from the non-OPEC producers. That will push prices up, but only slowly."
The new agreement, which fixes OPEC's output at 21.7 million barrels a day, came in response to a further slowdown in the world economy after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. "If we maintain current production," Mr. Rodriguez said today, "we can suffer a collapse of prices, for example, to $8 to $10 levels, and this would present very serious problems for producers and consumers alike."
Meeting in Vienna last month, OPEC said it would cut its own production only if non-OPEC members agreed to reduce their exports by 500,000 barrels a day. After lengthy negotiations, Russia and Norway agreed to cuts of 150,000 barrels a day each; Mexico by 100,000 barrels; Oman by 40,000 barrels; and Angola by 22,500 barrels. OPEC decided to go ahead even though those promises fell short of the 500,000-barrel goal.
"It took a lot of effort to obtain cooperation from non-OPEC countries," said the Algerian energy and mines minister, Chakib Khelil, who holds the rotating presidency of OPEC through Dec. 31. "It was a long process that will have a very important effect on price stability."
Analysts remain skeptical that Russia will comply fully with its pledge. Russia's initial response to OPEC's request for a 200,000-barrel-a-day cut was a counteroffer of just 30,000. After a war of words with Saudi Arabia, it eventually agreed to a cut of 150,000 barrels a day for three months. But Russia is continuing a major push to find new markets for its oil exports.
"The Russian government has given its word, but the Russian companies are now privatized and have no incentive to cut production," Mr. Drollas said. "They have made investments and, by cutting production, they will not recover their investment. They can promise a cut in exports, but exports are always down at this time of the year because of high domestic demand."
Mr. Rodriguez said he would travel to Moscow early next year to try to reinforce Russia's commitment.
Stable oil prices are in everyone's interest, he said. "For many industrialized nations, the revenue from oil taxation is a major part of their budgets," he said. "Oil is not just a question of the stability of oil producers."
Even a modest rise in prices, though, would impede global economic recovery, some analysts believe. "I think Mexico, Norway and even Russia see the benefits of lower prices for the world economy in the short run," Mr. Kilduff said. "But for OPEC producers, a drop in oil revenue hurts them. Venezuela and some Middle East governments are in trouble and are interested in higher prices."
Mr. Drollas was more pessimistic. "Prices will rise, but there will be repercussions," he said, "because it will make the world economy grow at a slower rate, it will destabilize oil prices and encourage non-OPEC countries to push up production. OPEC countries are harming themselves in the mid term, but they only care about the short term."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Rise in Consumer Confidence Helps to Push Up Shares

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
As it approached the end of its second consecutive down year, Wall Street remained positive yesterday as stocks managed some slim gains in response to positive economic news and managed to offset some typical year-end tax selling.
 The Dow Jones industrial average also reached its highest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. 
 The market got a big lift when the Conference Board reported its consumer confidence index rose to 93.7 from 84.9 in November. Meanwhile, sales of new homes soared 6.4 percent in November, the largest increase in nearly a year, according to the Commerce Department. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.68 points, to close at 10,136.99. It was the Dow's best close since the terrorist attacks, which caused the blue chips to drop to a yearly low of 8,235.81 on Sept. 21. The Dow also has gained 95 points in the previous two sessions.
The broader market was also higher. The Nasdaq composite index gained 10.84 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,987.26, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 3.89 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,161.02.
Investors were also heartened by a report on orders of durable goods. Although orders to the nation's factories fell 4.8 percent in November, mainly because of a big drop in demand for military airplanes, demand rose for many other big-ticket items, including computers, cars and industrial machinery.
"To me, the market's responding to the fundamentals," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers. "There's been some positive earnings news, some positive guidance, and today you had a nice jump in consumer confidence. That's all good for stocks."
While the market's mood was upbeat, some investors sold stocks to take tax losses for 2001, a yearly occurrence and particularly predictable in years when the market falls.
"You are down to the crunch time of those who are left to take some tax losses," said Matt Brown, head of equity management at Wilmington Trust. "It makes sense for taxable investors, and when you have had back-to-back down years, you have to expect some year-end tax-loss selling."
Yesterday's gainers were mostly concentrated in technology sectors, which many investors expect will lead the market higher next year. Broadcom rose 95 cents, to $43, while PMC-Sierra gained 93 cents, to $22.78.
Yahoo climbed 53 cents, to $18.30, on a fourth-quarter revenue upgrade by a Merrill Lynch analyst, Henry Blodget. Mr. Blodget estimated the Internet portal would post revenue of $175 million, above Wall Street's forecast of $168 million.
Blue chips were more mixed. American Express rose $1.05, to $36.05, but Procter & Gamble fell 64 cents, to $79.51. General Motors gained 95 cents, to $48.92, while Coca-Cola declined 77 cents, to $47.17.
Oil stocks were slightly higher after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries confirmed that it would slash 1.5 million barrels a day from its daily crude production to firm up sagging oil prices. The cuts, a 6 percent reduction, will begin Jan. 1, and last at least six months. Conoco rose 13 cents, to $28.38, while ChevronTexaco also gained 13 cents, to close at $90.44.
Another reason for yesterday's gains was the so-called Santa Claus rally, an annual occurrence between Christmas and New Year's when stocks move higher as investors grow hopeful about the year ahead and money managers adjust portfolios, picking up stocks that have reached bargain prices.
With one more trading session left in 2001, the major indexes are still showing significant losses for the year. The Dow is off 6.02 percent, while the S.& P. 500 is down 12.06 percent. The Nasdaq, which skidded early in the year on the continuing shake-out in high-technology companies, is off 19.56 percent.
Treasury bond prices slipped yesterday. The 10-year Treasury note fell 10/32 , to a price of 99 8/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.10 percent from 5.08 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 30/32 , to 97 22/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.54 percent from 5.48 percent.

HEADLINE: Positive Reports Hint at Swift Recovery 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
A flurry of unexpectedly positive reports hinted yesterday that the economy might make a swift exit from recession.
 The latest figures on home sales, consumer confidence, orders for durable goods and claims for unemployment benefits all came in better than anticipated. Despite the pleasant surprises, economists still warned of a feeble recovery next year. 
 Consumer confidence, as measured by the Conference Board, made its biggest one-month surge in almost four years. The business group's index, which is based on consumers' satisfaction with business and employment conditions, jumped to 93.7 in December, from a revised level of 84.9 last month. The reading suggests that consumers are almost as confident as they were in August. 
Analysts from several Wall Street research groups had forecast a decline in consumer confidence rather than a gain. Kevin Logan, the senior United States economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, credited the rise to Americans' resilience from the terrorist attacks.
"There was a lot of fear that the shock could cause consumers to go into hibernation" and the recession would deepen, he said. "The shock of Sept. 11 and all those events seems to have faded more quickly than any of us thought a short time ago."
Consumers may also have begun to feel more secure about their jobs. First-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by only 7,000 last week, just half of Wall Street's consensus prediction, to 392,000, the Labor Department said. New weekly claims have dropped by more than 100,000 from their peak in October, though 3.7 million people are still receiving benefits.
Plenty of consumers were buying houses last month. Sales of existing homes rose 0.6 percent in November, to an annual pace of 5.21 million units from a revised 5.18 million rate in October, the National Association of Realtors said. New home sales jumped 6.4 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported.
Behind the uptick were good weather and low mortgage rates. Thirty-year mortgage rates fell to 6.45 percent early last month, according to a survey by Freddie Mac.
The figures for new home sales were the most notable, said Robert E. Mellman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, because new houses represent "real activity in the economy."
The Commerce Department's report of a 1.1 percent increase in orders for durable goods, excluding transportation items, also impressed Mr. Mellman. "In the durable goods reports, it really looked like core capital goods were stabilizing, and high-tech orders were stronger than they were three months ago, which we took to be pretty significant," he said.
The durable goods report, excluding transportation, followed an increase of 2.9 percent in October, the first back-to-back gains in almost two years. But overall orders fell 4.8 percent in November.
Both Mr. Logan and Mr. Mellman said they still expected the economy to expand at a slow pace next year, perhaps only 2 percent. Economic growth can come from spending by households, companies and the government or from improving the nation's trade balance. Yet none of these areas look particularly strong, Mr. Logan said.
"The recession was pretty much caused by a very sharp drop in business investment spending," Mr. Logan said. "Given that the last two months have seen a pickup in orders for capital goods, that suggests that we might be coming to the end of that process." But although businesses' spending will stabilize, Mr. Logan said, investment is unlikely to reach the levels of the late 1990's.
Do not look to consumers for extraordinary buying, either, Mr. Mellman said. Consumer spending has remained fairly strong all year, he said, and he predicted it would probably not rise enough to ensure a strong recovery.
After previous recessions, he recalled, the economy grew by 5 or 6 percent -- well above average -- in the first two years of recovery. "Usually that was because consumer spending on durable goods and autos got clobbered, and they came back at double-digit strength." This time, Mr. Mellman said, "they haven't got clobbered, so they can't come back."
Though military purchasing has been higher than anticipated because of the war in Afghanistan, the Republican-controlled House has refused to include much new spending in any economic stimulus package.
The trade balance faces perhaps the worst prognosis. "The rest of the world is in recession, or at least growing at a sub-par rate," Mr. Logan said. "Exports are likely to be very weak."
Adding to the problem, the dollar has lately shown unusual strength against Japan's currency. Its value has risen steadily, to 131.24 yen from 116 yen, in the last three months. Last year, when the rate averaged 108 yen, Japan exported $2 worth of goods to the United States for every $1 it imported from America. The change in the exchange rate is likely to worsen the ratio.
A rebound in oil prices, which usually shows up as an increase in imports, may also be on the horizon. Yesterday, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries confirmed a production cut of 1.5 million barrels a day, and other major producers said they would also curtail production.
"They're looking to stabilize prices," said Ann-Louise Hittle, senior director at Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "If that's their goal, then they will achieve it."
But Ms. Hittle added that prices were unlikely to rise enough to do the economy much harm. She said that West Texas Intermediate crude oil, an industry benchmark, would probably sell for $21 a barrel in the next few months. "That would not have a large depressing effect on the economy, because that's still lower than where we were for almost all of 2001," she said.
Moreover, Mr. Logan said, it's never too early to get excited about promising numbers. "The data's always telling you something about the direction of the economy at the margin," he said. "Even if it's minor changes, it's giving you some sign."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joshua Sanchez, 7, photographs his brother, Nathan, 4, in a Best Buy store in East Palo Alto, Calif., while their father, Raul Sanchez, looks on. Spending by such consumers is important to an economic recovery. (Associated Press)(pg. HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Dow Reaches Highest Point Since Sept. 11 Attacks
With only one more trading session left in 2001, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at its highest level since the terrorist attacks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.68 points, to close at 10,136.99 -- the Dow's best close since the terror attacks, which caused the blue chips to drop to a yearly low of 8,235.81 on Sept. 21.
 The broader market was also higher. The Nasdaq composite index gained 10.84 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,987.26, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 3.89 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,161.02. Share prices rose in response to some hopeful signs on the economy, including a big increase in consumer confidence last month. Also, sales of new homes soared 6.4 percent in November, the largest increase in nearly a year, according to the Commerce Department. C4. 

TV Forms Bond With Bereaved
A handful of people whose loved ones were killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks have been drawn into a mutually beneficial relationship with television, feeding the 24-hour news networks' need for fresh material about the attacks and their need to keep the coverage focused on the victims and their families. B1 .

N.Y. Lures Different Type of Tourist
Those who market New York City as a tourist destination are facing a new sort of visitor: those here mostly, sometimes only, to view the ruins of the World Trade Center. These more somber tourists are in little mood to spend, and the city does not want to market itself around the tragedy. B1.

Xerox Receives Additional Money
Xerox said it had received $340 million in financing from GE Capital, secured by part of the company's receivables. The funds are in addition to the $835 million Xerox received last month from GE Capital, with more financing expected in February. C4.

Japan May Help Banks, Again
The government of Japan said that it was considering injecting more cash into the banking system to help it address its burden of bad debt, which totals $1 trillion. The comments, by Taku Yamasaki, secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, were the first direct acknowledgment from Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's inner circle that the industry cannot solve its problems alone. C3.

Deutsche Bank to Cut 2,100 Jobs
Deutsche Bank said that it would eliminate 2,100 jobs in its corporate and investment-banking unit, part of a 10 percent reduction in jobs this year. About 900 workers in the United States would be laid off. C3.

French Unemployment Reaches 9%
Joblessness in France rose 0.1 percent, to 9 percent last month, the seventh consecutive monthly rise, the government said. The finance minister, Laurent Fabius, said France was facing the effects of the slowing economies of Germany, Japan and the United States. C2.

Ernst & Young Settles Investor Suit
Ernst & Young's Bermuda affiliate has settled with investors who brought a $400 million suit against Manhattan Investment Fund Ltd., Michael Berger's bankrupt hedge fund. C3.

Giuliani Near Deal on Stadiums
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that the city has entered into tentative deals with the New York Yankees and the New York Mets to build new stadiums for $1.6 billion in the backyards of the team's current ball parks. A1.

Financial Markets Open Monday
Financial markets in the United States will be open on Monday, but will be closed on Tuesday, New Year's Day.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TOURISM; 
Pilgrimage to New York City: Paying Respects and Spending Little

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
Those who market New York City to tourists face a delicate problem. The city is desperate to attract visitors to spend money, especially downtown, where businesses have been suffering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But the biggest tourist attraction downtown, and probably in the city, is the site of that attack. And the thousands of people who visit it every day are proving to be tourists of a sort that the city has never seen before.
 "It's a sad tourist," explained Rachelle Friedman, co-owner of J & R Music and Computer World, across Broadway on Park Row not far from the disaster site. "It's not the same kind of tourist at all." 
 They are not exactly happy to be here, and many say they are not interested in splurging on shopping and entertainment for themselves -- especially within blocks of such an unnerving landscape. 
Officials in the tourism industry are unnerved, too. They know the disaster site is the sole reason many of these people visit New York, but they dare not market the city that way. Advertisers are squeamish about making pitches to the growing numbers of tourists at ground zero, urging them to spend money once they are here. Many businesses are reluctant to be seen as profiting from the tourists' presence, and, indirectly, the tragedy of the terrorist attack.
Granted, even the thriftiest visitors need to eat and sleep, so they must be spending money somewhere in the city. But businesses near the site say they have seen no big increases in sales, and tourism officials are convinced that the ground zero tourists represent an untapped market.
Apart from estimates, it is unclear how large this market is. Hard figures are hard to come by, because there is no entry point to the area around ground zero in which to count visitors. There are no turnstiles, tour guides or information booths. 
The closest thing might be St. Paul's Chapel, where Trevor Bleedorn, a volunteer, hands out colored markers to people who want to sign memorial sheets hung along a stretch of Broadway. He estimates that he talks to 2,000 people a day, and that thousands more pass by silently.
The perimeter snakes a jagged path around 16 acres. Because of the sprawling nature of the site, keeping an official tally of visitors would be impossible, according to the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management, the New York City Police Department and NYC & Company, the city's tourist and convention bureau.
Simply put, "they're coming in from too many different directions," said Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of NYC & Company.
Some officials guess that to date, millions of people have visited the site, and they say there is enough anecdotal evidence to support the claim. The World Trade Center towers were the top tourist destination downtown before the attack, and Ms. Nicholas and others say the place where they fell retains that status.
"I would venture to say that would be the case," she said, "even without having any way of counting the people."
All it takes is a look at the throngs who gather around the perimeter every day -- often to the dismay of residents trying to put their lives back together. People spill off the sidewalks and into the street. There are church groups in matching jackets, and families who show up with grandparents, cousins and toddlers. And always, there are the individuals, standing alone, crying, thinking, filming. Moving quickly through the main gathering spots on Broadway is close to impossible.
For Lower Manhattan businesses with sales down as much as 30 percent from what is normal for this time of year, the opportunity to reach such an untapped market might seem irresistible. Still, many have resisted. 
David Morrow, the assistant general manager of the South Street Seaport, has not seen sales completely rebound since the attacks. But he agreed that reaching out to the ground zero tourists would be in bad taste. It is as if they are close, but untouchable. 
"I'm not sure we've seen much activity from them," he said, "not that we expect to or want to try to. We respect very much that they're here to offer condolences."
Businesses directly on the path to ground zero have not fared much better.
Mitchell Graber, the manager of Edwardo Galleries Ltd., a store on Broadway near Beekman Street that sells figurines, sees the crowds of people passing, cameras around their necks, guidebooks in hand, "but they keep passing," he said. "They don't stop and buy anything."
Even among some businesses, like tour organizers, that have stood to gain from the upswing in visits to ground zero, there has been a tendency to shy away from profiteering.
"I have trouble with the idea of making money off the tragedy," said John Pascale, the owner of NYC Tours, who added that he had refused most requests for organized excursions exclusively to ground zero. He does, however, include the site as part of a standard tour of downtown. 
"Initially I was weirded out when people started requesting to see it at all," he said. "I thought it was sort of gross. But I have been overwhelmed by people's reverence and respect for the site. Certainly it is now part of the city's history and I need to show it, just like Grant's Tomb. In that way I think we have a responsibility, but only in the context of a tour of the city. I also think people need to see the rest of the city coping and surviving." 
The city continues to cry out for tourists to fill theaters and restaurants in nationwide commercials and campaigns, but the disaster site -- despite its popularity -- is not something anyone will see used in that effort, at least for now.
"It's not appropriate; it's still too tender a situation to discuss in terms of marketing," Ms. Nicholas said. "I think the natural course is that people will flock down there to ground zero. That's a bold leap then to market it. I wouldn't feel comfortable doing that."
In an unlikely twist, the owners of some small businesses in the area have actually begun to complain about the high number of tourists.
"This whole area is getting too much attention," said David Cohen, who owns Chelsea Jeans, a clothing store on Broadway near the corner of Fulton Street. A glass-enclosed corner of the store offers a grim reminder of Sept. 11, preserving stacks of clothing covered in ash and debris. "My manager complains about the tourists because they block the store and customers find it hard to get access. The tourists, they look, take a picture and leave."
Then Mr. Cohen sighed. "We're learning to adapt." 
Tourists roaming through residential streets, mainly in Battery Park City, angling for the best view, have drawn the ire of many residents, who view them as intruders.
The number of ground zero tourists in Battery Park City became an issue in the design and placement of a temporary pedestrian bridge crossing West Street in the neighborhood. Residents were concerned that if it offered too good a view, it would serve less as pedestrian bridge than as a viewing platform.
"It's a big issue, and many people are concerned because tourists make it very hard for the community to function as a living community, especially for children," said Jane Bock, a lawyer who lives in Battery Park City. "Many people would like the tourists and viewing stands to stay in commercial areas. I think there must be a solution that fits everyone's needs."
For now, the city's attempt at giving structure and organization to the crowds at ground zero is in the form of four proposed viewing platforms around the disaster site.
The first temporary structure is on Fulton Street, between Church Street and Broadway, just south of St. Paul's Chapel, which may open to the public as early as today. The entire structure will support more than 1,000 visitors at a time.
The platforms will make it easier to see what is going on at the site and to take pictures as the work moves deep into the ground. Without the height the platforms offer, it is hard to see anything. But people take pictures anyway.
"I feel like it's disrespectful, like I shouldn't be taking pictures," said Megan Coffey, a former New Yorker who now lives in St. Louis. She was visiting the site on Christmas Eve with her husband, Sean, wondering if she should "just absorb" it. 
"I don't want to treat it like it's a tourist site," she said, pausing to think, looking around, "but I guess that's what it is."
