HEADLINE: ''Bons Mots? You Decide''

 BODY:
THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness.

Were you paying attention? Try this test.

PART 1
Who spoke these words and about what?

1) ''It is not good news for America.''

2) ''She has the full support of the board and will continue to lead the company through these challenging times.''

3) ''The more I see about this deal, the less I like it.''

4) ''I was smiling going in, because how often in your life do you and your company have an opportunity to make a difference?''

5) ''I have no desire to be next at bat.''

6) ''We are on the side of angels.''

7) ''This is an industrial policy designed for shareholders of the winning companies.''

8) ''It would be a good time for all parties to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out.''

9) ''Today, America goes back to business.''

10) ''What keeps me up at night is doing my own e-mail. I wouldn't say that anything keeps me up at night worrying.''

PART 2

What were these people talking about when they spoke these words?

1) In April, a senior Bush administration official said, ''It would be like having a cheeseburger without cheese.''

2) In March, Dick Conway, an economist in Seattle, said, ''Well, it has made us forget the earthquake all of a sudden.''

3) In September, Alexander Danielides, a junior at the Bronx High School of Science, said, ''The Vietnam generation is a little more cautious than we would be.''

4) In April, Ira Kay, a consultant at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said, ''It's the gift that keeps on giving.''

5) In June, Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, said: ''It is one thing for one shark to eat another. It is quite another for the shark to eat the minnows.''

6) In April, Elliot Schrage, senior vice president for global affairs at Gap Inc., said: ''We are not the all-powerful Oz that rules over what happens in every factory. Do we have leverage? Yes. Is it as great as our critics believe? Not by a long shot.''

7) In March, Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, said, ''I've decided to take this issue off the table.''

8) In December, Thomas R. Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, said, ''This was another big move in this continuing clash of titans.''

9) In January, Kathleen Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for Lucent Technologies, said, ''Henry decided it was not the best use of our assets.''

10) In September, Fay Weldon said: ''I thought: 'Oh no, dear me, I am a literary author. You can't do this kind of thing; my name will be mud forever.' But then after a while I thought: 'I don't care. Let it be mud.' ''

''Answers to the Quiz''

PART 1

1) President Bush, commenting on the October unemployment rate.

2) Stanley Silverstein, general counsel of Warnaco, speaking about its chief executive, Linda J. Wachner, as Warnaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June. Mrs. Wachner was fired in November.

3) Walter B. Hewlett, declaring his opposition to Hewlett-Packard's plan to merge with Compaq Computer.

4) Helge H. Wehmeier, chief executive of Bayer's American operations, referring to the company's agreement to sell its anthrax medicine, Cipro, to the government at a discounted price.

5) Robert W. Pittman, chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, after his peer and rival, Richard D. Parsons, was named to succeed Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive, next May.

6) Jeffrey K. Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, in March, dismissing critics who saw Enron as a profiteer in California's energy crisis.

7) Robert B. Reich, former secretary of labor, criticizing the legislation passed to bail out the nation's airlines after the terrorist attacks.

8) Bill Gates, in June, commenting after a federal appeals court threw out a lower court's order that Microsoft be broken up.

9) Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, reopening the exchange after it was closed for four days as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks.

10) Gordon E. Moore, co-founder of Fairchild Semiconductor and the Intel Corporation, upon his retirement last spring, discussing the widespread use of personal computers.

PART 2

1) He was referring in general to the demonstrations that accompany world trade talks (in this case, the Summit of the Americas that took place in Quebec) and specifically to the tear gas that authorities use to break up the protests.

2) He was commenting on the announcement that Boeing was moving its corporate headquarters out of Seattle after decades as the mainstay of the region's economy.

3) This teenage investor was talking, a few days after Sept. 11, about the willingness of his generation to stay in the stock market when conventional wisdom suggested otherwise.

4) He was describing reload stock options, a form of compensation that gives executives who exercise them both a share of stock and a new option.

5) He was questioning Wall Street's erosion of ethical conduct at a Congressional hearing on conflicts among brokerage firm research analysts.

6) He was commenting on the difficulties of trying to improve conditions in foreign factories.

7) He was announcing his decision to sell about $100 million worth of Alcoa stock and options that he had planned to keep.

8) He was referring to the battle over broadband between AOL Time Warner and Microsoft after Comcast outbid rivals for AT&T's cable television business.

9) She was discussing the decision by Henry B. Schacht, the interim chief executive of Lucent, to sell the Hamilton Farm Golf Club, an expensive white elephant that the company developed before its fortunes plunged, causing huge layoffs, write-offs and restructuring.

10) She was commenting on her new novel, ''The Bulgari Connection,'' for which Bulgari, the Italian jewelry company, paid her an undisclosed amount in return for a prominent place in the book.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
The Deadly Importance of Making Distinctions

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
ARCHITECTURE is a protagonist in the public realm. Often, it is called upon to enact the primal drama of loss and compensation. When the loss is great, compensation is often visualized in terms of civic grandeur. The losses this year were incalculable.
 The attacks on the World Trade Center were felt across many dimensions of space and time: from the neighborhood to the globe; from the televised real-time moment to history's multiple points of view. The attacks' target was modern civilization. Civilization fought back, not just with weapons and slogans, but with the capacity to contemplate its highly complex self. The attack drove home the importance of discriminating between modern, progressive outlooks and oppressive, feudal ones. 
 Discrimination was the big story in architecture this year. This matters; that doesn't. This is useful; that's a waste of time. This feeds into the future; that is stuck in a dead end. Clarity itself came into sharper focus. This is an idea; that is a box of orange Jell-O. This is architecture; that is etc., etc., etc. Such distinctions are not easily made, but they are worth the time and effort it takes to form cultivated opinions.
The need for more penetrating analytic tools became urgent before Sept. 11. In March, a team of real estate developers organized a competition to select the architects to plan an office and residential complex for the so-called Con Ed site, a nine-acre property on the East River waterfront just south of the United Nations headquarters. Announced with great fanfare as an international search for architects of major talent, the competition invited submissions from three winners of the Pritzker Architecture Prize and other noted figures on the world stage. It ended with the choice of two local firms of lesser distinction.
During the selection process, Richard Meier and Peter Eisenman withdrew after they were asked to play a subordinate role as consulting architects. Rodolfo Machado and Jorge Silvetti, Boston architects who had agreed to participate as consultants, later resigned as well.
In the past, episodes like this tended to fall beneath a critic's radar. On the premise that all architects are created equal, it is often assumed that only fully realized designs should be subject to critical appraisal. Actually, all phases of the building art -- including zoning, economics, politics, context, history, aesthetics and ideology -- fall within the traditional scope of critical interpretation.
To these factors must be added the inflated and inflationary pressures of professional marketing. Architects operate in an increasingly competitive market and in an aesthetically eclectic period that is not guided by educated consensus on matters of taste or style. The profession benefits from the myth that its members cannot be qualitatively ranked.
The Con Ed competition illustrated H. H. Richardson's belief that the first law of American architecture was to "get the job." The developers didn't want to pay for architecture. But Richardson never suggested that marketing should be the only law. Concepts other than social Darwinism should make an appearance from time to time. Architects can't buck the market system and shouldn't try. They should use the system as an intellectual as well as an economic framework. They should make vivid architecture from the system's inherent contradictions.
"How can you criticize people for doing what they think is right?" I was asked that question, in one form or another, many times this past year. My routine answer: "I read a lot of history."
In the weeks following the attacks, the Con Ed competition came to seem like a warm-up for the full-dress performance of an anxious status quo. The city's leading corporate architecture firms linked arms with their developer-clients to devise strategies for turning a catastrophe into a business opportunity. An ad hoc group, the N.Y.C. Rebuild Infrastructure Task Force, convinced its members that they had earned the moral stature of firefighters, medical personnel, emergency volunteers. Onlookers were less persuaded.
The attacks required the entire city to draw on its deepest resources of historical awareness and imaginative reflection. But it did not entitle architects to assume that they had been awarded a special franchise to answer the call. Survivors, philosophers, firefighters, shopkeepers, musicians, window dressers and dentists have at least as much right to the public's attention. All of us have had to fight feelings of helplessness.
Quite a few projects did deserve the limelight this year. In New York, they included the American Museum of Folk Art, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien; the Prada store in SoHo, by Rem Koolhaas; the Neue Galerie New York, by Annabelle Selldorf; and the Melrose Community Center in the Bronx, by Diana Agrest and Mario Gandelsonas. There were also promising designs for future projects by Norman Foster, Jean Nouvel, Gwathmey & Siegel and Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio. Preservationists rallied to prevent the disfigurement of Eero Saarinen's T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy Airport.
Out of town, there were openings of new buildings by Mr. Koolhaas, Tadao Ando, Santiago Calatrava and Rafael Vinoly. I wasn't able to cover most of those works. The unfolding of events in the politics of New York architecture was a story I couldn't overlook. This story was not, in any case, so divorced from the aesthetics of architecture as you might think. The political story went far toward explaining why the city's architecture so seldom registers on the artistic scale.
From my window at home, I have a good view of the Secretariat building of the United Nations. It was completed just half a century ago. It was my beacon on the skyline throughout 2001.
This was a year in which many, including those of us who are not pacifists, decided that world peace wasn't too corny a topic to think about. The architects of the United Nations headquarters were among the heroic figures of a great generation. Like the members of the United Nations, they were not afraid to face the contradictions of their time, particularly those that emerged from conflicts between global and regional perspectives.
Nor were they afraid to be criticized for doing what they believed was right. As they understood it, generating conflict was essential to the development of discrimination. Looking back at contemporary commentary on the United Nations, much of it hostile, you will realize that great architecture seldom reinforces preconceived ideas of normalcy. It parts company with them, and, in the process, reveals conflicts that have long been lurking underground. Such revelations provide the fuel that drives public life forward.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW: MUSIC; 
Of Necessity, Thoughts Turned To Purpose And Relevance

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
THE year in classical music was fraught with organizations everywhere reeling from the national economic downturn. By the summer, the very survival of the respected St. Louis Symphony Orchestra came into question. Even the renowned Chicago Symphony grappled with financial setbacks.
 Then came the horror of Sept. 11. The first reaction of classical-music ensembles and companies, like arts organizations everywhere, was to go through a crisis of relevance. What is the role of music in a newly insecure world? How best to respond to brutality and loss? 
 The New York City Opera had been scheduled to open its season with a new production of Wagner's "Fliegende Hollander" on Sept. 11. Urged by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to get under way as soon as possible for the sake of the city's morale, the City Opera found the inner strength to regroup. Four days later, on a Saturday afternoon, singers, staff members and administrators, led by the company's general director, Paul Kellogg, appeared on the stage of the New York State Theater to sing the national anthem before presenting the new Wagner production. In the evening the company continued as scheduled with, of all things, the director Jonathan Miller's zany take on "The Mikado."
In a way, for me, that was the most meaningful day of music in 2001. By just showing up, let alone performing so valiantly, the company made it safe again -- not physically safe (no New Yorker will ever take that for granted again) but emotionally safe -- to let ourselves enjoy music, to be stirred by Wagner and amused by Gilbert and Sullivan.
As other companies opened their seasons, some decided to alter their programs in memory of the victims of the terrorist attacks. Kurt Masur conducted the New York Philharmonic and the New York Choral Artists in a noble performance of Brahms's "German Requiem" in September. Other organizations thought that the right response was to go on with challenging programs as planned. One such was the Miller Theater at Columbia University, which opened another adventurous season in September with the Absolute Ensemble in a riveting performance of Mark-Anthony Turnage's visceral and grating orchestral work "Blood on the Floor."
Various visiting ensembles struggled with what to perform for their first appearances in New York. Claudio Abbado and the Berlin Philharmonic, in three concerts that opened the Carnegie Hall season in October, decided to replace Mahler, Webern and Wagner with several Beethoven symphonies. The orchestra gave a thematic reasoning for the shift: in a time of chaos, Beethoven provides certitude. Actually, you could argue that Mahler's tormented Seventh Symphony and Webern's haunting Six Pieces for Orchestra might have been even more appropriate. But the Beethoven performances were utterly distinguished.
Of course, the questions of relevance that were forced on classical-music organizations in the aftermath of the attack are the very questions they should be addressing anyway. In this regard, it was particularly dismaying to watch the constituents of Lincoln Center struggle toward some consensus over a major redevelopment plan that remains uncertain. Still, on their own, the individual organizations did memorable work.
Though Mr. Masur has not done enough to introduce new works, especially by American composers, into the Philharmonic's programs, he was in his element in February, conducting the premiere of Hans Werner Henze's impressive Symphony No. 9, scored for orchestra and chorus. The Philharmonic debut of the dynamic young American conductor David Robertson, in a thoughtful program of Wagner, Schoenberg and Beethoven in April, hinted at what might have been had the orchestra acted more boldly in choosing its next music director. That appointment went instead to Lorin Maazel.
At the Metropolitan Opera in the spring, James Levine could do no wrong, it seemed. From the amazing Met orchestra, he elicited remarkable performances of Wagner's "Parsifal," with the tireless Placido Domingo still extraordinary in the title role; Berg's "Lulu," with Christine Schafer as Lulu in an impressive Met debut; and Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos," with Deborah Voigt just wonderful in her signature role.
And as if in answer to the accusation that the Met operates on a lower level when Mr. Levine is not on the podium, two of the company's most stunning productions in years were non-Levine events. In the spring Valery Gergiev, with a brilliant production team brought mostly from the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg, offered a gripping account of Prokofiev's "Gambler." And just this month, two Germans, the conductor Christian Thielemann and the director Herbert Wernicke, in his American debut, collaborated in a musically and dramatically enthralling production of Strauss's long and difficult "Frau Ohne Schatten," with Ms. Voigt surpassing herself as the Empress.
Carnegie Hall was, once again, an exemplar of balanced, innovative and important programming. When Pierre Boulez conducted three concerts with the Vienna Philharmonic in March, his modernist inclinations and the orchestra's time-tested elegance blended fascinatingly in works by Bartok, Stravinsky, Webern, Bruckner and Mahler. The mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli, with the excellent period-instrument ensemble Il Giardino Armonico, offered a revelatory program of little-known arias by Antonio Vivaldi in February. Ms. Bartoli is single-handedly altering the general perception of Vivaldi as a human concerto factory. Daniel Barenboim's three concerts with the Chicago Symphony in October offered some compellingly performed Wagner: lots of it, including Act I of "Die Walkure" and the complete "Tristan und Isolde." For me, the memorable work in those programs was Elliott Carter's engrossing and ingenious new Cello Concerto, written for and performed by Yo-Yo Ma. It was the most exciting new work I heard this year.
The French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, best known for his work in contemporary music, gave the recital of the year at Carnegie Hall this month. In an intelligently fashioned program, Mr. Aimard made striking connections between Berg, Beethoven, Liszt, Debussy and Ligeti. They all emerged, rightly, as radical voices. The young Christopher Taylor deserves special mention for his transfixing performance of Messiaen's "Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jesus," nearly two and a half hours of staggeringly difficult music, at the Miller Theater in February.
A notable appointment this year was Mr. Levine's as the next music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. It makes sense both for the orchestra and for him. But everyone in the business will be watching to see what happens when he takes the helm full-time in 2004, for Mr. Levine extracted, on a two-year trial basis, a potentially important concession from the musicians.
Invoking the simple principle that some works are harder than others, he asked for flexibility in the union-enforced weekly rehearsal schedule. He did not want more total hours, just the ability to add sessions one week in exchange for cutting back in another, depending on the programs. What could be more sensible? But traditionally, unions have resisted any tinkering with their regular workload.
It could be a significant step toward opening up American orchestras to more experimentation and challenge, and in helping these tradition-bound organizations to address questions of mission and relevance that they must ponder, now more than ever.

HEADLINE: OPINION; 
The Gulotta Legacy: His Version

BYLINE:  By THOMAS S. GULOTTA; Thomas S. Gulotta's term as county executive of Nassau County expires on Tuesday.

 BODY:
IT has been a privilege and an honor to serve the residents of Nassau County for the past 14 years. Working with our residents since 1987, we have built upon our strengths and addressed our weaknesses. County property taxes have been controlled, the crime rate has been dramatically cut, unemployment is at an all-time low, commercial vacancy rates are at record lows and residential property values have soared. Today, Nassau County is a far better place to live, work and raise a family than it was in 1987.
 Nassau County is a safer place to live and raise a family. In 1987, 44,465 major crimes were committed in Nassau County. Virtually every year since then, the number of major crimes has steadily declined. Today, major crime in Nassau County has been cut by more than 50 percent and has reached a 25-year low. It should also be noted that despite the increased vehicular traffic since 1987, drunken driving-related deaths have been cut by 44 percent. 
 Our local economy is stronger and much more diverse than it was in 1987. Earlier this year our unemployment rate reached a historic low of 2.3 percent, the lowest in the state and one of the lowest in the nation. Nassau's commercial vacancy rate has been cut to 4.3 percent, the lowest in 10 years, compared with a 6 percent commercial vacancy rate in 1987. The low unemployment and commercial vacancy rates have been achieved despite the creation of thousands of jobs and a dramatic growth in office space.
Between 1987 and 2001, Nassau County-assisted projects resulted in the retention of 25,134 jobs with a payroll of more than $829 million and the creation of 16,386 new jobs with a payroll of $447 million. The transformation of Nassau's economy was not easy, as the early 1990's witnessed tremendous cutbacks in the defense industry on Long Island. While defense technology remains an important component of our economy, our local efforts to diversify have created greater stability for our work force. More than ever, our children have reasonable job opportunities.
Nassau County's property taxes have been kept under control. Despite the fact that 75 percent of Nassau County's budget consists of spiraling mandated costs, the county has successfully cut discretionary spending to levels that have enabled us to consistently cut or freeze the county's portion of property taxes. For instance, by modernizing, streamlining and computerizing we have cut the county's work force by 41.2 percent since 1987 without compromising the high quality of government services our residents receive.
Some have suggested that the failure to increase property taxes contributed to the county's fiscal woes. The property tax is the single greatest burden sustained by many of our residents. As property taxes increase home values decrease, older Americans on fixed incomes are forced to move elsewhere and young couples are prevented from establishing families here. Accordingly, it was our objective to keep money in the pockets of our taxpayers. Any loss of revenue in property taxes would be compensated for by increased revenue in sales taxes.
Unfortunately, as county property taxes were being controlled, property taxes assessed by other taxing entities were increasing. As a result, the taxpayer was realizing minimal positive effect in increased spendable dollars through the county's efforts and sales tax revenues were not compensating for the loss in property tax revenues. Working in a bipartisan fashion with the County Legislature, steps have been implemented that ensure the county's fiscal health.
To preserve our county's natural resources, we enacted the Perpetual Preservation law, designed to protect our parks, green spaces and water recharge basins. Nassau County was the first municipality in our region to adopt a countywide comprehensive water management and conservation program. By accessing federal financing, Nassau County has the largest fleet of natural gas-fueled buses east of the Mississippi. Soon the entire fleet will be retrofitted to natural gas. Stringent anti-graffiti laws and beautification programs have significantly reduced visual pollution.
Our quality of life is enhanced by a network of county parks, where family cultural, educational and athletic activities abound. Today the New York Power and the New York Rough Rider soccer teams call Nassau County their home. The Women's Sports Foundation has relocated to Eisenhower Park, which also serves as the site of the newly constructed aquatic center, the largest indoor aquatic facility in the United States. Coupled with a new sports complex at Mitchel Field, Nassau County has become a major sports mecca in the Northeast, holding major national and international sporting events. Not far from Eisenhower Park you can witness the construction of Museum Row, a series of world-class museums that will serve as a major educational, cultural and tourist attraction in the Northeast. The Cradle of Aviation Museum, the pivotal facility at Museum Row, is scheduled to open this spring.
It is no wonder that national surveys cited in Money magazine, Places Rated Almanac and Forbes magazine have listed Nassau County as one of the best places to live, work and raise a family.
I have always cared deeply about the people who live in our county. While there might have been differing opinions about policies, I have always done my best and have worked tirelessly placing the interests of our residents first. I sincerely hope that our joint efforts have provided the hope and opportunity for our children to share in the same dream that caused many of us and our parents to call Nassau County our home.
I offer a parting piece of advice to the young men and women reading this essay. While you may not get rich through a career in public service, your riches will manifest themselves in other ways -- by realizing that you have made a meaningful difference in other people's lives. For this opportunity, I am grateful and thankful to the residents of Nassau County.

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: 70'S: ABE BEAME, B. 1906 CARROLL O'CONNOR, B. 1924, JOEY RAMONE, B. 1951; 
Those Were the 'Drop Dead' Days

BYLINE:  By Mark Jacobson 

 BODY:
Amid the neoapocalyptic iconography of 1970's urban decay -- the graffiti-strewn IRT car, the South Bronx 2/3 Fort Apache, Gerald Ford telling us to "drop dead" -- Abe Beame, Carroll O'Connor and Joey Ramone form a distinctly outer-borough triptych. In the context of their mutual heydays, the three can be seen as ghosts of New York past, present and what then passed for a (postmodern) future.
 The city's 104th mayor, and probably its shortest, the 5-foot-2 Beame was clearly a man out of time when he was elected at the advanced age of 67. Chosen in 1974 as the gray accountant antidote to the failed patrician extravagance of the Lindsay years, Beame was supposed to know the buck. Yet he wound up presiding over the city's near financial collapse, portrayed on the cover of Time as a Dickensian hobo looking for a handout. 
 It is a cruel twist of fate, Abe Beame as New York's Herbert Hoover. After all, it was people like Beame -- New York's first Jewish mayor -- who had built the city into a great immigrant empire. Arriving at Ellis Island in 1906, he grew up on the Lower East Side as the son of a Eugene V. Debs Socialist, graduated from C.C.N.Y., taught bookkeeping at Richmond Hill High School during the Depression and lived in Crown Heights with his wife, Mary, while unmeteorically working his way through Democratic Party clubhouse politics. Yet, in charge of a metropolis teetering toward ruin, Beame found himself dismantling the dream mechanism that made possible his unlikely rise to power. He fought with unions, raised the transit fare, ended open enrollment at City University and, perhaps most gallingly to Beame himself, engaged in a contest of vicious racial politics in his 1973 runoff with Herman Badillo, then a liberal democrat -- a campaign during which trucks blaring salsa mysteriously appeared in Jewish neighborhoods in the middle of the night.
By most accounts a decent man who was not without his successes (the 1976 Bicentennial celebration among them), Beame was rarely heard complaining about the sea change that drowned his administration. Venting over shifting contemporary conditions was left to cranks like Carroll O'Connor's well-named Archie Bunker, who waged verbal siege warfare with the newer, scarier New York from his pillbox Queens living room. Upwards of 50 million people tuned in to "All in the Family" to hear the Nixon-loving Archie's weekly rages against "woman's lubrication," "birth patrol," "ecrology" and "minororities." For many, Archie's pre-John Rocker screeds, whether taken with the intended Norman Lear satire or not, amounted to bulletins from the urban crisis front. However, to O'Connor, who was born in the Bronx, grew up in Queens and taught in city public schools for years, Archie Bunker was never simply a bigot.
He was "a human being who is also a bigot," said O'Connor, who felt playing Bunker was primarily "a reporting job, because Archie is a reactor, reacting to his time and place." This was the reason, remarked O'Connor, that he didn't mind being typecast as Archie Bunker. "He was real," O'Connor said.
While Archie has grown increasingly cuddly on Nickelodeon (declawed at least partly because of the vibrant multinational immigrant Queens that supplanted the one he was supposed to represent), the punk world of the Ramones, and their emblematic singer, Joey Ramone, remains eternal. Straight outta Briarwood, straight offa the F train, the Ramones were beyond the prosaic confines of municipal-bond failure. If the world was coming to an end, they opted for low-tech fast-forward time travel, reimagining themselves as leather-clad cartoon citizens of a Bowery-like planet somewhere on the other side of Judgment Day.
Singing about beating on brats with baseball bats and fueled with a disco-eschewing ethic built entirely on three chords, the Ramones were the Beatles of urban decay. Joey, all hair, legs and rose-colored granny glasses, was everyone's favorite. A surprisingly sweet crooning compendium of every adolescent fear, not wanting to go into the basement because of "something down there," Joey, ne Jeffrey Hyman, laughed at grisly Fate because, like, what other response was there, huh, pinhead?
The Ramones played more than 2,000 shows, all at the same breakneck 1-2-3-4 pace, 20 songs in 35 minutes. But a personal favorite, scheduled for CBGB's, remains one that never happened. It was that famously hot July night in 1977 when Con Edison blew up, centerpiece of the yet-unnamed Summer of Sam. Since there can be no rock, much less punk rock, without electricity, the Ramones were canceled, a vast disappointment. As stores were looted by people The Post called "animals" and fires raged around Yankee Stadium, a need for reassurance arose, someone to say everything would be all right. But when the TV finally came back, Abe Beame (no Rudy, he) was nowhere to be seen, not in our house at least. Instead, there was Archie Bunker, fuming about how he would not give blood because his bodily fluids might end up inside a black man. Even that was a rerun, which is how it was, the last time the city was on the brink.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Beame (top), 1975; Ramone, with Deborah Harry of Blondie, 1977; O'Connor as Archie Bunker, 1973. (Mark Godfrey/Magnum Photos; Roberta Bayley/SLP/Stock; The Everett Collection)

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: ROGER STARR, B. 1918; 
The Contrarian

BYLINE:  By Jack Rosenthal 

 BODY:
Roger Starr, a restless bear of a man, brimmed with expertise. He knew where to find the best jewelry on 47th Street, the best fly fishing on the Beaver Kill and the most memorable conch stew in Islamorada, Fla. He loved tennis, bridge and pool. He knew classic architecture in Sicily and unusual words like "trunnion" and "gudgeon" (both referring to bus parts and the latter also to fish). 
 He also mastered a series of careers, as an intelligence officer in World War II, head of his father's barge company, director of an important civic association and New York City housing administrator. Then, at 59, he took up the career his son Adam thinks he loved most, as an editorial writer for The New York Times. Occasionally, his opinions were more provocative than persuasive. But invariably, when he spoke from real knowledge, he taught. Here are some examples, in his own words. 
 The Living End. In his 1966 book of that title, he twisted the tails of celebrated urban commentators like Jane Jacobs, who had more prescriptions than experience:
"Concentrate on the urban crowding recommended by Mrs. Jacobs, and you fly in the face of the shrunken populations ordered by Lewis Mumford; put low-income families into middle-class developments, to take the suggestion of Herbert Gans, and you confront Marya Mannes with an even greater loss of the city's tone; refuse to construct truck highways, in response to the pleas of Victor Gruen, and you may be contributing to the very growth of unemployment feared most by Michael Harrington."
Planned Shrinkage. In 1976, Starr contemplated the abyss of fiscal crisis and the blocks of broken bricks in places like the South Bronx. In this magazine on Nov. 14, 1976, he wrote: 
"Planned shrinkage is not a popular idea -- for simply suggesting that the Department of City Planning study it, I was denounced as a genocidal lunatic and enemy of man. . . . Much of the expressed hostility was based on a genuine fear that somehow the poor would be victimized by this policy. But the opposite is true. The poor, who need the greatest service from the city government, would be worst hurt by a failure of the city to use its resources economically."
The Blessings of Public Housing. Starr was often drawn to conservative positions in his later years, but nothing ignited him faster than glib criticism, from left and right, of public housing. Here's what he wrote early in Reagan's second term:
"Does the administration not have ears? Does it not hear the national call for programs to house the homeless? Of all the programs that have emerged over the years, the most effective has been well-managed public housing like New York City's. One in every four public housing apartments is now thought to contain an additional family doubling up with relatives or friends. Each would otherwise be part of the homeless flood."
Westway, R.I.P. One of his great public disappointments was the 1985 death of Westway, the sunken freeway and park proposed to replace the West Side Drive. In four swift sentences, he made the case anew:
"Far from being fatal to cities, automotive traffic brings them to life. There is no sweeping it away in romantic illusion. Westway may have been an ambitious, complicated and expensive solution. It is survived by the problem."
Love of the City. A 1983 heat wave drove people to the air-conditioning of the F train and prompted him to reflect on another time: 
"Back then, everyone except beer barons with bulletproof Packards went by subway. Poets slept in them. Carefully nurtured children took their first independent voyages on the subway (to look at the dinosaurs in the Museum of Natural History). If lucky, they took over the front window of the first car and peered ahead at stations suspended in the darkness while the tracks unrolled like the future itself."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Partners Who Run a Different Sort of Steakhouse

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
BEFORE they decided to build the Boulder Creek Steakhouse chain together, its founders considered whether their nearly lifelong friendship could survive the challenges that a business partnership inevitably brings. They decided it could.
 "We are like family," Mario Sbarro said, describing his relationship with Anthony Scotto. "We both like to work and like what we do. We even go on vacations together." 
 In fact, they have piloted several expeditions through Europe, each involving dozens of people of different ages from both families. 
The easy camaraderie stems from similar backgrounds, values, working style and years of familiarity. Mr. Sbarro and Mr. Scotto are both natives of Naples who immigrated to the United States as teenagers. Both were raised in Bensonhurst by families in the food business who knew each other. The Sbarros ran a salumeria, the Scottos an Italian restaurant. Both became family business patriarchs whose operations rely heavily on an extended clan in pivotal positions. 
Mr. Sbarro's name is familiar: his name is on 950 Sbarro restaurants. Mr. Scotto runs four major Long Island catering halls -- Chateau Briand in Carle Place, Fox Hollow in Woodbury, Westbury Manor and the Watermill in Smithtown -- and various spinoff ventures, including the Inn at Fox Hollow, which is scheduled to open in Woodbury next month.
Their operating styles are similar; both men shy from the spotlight, preferring to involve themselves in the endless culinary and managerial details of running their empires.
Harold Kestenbaum, a franchise lawyer in Garden City who knows both men and who is a director of Sbarro Inc., described them as adroit entrepreneurs very much at home in the highly competitive restaurant industry. "They complement each other very well," Mr. Kestenbaum said. "Tony knows the industry from the catering and the fine dining side, and Mario from the fast-food side and the location side."
In 1995, the men went into business together, forming Boulder Creek Holdings with a third partner, Sal Moscato, the owner of the Erga Bakery in Bethpage. The first fruit of their collaboration opened the following year in East Norwich. The eighth Boulder Creek Steakhouse opened recently in Linden, N.J.; the ninth is scheduled to open next year in Brooklyn.
The partners said that they intended for the chain to keep growing, both on and off Long Island. "We definitely aren't finished yet," Mr. Scotto said.
The chain's concept, Mr. Scotto said, fits into the growing category the restaurant industry calls "themed casual." The idea was to create an environment in which women and family groups would feel as welcome as men. 
In contrast, the traditional steakhouse has long been viewed as a kind of male clubhouse, with imperious waiters, limited menus and an atmosphere in which children were not welcome.
"The traditional steakhouse chain, such as Morton's of Chicago and Ruth's Chris, gives off a kind of macho feeling," said Milford Prewitt, a staff writer at Nation's Restaurant News, a weekly trade publication. 
At Boulder Creek Steakhouses, the two founders said, they want to deliver the message that everyone is welcome. "If your kid kicks the back of a chair or spills a glass, it's O.K.," Mr. Sbarro said over lunch with Mr. Scotto at the Boulder Creek Steakhouse on North Broadway in Hicksville.
Mr. Scotto added, "Boulder Creek is not intimidating to anyone." 
While running a steakhouse was new to Mr. Sbarro, it was a case of "been there, done that" for Mr. Scotto, who in the early 70's a founded a Long Island chain called the Steer Barn, which closed nearly 20 years later, a victim of changing consumer tastes, Mr. Scotto said.
By the mid-90's, steakhouses were becoming popular again. "I said, 'Tony, I think red meat got a bad reputation back then'," Mr. Sbarro recalled. "How about we try it again?" 
As for prices and atmosphere, the model the partners had in mind were chains like Bennigan's and Ruby Tuesday. The idea was to foster an easygoing environment where customers could order fish, salads or other light fare without fear of eliciting sneers from staff members. 
"We wanted to create a steakhouse with plenty of food choices and an atmosphere that was fun," Mr. Scotto said. 
In inventing Boulder Creek, they designed a Gold Rush decor quite different from the traditional clubby steakhouse interior. Signs on the wall proclaim the goods and services of such real and mythical businesses as the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad, the Boulder Creek Hotel and the Colorado Paint and Pickaxe shop.
The menu sends a similar message. Diners who select Doc Holiday's Primavera might suspect that Doc has returned to the gulch after a visit to Ischia, one of the partners' favorite vacation destinations in the Bay of Naples. Among the steaks, the leader of the pack is the Outlaw, a 32-ounce porterhouse with garlic and rosemary, a gustatory clue to the chain's Italian heritage. 
The family-friendly nature of the chain is underscored by the so-called "Yee-hah Man" advertising campaign begun nearly two years ago. The ads, in print and on television and radio, include a stylized cowboy shouting "Yee-hah!" The campaign, developed by George Lois, the Madison Avenue legend, in conjunction with the EGC Group in Hicksville, seeks to emphasize freshness by depicting a herd of steers roaring through a Boulder Creek restaurant.
"We created something that as soon as you hear it, if you're on Long Island, you think of Boulder Creek," Mr. Lois said.
Along with the Boulder Creek Steakhouses, Mr. Sbarro and Mr. Scotto have begun two traditional steakhouses, Burton & Doyle in Great Neck and Chas. Rothman's in East Norwich, as well as the Baja Grill, a Tex-Mex spot, and Waves, a low-key tropical restaurant. 
In all, the restaurants pull in $45 to $50 million a year, Mr. Scotto said, and the Boulder Creek Steakhouse chain accounts for the bulk of those revenues.
The decision to enter that category, represented nationally by chains like Outback and Lone Star, was a smart move, Mr. Prewitt, the restaurant industry reporter, said. "The price point is manageable to most people, and they are well positioned to come out of this recession pretty strongly," he said. "The only thing that's limiting their growth now is saturation. At this point real estate costs are rising, and there are only so many more affordable locations where they can expand."
Mr. Scotto and Mr. Sbarro said that they both continue to enjoy their partnership, which has involved what Mr. Scotto called the occasional compromise, although never, he emphasized, involving food quality.
"When you have a partner, you have to learn give and take a little," Mr. Scotto said, smiling broadly. 
Mr. Sbarro nodded. "He's a great partner," he said. "Of the two of us, he's the people person."
Mr. Scotto smiled again.

HEADLINE: Going Out of Business? They Can Help 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
ON Nov. 30, 125 conservatively dressed men and women gathered to bid on some of the choicest real estate in the metropolitan area. Because Lechters Inc., the housewares giant, had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, DJM Asset Management of Melville was conducting a "going out of business" auction of all 315 of its stores. The sale, held in Manhattan at the crowded offices of Lechters's lawyers, was a controlled and orderly event, evoking the low-key sophistication of Sotheby's and Christie's.
 DJM and Keen Realty Consultants of Great Neck are two of a mere handful of companies that financially troubled retailers turn to when they need to unload their stores as expediently as possible. 
 DJM and Keen are sometimes referred to as the "repo men of retailing," and when companies go bust, they are on the scene faster than the "everything must go" signs are posted. Armed with expertise in bankruptcy law and real estate, these liquidators can assess a property's value, from its rent and location to its electrical system and ceiling height. Both companies seek to raise cash for their debt-ridden clients and help them avoid paying rent on faltering stores. 
Often, properties are disposed of through a highly publicized auction. Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection allows failing companies to hold on to their stores' leases until they expire, and subletting, particularly for choice locations, can bring in millions. For their efforts, brokers like DJM and Keen get commissions ranging from 3 percent to 7 percent on the cash they raise.
The economy's slide has meant big business for these brokers. DJM has liquidated a record 50 million square feet of retail space this year, compared with 18 million last year.
"Every year there's one sector that gets clobbered, and this year it was anything to do with housewares," said Andy Grazer, DJM's co-president. "We had no problem selling on Long Island. Businesses still want to come here, and real estate is still desirable." 
Mr. Grazer auctioned off a total of 80 Lechter leases, and the remaining 235 or so will revert to their landlords. Of the chain's 15 Long Island locations, 11 were sold at the November auction: Lechters stores in Freeport, Oceanside, Bridgehampton, Riverhead and Massapequa were snatched up by well-known retailers like Strawberry, Coconuts, the Children's Place and Payless. Mr. Grazer estimated that about 90 percent of the $6.5 million raised at the auction came from stores on Long Island and in New York City. 
Keen held its own auction in November to sell the leases of Cosmetics Plus, after the chain, based in New York, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August.
In contrast to DJM's low-key auctions, Keen's are exercises in "sheer craziness" and not "prim and proper like Sotheby's," said its president, Harold Bordwin. He said the recent Cosmetics Plus auction was not as successful as he had hoped, and he attributed the inability to sell all 21 leases to the terrorist attacks.
"The auction didn't go well," he said. "It was hard to find a lot of prospects. People are more conservative in the aftermath of Sept. 11." 
While the lease for a store on Fifth Avenue was sold to Coach for $725,000, there were no bidders for the 5,700-square-foot store at the Source mall in Westbury. . Control of the property reverted to the landlord, the Simon Property Group, the largest mall owner in the country, whose holdings include Roosevelt Field and the Walt Whitman Mall as well as the Source.
Because bankruptcy law allows companies to retain their leases, landlords will often bid for the leases on their own property. 
Typically, the liquidation process runs smoothly under the supervision of federal bankruptcy courts, which generally send a court reporter to lease auctions to record the proceedings. Often a company will attempt to restructure itself under Chapter 11 and emerge from bankruptcy in fiscal health. But few companies actually accomplish this. Area stores like Loehmann's, Pathmark and the Wiz, which was saved from bankruptcy by Cablevision in 1998, are notable exceptions. 
In the last several years, Long Island has seen some familiar retailers, from Pergament to Caldor, go out of business. In January, DJM expects to hold an auction for McCrory's, one of the country's oldest discount stores. It is closing its remaining 200 locations permanently, including a store in Holbrook. In in its heyday, McCrory's owned 1,300 stores nationwide. 
DJM also helped dispose of the remaining Grand Union supermarkets. Kimco Realty of New Hyde Park, the owner of 500 strip malls around the country including many on Long Island, often buys leases and then sells them to other retailers. It replaced a Grand Union in Plainview with a Fairway store and a Caldor in Bridgehampton with a Kmart. 
Many of the retailers in a variety of sectors have suffered from the success of retail wonders like the Home Depot, Wal-Mart, Target and Bed Bath & Beyond. These stores are what brokers refer to as "category killers."
Harold Bordwin of Keen called Cosmetics Plus a "terrific franchise" that got eaten away by the increase in discount drugstores like Duane Reade and the vast brand selection at Sephora. 
Earlier this year, Keen handled a bankruptcy auction for Family Golf Centers, based in Melville, which had been the country's largest operator of driving ranges. At a large auction in Manhattan, Keen disposed of 60 Family Golf properties, including sites in Syosset, Farmingdale and Lake Grove. 
Family Golf's 169,000-square-foot Sports Plus Center in Lake Grove was the single biggest money maker in the $103 million auction, fetching $10 million for the 42 years remaining on its lease. The center, which never closed, has an ice-skating rink, bowling alleys, 200 video arcade games and a rock-climbing wall. 
While the brokers are concerned with the dollars-and-cents aspects of their transactions and with raising as much money for their clients as possible, they are not immune to the human toll that a bankruptcy filing takes on a company and its employees. 
"There's a lot of difficult emotion," Mr. Bordwin said. "Any time companies are liquidating, people are fired. Others are left behind to do the work of many."

Harold Bordwin, center left, is the president of Keen Realty Consultants of Great Neck, which handled the auction of Cosmetics Plus leases. (Phographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

 BODY:
Animals as Art
The myriad ways in which artists portray animals in paintings, sculpture and illustrations is being explored in a family exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through March 10.
 By comparing several artists' concepts with taxidermy mounts of real animals, children get a first-hand experience with creative imagination at work. 
 "The Real and the Imagined: Animals in Children's Book Illustration," as the display is titled, contains 27 animal mounts from the museum's natural history collection.
They include comparing an 8-foot-tall grizzly bear, say, to the Paddington Bear. Preserved foxes, wolves, mice, raptors, woodland birds and city swallows are matched with 70 pieces of original art by William Wallace Denslow, Wendell Minor, Grace G. Drayton, Fred Banbery, Nancy Carol Willis, John Schoenherr and others. 
The books for which the artwork was done are on display as well, and children are invited to sit at leaf-shaped tables on mushroom-shaped stools to read them.
The museum, at 1 Museum Drive, near Exit 3 of I-95, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.
Admission for adults is $4; students and people 65 and older pay $3. Children under 5 are admitted free. Admission is free for everyone on Tuesdays.
For more information, call (203) 869-0376.

Designers Highlighted
Two fashion designers are being celebrated in an exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford called "Architects of American Fashion: Norman Norell and Pauline Trigere."
While both Mr. Norell and Ms. Trigere were icons of elegance, simplicity and timelessness, they worked in very different ways.
Mr. Norell, who died in 1972, drew his designs, sometimes with notations and fabric swatches attached. Ms. Trigere cut and draped fabric freehand on a live model.
They were both recipients of two Coty Awards each and one Hall of Fame Award each.
Ms. Trigere closed her atelier in 1992, but today, at the age of 92, she continues to design accessories, perfume, $125 pill boxes, $25 hearing aid cases and $95 walking sticks.
She was awarded the medal of the Legion of Honor in ceremonies held at the French Embassy in New York on Dec. 16.
Ms. Trigere was born in Paris, but achieved her reputation as a preeminent American designer in New York from the 40's through the early 90's.
Visiting hours at the Atheneum are Tuesday through Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is $7, students and adults 62 and older $5, ages 6 through 17 $3. Admission is free on Thursdays and before noon on Saturdays. Information: (860) 278-2670.

Anyone for the Beach?
One can take some deep breaths and unwind from the holidays during a nature walk along the beach and among the dunes with Colleen Noyes, naturalist educator at the Connecticut Audubon Coastal Center in Milford. 
The group will walk south from the center at 1 Milford Point Road on Saturday at 2 p.m., headed for the sandy shore.
To register at $6 for adults, $4 for children: (203) 878-7440.

Toy Train Exhibition
There was a time when the mention of toy trains was synonymous with the name of A. C. Gilbert, a Yale man from Oregon who enrolled at the college in 1903 and remained in New Haven to build his internationally celebrated toy train company.
When real railroads took a back seat to planes and automobiles in the 1960's the passion for toy trains ebbed, but it is regenerating along with renewed interest in train travel.
This is the 16th consecutive year that the Eli Whitney Museum has mounted a holiday exhibition of Mr. Gilbert's Railroad. This year's display features his famous American Flyer trains of the 40's; they are still running like new along an elevated platform 12 feet wide and 30 feet long.
Circus cars, Pullman sleepers, freight cars and coal cars are pulled by locomotives through a re-creation of New Haven, from coal mines to Yale to downtown to outskirt farms. 
Visitors can operate the trains by pushing buttons placed along the edge of the platform at 15 locations. They can also craft trains with interchangeable parts, view Mr. Gilbert's Erector sets and browse the gift shop.
The museum, at 915 Whitney Avenue in Hamden, just over the line from New Haven, is open Wednesday through Friday from noon to 5 p.m.; Saturday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., and Sunday from noon to 5 p.m.
Admission is $3 for adults, $2 for children.
Information, (203) 777-1833.

Lectures in Darien
"Turkey, Bridging Two Worlds," a series of five lectures, will be given by a roster of speakers beginning this week in Darien.
Peter Awn, from the Department of Religion at Columbia University, will kick off the series on Thursday at 10 a.m. His topic will be "Turkish Culture -- A Balancing Act."
The lectures, organized by the Darien Community Association at 274 Middlesex Road, will continue on subsequent Thursdays through the end of January.
"Architecture and National Identity in Modern Turkey" will be discussed by Sibel Bozdogan of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's School of Architecture, on Jan. 10, followed on Jan. 17 by Stephen Kinzer, a former New York Times bureau chief in Istanbul, speaking about "Crescent and Star." 
Two speakers are scheduled on Jan. 24 when Oner Ayan of Raymond James Financial talks about "The Turkish Economy and the European Union," and Tosun Aricanli of the Department of Community Economic Development at Southern New Hampshire University explores "U.S.-Turkish Relations, Yesterday and Today." The final subject will be "Turkey's Long Struggle for Human Rights Reform," addressed by Neil Hicks, a member of the Lawyers Committee on Human Rights.
With the exception of the program on Jan. 17, which takes place with a reception at 7:30 p.m., all the lectures begin at 10 a.m. The cost is $50 for the series and $15 for individual sessions.
Information for tickets: (203) 655-9050.
