HEADLINE: Memories And More 

 BODY:
Every day the memorials continue, as they should, for the dead of Sept. 11.
 This article is not about those memories. It's about other lives that ended in the year 2001, lives that ended as many of them were lived: without fanfare, without headlines in the local paper, let alone the national press. 
 Marcelle S. Fischler has written a collection of vignettes about lives that changed Long Island for the better in ways large and small. In a year when so much was lost, here are other memories worth preserving.

Helping the Outcasts
Teresa Kennedy and Sister Mary Waters worked as a team, founding Mercy Center, which operates homes for homeless and unwed pregnant teenagers on the South Shore of Suffolk County. 
It was the early 1980's and the cases poured in. A mother who had recently remarried wanted her teenage daughter to move out. The new husband didn't want her. The girl needed a place to live.
Sister Waters, who worked at a parish outreach program in Blue Point, sought help from Mrs. Kennedy, who was a dedicated volunteer case workers and also a friend. In 1983, they opened a shelter in Patchogue for 16- to 20-year-old girls. 
Two years later, after being approached for help by the Suffolk Network for Adolescent Pregnancy, they opened two community residences for unwed pregnant and parenting teenagers, and later, three other homes as part of a supervised transitional independent living support program. Since then, the homes have taken in 1,000 young women. 
Mrs. Kennedy, known as Tee, made the Mercy Center her mission. Her own children were nearly grown and she threw herself into volunteerism. Full of spunk, determination and political savvy, Mrs. Kennedy made connections and allayed fears in Islip and Sayville that the homes would be disruptive. As president of the board she was instrumental in setting policy for the agency. 
"A lot of the credit and the development of the programs and the ambience that the center brings to these girls was very much due to her influence," Sister Waters said, recalling how Mrs. Kennedy often was able to help the teens reconcile with their parents.
Mrs. Kennedy died of brain cancer on Aug. 22 at age 66.

A Force for Integration
The draft had begun but James Davis volunteered to join the Army during the Korean War. Like all the recruits, he was proud to be able to serve his country. Off he went, from Glen Cove to Hempstead and then on to Fort Dix, N.J., without a hitch. But when the new recruits left Fort Dix, the whites were sent to one rail car and the blacks to another. 
The experience of discrimination shaped his future. After his discharge in 1951 as an Army sergeant, Mr. Davis joined the Glen Cove N.A.A.C.P. and became a civil rights leader on the Island. Later he was director of the Long Island Regional N.A.A.C.P.
Schools in Glen Cove were segregated in the early 1950's. South Elementary, where his daughter, Sheryl, was enrolled, was predominantly black. The three other schools in the district were white. Mr. Davis filed suit, naming Sheryl, then 6 or 7, now Sheryl Goodine, as the plaintiff. After much resistance, Ms. Goodine recalled, the Board of Education relented, and the children from South were bused to the other schools. 
"He really did help to change the face of Glen Cove," Ms. Goodine said. "He forced the integration of the Glen Cove Volunteer Fire Department and the Glen Cove Police Department." 
As president of the Glen Cove N.A.A.C.P., Mr. Davis was instrumental in passing open housing laws in Glen Cove and Nassau County. The branch established a not-for-profit development fund and opened 54 units of low- and moderate-income housing on Dickson Street in Glen Cove. 
In 1964, Mr. Davis ran for mayor of Glen Cove. He didn't win, but that wasn't the point. He managed to draw attention to the needs of the minority community. He also took part in voter registration drives in Mississippi in the late 1950's and early 1960's and marched with Martin Luther King Jr. from Selma to Birmingham. 
After he retired in 1984, Mr. Davis volunteered for the Glen Cove Child Daycare-Head Start Center and secured financing for the center to relocate. It was later dedicated as the James Davis Glen Cove Child Day Care/Head Start Center. For many years, he was chairman of the Martin Luther King Commission in Glen Cove. In the 1990's, Mr. Davis had a Sunday morning radio show on WHLI, "Focus on the Black Community," that was broadcast in the tristate area. 
Mr. Davis died of kidney failure on Nov. 13. He was 74.

Death and Taxes
F. Daniel Moloney had a positive outlook and a great sense of humor. He had to. He dealt with the only two certainties in life: death and taxes. And he took a lot of ribbing for it.
Mr. Moloney, Brookhaven Town's tax receiver for the past 22 years, was also a mortician, the founder and owner of five local funeral homes and a multifaith tribute center that bore his family name. "I tell people who complain that I don't raise taxes, just collect 'em," he once said. "Same in the funeral business. I have nothing to do with people dying. I just bury them."
Mr. Moloney never wanted the bereaved to feel like they were coming to a funeral home. Instead, he created park-like settings with gazebos, fountains and bronze statues of children at play. "They were coming down to Dan's place," said one of his eight children, Peter Moloney. "We got away from that dreary, dark atmosphere of funeral homes past." 
To create Irish cheer, Mr. Moloney placed cuddly stuffed sheep, pigs, dogs and other farm animals on the lawn outside his Lake Ronkonkoma funeral home. Inside, he painted the walls bright colors, lining the shelves and tabletops with Hummels and porcelain figurines and putting out stuffed animals and dolls for children.
His style once earned him a national "Pursuit of Excellence" award from the Funeral Directors Association for "special in-house activities." That included tours of the facilities -- the other homes are in Holbrook, Bohemia, Central Islip and Hauppauge -- and a crematory that offered closed-circuit viewing for the deceased's family. And he piped in uplifting music: Liberace and traditional Irish folk tunes, not dirges. 
When Mr. Moloney opened his first funeral home in Lake Ronkonkoma in 1962, he had only $24 in the bank. Trying to develop a customer base, he drove a woman to the hospital every day to see her husband. When he died, she went somewhere else. He joined every organization that he could, trying to get his name out. That eventually led to politics and to the Moloney family funeral homes becoming the largest family-owned and operated funeral chain on the Island. (There was also a power boat named Gonna Getcha).
"The toughest campaign for tax receiver I ever had was 18 years ago when I was running against a psychologist who claimed I didn't take the job seriously enough," Mr. Moloney said in an interview in 1996. "At a public debate in Patchogue, someone asked him if he was elected would any of his patients visit him on the job. He said that would rarely happen. Then I got up and said: 'I'm Dan Moloney, owner of the local funeral parlor. I can guarantee none of my clients will ever show up at Town Hall.' The place broke up and I won running away."
Mr. Moloney died of cancer on Aug. 26 at age 63. 

Law Enforcement Innovator
Every boulevard in Long Beach abuts the beach and teenagers like to hang out under the 2.2. miles of boardwalk. As police commissioner, Thomas Browne realized it would be easier to patrol there if his officers were on bicycles rather than in cars. 
The program was an instant success, one of a series of policing triumphs that Mr. Browne instituted during his 27-year law enforcement career. Mr. Browne also started the department's domestic violence unit and a Drug Abuse Resistance Education school program.
"He did more than any police commissioner with more interaction with the police department and the schools," said Kenneth Cohen, who succeeded him. 
Under Mr. Browne's leadership, officers participated in career days, read stories to schoolchildren and got to know the youngsters from elementary through high school. And he instituted community policing, assigning certain officers to particular neighborhoods at certain times to create familiarity. Mr. Cohen said Mr. Browne aggressively recruited minority police officers for the 77-member force. He even started classes with his wife, Jeanne, to tutor minority applicants to better prepare them for the civil service examination.
"He enjoyed being in the community and working with the people on a more personal level," Mrs. Browne said. "He was very determined. He was always, always, always looking to help someone else. He thought any position of power should be used to help." 
He died of cancer on April 1 at age 57. 

Pioneering Cardiologist
When a heart attack occurs, the quickest way to open the blocked artery is angioplasty, passing a wire through the artery to the heart with a balloon and stent.
Until Robert Rubino, a cardiologist, launched the primary angioplasty programs at Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center in West Islip and Southside Hospital in Bay Shore last May under a New York State program, using that technique wasn't possible in the area.
Dr. Rubino was the first interventionalist to join South Bay Cardiovascular Associates in West Islip and the first to do primary angioplasty at both hospitals. Having Dr. Rubino working the catheterization lab meant that South Shore patients would receive the treatment of choice, with less damage to the heart than the alternative of using drugs to dissolve the clot causing the attack. He also did elective angioplasty at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, where he had completed a fellowship in interventional cardiology. 
"He brought the standard of cardiac care for this community to the premier level, so the people in this community now can receive on an emergency basis a treatment that is exactly the same that they would receive in any tertiary care hospital, St. Francis or Manhattan," said Dr. Larry Altschul, director of cardiology at Good Samaritan. "If they came in with a heart attack, they have an equal chance of living."
Dr. Rubino, of Manhasset, was a gentle, soft-spoken physician with a good bedside manner, able to put patients at ease. 
"He had that rare ability to bring a certain level of calm to a highly stressful situation," Dr. Altschul said. "In the catheterization lab, he had the kind of personality where he could take a high stressful situation and bring down the level of anxiety to a very workable, comfortable level." 
Because of the success of the program Dr. Rubino launched, 23 other hospitals in New York State have been given permission to do primary angioplasty.
Dr. Rubino, 40, died in a car accident on Aug. 5, the 11th anniversary of his marriage to Debra Guzov.

Starting a College
It was an adventure for Thomas F. Irvine to start a college from scratch.
When the State University of New York system was created 40 years ago, Dr. Irvine was hired to start the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences for the State University at Stony Brook. Before the campus was built, the college was housed in temporary quarters at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. 
He would take prospective professors out to Port Jefferson and tell them, "I can't offer you much money, but how can you turn down this view?" said his son Thomas Alexander Irvine, surmising that as a landlocked child from Pittsburgh, his father was drawn to take the job for its proximity to the water. 
Dr. Irvine, who was dean for 10 years and then became a professor of mechanical engineering, set the school on a path to become top-ranked nationwide, "the Cal Tech and the Berkeley of the east," said Fu-Pen Chang, a professor in the department of mechanical engineering.
Dr. Irvine's specialty was heat and mass transfer and he was a vigorous advocate of international cooperation in his field. He held appointments at laboratories in Germany, Yugoslavia, Britain and Italy. In 1972 he founded a technical journal, "Heat Transfer: Soviet Research," which led to direct cooperation between American and Soviet scientists.
Though many of the applications of his work are in the atomic energy industry, his personal political stance was pro-conservation, his son said. He rode a moped to work, rain or shine, and cut an interesting figure on campus with his tweed suit, knickers and tie. An avid amateur recorder player and collector, he practiced during lunch hour and loved to listen to and sing hillbilly music, accompanying himself on the harmonica.
Dr. Irvine built his own fiberglass houseboat, never venturing past the landlocked waterways of the North Shore. "We never went on vacation, but sat in the mud in East Setauket harbor," Thomas A. Irvine recalled.
Dr. Irvine, of St. James, died of cardiopulmonary arrest on June 2 at age 78. 

Helping the Victims
Before the 1970's, there were neither shelters nor services for abused spouses. Crisis centers for rape victims didn't exist and there were no mandatory arrest policies or preventive education.
Millie Steinberg, who was one of the first women elected to the Suffolk County Legislature when she took office in 1973, raised her voice. A mother of three from Setauket, she dared to say that domestic violence and sexual assault were unacceptable crimes. In 1976, she helped create the Victims Information Bureau of Suffolk, which provides counseling, legal advocacy and other services to victims of domestic violence and rape, sexual assault and elder abuse and community education, said Pamela C. Johnston, executive director of the nonprofit organization.
"You really had to be a strong advocate to be heard back in those days," Ms. Johnston said. "Her spirited and intelligent advocacy paved the way for major changes in the way Suffolk County law enforcement and the courts respond to domestic violence and sexual assault. Nearly three decades later, Suffolk County still leads the way in public policy and service provision for victims." 
A liberal and a feminist long before it was popular, Ms. Steinberg also worked for women's rights, civil rights and reproductive freedom. Long before anyone took up the no-smoking charge, Steinberg wore a T-shirt proclaiming "Lungs at Work: No Smoking" to the legislature. 
Ms. Steinberg died on July 9 of complications from a fractured hip. She was 91. 

A Late Bloomer
Roger Wunderlich, the historian who founded and edited the Long Island Historical Journal, received his bachelor's degree at the State University of New York at Stony Brook at age 68, a master's at 69 and a doctorate at 71. 
"He always said he went to life in order to go to school," said his daughter, Elizabeth Ewen, a history professor at SUNY-Old Westbury. "He was like a self-taught man."
Dr. Wunderlich was always enchanted by history, literature and philosophy, but it wasn't until he retired that he was able to pursue his passion full time. When Ms. Ewen received her doctorate, it inspired her father to do the same. His doctoral thesis was on Modern Times, an obscure libertarian village established 140 years ago in what is now Brentwood. "Low Living and High Thinking at Modern Times, New York," was published when he turned 78.
Upon graduation, Dr. Wunderlich joined Stony Brook's history department, becoming a research associate professor. On campus, he was known as the "sage of Long Island."
"He felt the way Long Island history had been studied before was ancestor worship," Ms. Ewen said. "He wanted to create a social-political history of Long Island. He thought the history of Long Island was a microcosm of America."
He said the key to its history was the three-tiered evolution from rural (1640-1910), to suburban (1910-1965) to postsuburban (from about 1965 on). Students clamored to get into Dr. Wunderlich's Long Island history course, which was always overenrolled. The Long Island Historical Journal was also an immediate hit. 
Born in Manhattan, Dr. Wunderlich spent a year at Amherst but had to drop out because of the Depression and went to work for the family's greeting card business. He married Frances, his wife of 60 years, and enlisted in the Army. In 1945, they moved to New Hyde Park, purchasing a house under the G.I. bill, later settling in Port Jefferson and working as a traveling salesman, selling books and stationery for a small company and enjoyed his work.
Dr. Wunderlich died May 19 at age 86.

Shaping a Museum
Though it didn't change names from the Museums at Stony Brook to the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages until long after her tenure as director, it was Susan Stitt who initiated the switch.
Ms. Stitt brought the museum out from the doldrums of a sleepy small town museum and into the late 20th century. She was the one who was responsible, in the early 1980's, for expanding the carriage collection established by Ward Melville, the tycoon who spent millions on historic preservation in Stony Brook. She also oversaw the construction of the new, climate-controlled building to house the vehicles, garnering acclaim for the structure and its contents. She expanded the museum's American painting collection, including works by William Sidney Mount, who painted in Stony Brook. 
To keep the collection in one location, Ms. Stitt closed the craft museum in the village. When she hired a professional educator, the department started to teach docents how to explain the collection to visitors. 
"Before that, there wasn't much of that at all," said Sue Wallen, a former director of education at the museum. "Because she was museum trained she was able to lead the museum into a new way of thinking." 
For her achievements, Ms. Stitt received a national award, the Katherine Coffey Award, which has been called "the Oscar for museum administration." 
Ms. Stitt, a native of Virginia, made her own clothes, and loved gardening, travel, cooking, mystery stories and her Abyssinian cats. She had a 30-year-career in museum management, and after leaving Stony Brook became president of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.
Ms. Stitt died March 21 of cancer. She was 59.

An Environmental Mayor
Richardson Pratt Jr. was on the train by 6:45 each morning and returned home to Lloyd Harbor by 7 each night. By day, he was president of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn as well as managing director and, until he retired last year, chairman of Charles Pratt and Company, which was established in 1891 to oversee the Pratt family interests.
But it was by serving as mayor for 16 years in Lloyd Harbor that Mr. Pratt made his mark. In this quiet, upscale community of 9.2 square miles on a North Shore peninsula, he had a deep commitment to historic preservation and the environment. He wanted to make sure the 3,500 residents were aware of the importance of the wetlands, open space and trees. 
Lured by the open space quickly disappearing in Nassau County, Mr. Pratt bought land in Lloyd Harbor in 1949, and moved there with his wife, Jan, in 1963. Elected mayor in 1983, Mr. Pratt was determined to protect the village's natural beauty and pushed for the creation of a local waterfront revitalization program to help keep control over areas such as Caumsett State Park, Target Rock National Wildlife Preserve, Coindre Hall and West Neck Beach.
Lloyd Harbor finally adopted the program in 1996, making it one of only a few villages with access to powerful legislation that gave local government influence, and in some cases control, of capital projects and permits issued by state or federal agencies.
Mr. Pratt died of pancreatic cancer on May 1. He was 78. 

A Lover of Elms
Every morning, rain or shine, Charles Edgar Whitmore was out on his bicycle, riding without socks as he pedaled around the village of East Hampton to check on the trees, particularly his beloved elms. 
While Dutch elm disease devastated most of the Island's elm population in the last half century, Mr. Whitmore, an arborist and entomologist known as Doc, helped the massive old trees that shade Main Street withstand the beetle-carried blight. 
"He was instrumental in developing a program to save the elms in East Hampton," said Mr. Whitmore's son, Jack, who with his father built the largest landscaping company on the East End. "He instituted a program out here that kept the elms viable and kept the legacy of the elms. The elms and the main street of East Hampton have both gone hand in hand."
Mr. Whitmore knew every tree on every property, his wife, Eleanor, said, cycling 25 to 30 miles on his daily tour, always ready to gab with their owners, whether they were clients or not. "He did all his business on a bicycle," Mrs. Whitmore said. "He said he wasn't going to get dressed up or take anyone to lunch." 
It never affected the landscaping, horticulture and lawn work business, which now has 325 employees, and 180 East Hampton and Orient acres where evergreens and trees are raised.
East Hampton had more than 300 elms at one time, one of the largest concentrations on the East Coast. Some were lost to hurricanes. Then the others began getting sick. Working with the Ladies Village Improvement Society and using a fungicide, Mr. Whitmore numbered the elms, identified them and saved just about all of the 135 left. Once he started the program in 1976, the mortality rate went from 25 to 30 trees a year to 1 or 2. 
Last year he received the first Long House Reserve gold medal for his work with East Hampton's trees and for excellence in horticulture.
Mr. Whitmore died March 17 at the age of 81.

Saving a Species
The banning of the insecticide DDT in the United States and many other countries is one of the environmental success stories of the 20th century. It started in 1967 with Dennis Puleston, a naturalist, boat designer, yachtsman, skilled painter of birds and modern-day explorer from Brookhaven. Mr. Puleston was one of the 10 founders and the first chairman of the Environmental Defense Fund, now one of the most powerful environmental organizations in the world, with 300,000 members and an annual budget of about $42 million.
Mr. Puleston, a keen ornithologist and the head of science and public information at Brookhaven National Laboratory, came from England. Ospreys, birds of prey that live off fish, hadn't nested there for 100 years. The opportunity to study ospreys at the privately owned Gardiners Island on the East End was one he couldn't pass up, said Art Cooley, a trustee and co-founder of the Environmental Defense Fund. 
"It was his studying of ospreys on Gardiners Island that led to our understanding that their reproductive abilities were dropping off dramatically in the 1960's," Mr. Cooley said. "Because of the ban of DDT, a whole series of species of birds have been able to return in numbers." 
Mr. Puleston concluded that the ospreys were becoming reproductively extinct as a result of dichloro-diphenyl-trichlorethane, or DDT, being sprayed in the area to keep down mosquitoes. The insecticide weakened the shells of the birds' eggs to the point that they broke when an adult bird sat on them. In 1966, Mr. Puleston and several colleagues won their first action, a lawsuit against the Suffolk County Mosquito Commission for its use of DDT. 
With Mr. Cooley, Mr. Puleston would take groups of students from Bellport High School on informal field trips nearly every weekend. At Montauk, they watched the seals and sea ducks in winter and in spring saw the annual migration of warblers deep in the Pine Barrens at Warbler Woods on the Carman's River, a piece of Yaphank property that Mr. Puleston ultimately persuaded the county to purchase as part of the protected lands along the river's watershed.
He gave slide shows at garden clubs all over the Island and taught ornithology to adult education classes at Patchogue High School for many years. Mr. Puleston had a "wonderfully gentle way of helping people understand what they were looking at," Mr. Cooley said.
After retiring from the lab in 1970, Mr. Puleston embarked on a second career as a lecturer and a guide, accompanying tourists on more than 200 seafaring journeys around the world, including more than 35 to Antarctica. Every morning at first light he'd be on the ship's bridge looking at albatrosses and other seabirds, quietly helping others spot the wildlife. 
"He was always out on deck," said his son, Peter Puleston. "He never wore a hat. There was always snow freezing in his hair. He seemed to be impervious to heat or cold. He wore the same clothes, winter or summer."
Mr. Puleston studied biology and naval architecture at London University, then, in 1931, set out across the Atlantic with a friend in a small sailing sloop and was shipwrecked at Cape Hatteras. "I staggered to your shores," he once told a reporter.
Undaunted, he completed a six-year odyssey down the eastern seaboard of the United States, around the Caribbean and across the South Pacific, arriving in China just as the Sino-Japanese War was beginning.
Working with a naval architecture firm in New York in 1942, he helped design the DUKW amphibious landing craft used by the Allies.
Mr. Puleston's home was always filled with pets and injured animals, Peter Puleston recalled. He kept dead birds in the freezer to use as models for his painting, sitting down at his easel in the evenings while the children did their homework. And he had a pet vulture named Alger with a six-foot wingspan that rode on his shoulder.
Mr. Puleston died on June 8. He was 95.

A Hispanic Leader
When he was 30 years old, Paul Irizarry realized he had to turn his life around. He knew he had leadership qualities, but being leader of a gang in Spanish Harlem was not taking him where he wanted to go. He was into drugs and into trouble, with a six-month stint in a Kentucky jail for possession of heroin. 
What he needed was an education and a fresh start. So when his brother Frank and his wife invited Mr. Irizarry to join them on Long Island, he jumped at the opportunity.
The lad who cut class, gambled his lunch money and regarded gangsters as role models became a respected Hispanic leader on the Island. He helped build Adelante of Suffolk County Inc. from a Brentwood-based cultural and civic organization known for its annual Puerto Rican Hispanic Day Parade into a multiservice agency for Hispanic residents. Mr. Irizarry was the president and first executive director of Adelante, which means to go forward. 
"My husband believed a lot in education," said Mr. Irizarry's wife, Hilda. "He came from a very poor family. His parents never encouraged education on him. They wanted him to work. He realized without education you are nobody." 
After landing a job as an orderly at the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center, Mr. Irizarry enrolled in its nursing school and became a registered nurse. While working full time, he went to the State University of New York at Stony Brook, earning a bachelor's degree in liberal arts, then a master of arts and a master's degree in public administration. He was 51 when he received his doctorate from Nova University in Florida. 
"He spent most of his life studying," Mrs. Irizarry said. "He said: 'Going back to school is really very hard for me. I have to read and read and read things over and over to really grasp it in my mind. It is not as easy as when you are young. That is why young people should stay in school.' " 
Mr. Irizarry worked his way up from R.N. to staff nurse to head nurse to deputy director of administration at Pilgrim and was a consultant for United Way on the Island.
To make Pilgrim part of the Brentwood community, he brought 1,200 patients to see the Puerto Rican Hispanic Day parade every year. He got the people in the community involved in Adelante and Adelante involved in the hospital. He helped form a bilingual ward for Spanish-speaking patients.
When Adelante was formed in 1966, it was a civic and cultural club. Mr. Irizarry became active as a volunteer in the mid-1970's, and dreamed of building it a home. The high-ranch house with upstairs offices and a conference center in the basement opened in 1989. 
A few months later, he retired from Pilgrim and became Adelante's first executive director. Mr. Irizarry brought in educational services, including computer training programs, English as a second language and a youth leadership program. His vision included supported housing for the mentally disabled, a mental health drop-in center, vocational training, a nutrition program for the elderly and a seasonal lawn service program for the elderly and disabled citizens in Islip town. This year, Mr. Irizarry was the grand marshal for Adelante's signature event, the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Day Parade, the second largest in New York State, after New York City. 
He was 70 when he died of colon cancer on Aug. 11. 

A Painter of Stature
Two years ago, Anne Cohen DePietro, chief curator of the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, stopped by Esteban Vicente's Bridgehampton studio. The artist was painting, working the edges of a canvas filled with clouds of evanescent green. Tables were covered with Dixie cups filled with paints in the vivid pinks, brilliant yellows and lime greens of his wildflower garden. He brushed a horizontal stripe of mint green, and paused. Ms. DePietro remarked that he had been hard at work. "No, I've been painting," Mr. Vicente replied. 
Mr. Vicente, a Spanish-born artist who has a museum devoted to him in Segovia, Spain, and a street named after him in his birthplace, Turegano, was at the forefront of the New York School of abstract expressionism in the 1950's. 
"My culture is Spanish, but I am an American painter," he told his archivist, Ellen Russotto, time and again. "People make a mess out of the world. It takes artists to put it in order."
Mr. Vicente didn't know how to drive, swim or ride a bicycle, recalled his wife, Harriet. When they rented a pond-front home in Sagaponack in 1963, he covered the windows in brown paper so he wouldn't be distracted by the view. The following year, they purchased a simple Dutch colonial farmhouse on Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton, recognizable by the playful, multicolored sculpture on the front lawn.
Mr. Vicente was one of the founders with Elaine de Kooning of the annual Artists and Writers softball game. He was the pitcher. Instead of just throwing balls, he lobbed two oranges, a grapefruit and a coconut that he and the De Koonings had painted white to resemble a baseball; when hit, they burst in the air. One batter was showered with juice, the next with coconut chips.
Mr. Vicente painted seven days a week, Mrs. Vicente recalled, but always had time for visits from children and artists. He taught until he was 96. From the time he was 12, Mr. Vicente drank two glasses of wine every day, very often at the picnic table under the arbor at lunch with anyone who may have dropped in. He used to walk daily to the post office and the Candy Kitchen in Bridgehampton, where he held court with the rich, the famous and the poor, from the mayor of New York to the local plumber.
"Everyone knew the season had started because he walked from the house to the post office," Mrs. Vicente said.
As an artist, Ms. De Pietro said, Mr. Vicente's work spanned the 20th century.
His style changed through a career that included sojourns in Paris, Barcelona and New York.
"What he took from the East End was this amazingly beautiful palette from his garden," Ms. De Pietro said. "Once he came here he brightened his palette. Long Island transformed his palette. His work became increasingly luminous. Everyone talks about the light of the East End and you certainly see that in Esteban's paintings."
Mr. Vicente died on Jan. 10 at age 97.

A Lighthouse Savior
Her headstone reads "Keeper of the Light." 
Giorgina Reid saved the Montauk Point Lighthouse. Wind, rain and the seas were eroding the bluffs around the 200-year-old beacon at the rate of more than a foot a year, threatening to eventually topple the sentinel into the waves. A 700-foot stone revetment constructed at the base of the cliff by the United States Army Corps of Engineers after World War II diminished but didn't stop the erosion.
In the 1960's, when federal officials decided they were going to abandon the lighthouse and erect a steel tower half a mile inland, the publisher Dan Rattiner rallied local sentiment in his weekly papers and held protests and a candlelit vigil to save the light. His crusade caught Ms. Reid's attention. 
A textile designer and photographer, Ms. Reid was fluent in five languages but had neither engineering nor environmental training. After a 1962 nor'easter snatched part of the bluff her waterfront cottage in Rocky Point was built on, she created a terracing system. It halted the beach erosion and she started helping other homeowners. Ms. Reid patented her method in a book, "How to Hold Up a Bank."
She called Mr. Rattiner and volunteered to build a series of terraced steps filled with layers of sand and dead reeds on the lighthouse's bluff face where beach grasses could grow. Coast Guard officials were skeptical but allowed her to try it, Mr. Rattiner recalled, provided she take out an insurance policy in case she was injured. She started the project on Earth Day 1970 and soon expanded across the bluff. After two years, the Coast Guard engineers dropped plans to demolish the lighthouse and began drawing up plans to further her work on a larger scale with federal funds. Ms. Reid continued her terrace building as a volunteer and consultant. 
The stabilized bluff rises about 70 feet above sea level, at a steep angle of roughly 45 degrees. The lighthouse stands 100 feet from the edge. Because of Ms. Reid, the erosion has slowed.
"The nerve of this lady to think she could stabilize the bluff," said Gregory Donohue, erosion control director of the Montauk Point museum, who has continued Ms. Reid's work. "She was a feisty woman, all of four-foot-eleven, with the heart of an elephant."
Ms. Reid died on June 16. She was 92.

A Forthright Publisher
Robert Richner was never a writer or an editor. He went into the newspaper business to make money; the product may as well have been widgets. But throughout his career as the publisher of a chain of award-winning community newspapers, Mr. Richner never let himself be influenced by anyone with a political agenda or an ax to grind. Threaten to pull advertising or publish the legal notices in a competitor's paper? No matter. Mr. Richner stood his ground.
"My dad was a really straight arrow," said Stuart Richner, who with his brother Clifford took over the helm of Richner Communications after their father's health began to fail in 1987. "Extremely hardworking, extremely honest. My dad did not let people sway him even when it came to economics." 
Mr. Richner, of Hewlett Harbor, was a C.P.A. by training. After opening an accounting office in Lawrence, Mr. Richner decided to invest in The Nassau Herald and The Rockaway Journal, which were just down the block and doing poorly. 
"He felt the papers had been under absentee management so long he felt if somebody paid a little bit of attention that there was potential to make some money," Clifford Richner recalled. Before he knew it, Mr. Richner and his wife, Edith, also an accountant, were ensconced at the paper full time.
And though the initial venture was through Republican contacts, Mr. Richner was very independent.
"There is a certain irony," Clifford Richner said. "He got his back up. He immediately started to have fights with the local Republicans out here who expected to control him and get their pictures in. They still do, but they're not quite as surprised anymore if they don't." 
Mr. Richner also started running political endorsements, not a particularly safe move economically for a small paper, and ran an unflattering cartoon about Ralph Caso, who eventually became the county executive.
"He stood up to them," Stuart Richner said. "For someone who would claim he was just in this to make money as a business, this wasn't going along and getting along, which was what the party expected you to do. To this day we still get accused by the Republicans that we're Democrats and we get accused by the Democrats that we're Republicans."
By 1987, he had seven papers, including The Rockaway Journal, The Nassau Herald and The Oceanside Island Park Herald, an advertising shopper with a 100,000 circulation and a commercial printing division. Today, Richner Communications owns 14 community papers and 9 editions of PrimeTime, a free shopping guide. Total circulation is about 200,000.
"He was very progressive in his thinking," recalled Leatrice Slote Spanierman, his editor of 30 years. "He was the kind of person who let a woman take over in those days. When editors had ideas, he backed us."
Mr. Richner approved an open-forum youth section written by high school and college students. And when someone proposed a radical feminist section, he ran a weekly section called "Sisterhood" for about a year.
Mr. Richner was in the forefront of the fight against building the Rockaway Expressway, which would have divided Queens and Nassau. And he was very supportive of Morris Kramer, whose dispute with the Lawrence school district landed in the United States Supreme Court and ended a variety of restrictions on voting rights.
"His integrity and his principles stuck," Ms. Spanierman said. "A lot of politicians put pressure on him. There were rocks through our window and he never bent."
Mr. Richner died Sept. 18 at age 79.

A Coliseum Mover
Joseph Jaspan was known as the "architect of the coliseum."
A hardworking lawyer, he was named county attorney after Ralph Caso was elected county executive in 1971. The Nassau County Memorial Coliseum was close to completion. It was Mr. Jaspan who was responsible for negotiating contracts and bringing in the Islanders, a new franchise at the time, and the Nets, the basketball team that now makes its home in New Jersey. 
Mr. Jaspan hired Peter King as deputy county attorney, giving the future congressman his start in public life. In 1974, Mr. Jaspan became an acting state Supreme Court justice on the Court of Claims. Later he was of counsel to Jaspan, Schlesinger & Hoffman, a Garden City law firm where his son, Arthur Jaspan, is a partner. 
Before becoming county attorney, Mr. Jaspan was counsel to State Senator Norman Lent, who later was elected to congress. He was involved in writing Medicaid legislation for the Joint Legislative Committee on Health. A family man, Mr. Jaspan discussed politics and the law at the dinner table. Both of his sons became lawyers. 
Mr. Jaspan died of cancer on April 5. He was 88.

HEADLINE: The View From/East Lyme; 
The Tale of a Children's Museum Without a Lease

BYLINE:  By JOE WOJTAS 

 BODY:
OVER the last decade, the Children's Museum of Southeastern Connecticut in East Lyme has attracted more than half a million visitors, but it may soon be a museum without a home.
 The Board of Selectmen voted to end the museum's $1 annual lease and to sell the building early next year to the highest bidder. The museum had hoped to extend its lease to 2004, when it plans to open a much larger museum along the Thames River in New London. 
 Andrew Pappas, a local restaurant owner who is one of the founders of the museum, said that he, like some other residents, was bitter that the museum will be moving. He said the founders' intent was to have a small local museum, not the large regional operation that board members now envision. 
"There are some hard feelings among residents here," Mr. Pappas said. "They wonder why we are giving them a dollar a year rent when they are bailing out on us."
First Selectman Wayne Fraser said the town decided it did not want to be in the rental business anymore and could use the proceeds from the sale to build badly needed athletic fields.
The building is valued at $350,000. A new tenant would also generate tax revenue for the town, because the nonprofit museum pays no taxes. The 4,500-square-foot building is situated at the west end of Main Street in the Niantic business district.
"They've decided to move," Mr. Fraser said. "We wish them well, but we're not going to keep subsidizing them when they're moving out of town. It may come out like we're adversaries, but it's not like that. We just want to sell the property and move on."
The town plans to accept bids on the property until February. The museum's lease extension is expected to expire at the end of April. Although Mr. Fraser said the town was willing to sell the building to the museum if it were the high bidder, it is unlikely the museum will submit a bid.
Tony Mollica, the museum's executive director, said the museum cannot wait until February or March to find out if it is the successful bidder because it would not have enough time to get a temporary location before April. 
Although both town and museum officials have expressed displeasure with each other over the last several months, Mr. Mollica and Mr. Fraser are playing down any controversy.
"It's their prerogative; it's their choice," Mr. Mollica said. "You have to respect people's choices. One of the things we haven't lost sight of is that they gave us a great start here. We've done well here and their support has been instrumental in us doing well.
Mr. Mollica said the museum had made a standing offer for the property that he said "is in the ballpark" of the town's $350,000 appraisal. He declined to be more specific. He said the museum had also offered to pay the town $8,000 a year, the amount the property would generate in taxes, if the lease were extended through 2004. 
"Is there really any interest in keeping us? That's a question for the town," he said. "If there is, then that has to be passed on to us. If not we understand that they need to move on to other things. We've tried all kinds of things. I think it just might be time. It's sad, but I have no ill feeling." 
Mr. Fraser said that since the original lease expired in October, the museum had not paid the $2,500 monthly rent that the Board of Selectmen established and then lowered to $1,200. Mr. Mollica said paying the rent would take a big chunk out of the museum's $350,000 annual budget.
Mr. Fraser said the rent was less than the market rate of $3,600 and would help pay some of the transition costs. Still, he said, the town does not want to be a landlord.
"That's not our business," he said. "Unless we're making a reasonable return for the taxpayers we should look at where our funds can be better spent."
Since the museum opened in 1992, it has provided a wide range of hands-on activities, classes and exhibitions for children ages 1 through 12. 
One section of the museum is devoted to science, history and music. There are microscopes that children can use and instruments they can play. There is also a human skeleton, preserved human heart and lungs, meteorites and live snakes, newts, fish and a tarantula. Outside there is a six-ton, two-person research submarine. 
Mr. Mollica said that by the museum's second year of operations, officials knew the building was too small. A consultant predicted that the museum's annual attendance of up to 60,000 had the potential to climb as high as 250,000 if it were in a larger building.
Mr. Mollica said that there were days when the museum had to turn away visitors because it would exceed its capacity of 195 people. "We knew we had to do something to accommodate people," he said.
The museum began looking for a new site, and the town offered property, including a former post office and a piece of undeveloped state land across from a state prison here. The town had hoped the museum would maintain a satellite facility here even if it moved to New London.
"The town has bent over backward looking for a site for them," Mr. Pappas said.
Not everyone sees it this way.
"It's awful that the town has made things so hard on them," said Heidi Messina of New London, who was visiting the museum this month. "They don't want to leave this town. The kids will lose out and that's not fair."
While teaching a preschool class at the museum, Lisa Harden of Clinton said that if the museum moves, the local economy would suffer because visitors would no longer spend money in the nearby restaurants and shops. 
During the museum's search for new location, New London officials offered land in rundown Riverside Park between the United States Coast Guard Academy and Connecticut College. The city offered to improve the park and build a walkway linking it to the downtown waterfront, which is in the midst of a revitalization project. The city has agreed to a 50-year lease at $1 annually.
"It was a tough site to say no to," Mr. Mollica said.
Meanwhile, the museum has begun an $11 million fund-raising campaign and has already received a $500,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Plans call for a 29,000-square-foot building that includes a preschool. One of the design highlights is a recreation of a Charter Oak tree that children will use to climb through the roof of the museum room to an outside viewing platform.
Until then, museum officials were hoping they had a home in East Lyme, especially since in September 1999 the Board of Selectmen approved a lease extension to 2004.
Mr. Fraser, however, did not sign it, something that surprised museum officials a few months later when they found out. Mr. Fraser said that when he learned of the museum's plan to move to New London he decided it was not in the town's best interest to extend the $1-a-year lease. 
Mr. Mollica said: "We don't want to talk about that. We don't want to make things any more difficult than they are. I think there were mistakes made by both parties." 
When the museum's lease expired in October, the board first extended it to the end of December and is now expected to extend it until April when a sale is completed.
The town first put the property up for sale in November and required that the minimum bid be the appraisal price of $350,000. There were no bids so the board decided to seek new offers, with no minimum.
As the town fields the offers, Mr. Mollica said he hopes to announce the location of the museum's temporary home by mid-January.
"It's a shame it had to come to this," he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS; 
Fee Hike Rankles Some Golfers

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
THERE was no shortage of controversy surrounding Westchester's budget for 2002, which was finalized this month at $1.3 billion.
 The Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, said that the county, facing tough economic times, must do some "belt-tightening," including a 3.8 percent property tax levy, a freeze on social program spending, as well as hiring and salary freezes. 
 But a smaller item in the budget -- an increase in greens fees at the county's five public golf courses -- has raised hackles among golfers, particularly seniors, who enjoy special rates. People 60 years old and up now pay $11 for a round of golf during the week and the regular county resident rate of $21 on weekends. The new budget raises fees $5 on weekdays and $6 on weekends. 
"I know a $5 increase doesn't sound like a lot to someone making a regular paycheck, but a 40 percent hike is steep for us," said Tom McPhillips, 70, who has played on the county's courses for more than 50 years.
Mr. McPhillips, a retired banker from Scarsdale, said that with the fee increases, courses would lose business.
"There are guys I play who just won't play as much," he said, loading his golf bag into his trunk last Wednesday at Sprain Lake Golf Course in Yonkers. 
Marty Capobianco, president of the Dunwoodie Senior Golf Club, which has about 65 steady members who play regularly at Dunwoodie Golf Course in Yonkers, said "a lot of our guys have been bellyaching about the fee increases" and may go instead to New York City courses in the Bronx.
"They feel they've worked hard their whole lives and now in their retirement, golf is one of the few things they can still afford to do," said Mr. Capobianco, who, at age 90, can still shoot in the low-90's. "We have guys who say they can't afford this, that they'll quit playing altogether."
Joseph A. Stout, first deputy commissioner for the county's parks department, said that fee increases are necessary to pay for renovations of county courses, and for the construction of Hudson Hills, a course currently being built in New Castle.
But, he added, the parks department only recommended a $2 weekday raise for 2002, and $3 on the weekends. Any fee increases must be approved by the parks board, which will take up the issue at its Jan. 17 meeting. The county will have invested about $30 million between 1996 and 2006, he said.
The county's five golf courses close today for the winter and will reopen March 29, weather permitting.

HEADLINE: Fast Tracks To the Past 

BYLINE:  By DIANA MARSZALEK 

 BODY:
IN its glory days, the Yonkers train station was an elegant hub for prosperous commuters traveling along the Hudson River. Designed by the same architects who created Grand Central Terminal, the Beaux-Arts-style building was encrusted with decorative metal and woodwork, crowned with a partially copper roof and lighted by chandeliers. 
 When the station opened in 1911, Yonkers was already a prosperous city in its own right. Copper magnates, businessmen, entertainers and philanthropists were among those attracted to its palatial homes and thriving waterfront industries, as well as its proximity to Manhattan. 
 The large, ornate station was built to serve these people, as well as Yonkers' immigrant population. New York Central Railroad tycoons, who owned and operated the Hudson Line at the time, were determined to create the premier railroad of its time. They built the Yonkers station, with its stylish waiting rooms and covered platforms, to impress. 
Time, though, has taken its toll on the riverfront structure. A casualty of the Northeast weather, wear and tear, and Yonkers' economic decline, restoring the station, which Metro-North Railroad has recently undertaken, requires far more than a good paint job.
"We are trying to bring it back to its original glory," said Mari Miceli, who as assistant director of facilities engineering for Metro-North, is overseeing the project.
That's where Lynn Drobbin and Wesley Moroz come in. 
The pair, who work in Pelham and together make up Lynn Drobbin & Associates, have made a career of keeping the history of the area's public buildings alive. Part preservationists, part experts and part sleuths, Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz have the job of identifying the finest architectural details of historic buildings and structures, and then finding ways to make sure they are retained or restored when the structures are renovated. 
Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz work primarily on transportation projects. Some, like the planned $26 million restoration of the Yonkers train station, are high profile. The station is the first piece of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's and Metro-North's three-and-a-half year, $87.4 million project to rebuild nine Hudson Line stations, including four in Yonkers and five in the Bronx. 
Other projects, however, stretch the imagination of those who are not transportation buffs, who may fail to see the historic or architectural value in pedestrian overpasses, viaducts, roadways and retaining walls throughout Westchester County.
But federal and state law require public agencies to make sure they aren't tampering with anything historically significant when they begin projects such as road reconstruction, repairing infrastructure or tearing down bridges. Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz have to figure out how to do that. It may mean recreating the design of a window, finding an exact tile match or restoring waiting room benches.
Sometimes, Ms. Drobbin said, a structure may be deemed historic because the method or tools used in its construction may be significant. In other cases, the history of a structure is measured more by the role it played in county life or the influence it had on its surroundings and community.
The allure of train stations in Westchester County dates to the early 20th century and the golden age of railroads. Train travel was already such a part of New York area living that George M. Cohan wrote about the New Rochelle train station in his 1906 song "Forty-Five Minutes from Broadway." The New York Central Railroad, which operated the lines that run through Westchester County, was owned by the wealthy Vanderbilt family.
The architectural firms Warren & Wetmore and Reed & Stem, which designed Grand Central Terminal for New York Central, designed the Yonkers and Poughkeepsie stations as well, which echo Grand Central's high ceilings and arched windows.
"Grand Central Terminal was designed to be the symbol of the greatest railroad of the 20th century," said Dan Brucker, a Metro-North spokesman. "Suburban stations were some very close relatives, which replicated that symbol on a smaller scale."
In the intervening years, and as car culture blossomed in America, many stations, including Yonkers, fell victim to neglect. 
Now, however, train stations around Westchester County are getting new lives, not only serving their original purpose but housing other facilities as well.
The Mount Kisco, Valhalla, Hartsdale and Cold Springs stations all house successful restaurants. In Cold Springs, Depot Restaurant has recreated some of the romance of railroading by placing tables on the outdoor platform, allowing patrons to watch the trains roll past.
Neither Ms. Drobbin, 49, nor Mr. Moroz, 44, were particularly fascinated by train travel until their work led them to it.
Ms. Drobbin, whose interest in architecture was initially sparked during a summer college internship in New Orleans, spent the early part of her career working as a preservationist on a variety of projects. Mr. Moroz worked on a computer, which he used to draft architectural drawings.
The two, who were married but have since separated, started focusing on transportation about 12 years ago, when Ms. Drobbin started her own firm after four years as a historical and environmental specialist at NJ Transit. 
Today, the company is in a historic Pelham building that was home to the Sanborn Map Company, which designed insurance maps of buildings that Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz use in their work today.
"The railroads are scenic and romantic and have a sense of history," Ms. Drobbin said. "They are so tied into how this country was built."
Three years ago Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz were charged with finding a way to modernize the Woodland Viaduct, a 1920's bridge on the historic Bronx River Parkway in White Plains that was strained by today's traffic, while maintaining its historical integrity. Because of its historic status, engineers were not permitted to knock it down. With Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz's guidance, they found a way to reinforce the existing structure and improve the roadway while retaining the bridge's original appearance. 
And then there are those gems that pique just about anyone's interest. Most notable has been Ms. Drobbin's and Mr. Moroz's work to preserve Coney Island's parachute jump, a 1939 World's Fair ride that is the only remaining element of Steeplechase Park, closed long ago. Long gone are the days when thrill-seekers would plunge with parachutes from atop the 250-foot steel tower. After years of neglect the structure was filled with roosting pigeons. Its future uncertain, Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz dug into the parachute jump's past to discover how the original ride was constructed and how best to preserve it. 
The idea of recapturing a bit of Coney Island's past was realized as work crews repaired, painted and stabilized the ride to make it a standing (but not functioning) keepsake next to the new Brooklyn Cyclones' KeySpan baseball stadium.
The demand for experts like Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz has grown over the last 35 years, since the enactment of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966, which was established after the demolition of the old Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. The law requires agencies overseeing federally financed projects to preserve historically significant structures when feasible. States followed suit, passing their own regulations. New York State passed its historical preservation law in 1980. 
Whether a project is governed by the federal or state law generally depends on who is financing it. Since many projects, including the railroad renovations, are financed by a mix of state and federal grants, the overseeing agencies are often required to meet both state and federal standards.
The Hartsdale train station posed a particular challenge for Ms. Drobbin and Mr. Moroz. Their task was to ensure that the building remained true to its past even though a Starbucks Coffee shop was moving into the property. 
The building has been restored in such a way that it retained its character.The Starbucks, which opened in late 2000, sells not only lattes and mochaccinos but train tickets as well.
In Yonkers, city and railroad officials are banking on the renewed train station to be the centerpiece of a riverfront revival, which will also include a new library and park. 
Not only will the improved train station have access to the adjacent river, but also officials hope the project draws private developers to build offices and renovate other buildings nearby.
In doing so, officials said, restoring the train station may help bring back life to an aging area -- and perhaps recapture some of its glory.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
Truth in Advertising

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN

DATELINE: RIDGEFIELD 

 BODY:
THE dish is called, simply, Shanghai casserole. On a menu that otherwise bristles with useful information, its entry is unadorned. You choose medium ($13.95) or large ($19.95). We chose large. 
 There were seven at our table that evening, and our leftovers would have fed everyone else in the restaurant. It was an extraordinary dish, at once bracing and comforting, a giant ceramic crock of sturdy chicken broth with pork, scallops, cellophane noodles, salty fish balls and fist-sized chunks of Napa cabbage. All of it was suffused with the insistent, curative aroma of ginger. It was a soup you could get lost in, like a great novel. 
 And while it may have been the best dish we tried in two long evenings at China 46, it was far from the only unexpected pleasure. The place hardly looks like a restaurant, at least one worthy of the name. It squats at the side of Route 46, in a converted diner next to a truckers' motel. Its tall, blaring sign, probably visible from the international space station, promises "Authentic Chinese Cuisine" -- usually a guarantee that the cooking is anything but authentic. 
In this case, however, it's the simple truth. Cecil Wang, the 50-year-old owner, came to the United States 22 years ago from Shanghai. He ran a Chinese restaurant in Lancaster, Pa., then the Beijing Duck House in Edgewater. Last spring, the old diner on 46 -- most recently Phoenix Garden Too, a Cantonese seafood place -- became available, and Mr. Wang seized the chance to present the food of his home city.
I have never been to Shanghai. I'm told it exerts a powerful pull on those who have. Stephen Wong, a writer and consultant on Chinese food based in Vancouver, British Columbia, speaks of a cuisine whose roots far predate the city's powerhouse new-economy ambience and shimmering skyline -- cooking based on mild and balanced flavors, on soy sauce and fermented bean paste and mild doses of ginger and garlic, with much seafood and plenty of braising.
Mr. Wang, of China 46, is particularly proud of a dish called superior ruby pork, which the menu describes as "a giant pork shoulder with mixed herb simmered for hours; served very tender as melt in your mouth." I'm sorry I didn't try it; I take the description at its word. Certainly the entry for seaweed-dipped flounder is on target: "a large flounder filleted, lightly breaded with seaweed powder, then fried . . . our own unique one fish for two taste." More like seven or eight: this platter weighed down the table of an extended Chinese-American family, who took in my pleading glances and offered me a bite. The flounder was crackling and greaseless, like first-rate fish and chips, and the seaweed gave it a haunting maritime tang.
Of many fine appetizers, the most dazzling is a platter of tiny snails, towering over the table like a ski run made of black olives. The way to eat these babies is to place them between tip of tongue and roof of mouth, close tightly, and draw out the meat -- along with a thimbleful of delicate soy-garlic-ginger sauce -- with a single sucking motion. 
Other dishes draw on the Shanghai fondness for gelatinous ingredients -- jellyfish, tripe, sea cucumber, shark's fin -- which are considered particularly nutritious and are prepared in ways that emphasize the spicing rather than the main ingredient. Tripe meets ox tongue in a lovely, vibrant appetizer; the meats' contrasting textures play off against each other, and most of the flavor comes from a hot pepper sauce cooled by cilantro. Chewy, slippery cellophane noodles get similar treatment in a lively sauce powered by capsicum, or hot red pepper. 
Thin-sliced beef marinated with star anise is so soft it almost doesn't need chewing -- an odd sensation at first, but agreeable. Its texture was yin to the yang of a cool, crunchy cabbage in a surprisingly mild dressing of hot pepper, rice wine and vinegar. Familiar appetizers like sesame pancake and pork dumplings were no better or worse than the versions in a thousand Chinese restaurants from here to Lancaster.
Noodles are another specialty of Shanghai, and here they're hearty and unrefined -- snack-cart food. We enjoyed the vegetable chow fun -- broad noodles that drew a pleasant smoky taste from the wok -- and dense, earthy Northern China beef noodle soup. 
Beijing duck is offered here, probably as a crowd pleaser. A specialist emerges from the kitchen with the whole bird on a cart; he is dressed all in white -- apron, T-shirt, Howard Johnson-style cap -- and has the deadpan tableside manner of a taxidermist. He slices with unnerving dispatch. The final product is reassuring, though. The duck is rich, crunchy and ample, the pancakes fresh, the plum sauce dark and unctuous. Another familiar dish, General Tso's chicken, is respectable and forgettable. The only awful dish we tried was sweet and sour chicken, a 1960's relic whose dubious charms have evaporated with time.
The menu at China 46 is bewilderingly long, with more than 200 items (though some were not available on either of our visits, and others must be ordered in advance). This is true of many Asian restaurants, of course. But there are two important differences. The dishes here are genuinely unusual, in a style few Americans have encountered. And they are good -- so good they make you want to come back and see what fresh pleasures await. Fish maw, anyone?

China 46
88 Route 46 (westbound), Ridgefield
(201) 313-0088

VERY GOOD

HEADLINE: The Great Red, Green and Blue Way 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
THEY say the light-emitting diodes are bright on Broadway. Just when it seemed Times Square could not get much more dazzling, several new supersigns were switched on recently, transforming a half dozen office towers and stores into colossal, kinetic video monitors and digital displays.
 Though not as charming as the vintage Little Lulu and her Kleenex box or as insouciant as the puffing Camel smoker, they have enough candlepower to be visible at high noon. Millions of brilliant diodes have turned Times Square from an after-dark showcase into a round-the-clock spectacle. Their immediacy was evident on Sept. 11, when hundreds of pedestrians stood transfixed watching the collapse of the World Trade Center on the giant screens. For a moment, Times Square felt once again like Manhattan's town square, with people gathering for bulletins as they had during World War II. 
 Even when the content is far less compelling, the effect of two dozen jumbo screens playing simultaneously and inaudibly -- as if some cosmic "Mute" button had been pushed -- can be utterly mesmerizing. Individual commercial messages are subsumed in the marvelously discordant visual symphony. 
Buildings now wear signs as a second skin. At 745 Seventh Avenue, which is to be occupied by Lehman Brothers, the architects of Kohn Pedersen Fox sandwiched windows between spandrel panels of light-emitting diodes that wrap around and animate the entire base, from 49th to 50th Street. The Reuters and Instinet sign at 3 Times Square breaks the boundary between inside and outside with panels that seem to transmit images from the sky into the building.
Architecture might take an even wilder turn in the future with light-emitting polymers, flexible sheets that could wrap or wallpaper whole buildings, said John Mayo-Smith, vice president of technology at the R/GA Media Group of Manhattan, which developed the software behind the Reuters sign.
Not long ago, owners and tenants fought -- or at least questioned -- the signs required by the city and state to preserve the visual character of Times Square. Now, they exceed the guidelines. At 3 Times Square, the state required 14,000 square feet of signage. A total of 33,938 square feet was created: 15,169 for Reuters and Instinet; 12,769 for the Rudin Organization, developers of the tower; and 6,000 for the Prudential Insurance Company, the original owner of the site.
"It came down to our desire to push that envelope," said Glenn J. Elliott, senior vice president of real estate services at Reuters America Holdings. Edwin Schlossberg Inc. designed the Reuters sign, working with Fox & Fowle, the architects of the tower.
Although the latest Times Square signs are almost exclusively devoted to their sponsors, the owners recognize the commercial potential of giant video and digital displays that can be changed far more easily and rapidly than neon spectaculars, painted walls or even vinyl sheets. In the near term, however, the recession and a growing concern about light pollution may dampen demand for the supersigns.
"The sign industry is not what it used to be," said Douglas Durst of the Durst Organization, developers of 4 Times Square, which just mounted a big green "4" on the east face of the four-sided sign atop the tower. "We'd much prefer to have a tenant," Mr. Durst said, "but besides Teligent, we haven't had a tremendous amount of interest." And Teligent, a wireless communications company that took the west face, filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.
A bill to limit excessive outdoor illumination and "light trespass" across property lines has passed in the Legislature but not yet been signed by Gov. George E. Pataki. Among his concerns, his aides said, are that the lights of Broadway might be affected.
WHATEVER happens, though, it is clear that the little diode -- a semiconductor device that emits light when electricity passes through it -- has conquered Times Square.
"It's a world of L.E.D. components," said Kenton Jenkins, vice president and general manager of W.W.F. New York, which spent $7.9 million to recreate the bow-shaped marquee on the landmark Paramount Building at Broadway and 43rd Street and the arch around it. The marquee leads to the World Wrestling Federation store and restaurant.
While the arch was covered in a hoarding during reconstruction, the federation hung vinyl banners. It cost $30,000 to change them, Mr. Jenkins said. "You're money ahead, 10 years down the line, to put in an L.E.D. board," he said. "They're huge revenue centers in Times Square."
The sign was made by ADF Steel in South Plainfield, N.J., then trucked across the George Washington Bridge. Plans for a gala inauguration were overtaken by the September attack, which left sign operators scrambling to figure out what to display. Mr. Jenkins envisioned a billowing American flag. The diode sign manufacturer, Multimedia of Rancho Cordova, Calif., created the programming overnight and e-mailed it. On Sept. 12, the flag was unfurled.
The Paramount sign sets three new diode boards in a painstakingly recreated 1927 marquee. The original adorned the Paramount Theater, which closed in 1964, and was lost without a trace, said Robert Mark Parnes of Tobin + Parnes Design Enterprises, architects of the simulacrum.
To satisfy the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the new sign had to follow the signature bow of the old Paramount marquee. "This is the first L.E.D. sign to curve in the Y direction," said Andrea B. Dibner of Tobin + Parnes. "Seven or eight L.E.D. manufacturers said, 'You're crazy.' "
Mr. Parnes said that the original had been altered over time and that there was precedent for what seems to be the incongruous contrast of a Baroque frame around pulsating electronics.
The previous existence of another Times Square marquee, over the former Criterion Theater at 44th Street, provided the necessary precedent that allowed Toys "R" Us to build a sign over the sidewalk outside its store, which includes the space occupied by the Criterion. (The sign was made by Saco Smartvision of Montreal, which was also responsible for the Nasdaq sign.)
The electronic sign is not the real scene-stealer, though. That distinction goes to a scrimlike mechanical sign system that changes the store's facade constantly. "It's low tech in theory, but after that, it's more complicated than an L.E.D," said Philip Lenger of Show & Tell Productions of Manhattan, which created the Toys "R" Us signs. The store was designed by Gensler.
The chamfer-cornered sign is a grid of 165 sections, each 30 square feet, behind a glass curtain wall. Within each section is a 48-foot-long scroll between motorized rollers made by the Diazit Company, better known for blueprint machines. The scrolls, changed monthly, are imprinted with seven different images and also have one clear panel, so that the entire facade can be made transparent. Elliott Wahle, vice president and general manager of the Times Square store, said that the sign would eventually become a profit center on its own as a showcase for toymakers and that it would repay the investment, which he did not disclose.
Mr. Elliott, of Reuters, said his company might consider commercial use of its 290-foot-8-inch-high sign, which should be fully running next month. Its chief function, though, is as a "big window into the building," said the designer, Edwin Schlossberg.
"I wanted to create a metaphor for the sign: information coming from the top, from the ether and sliding into the building," Dr. Schlossberg said. Rather than eye candy, he said, it is to be a "vehicle by which the public could see into Reuters."
The sign, which cost more than $20 million, is shared by Reuters and Instinet, an electronic stock trading concern in which Reuters has a majority stake. "We provide data to clients but this is the first time we're able to present it to the public," said Calvin Mitchell III, senior vice president for global marketing and communications at Instinet.
What may be the most talked-about feature of the sign will be a news thermometer indicating whether it is a red hot news day or a cool blue one. Passers-by will be able to look up and quickly gauge whether they should be paying attention to bulletins.
"Hopefully, it will be useful," Dr. Schlossberg said. "We're in such a weird moment where people are desperate for more information but inured to so much."
The "temperature" would be established through a formula incorporating factors like the concentration of stories coming from one part of the world -- say, Kandahar -- and the number of hits that the stories are registering on the Reuters Web site.
Shaped like an inverted T, the Reuters sign is ideally suited for use as a thermometer, since it has an exceptionally tall and skinny stem, 13 by 169 feet, under which is the balcony of the Instinet president's office and a 28-by-46-foot screen. The horizontal crossbar is formed of nine more screens, cascading toward and into the lobby.
It is programmed automatically to draw news, pictures, videos, financial data and graphics from 27 sources; standardize the information; store it in a database; and schedule its display, coordinating images so they move seamlessly across the face of the signs and the voids between them. "Think of the sign as a cable news program on autopilot," said Mr. Mayo-Smith of R/GA. 
The sign was made by Diamond Vision Systems of Lawrenceville, Ga., a division of Mitsubishi Electric and Electronics, and has 5,660,672 light-emitting diodes.
Impressive as that sounds, it is less than one-third the number -- 18,677,760 -- of light-emitting diodes in the Nasdaq tower sign across Broadway. Only two years ago, Nasdaq was the shiny new kid on the block: a quarter-acre cylinder 120 feet tall.
Lately, however, it has been showing its age. As panels burned out because of water damage, those in the center were swapped for good panels on the edge, leaving a blank border. Nasdaq expects that the full array will be back in place early next year.
Nasdaq also intends to improve the imagery, which does not look as sharp as that on the newer signs, by commissioning graphics specially for the sign rather than borrowing and reformatting videos.

HEADLINE: Ballroom Dancing With a Russian Flair 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA VOWINKEL 

 BODY:
ELENA GRINENKO, a Russian ballroom dance champion, left her home in Moscow in 1998 to go to America. In September, she and her boyfriend opened the Dance Zone studio in Old Bridge.
 Peter Vaco emigrated to the United States seven years ago after revolution turned his life in Kosice, Slovakia, upside down. In 1999, Mr. Vaco, who began learning ballroom dancing when he was 9, opened the Indigo Ballroom in Somerville with his wife, Clea. 
 And then there are Alex and Tanya Koulik, who left Russia nine years ago and own the Royal Ballroom dance studios in East Brunswick, Millburn, Rockaway and Ridgefield. The Kouliks, European dance champions who live in Springfield, opened their first studio seven years ago. Their 20-year-old son, Vitaly, is a four-time United States ballroom dancing champion.
Ballroom dance in New Jersey is seeing a small renaissance. About half of the roughly 60 studios that teach ballroom dancing in the state are less than 15 years old, said Mary Wethington, president of the Garden State chapter of the United States Amateur Ballroom Dancers Association. And along with this growth has come an influx of top ballroom dancing talent from the countries of the Soviet bloc.
"There are definitely a lot of Russians and they're very, very high-level dancers," Ms. Wetherington said.
Other dance studios that have opened since 1998 include the Grand Ballroom in Midland Park, owned by Kathy and David Porro, and the Fred Astaire Dance Studio, a franchise in Englewood owned by Amy Cousins, who said many of her instructors were Russian.
Though Americans have generally been more likely to take classes in ballet or tap and to send their children for lessons in those disciplines, the Eastern European instructors said ballroom dance here seemed to get a boost a few years ago after a Gap commercial touched off a craze for swing dancing. More recently, hit songs by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony have sent people to dance studios to learn Latin steps like salsa, merengue and cha-cha.
The interest in ballroom dancing in New Jersey is reflected in the membership of the Garden State chapter of the dance group. The chapter was founded in 1991 with 200 members, Ms. Wethington said, but in 10 years has doubled, to 400. The national group was formed in 1965 to promote the acceptance of ballroom dancing as an Olympic sport, an effort that has not met with success.
The Indigo Ballroom has four instructors in addition to Mr. Vaco: Andrei Semenov from Russia, Eulia Baranovski from Belarus, Oksana Tryakina from Uzbekistan, Irina Sarukhanyan from Armenia. Two more Russian instructors are on the way.
Competitive ballroom dancing is categorized as either international or American style. The international style is broken down further into standard or Latin, while the American style is either smooth or rhythm. Dancers from outside the United States usually learn the international style.
Mr. Semenov and Ms. Baranovski, who are married and dance partners, took first place this year in the international standard category in a San Francisco competition. They finished in the top 10 this year in that category in a Montreal event. Mr. Vaco and his dance partner, Ms. Sarukhanyan, also took top 10 honors this year in American dance categories in a Boston competition.
"We all start dancing as kids," Mr. Vaco, 29, said. "That was thanks to Communism."
He added: "The government paid for all of my training. Maybe for this reason, Communism collapsed. They have to pay for all the ballroom dancing."
The Dance Zone's owner, Ms. Grinenko, who is 25, started dancing when she was 7. She was the 1994 Russian youth champion and, with Michael Nadtochy, was a semifinalist at the world championships that year. This year, they were semifinalists in a Latin dance category in the United States National Championship.
Most instructors say they immigrated to the United States for economic opportunities, made even more enticing after the 1998 financial crisis in Russia.
"In Russia, you cannot rely on your future," Ms. Grinenko said. "If you are a top couple, you can make money. If you are not a top couple, you do not make money."
Then there is the intangible pull.
"Every time in the world, there is some cultural center," Mr. Vaco said. "At this moment, it's New York. It's the center of the world."
Mr. Vaco said he came to New Jersey because of its proximity to New York and to join his mother and friends who lived here. Ms. Grinenko and the Kuliks said they came to the state because that is where they found work.
Still, ballroom dancing is not as culturally widespread in the United States as it is in Russia and other European countries. 
"People in America, the whole thinking was ballroom dancing means old folks," Mr. Vaco said. "In Europe, it's not like that. It's called dancesport."
He and other instructors said Americans were not as serious about ballroom dance as Europeans and Russians.
"At first, it's very difficult and hard to learn," Mr. Vaco said. "Some people just want to dance for fun. They don't want to become world champions."
The Dance Zone advertises in several Russian language newspapers in New Jersey, and is attracting clients from a large Russian community in the Old Bridge area, said George Falcone, Ms. Grinenko's boyfriend, who owns the studio with her. 
Dance Zone opened on Sept. 12. The studio held an opening party on Oct. 13, which attracted about 200 people, Ms. Grinenko said, adding, "I wasn't expecting that many."
At the Indigo Ballroom and the Fred Astaire dance studio, business slowed immediately after the terror attacks on Sept. 11. But Mr. Vaco said his business had rebounded.
"Not too many people lately want to go to New York," he said. 
At a recent session at the Indigo Ballroom, patrons said Sept. 11 inspired them to take up dance.
"After Sept. 11, it refocuses your priorities on the things you always wanted to do," said Patty Wilson, a 37-year-old from Somerville, who took her first lesson in mid-December and has signed up for more.
"How could you not want to dance?" she said. "It's nice to not have to do something where it's alcohol and bars."

Below, Irina Sarukhanyan teaching at the studio, where patrons danced recently, inset. (Photographs by Jill C. Becker for The New York Times)(pg. 9)
