HEADLINE: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; 
To Be Young, Eager and Unwanted

BYLINE:  By ANNA BLUMENTHAL; The writer, who lives in Manhattan, wrote "The Graduate Meets the Slowdown" for My Money, My Life on July 27.

 BODY:
IN May, I graduated from college with four years' worth of information, a half-dozen awards and a lot of self-confidence to go with a decent-sized ego. After taking a few weeks off, I started contacting employers from part-time jobs that I had during school. I thought they'd be thrilled that I was back in town and ready to roll up my sleeves full time. Instead, many said they just weren't hiring. 
 Perplexed, I began to browse the help-wanted ads and send out my resume. It didn't take long for me to realize that the job market had changed drastically since I last looked for work in New York, only a year before. This time around, it seemed that work was nearly impossible to find, especially for a recent college graduate with little experience. 
 After an anxious month and a half of sending out resumes and going out on interviews, I found a job selling advertising at a local weekly paper. Although ad sales was not a field I would have chosen, I really liked my job. Many of the people there were close to my age, and we got along well. The atmosphere was relaxed, and the hours -- strictly 9 to 5:30, and no working at home -- were just fine.
So I should have known that something was wrong.
If the job market was shaky before Sept. 11, it only became worse after. But once the shock and horror of those events wore off, I felt at least fortunate to have already found a job. While many of my friends were still desperately seeking work, I felt safe at my little desk in my office in SoHo.
Occasionally, after hearing about a friend who had lost a job at another company, I would ask co-workers what they thought about the security of our jobs. They would assure me that we were fine. 
"We're the ones bringing the money in," one colleague reasoned. "If they lay anyone off, it definitely won't be the ad reps."
Less than a week later, one of the publishers marched into our department.
"Meeting!" she announced. She said that she had been laying off people all day, and that in my department, the most recent hires had to be let go. About a half-hour later, I was out of work.
I figured, however, that my situation was not so unfair, compared with those of some others who had been let go -- department heads and people who had been with the company since the beginning five years ago. One man who had been there from the start had just married and was on his honeymoon. The day he returned, he had a message on his answering machine that said he should not come back on Monday.
Of course, layoffs are not really news these days. I've become part of a growing sector of the economy. On any given weekday, it's easy to find people to join me for a night on the town; fewer and fewer of my friends have to be at work in the morning (although fewer of us can afford more than one drink). When people I meet tell me they're unemployed, I greet them with a jovial high-five instead of the somber condolences I might have used a year ago.
Initially, being out of work is like a vacation that you didn't ask for; you have no choice but to enjoy the time off. But what's next?
Last summer it was hard enough to find work; finding reason for optimism about the job market post-Sept. 11 is nearly impossible. 
MORE and more, people are scrambling to piece together an income.
One friend poses for figure-drawing classes at art schools during the day, picks up a few shifts waiting tables at a nearby restaurant and posts a friend's coin collection on an online auction site for a base salary plus commission. An artist I know does freelance graphic design and works at night at clubs as a cigarette girl for a marketing company.
In these times, in this city, it seems that creativity -- not a master's degree or great connections -- is the key to success, or at least the way to pay the rent.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Turnaround Prospects After Two Bad Years

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
FOR many investors, the end of 2001 won't come a minute too soon. 
 Unfortunately, many were saying the same thing at the end of 2000. Major stock market averages have fallen for the second year in a row. 
 Steve Galbraith, the new chief investment officer for the United States strategy group at Morgan Stanley, took some time last week to talk about the new year and the odds that the market will hit a dubious trifecta. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. What are the key lessons of 2001?

A. If you had told me at the end of last year that corporate earnings were going to be down over 20 percent, that Enron was going to implode, that we would be attacked on our own soil but the Standard & Poor's 500 index would be down only 11 to 12 percent, I would have said you were crazy. It shows the resilience of the United States.
The key point to take away from 2001 is that there was no place to hide. Nine of the 10 S.& P. 500 sectors were down, the exception being consumer discretionary companies. 

Q. What does the market's strong recent performance tell you about 2002?

A. My basic pitch is that I don't want people to get too bearish on earnings and too bullish on stocks. The bears think earnings are going to stink, and the bulls think recovery in the economy will be huge. We will get some earnings growth, but it doesn't mean Nasdaq 5,000 all over again.

Q. Why do you part with the bears on corporate earnings?

A. First, earnings in 2001 will be down by a record amount. The reduction has been unbelievable. And, second, managements have had record restructurings, on the order of $130 billion. Plants are being closed and people are being fired, which should help the bottom line.

Q. Do you think technology stocks can continue their strong run of the last three months?

A. Technology stocks right now are trading at 48 times forward earnings. That is a little rich for my blood. I'm not saying not to play in the technology space. It is too big a part of the market. But you can say no to the speculative stuff, or areas where there is massive excess capacity, like telecommunications.

Q. What sort of investing approach would you advise?

A. The message we are sending to clients is to throw out a lot of traditional playbooks. The market this year has been really funky: the two worst-performing sectors were utilities and technology. I don't think that has ever happened.
We are taking an eclectic approach. I would own health care, which is not eclectic, but also industrial commodity stocks, like paper and chemicals, and a combination of retailers, some media companies and some auto suppliers. Three of those sectors are cyclical. The fourth, health care, is acyclical. 
The other message is that people have to get more creative. There are opportunities outside the mainstream, big-cap stuff. People need to look at small-cap stocks, at international markets, at corporate or high-yield bonds. 
Emerging markets are very cheap. It would not be dumb to look there, particularly if we get any kind of global recovery. 

Q. What asset mix would you recommend for 2002?

A. We think it is pretty traditional -- 65 percent stocks, 35 percent bonds.
Over the last 18 months, bonds outperformed stocks by a greater percentage than during any similar period since the Great Depression. 
Bond prices are not going to rally much further, but we take the low yields literally: the market is sending us a message that we are in a low-return environment. That is why I think stock returns in 2002 will be in the mid- to high-single-digit range. 

Q. What developments might make you change your outlook?

A. If Japan, Europe or Argentina get a lot worse, that will hurt, because about one-third of S.& P. 500 earnings come from abroad.
On the upside, if the fourth quarter turns out to be good and we don't get a slowdown early in 2002, then there will be upside through the year. That said, if we don't get really decent earnings gains by the third and fourth quarter, when the year-over-year comparisons are going to be much easier, we are in serious trouble.

Q. Which stocks do you favor?

A. Industrial companies like Caterpillar and ITT Industries, Schlumberger in oil services, International Paper and Eastman Chemical in the industrial raw material area. Airline stocks like AMR. A hotel stock like Starwood. And retailers like Barnes & Noble and Abercrombie & Fitch.

HEADLINE: MIRROR, MIRROR; 
Black Is the New Black

BYLINE:  By Penelope Green 

 BODY:
THE Thursday before Christmas was mild and sunny, yet if you squinted through the late afternoon sunlight, you might have discerned a somber pattern: At the Museum of Modern Art gift shop on Spring Street, three 50-ish women in black leather motorcycle jackets drifted past the felt coasters and bowls on the sale table. On Broadway and 44th Street, a rather conventionally dressed woman sported a black leather skullcap; a young man on West Ninth Street rushed by in black jeans, black T-shirt and black motorcycle jacket. This was not "fashion" black, but old-style urban black, the sort made by American companies like Schott and Walker.
 "Those things are our best sellers," said Lisa Lehar, a saleswoman at International Boutique on La Guardia Place, which sells Schott motorcycle jackets, United States Navy oxfords, Walker steel-toe boots and religious items like rosaries and menorahs. Sales have hardly dipped this fall. "If you're going to buy one thing, it will probably be in black," Ms. Lehar said. 
 New York City looks a little rougher these days, a little raw and dark, and all of a sudden, some New Yorkers do, too. After years of flirting with irrational exuberance in clothing, trying on the sorts of colors usually seen only in places like Texas or Palm Beach, New Yorkers have reverted to the all-black wardrobe that is their birthright, their armor and their sword. Never mind that for a regrettable moment even Giorgio Armani and Helmut Lang fell for the credo that "pink is the new black."
"I had to go to the A.T.M. the other night," said one of my friends, who was pondering his black steel-capped boots and black leather jacket, "and it was late and I was uneasy in a way I hadn't been in a long time." He stepped gingerly past an individual at the door who clearly had no more compelling place to spend the evening, and felt as if the last eight years had never happened. "You want steel-capped boots and your black motorcycle jacket in times like these," he said, not altogether kidding.
For her spring 2002 collection, Alice Roi, a young New York designer, made clothes exclusively in black and gray. "I had done all these really wild collections and colors and short skirts, and that disgusted me," she said. "I wanted to do something serious, and black is very, very serious."
Black is the color of change, said Cristina Bornstein, who is the Tina of Tony & Tina Vibrational Remedies, a makeup line that is one part conceptual art project, one part whimsy.
"In color therapy, black is considered the first color," Ms. Bornstein said. "In the Hopi tradition, the rainbow sprang out of the color black, thus implying to us that black encourages forward movement. Socially, black is a mask: nobody knows what mood you're in if you're wearing black." Ms. Bornstein, suddenly remembering her role as a cosmetics company executive, suggested contemplating a black nail polish called Dark Matter. 
Black has historical cycles, as hemlines used to. "Colors have a clear cultural resonance," explained Valerie Steele, a fashion historian and the acting director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. They are not just the result of whatever is trendy in a given season.
Ms. Steele can describe a century of black: Black as the color of mourning during World War I. Black in the 1920's, in Chanel's little black dress (designed, some say, to mourn the death of a lover) and as an appropriately serious foil to the new role of women. Black in the 1950's as a chic little uniform -- the black cocktail dress with pearls. "Black at this point had a lot to do with 'being correct,' " Ms. Steele said. 
"This was a period when fashion went mass in a big way," she continued. "It wasn't just the socialites and the upper middle class wanting to be fashionable; it was the housewife." Black was an easy solution; black helped you conform. In her book "Fifty Years of Fashion" (Yale University Press, 2000), Ms. Steele reprinted a men's wear ad from the period that warns: "You're being watched! Dress right -- you can't afford not to!"
Black was all things in the 1950's: it was serious and intellectual on the beats, sexy and dangerous on bad boys like Brando and James Dean. The 1960's were purple, and the 1970's were beige, at least until the very end. By 1977, black had returned. Black was punk, then, and black was gay, in the new macho-leather styles. In the 1980's, black was avant-garde, the favored color of the Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo, who declared that she designed in seven shades of black. Black was for career women, too, dressed by Donna Karan in black cashmere. By 1990, black was a cliche.
"Now the riffraff are wearing it," the Village Voice essayist Cynthia Heimel lamented at the time. "People who know what 'leveraged buyout' means wear black. Wearing black has lost its intrinsic meaning."
This is around the time Ms. Kawakubo issued her second color koan: "Red is black," she said simply, and shut the door on the whole subject for the rest of the decade.
Last spring, in Paris, a team of fashion designers named Viktor & Rolf held a runway show they called the Black Hole. They painted the models' faces and hands black and dressed them in beautiful and slightly kinky, slightly Victorian and utterly black clothes. If the models closed their eyes, they looked like 19th-century cut-paper silhouettes. Actually, a lot of the European designers made a lot of black clothes, and a trend seemed indicated.
Many in the business described the designers as sensitive and prescient, equating their black palette with the darkening economic picture. Stores like Bloomingdale's bought and displayed liberal amounts of the stuff. Had you wandered into the shops in those first few weeks of early fall, you would have noted an eerie and parallel sobriety that was in keeping with the hideous reality of the street. Of course, nobody did wander into the stores much back then, and this particular black look ended up in a real black hole, as a seriously underrealized chapter in recent fashion history.
Is the color worth reviving?
"I think it's still a cliche," Tonne Goodman, the fashion director of Vogue magazine, said the other day. "And in New York it feels inappropriate. I certainly don't want to wear black. Too many people are in real mourning."
Kal Ruttenstein, fashion director for Bloomingdale's, worried that his fall windows were too dark. "We felt it was an important fashion color for the fall season," he said, stressing the word "fashion." "And so we went for it in a rather big way. It wasn't because of the economy. We don't believe that when the economy is rough, black comes to the fore."
Sometimes, he allowed, "black is the brightest color of all." In any case, Bloomingdale's spring windows will be white.
"When we saw black coming back last season, it had to do with that corsety-kinky-Victorian look," Ms. Steele said, "with Nicolas Ghesquiere switching from angel white to black and Tom Ford doing a dark purple that was like black. And then the whole season was abortive because of the recession and Sept. 11. Now nobody knows or even cares where fashion is going. If you're seeing black at all, it has to be a vernacular movement coming up from the street."
Ms. Steele, it should be noted, was wearing black leather pants and a black knit shirt. "My shoes are green," she said, "but they were a mistake."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ELMHURST; 
In Little Argentina, Transplants Watch As Their Homeland Unravels

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
The intersection of Junction Boulevard and Corona Avenue in Elmhurst is the New York center for all things Argentine. That means a sizzling skirt steak at El Gauchito restaurant, a cup of steaming mate with flaky vigilantes at the Rio de la Plata Bakery and a haircut from Carlos Liberti's barbershop. (There's nothing particularly Argentine about the haircut, but the shop doubles as an informal employment office for newly arrived compatriots and as the local spot to watch Argentine television via satellite.) 
 These days, Argentine Corner is also where many of New York's 14,000 Argentines come to discuss the economic crisis in their homeland. The crisis has made international news over the last 10 days with televised images of looting and the resignation of President Fernando de la Rua. 
 "Of course we're all talking about it," said Roberto Moyano, a 28-year-old car painter who has been in New York for a year and a half. Mr. Moyano sends more than $1,000 a month to his wife and son in Buenos Aires -- the salary his wife earns as a seamstress does not go far -- and talks to them almost every day. "All jobs are affected," he added. "Every day, the same money buys you less."
In interviews the other day, many Argentines said their relatives and friends back home were desperate to leave. That raises the question of whether New York, which is often a way station or destination for people escaping political and economic turmoil, should expect a flood of immigrants from Argentina.
John R. Logan, a professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Albany and an expert on immigration, said the city should expect some immigrants, but not a flood.
"The economic problems have been building for such a long time," he said of Argentina. "And there hasn't been a substantial migration." 
Some local residents agreed, saying that even people who want to leave cannot afford the plane fare. But others said they had seen many recent arrivals. 
"Lots of people are coming now," said Paola Maldonado, 21, who works at the Rio de la Plata Bakery. "We have family in Argentina that is suffering. They ask us for money, or for help in coming here and getting settled." A customer, Yanela Pena, 17, added that her aunt had decided to come to New York because of the crisis.
Almost everyone agreed on one thing: that government corruption had caused their homeland's economic woes.
"What we discuss the most is the robberies committed by Argentine officials," said Guillermo Cortez, a plumber from the Mendoza province. Which official deserves blame is a question that leads to much debate.
It is easier to understand the harsh economic realities."I have friends who say they can't stand it anymore," Mr. Cortez said. "There is nothing to eat. They can only think of leaving."
He vowed never to return: "To return to Argentina is to return to nothing."
 SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT; 
Where Edible Flowers Are as Easy to Come By as Eggs

BYLINE:  By MATT SEDENSKY 

 BODY:
Baby artichokes on the Food Network, chocolate chip cookies at Dean & DeLuca and pink radishes at JoJo on the Upper East Side all have something surprising in common. They come from Hunts Point in the South Bronx.
 "Before, food was coming here from all over the world, but it wasn't exotic," said Josephine Infante, president of the Hunts Point Local Development Corporation. 
 The demands of supermarkets and restaurants began changing about five years ago, Ms. Infante said, reflecting the desires of both affluent, highly educated customers and emerging ethnic groups. As a result, all kinds of foods now pass through Hunts Point, including Japanese sweet limes, tofu and epazote, a Mexican herb.
More than 150 food businesses at Hunts Point import items from about 60 countries. One third of those importers sell fine foods, Ms. Infante said, and the number has been rising steadily. 
"This is a growing industry," she said.
"And the fish market is going to have a multiplied effect on these foods as well," she added, referring to the Fulton Fish Market, which has moved there.
Indian Rock Produce, a high-end food company from Quakertown, Pa., set up a satellite branch in Hunts Point in September.
"You'd be foolish not to move to New York," said Albert J. Buehrer, president of the company, which sells things like gooseberries and edible flowers to the Ritz-Carlton and others. Hunts Point was designated an economic development zone in 1994, and Indian Rock is one of 130 businesses there that receive tax credits and other incentives.
"It certainly wasn't the place I wanted to do business," said Jeff C. Lichtenstein, owner of Gourmet Guru, which sells specialty foods like organic cheese. "It doesn't have the romance of some other locations, but people in the know realize this is becoming the food hub of the area."
Hunts Point has a total of 800 businesses on its 329-acre site, an area that makes it one of the world's largest food distribution centers. It added about 100 new businesses in 2000, and an estimated 150 new businesses were added this year.
"What can't you buy here?" asked Mr. Buehrer. MATT SEDENSKY

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Back to the Fold: From Dot-Com to Dad and Mom

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
AS a teenager growing up in Salem, Va., John Reynolds spent his summers working at Reynolds Siding, a remodeling company his parents have owned for more than three decades. He returned to work there after college, but he soon grew restless.
 "I wanted to do something different, to live in a different town and not work with my parents," said Mr. Reynolds, who is now 27. "I didn't understand how the working world worked, the demands, that people are expected to do work and have responsibilities. Also, having my parents as my bosses -- I didn't like that. They treated me like a kid." 
 In 1997, Mr. Reynolds left the family business to pursue a doctorate in theology at Duke University; he hoped to teach some day. But a year later, he changed his mind again and decided to work as a clerk for a law firm in Richmond, Va. 
Still unhappy, he returned to the family business in the summer of 2000. He is now a vice president for sales and marketing, and he is enjoying his work. "Once I worked for the attorneys I realized it doesn't matter who your bosses are, you're not always going to like them," Mr. Reynolds said. 
He said his parents welcomed his return. "They hadn't realized that I was an asset to them, and now they do," he said. 
Mr. Reynolds is among many young people who have decided to work at family-owned businesses. Some have grown disenchanted with the outside business world. Others have been forced to return after receiving pink slips or watching their new-economy dreams disintegrate, experts on family companies say. 
Nearly 90 percent of American businesses are family owned or controlled, according to the Institute for Family-Owned Business at the University of Southern Maine. (Among them are big-name companies like Cargill, Anheuser-Busch, Levi Strauss, Gap and Hallmark Cards.) Yet only 30 percent of the family-owned businesses in the country survive into the second generation, 13 percent into the second and fewer than 3 percent into the third, the institute said.
Whether the influx of adult children to family businesses will have a long-lasting effect on the companies remains to be seen. "I don't know where it's going to come out, but it's an interesting time," said Fredda Herz Brown, managing partner of the Metropolitan Group, a consulting firm in Tenafly, N.J., that works with family businesses. "It's so dependent on the economy and what's happening in particular industries. There's such tremendous, rapid change."
Many young people who come from families that own businesses return to the fold after a few years in the outside world, said Ann Dugan, founder and executive director of the Family Enterprise Center at the Katz Graduate School of Business at the University of Pittsburgh. 
"Even though what they say is one thing, when they see what the reality is in the outside world in terms of salaries and status and perks, they usually reconsider," she said. "Also, as they get older, people understand that they really do want to make a contribution to the family business -- that usually the family name is somehow affiliated with it, if not on the name of the business itself. And there is sort of a pride and ego that kicks in at that point as well."
Although many adult children, like Mr. Reynolds, had once said they would never work for the family -- fearing that it would be nepotistic or a sign of personal weakness -- they are finding it necessary to return to the nest. Still others wish that their parents had a nest they could return to.
Bill Shapiro, the founding editor in chief of MBA Jungle, a magazine for aspiring young executives, said he thought that nepotism was slowly losing its stigma. In fact, he included a favorable article about nepotism in the magazine's September issue.
"Nepotism makes good business sense; you probably feel more pressure to perform if Dad is signing your paycheck and your family name is on the company stationery," he said in an interview. "Also, relatives are often more efficient in their daily dealings. Relatives perceive one another's thoughts and emotions so viscerally and so quickly that an arched eyebrow or nervous tapping of the pen can take the place of a three-page memo."
COMPANY loyalty is also a factor for those joining the family business. "Everybody at the company -- from the board of directors to management to the line employees -- knows that you're not going to leave the firm and go to the competition for a fatter paycheck," Mr. Shapiro added. 
Joining the family business is also a chance to reconnect with family members, as Patrick Amori is learning. In March 2000, Mr. Amori, 29, left his job as an advertising account executive to help his father run Il Covo Dell'Est, an Italian restaurant in the East Village in Manhattan. Although he had earned a decent salary as an account executive and had many people working for him, "it wasn't what I wanted to do," said Mr. Amori, who is now the restaurant manager.
"I wanted to see what my father does every day; I wanted to see a side that was different from what I saw as a kid, when he would work all day and come home at night tired," he said. "Now I'm able to be part of his life and try to do good for the family."
Others have also found their experience rewarding. Melissa Wilson, 24, had never imagined working at Tito's Tacos, the taco stand started 43 years ago by her great-grandfather in Culver City, Calif. It now employs 70 people. "My family is a bunch of entrepreneurs, and I felt like it would be the easy way out if I worked for them," she said of her initial hesitation to join the company. "Plus, the business has caused lots of problems in the family because it was so successful -- people fighting about who's going to inherit it."
Two years ago, during the Internet boom, she graduated from the University of San Francisco with a degree in international relations and took a position as a Bay Area office manager at Icon Medialab, a Swedish company that helps businesses develop Internet marketing strategies. She said she received incentives including a high salary, overseas training classes, four-week vacations and promises of a promotion.
But as the months unfolded, it became clear that she was not going to be promoted as quickly as she had hoped. Her peers were being laid off, she said, and she felt she was in a dead-end job. So she quit and looked for new work, living off credit cards and saddling herself with $10,000 in debt. The only available jobs were other office-manager positions, which she did not want. Finally, she began working as a manager at the taco stand last April. Much to her surprise, she said, she is happy.
"I have the freedom to do things here I wanted to do at my dot-com and didn't realize I could do at a restaurant," she said. "I'm in a management position at the most famous taco stand in Southern California, making more money than I could ever have dreamed."
Having relatives as bosses can be difficult, she conceded, because it can be hard to separate business from family. But mostly, she added, "it's a blessing in disguise."
Ira Bryck, director of the University of Massachusetts Family Business Center in Amherst, Mass., cautions family businesses not to hire newly unemployed relatives just because they worry about their futures. "A family business that's going to grow has to make sure it's hiring based on the needs of the business," said Mr. Bryck, whose own family owned a children's wear store, Barasch's Kidstore, for four generations.
"The proper thing for the family business to do is a need assessment and say, 'Despite the fact that this person is in need, does our business need that member?' " he said. "Family business is not just a place to hide out -- it's a place to make contributions, to add your skills and talents. It's important for family members to say: 'You're going to have to commit to this company as you would to any company. You're not here to hide out until the economy heals itself.' "
Mr. Bryck predicted that family businesses in general would undergo many changes in the next 20 years, particularly as family-business owners of the baby boom generation retire. Some will be looking to expand by buying other businesses, and others will be looking to sell. "So there is an opportunity for family members to help grow the business," he said.
Many young people say that is exactly what they plan to do. "I want to franchise the company all over the country," Ms. Wilson said of the taco stand. "Then I want to retire."

HEADLINE: The Fine Art Of Being A Homebody 

BYLINE:  By KATE BETTS 

 BODY:
It was the kind of party you can't write about if you ever want to be invited back. Oh, not because of drugs or lubricious goings-on. Here's the scene:
 After passing muster with a couple of list-toting doorkeepers, you enter the landmark six-story Greenwich Village town house. A party captain takes your coat, placing it in a large plastic bag that is passed bucket-brigade-style down to the basement. (Sackcloth or sable is whisked away with equal aplomb.) 
 Upstairs, past the Damien Hirst paintings, you enter the luxurious, Lee Mindel-designed family rooms, where amid a sea of children, the Grinch is rear-projected on a giant flat screen, waitresses ferry heaping plates of pigs in blankets and peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and a glamorous crowd of adults who used to meet at a corner booth in Balthazar is discussing mortgage rates and the joy of slippers. 
Can this be New York, the high-heeled city where people who couldn't afford living rooms exported their nightly socializing to bars, galleries and restaurants?
For years, New Yorkers have turned public places into private spaces with the help of velvet ropes, party planners and ruthless attention to every detail of class and status.
Now suddenly home is where the heat is, the private living room the sanctum sanctorum of the social scene. A whole new set of protocols is required: dress codes, food, even the rules of self-promotion. A best-dressed crowd that used to go out largely to be photographed is now seeking privacy, which is why this fiesta in Greenwich Village, given by an art-collecting couple, was strictly off the record. 
"Nobody wants to entertain in a restaurant or a public place," said Serena Bass, the owner of a catering company. "They want to be huddled around their fireplaces, and they want it to be personal. We get a lot of requests for the food to look homemade, not catered. They want shepperd's pie, meatloaf and grilled cheese." 
Some attribute the retreat to a craving for intimacy and familiarity, after the wrenching dislocations of Sept. 11. Others see a return to frugality and inconspicuous consumption in a recession. 
And there is the need for the safety of home, rather than the vulnerability some still feel in public places, a mood that is widespread as New Yorkers prepare to celebrate New Year's Eve more privately than in the recent past. Restaurants report far fewer bookings for tomorrow night than in previous years. 
Traditional year-end benefits like the New York Botanical Garden's Winter Wonderland Ball and the Metropolitan Museum Costume Institute's so-called party of the year, which brought out the city's swellest in their sequins, are not being held this year.
Instead of limousines purring outside the latest incandescent restaurant, people are marveling about the carefully set tables they see at friends' homes -- tables to rival those measured out inch by inch in Robert Altman's brilliant exercise in to-the-manner-born Anglophilia, "Gosford Park."
"I hate to say it, but we have seen incredible business because of 9/11, especially parties for 10, 12 or 15," said Steven Attoe, who with Robert Caravaggi owns RSVP, a new catering company. "People want to be at home, and they want to see their friends." The partners, who also own Swifty's restaurant, on the Upper East Side, encourage customers to bring their own casseroles dishes when placing catering orders. 
For the last 10 years, New York women have perfected a ubiquitous social uniform of spaghetti-strap dress with Manolo Blahnik stilettos. It has gone everywhere in public and has been above reproach. 
Now the look of the moment is very different. At the Greenwich Village town house, it belonged not to the adults but to one of the Grinchkins, a budding member of what's called the tween demographic, who was scampering around in a taffeta hostess skirt from Calypso, a cardigan and ballet slippers.
Anne Kennedy, an agent for fashion photographers, who gave a birthday party for the novelist Frederic Tuten at her downtown home, chose slippers and looked much more chic than the darlings still hoofing around in spikes. "For a minute, I thought about wearing heels, but I never would in my own house," Ms. Kennedy explained. "It has to be more casual, but you still want to be somewhat glamorous."
"Cozy is not the word from hell anymore," said the designer Michael Kors. "The look is very 'Ice Storm,' New Canaan dressing at home. I see Geoffrey Beene pajamas at a fondue party. It goes back to the roots of American evening dressing. You know, the Claire McCardell cozy glamour look."
Mr. Kors, who between business trips to Paris, Milan and Japan squeezed in two dinner parties of his own this fall, marveled: "There are people in New York who have known each other for 15 years, and they've never invited each other over until now."
Vladimir Kagan, who designed the furniture in Gucci stores, gave a dinner party with his wife, Erica Wilson, at their Upper East Side apartment last Sunday "for all my stray-dog friends," he said, hastening to add, "but the guests were not dogs." 
"For us, the home is an oasis, especially now," Mr. Kagan said. 
While some would argue that generations of couples, particularly those who came of age in the 1950's and 60's, have always entertained at home, there's a whole new generation of fashionable people who are opening their shoji screens and loft elevator doors to friends they never thought of inviting over.
"People who were using restaurants as extensions of their personal space have changed that and brought people into their homes," observes Ruth Reichl, the editor in chief of Gourmet magazine, who is devoting her February issue to the family. "The fear people had about opening their homes is gone. And we all just continually talked about not wanting to be in public spaces, so the family/home issue made sense." 
At Gallagher's book shop on East 12th Street, a coveted address for fashion designers and photographers looking for inspiration in old books and magazines, the hot seller is Gourmet magazine from the 1940's and 50's.
"It's very surprising, but we have seen a lot of interest in the interior stuff from that period and all of the entertaining books," said Mike Gallagher, who is more accustomed to requests for old copies of Vogue from that period. "I think fashion people are paying more attention to the home and to entertaining."
This year, the designers Mark Badgley and James Mischka gave their annual Christmas party at home instead of in a restaurant, and to give it an even more personal feeling, they whipped up all of the lamb chops, shrimp and duck canapes themselves. 
On a similar note, the handbag designer Kate Spade recently found herself cooking roast chicken and chocolate chip cookies for Eve, her sister, until 1 o'clock in the morning.
Does this mean aprons and oven mittens will be next year's successor to last season's Fendi baguette? How does the dress code for a night on the town change when the fashion flock migrates from the restaurant and ballroom to the living room (and maybe even into the kitchen)? Is it merely a matter of trading in a gown for a blouse and a pair of jeans? Or opting for ballet slippers instead of stilettos?
SOME prescient designers have already whipped up a couture-meets-Cuisinart look for spring. Miuccia Prada's favorite evening outfit offers gold brocade pajama tops complete with piping. And designers as diverse as Alberta Ferretti and Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi are championing a softer, gauzy nightgown look, which would curl up nicely in front of a fireplace. At Gucci, Tom Ford has swapped his signature tight, sexy second-wife silhouette for a slouchy pair of paper-bag-waist pajama pants, which could look just as chic driving the car pool as they could on the veranda at cocktail hour.
"I think special-occasion clothes could be driven by this now, much more than the red carpet," said Josh Patner, a designer of the Tuleh label, a favorite of the young Upper East Side social crowd. "People do want to get dressed up, but not in the scrutiny of the world. Everybody is feeling antihype. People do not seem interested in pumped-up fantasy. It seems unfriendly. It is about having people in your house whom you actually like. It's not networky and air-kissy."
Marc Jacobs, whose widely imitated Louis Vuitton collection for spring was inspired by embroidery and handicrafts, sees a continuing emphasis on all things homemade and comfortable. "We were all in a very craft mode, and we felt this is the right time for that kind of warmth, comfort and human feel," Mr. Jacobs said.
The designer, long a mainstay of fashionable drinking places, was spending the weeks before Christmas making his home in Paris cozy for a visit from an old friend and her son. "I really want everything to be perfect," he said. "I have to have the perfect tree, the presents, the food. I've become quite obsessive about it." 
Of course, homey and informal are concepts open to interpretation, and they can mean something very different, depending on the individuals and their addresses. At a Christmas party in the elaborately decorated Fifth Avenue apartment of the socialite Patricia Altschul, one guest noticed that most of the women, including Nan Kempner and Annette de la Renta, were wearing haute couture, even as the canapes being passed consisted of pigs in blankets and Krispy Kreme doughnuts.
"It's a compliment to the hostess to dress up a little bit," said Marina Rust Conner, a stylish fixture at charity galas and in the party pages of fashion magazines. "And when someone like Nan Kempner says very casual, very informal spaghetti dinner, you know that means you can wear velvet pants and the men should wear ties. And it also means that some people will be in couture."
Perhaps the biggest challenge to the style-setting crowd who are used to going out five nights a week is not what to wear and what to serve. It's figuring out what to say.
"When people are in your home, they actually talk," said Daniel Romualdez, an interior decorator. "They open up and talk about things that are personal. It's not that kind of mindless conversation you get at those benefit dinners where everyone just recites their recent travel itineraries." 
Here's a New Year's resolution for the reformed velvet-rope crowd: return the borrowed ball gowns and stop talking about fashion.
Oh, maybe next year.

HEADLINE: The Life Serene 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE O'DONNELL 

 BODY:
IT was the day that Sister Mary of the Incarnation would take her final vows of chastity, poverty and obedience as a cloistered Dominican nun and bride of Christ. The small chapel of the Corpus Christi Monastery was full of female heads shrouded by veils and those whose uncovered hairdos had frizzed in the light December rain.
 With her back to the congregation, Sister Mary of the Incarnation stood before the priest on the altar and bowed. Her long black veil, worn specially for this occasion, stopped short of her white socks and sturdy dark shoes. 
 "Behold, dear sister, two crowns: one comely, the other of thorns," the priest said. A circlet of prickly branches and another of fresh roses and lavender were presented. 
As Sister Mary of the Incarnation gestured to choose the thorns, her face became visible: deeply flushed and smiling. The prioress, Sister Maria Pia, beamed as she wriggled the crown of thorns over Sister Mary's pink forehead.
"Are you resolved to give yourself to God alone, in solitude and silence, in persevering prayer and willing penance, in humble labor and good works?" the prioress asked.
Sister Mary of the Incarnation responded: "I am, with God's help and yours."
The wedding was over.
Afterward, Sister Mary mingled in the parlor with relatives who clutched cake plates and cameras. The next time they visited, she would stand in the cloister, the nuns' private domain, and greet them from the window that divided her world from theirs. But for now she moved happily among her guests, offering more cake and shyly posing for pictures. 
It was a festive day after a difficult autumn.
The year just ending has been a most trying one for New Yorkers. Many people felt that the enormous scale of the tragedy unleashed on Sept. 11 tested their inner strength more keenly than ever before. In the wake of such devastating loss, New Yorkers turned inward, seeking ways to stanch the emotional pain. Attendance at houses of worship rose, as did participation in yoga and meditation classes. 
The nuns of Corpus Christi Monastery, one of three such religious enclaves in the city, have long striven to lead spiritually centered lives. Since 1890, women who have sworn themselves to Christ have lived behind a high stone wall in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx.
This year tried the fortitude of the nuns, too, as they stood on the hill in the back of their garden and, from their postage-stamp view of Lower Manhattan, watched the great towers fall. They wept, dropped to their knees and prayed. They continue to pray daily for the victims, some of whom they knew, in a special evening session. Even now, they wince at the mention of the disaster.
And yet, a visit to the monastery during the holiday season still reveals the quiet centeredness that cloistered life has long cultivated. A monastery is a home for religious men and women who remove themselves from the outside world to pray. A cloister is the part of the monastery that only those who have taken vows may enter, to preserve the simplest form of material life and save one's mind and soul for God.
Now that the monastery, like the rest of New York, has been indelibly affected by the trade center disaster, it is the old routine of prayer that continues to give the nuns solace. Though deeply shaken, the nuns of Corpus Christi are still firmly rooted in their faith.
The monastery occupies an old gray building on Lafayette Avenue at Barretto Street surrounded by rambling, tree-filled grounds that seem to owe more to the enchanted realm of Harry Potter than to the long-troubled South Bronx. Inside the four-story structure is the cloister, the nuns' living and working quarters, which hug an inner courtyard and are off limits to visitors.
Inside the cloister, quiet and prayer are observed -- except for 30 lively minutes a day -- so the nuns can pursue contemplative life. There is no vow of silence, just an effort to speak no more than is necessary so the mind is free to roam toward God. Six times a day they meet in the chapel to recite Old Testament Psalms and standard Roman Catholic prayers, but it is contemplative life that allows individual prayer to develop subconsciously.
The very survival of this spiritual community is a small miracle: for more than a century, the nuns' way of life has withstood the monastery's unlikely site in a neighborhood infamous for drugs and prostitutes. For nearly half a century, the monastery has shared a block with the notorious Spofford Juvenile Center, once a home for troubled boys, now coeducational and topped with coils of razor wire. Four blocks away is the 41st Precinct station house, long known as Fort Apache in a nod to the crime that ravaged the neighborhood in the 70's and beyond. 
Things have improved in recent years, but statistics still paint a bleak picture: the rate of most crime has dropped, but this year the murder rate has more than doubled. What will happen as the current recession takes hold is uncertain, and some problems seem intractable. 
"You working?" the man behind the wheel of a gray Acura called to a young woman walking in front of the monastery one Sunday afternoon as he slowed down to match her stride. 
Despite efforts to close local strip clubs, prostitution still plagues the neighborhood; prostitutes work right next to the monastery's great stone wall. Cars with legitimate business in the neighborhood move quickly. The drivers of the slow ones are looking for women.
Not long ago, youngsters used to scale the wall and steal tomatoes from the garden. Addicts tossed needles over the wall and, once, a mattress with little spring left. The razor wire installed a decade ago has not kept drug dealers from lingering at the bottom of the hill, just outside the wall.
The nuns are not oblivious to these incongruities. They pass out food and blankets to those who ring their bell in need. But inside the wall, only the sounds of the South Bronx seep in. Corpus Christi is in the city, but somehow it is not really of the city.
From the hill in the garden, the city's flattened skyline appears gray and crowded, not particularly inviting compared with the monastery's rambling trees and gardens. Gnarled poplars and elms dwarf the towers of Manhattan, and the Empire State Building is a stickpin next to a statue of the Virgin Mary in the foreground.
Most people would say the nuns live cut off from the real world. Yet the nuns believe that within the cloister's walls they have found the real world and that silence allows them to maintain their prayerful way of life. 
"Silence humbles the mind and detaches it from the world; it would create a kind of solitude in the heart like that you court," Fenelon, the archbishop of Cambrai, wrote the countess of Gramont in 1690. "It would supply much that you need under present difficulties."
While the world outside the wall has changed from rambling country estates to a crack-ravaged neighborhood slowly brushing itself off, the world inside has had a subtler metamorphosis. In the old days, Corpus Christi, like other local monasteries, had a house full of nuns. Back then, they were divided into three categories: lay nuns who did the cooking and cleaning; extern nuns who dealt with the outside world; and choir nuns, the only ones who lived in the cloister and who did the creative chores of writing prayers and composing music.
But as the spring of vocations dried up, orders stopped segregating the nuns. Now the monastery has 18 nuns (down from 57 at the peak in 1919), 17 choir nuns and one extern, who share all the household work and support themselves by selling communion wafers to nearby churches.
The nuns are all avid gardeners, growing roses, herbs and vegetables that this year have thrived into December. Sister Roseanne, 83, is one of the most enthusiastic gardeners. Last year, she had heard of an earth-moving machine and decided to rent one for the dormant front garden. She called equipment rental companies and, in her lilting Irish accent, explained her gardening needs. 
Are you sure it's a backhoe you need? The rental company employees asked. Yes, it is, she answered. The questioning continued. Finally, someone guessed that what she really wanted was a rototiller. It was delivered, and Sister Roseanne, who entered the monastery as a choir nun trained in art and music, operated it herself.
Sister Mary St. John is the last extern at Corpus Christi. She is 75, and has been a nun for 48 years. For most of that time, she slept alone in a room just outside the cloister. During the day she bustled around the perimeter of the cloister answering the front door and tending the garden with the other nuns. 
As the externs died and no new ones took their place, the prioress had their rooms renovated into guest quarters for outsiders who came on retreat. 
Sister Mary St. John moved inside the cloister to sleep. But she still occupies the perimeter of the cloister, acting like the moat of a medieval castle. A door in the front hall leads to the extern basement, where she cares for Chrysostom, the monastery's shy Siamese cat. There is also the giant asparagus fern Sister Mary St. John tries to coax back to health, despite the needles it drops like a Christmas tree in January. The basement, neat and warm, suggests a feminine rec room, decorated with cut flowers, pictures of the pope and a prayer book from the 1960's inscribed "Sr. Mary St. John."
Chrysostom is domesticated, and, like his mistress, does not wander far from his quarters. The one time the nun opened the window for him to go out and roam, he came back with ear mites. Sister Mary St. John knows all the squirrels on the grounds and has been keeping an eye on the ripening pregnancy of a raccoon that has taken shelter in the crawl space under the chapel. 
One afternoon a busload of middle-age Catholics from Westchester arrived for Mass in the chapel. People do this occasionally: visit and pray in the small chapel attached to the choir that serves as the nuns' own cloistered chapel, separated by three sets of Gothic-arched doors. 
The Westchester parishioners appeared well off. The men were silver-haired retirees, and the women wore silk scarves and carried leather handbags. The lipstick of the women looked as if it had been freshly reapplied before they stepped off the bus. A lapel pin read, "Jesus is the reason for the season."
The nuns greeted them all warmly. They liked having visitors, which meant they could open the large windows of the cloister's parlor and chat with their guests before evening vespers.
Sister Mary St. John stayed outside the cloister with the guests. Her cheeks were rosy from laughing and entertaining. The contrast between her light polyester robe and the wools and silks of the visitors was almost as pronounced as their differing complexions. Sister Mary St. John has soft skin that is virtually wrinkle-free. The skin of the Westchester women, many in their 50's and 60's, looked made-up and tired. 
The women surrounded the nun, trying to understand what it was, exactly, that she did all day. Sister Mary St. John was in a teasing mood. "Besides feeding the pussycat?" she answered.
Mass was beginning, and the wools and silks streamed down the corridor to the chapel.
"Sometimes, because of the noise of the world in which we live, the longing of the human spirit is crushed," the priest said in his homily. "When we come to a place like this, it is a gift, isn't it?"
A typical day. The nuns rise at 5:30 and walk noiselessly into the chapel, filling it by 6:15 a.m. Six days a week their mornings begin this way. On Sundays they sleep for an extra hour.
Some stay up all night in the chapel praying. The nuns take turns adoring the perpetual display of the Blessed Sacrament, the body and blood of Jesus in the form of the communion host.
Over the years, contemplative life wears away at the words of formal prayer like water smoothing stones, and adoring the Blessed Sacrament provides ample time for contemplation. It takes experience to be able to pray that way. But when it happens, it brings the nuns joy, because that is the type of prayer that transcends everything material: words, music, everything.
Still, they follow the rule of St. Augustine and gather in the chapel six times daily for formal prayer. This morning, like all mornings, the 18 nuns sit in two groups on either side of the chapel facing one another as they sing the Psalms. The room is lighted by electricity and candles, and predawn darkness presses against the windowpanes.
"Glory be to the Father and to the Son and to the Holy Spirit," they sing, bowing deeply. "As it was in the beginning, is now and will be forever, amen." 
Sister Mary Dominick, the one novice, stifles a yawn. She is 21, is from Vancouver Island in Canada, has been at the monastery for a year and a half, and wears the white habit that means she has yet to take her final vows, when she will exchange it for a cream-colored gown and short black veil. She is young enough to have a teenager's imperfect skin and modern enough to have perfectly straightened teeth.
When she arrived at the monastery to meet the nuns, she was still a teenager in many ways. They had gathered in the courtyard to pose for the picture to put on their annual Christmas card, and Sister Mary Dominick wandered off and climbed the awning over the loggia. Leaping off, she landed in a heap on the grass. Heavens! The nuns rushed to her side, expecting every bone to be broken. Sister Mary Dominick grinned at them. She was fine.
A few minutes after 7, the Rev. Peter Bannan arrives. Every weekday, Father Bannan drives from Pelham in Westchester County to say Mass. On days when he cannot be there, a nun takes out the telephone directory and calls around to parishes to see who else can come. 
The Gospel this day is about the poor widow who gave two small coins to the temple and the rich man who made a larger donation. There is a click as Sister Mary Imelda presses play and record on her tape recorder, even though the noise sometimes bothers the nuns sitting around her.
Later, Sister Mary Imelda played back Father Bannan's homily, and wrote it out longhand to save with all of his other homilies she had saved over the years. She thought they were wonderful. Would make a wonderful book.
"Burn them," he said.
"Sometimes," Sister Mary St. John said quietly, "you get so wrapped up in yourself it's hard to find Jesus in here." She paused to consider how odd that sounds coming from a cloister. "I guess anywhere you are, you can get too wrapped up in yourself," she said.
Every day after lunch, there is a 30-minute recreation period when the nuns talk and play Ping-Pong and badminton. They can be quite boisterous, and they take a bit of pride in Sister Mary St. John's professing shock that these are the same choir nuns she knows. Then follows an hour of profound silence.
At 7 p.m., the nuns flow back into the chapel's choir for compline. They sing the Psalms as rain patters outside. A plane passes overhead. Then Sister Maria Pia, the prioress, reads the closing prayer. In a few minutes, profound silence will begin and last until morning prayer.
But the nuns do not leave the chapel. Someone rises to turn off the lights and blow out the candles. Formal prayer is over. In the dimness, the dull memory of light keeps barely visible the outlines of the habits. In the last three months, the nuns have been contemplating the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, praying for the victims but without using words. It is the most powerful way they know how to pray.
Then one by one, the figures silently leave the chapel.

HEADLINE: Even the Smartest Money Can Slip Up 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
"The more intense the craze, the higher the type of intellect that succumbs to it."
Benjamin Anderson,
"Economics and the Public Welfare," 1949
 THE year just ending has been painful for most investors. It has probably hurt even more for some big names who achieved fame on Wall Street for being a bit smarter than the average guy. 
 If 2000 was the year when lucky young Internet millionaires lost it all, 2001 was the year when the smart money looked a lot less smart. Many investors whose names have for years graced the Forbes 400 list of the world's richest people lost hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars. 
Many of the superrich, in fact, got into trouble the same way so many little guys do: they got carried away by an investment fad at its very top, making ill-considered deals at the height of a market mania in 1999 and 2000 whose flaws became apparent as the economy softened. Others failed to diversify, or neglected to take profits in good times, holding on too long as highflying stocks plummeted to the single digits in price. And many who controlled companies were slow to cut back on debt when times were good. 
Though it's painful for any investor to nurse losses, it's even more embarrassing for these investors -- people like the Bass brothers of Texas and Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft co-founder, and Craig O. McCaw, the cellphone pioneer -- whose humiliation is often public.
One such investor, Abraham D. Gosman, a real estate and health care entrepreneur whose businesses have fallen on hard times -- but who is hardly a household name -- filed for personal bankruptcy protection in March. Soon after, he was mentioned by Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, as a deadbeat debtor who had shielded assets from creditors. 
Two companies that Mr. Gosman once ran -- Innovative Clinical Solutions, which provides support services to health care companies, and CareMatrix, which operates housing for the elderly -- had filed for bankruptcy in 2000. Proposing an amendment to the bankruptcy reform bill, Mr. Kohl said Mr. Gosman, once a member of the Forbes 400, had personal debts of more than $233 million but, thanks to favorable debtor laws in Florida, was hoping to hold on to his 64,000-square-foot mansion in Palm Beach. Mr. Gosman has valued the property at $40 million to $50 million, according to a recent court filing. A lawyer for Mr. Gosman did not return calls.
Most of the other centimillionaires or billionaires who got into trouble this year did not fall as far as Mr. Gosman, proving again that the rich do differ from everyone else. Many still seem to be quite wealthy -- though it is difficult to determine exactly where they stand. The rich are notoriously private and quick to punish advisers who do not maintain strict confidentiality about them. Virtually every money manager interviewed for this article declined to comment on the record, though some willingly described the behavior of customers.
"These guys are deal junkies," said one Wall Street investment banker who asked not to be identified because some of his clients were suffering. "But it's not like they bet their last nickel or anything."
THE fate of the Enron Corporation provides one example. As it plunged into bankruptcy a few weeks ago, employees were left largely without pensions because the company's 401(k) plan had invested heavily in Enron stock. But the Belfer family of New York, one of the largest individual shareholders, with stock once worth some $2 billion, retains substantial real-estate assets that cushion the blow.
Paul G. Allen, who founded Microsoft with Bill Gates but left the company years ago, also had considerable setbacks in his investment portfolio this year. But he still ranked third on Forbes magazine's survey of the rich, published in October, with a net worth of $28.2 billion. 
Mr. Allen suffered big losses on his stake in RCN, a telecommunications company. In February 2000, he invested $1.65 billion in RCN, taking a stake in the form of preferred stock convertible into 26.6 million RCN shares. Today, the stake is worth $79 million.
Fortunately for Mr. Allen, his nest egg includes some 138 million shares of Microsoft, worth almost $9.4 billion. A spokesman for Mr. Allen's investment firm, Vulcan Ventures, declined to comment.
Mr. Allen's debt status is unknown. But some of these financiers -- like overextended individuals struggling to pay their credit card bills -- simply took on too much debt during the good times of the last decade.
Just last month, chemical companies controlled by Jon Meade Huntsman, a prominent donor to the Republican Party whose son is a deputy United States trade representative, announced that they could not make interest payments on junk bonds due this month and in January. The companies, which include the Huntsman Corporation and Huntsman Polymers, carry more than $2 billion in debt and have been hit by rising costs, a result of industry overcapacity and a spike in energy prices, particularly natural gas, in 2000 and early 2001. 
Mr. Huntsman will have to offer some concession to bondholders. That may dent his net worth, which Forbes estimated at $3.8 billion. It could also put a crimp in his considerable donations to charity. A spokesman for Mr. Huntsman's companies said he had donated $350 million over the last five years, largely with profits from his chemical companies. Most of that money went to a cancer research center he formed three years ago.
Dennis R. Washington, who made his fortune in the shipping, mining and railroad industries and who rescued the construction giant Morrison Knudsen from bankruptcy in 1996, suffered, too, after his Washington Group International, as Morrison Knudsen is now known, filed for bankruptcy this year.
Mr. Washington, who was recently worth $1.6 billion, according to Forbes, stumbled after his company acquired a division from Raytheon in 2000. Shortly after the deal closed, the Washington Group said Raytheon had overstated the division's assets and understated its liabilities. (The Washington Group sued Raytheon but has since settled the suit.) 
The acquisition ended up costing the Washington Group, which had taken on $1.2 billion in debt last year partly to finance the deal, twice as much as expected, said Joel Levington, an analyst at Standard & Poor's.
"They wanted to take a stab at becoming one of the top-tier construction companies in the United States," Mr. Levington said. Instead, Mr. Washington suffered a rare setback.
Terrence Dwyer, a junk-bond analyst at KDP Investment Advisors, a research firm in Montpelier, Vt., said, "Dennis Washington is a respected entrepreneur and a really bright guy." But this latest deal was clearly a mistake, Mr. Dwyer said. "I think this was an overreach." 
A spokesman for the Washington Group, Brent Brandon, said Mr. Washington had been "fighting mad" about the outcome of the Raytheon acquisition. Mr. Brandon said, however, that the company's bankruptcy filing was hardly a personal disaster for Mr. Washington.
Though Mr. Washington lost the $200 million his shares were worth before the problems with the Raytheon acquisition were disclosed, he made at least that much this year among his other investments, Mr. Brandon said. "Basically, his net worth went sideways," he said.
Nor has Mr. Washington given up on the company. He reached an agreement with creditors that gives him options for 10 percent of the company's stock and could ultimately result in his buying a stake of 40 percent in the Washington Group, which should emerge from bankruptcy protection early next year.
Another longtime billionaire and prominent political donor, Carl H. Lindner, 82, who made his fortune in the 1970's and 80's in insurance and other investments, was hurt this year when his Chiquita Brands, the banana exporter, filed for bankruptcy protection. Mr. Lindner had expanded Chiquita's business aggressively in anticipation of increasing sales in Europe. But soon after the expansion, the European Union enacted import restrictions.
Mr. Lindner's Chiquita investment is not a majority of his net worth, but the year has also been rough for his insurance company, the American Financial Group, which faces losses related to asbestos claims and the World Trade Center attacks.
MORE than anything else, the treacherous telecommunications sector brought down the wealthy. Troubles in telecommunications, which ranked second only to the Internet in late-1990's hype, inflicted losses on several big investors who had no previous experience in the industry but who were attracted to the big leaps that telecom stocks were making in 2000. Other investors, like Craig O. McCaw, who made his fortune in cellular phones but lost billions recently on two telecommunications start-ups, should perhaps have been able to see the market overcapacity. But Mr. McCaw and others seem to have been persuaded that they had stumbled upon the next big thing -- one that had no bounds. 
In theory, these investments in telecommunications, unlike many of those in the Internet, were backed by tangible assets that could be sold if necessary for at least the value of the investors' original stakes. "People thought that if you put hard assets into the ground, at the very least you'd get your money back," one investment banker said.
In reality, there were so many telecommunications start-ups that the supply far exceeded the demand. One company, Viatel, a seller of phone and data services, had investors like Thomas O. Hicks, an owner of the Texas Rangers and chairman of the leveraged-buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst. Viatel filed for bankruptcy in May and could not muster any worthwhile bids when it tried to auction its assets in August.
To financial historians and others, the fact that so many smart people were blindsided following the crowd is not surprising. Rich people are tempted, too. They see huge profits being made by other mortals and want in on the fun. 
"If you look through history, after periods of great wealth creation, creative destruction happens," said one money manager about the big telecom losses suffered by some big names. "It makes sense that the people who did the best will be the most undisciplined. You get lulled into a sense of complacency by your success."
James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a persistent market bear, had a similar take. "So thick in the air was the pixie dust of the new economy that everyone breathed it in," he said. After a bull market of more than 20 years, he added, "even smart people were programmed to suspend belief."
SID RICHARDSON BASS and Lee Marshall Bass are another example. In the 1980's, these brothers, based in Fort Worth, became legends thanks to their savvy investments in beaten-down stocks like Walt Disney. 
But after gazing at the much larger returns being earned in technology and telecommunications, the Basses suddenly began to buy stakes in highfliers like NTL Inc., a communications services company, whose stock has fallen from nearly $50 a share in October 2000 to just 93 cents on Friday, and GlobalStar Telecommunications Ltd., a satellite telephone concern that suspended payments on its long-term debt in January and sells for 17 cents a share.
The investments were made after Sid Bass, who for years had largely delegated his investments to others, decided to take a more active role. "Sid was feeling kind of out of things," said one investor close to the family.
In September, to cope with a cash shortage, the Basses sold a 6.4 percent stake in Disney for $2 billion. A spokesman for Mr. Bass declined to comment.
Speculation by sophisticated investors and financiers is hardly unprecedented: big names in business were crushed in the 1920's, too. William C. Durant, a founder of General Motors, left that company in disgrace in 1920 after losing a fortune in stock speculation. Apparently unchastened, Mr. Durant lost a second fortune in the markets in the 1929 crash.
"He assembled G.M., but he apparently didn't have superior insight into the stock market," said Martin Fridson, chief strategist in the high-yield bond department at Merrill Lynch. "Someone can have a particular insight into an industry or investment specialty, but that talent is not necessarily transferable."
Initially, the principals of Hicks, Muse, for example, made a fortune in leveraged buyouts in industries like food and radio and television. 
But over the last few years, intense competition in the leveraged-buyout world forced Hicks, Muse to venture into areas crowded with other investors. In 1998, it teamed up with Henry R. Kravis and his partners at Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and paid $1.6 billion for Regal Cinemas, one of several theater chains acquired by buyout firms in the late 1990's. All of them opened theaters when movie attendance was shrinking. Regal filed for bankruptcy in September, and Hicks, Muse is likely to lose all of its investment in the company.
Then, at the peak of the market in late 1999 and early 2000, Hicks, Muse invested $1.3 billion in six publicly traded telecommunications companies: Globix, ICG Communications, RCN, Rhythms NetConnections, Teligent and Viatel. Four of them -- Viatel, ICG, Rhythms and Teligent -- filed for bankruptcy this year. Just last Thursday, Globix said it was considering a bankruptcy filing, as well. RCN's shares trade for less than $3 a share.
"What did Hicks, Muse know about telecommunications?" one analyst asked.
Clearly, not enough. A spokesman for Hicks, Muse declined to comment, although Mr. Hicks has promised investors that the firm will return to its original strategy.
THE successes of some of these investors in other industries make them reluctant to give up, even when the market turns against them. 
Over the last two years, Forstmann Little, which is led by Theodore J. Forstmann, has invested $2.5 billion in two struggling telecommunications start-ups: XO Communications and McLeodUSA. But in early December, even after their stocks fell to less than $1, Forstmann Little announced plans to invest more in both companies. It will put $400 million more into XO and is offering to buy McLeod's commercial-directory business for $535 million, convert its $1 billion in preferred stock into common stock and invest $100 million more in McLeod common shares. 
The investment represents a substantial percentage of the assets managed by Mr. Forstmann's firm, other investors said. "What is he trying to prove?" one money manager wondered.
A spokesman for Mr. Forstmann said that "in both cases, you have sound businesses with too much debt" and that Mr. Forstmann would be increasing his investment only after the companies reduced their debts.
For some investors, there's no shame in setbacks. Last month, Donald J. Trump -- eyeing the depressed economy and potential new rivals after New York passed a law expanding legalized gambling -- asked holders of junk bonds issued by his three Atlantic City casinos to renegotiate the terms of the debt, either cutting the interest rate or delaying when the bonds are due. 
In an interview last week, Mr. Trump said extraordinary circumstances called for extraordinary measures, adding that bondholders understood that "the world has changed since Sept. 11." It is because of the terrorist attacks that New York is seeking the additional revenue that gambling would provide. 
With so many wealthy people diminished by all of the year's events, the state has plenty of company.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Yes, There Are Still Optimists in Japan

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
INVESTORS betting on a recovery in Japanese stocks are not easily discouraged. After three short-lived rallies in the 1990's, they are again hoping that the market will finally pull itself out of its decade-long funk.
 Fund managers with a mandate to invest here have some reason for quiet optimism for 2002. Many big names, like Nippon Steel and the Pioneer Corporation, are trading near 10-year lows, making Japan one of the cheapest industrialized markets. Bargain-basement prices are leading to mergers and takeovers that were previously unimaginable, as evidenced by a deal that would give Roche of Switzerland a majority stake in Chugai Pharmaceutical. Waves of companies are announcing revampings, encouraging investors. 
 As the year turns, though, the pessimists have the upper hand. Investors, encouraged by the election of a tough-talking prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, bid up stocks in April and May. When his reform bandwagon stalled, stocks resumed their decline, propelled by mounting banking problems, falling semiconductor prices and the events of Sept. 11. The Topix -- an index of all top-ranked companies on the Tokyo Stock Exchange -- fell 19.6 percent in 2001, its eighth one-year decline since 1990.
Mutual funds that invest dollars in Japan fared even worse because of the yen's 16 percent slide against the dollar. Through mid-December, these equity funds were down more than 30 percent, the largest decline of any international category, according to Morningstar. 
As Koji Nishigaki, president of NEC, the electronics giant, said recently, "I want to forget this year as soon as possible." Unfortunately for Mr. Nishigaki, whose $44 billion company delayed listing on the New York Stock Exchange this year, 2002 does not look much better.
The economy has fallen into its fourth, and perhaps deepest, recession since 1992, pushing the unemployment rate to a high and sapping consumer spending. Exports and government spending are sputtering as the American economy falters and as Mr. Koizumi tries to rein in debt. The Bank of Japan expects the economy to shrink about 1 percent in both 2001 and 2002.
In recessions past, Japan ramped up exports, pumped taxpayer money into the economy and cut interest rates. With those options mostly exhausted and the banking system in shambles, investors hope that Mr. Koizumi, who wants to overhaul the tax code, deregulate crucial industries and force banks to write off bad loans, can overcome the forces allied against him.
BUT the prime minister will probably disappoint investors, whether he succeeds or fails. If he has his way, Japan will fall deeper into recession as deregulation and loan write-offs drive up bankruptcies. If conservatives kill Mr. Koizumi's program, investors are expected to sell stocks in the belief that lawmakers are not serious about fixing structural problems. Judging by the pace of reform in past administrations and the string of defeats that Mr. Koizumi has already suffered, the Japan bears have history on their side.
"Don't hold your breath for quick reform in Japan -- particularly of bank bad debts -- or you will both underperform and die before it," David Roche of Independent Strategy, an investment firm based in London, said in a recent report.
But there is a silver lining: because of their woes, banks, contractors and real estate companies make up only 11 percent of the Topix, about half of their weighting in 1998. So even if the government mismanages the bank cleanup, the effect on the broader market is more limited than it was during the previous recession.
More important, plenty of big Japanese companies are still partly insulated from the domestic economy, and many of their stocks are more affordable than at any time in the last 15 years. Matsushita Electric Industrial, Toshiba and Fujitsu are trading at well below their peaks, yet have little debt, strong brands and well-trained work forces. All of them have announced job cuts, factory closures and plans to spin off or trim unprofitable divisions. Mr. Nishigaki at NEC, for instance, announced plans to eliminate more than 10,000 jobs, close overseas factories and emphasize software and services over memory chips. Toshiba is also promoting high-margin networking and wireless products and moving low-end refrigerator and air-conditioner lines to China.
"Toshiba reminds me of General Electric 20 years ago," said Robert Sasaki, managing director at Bear, Stearns in Tokyo. "I don't know if they have the will to do what 'Neutron Jack' did," he said of John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s former chief executive, who scrapped unprofitable businesses and kept the winners. "But they definitely have the opportunity."
The cost-cutting is expected to nearly double Japanese companies' return on equity, to 2.8 percent next year. While that is just one-eighth of what American companies earn, estimates by Goldman, Sachs show that the change would be enough to lift the Topix above 1,200, about 20 percent.
Despite Japan's troubles, its consumers are still the world's second wealthiest, behind those in Luxembourg, on a per capita basis. Companies that can tap into these deep pockets have a good shot at weathering the downturn.
"Consumers have the spending power -- it's purely a matter of catching their fancy," said Mark W. Headley, portfolio manager of the $330 million Matthews Japan fund, based in San Francisco. Among his top 10 holdings are Monex Securities, a Japanese online broker; Belluna, a mail-order clothing company; and USS, which manages used-car auctions. The fund has lost more than 40 percent this year.
There is even promise in slow movers like Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, which has lost more than half its market capitalization in 18 months. N.T.T., the former state-run monopoly, controls 88 percent of the local fixed-line market and dominates broadband, data and software services. The government's plan to sell off more of its 41 percent stake in 2002, some analysts reason, will force the company to make deep cuts to please shareholders.
AND then there are perennial winners like Toyota Motor, Honda Motor, Nintendo, Canon and other exporters that make the bulk of their profits overseas. Through the 1990's, these companies geared their operations to turn a profit even when the yen strengthened. The dollar's recent break through 130 yen means exporters will earn even more when they repatriate profits. Toyota and Honda make an estimated 10 billion yen ($77 million) for each one-yen increment above their break-even point of 110 to the dollar. These automakers have a huge impact on parts suppliers, materials makers and advertisers, so their success can cause broader rallies.
"Even though exports are a small part of the economy over all, the market needs something to turn it around," said David Semaya, president of Merrill Lynch Investment Managers in Tokyo, which handles $10 billion of United States money in Japan.
The first half of 2002 will likely be rough. Analysts expect profits to plunge more than 30 percent in the October-to-March period, about twice as much as in the previous six months. Once those declines are out of the way, stalwart investors can again focus on the companies that can make their way out of Japan's economic wilderness.
