HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
New London Is Bustling After Pfizer Complex Opens

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THREE years ago when Pfizer announced it was going to build a $300 million, 790,000-square-foot research center in New London, it planned to occupy the complex in phases over several years. Instead, the three buildings, which opened last summer, are already filled, and the rest of the city is quickly changing as well.
 New London officials have approved a master development plan for a hotel, conference center, offices and housing that will get under way next year on an 90-acre parcel near Pfizer and have given preliminary approval for up to 220 condominium units on two acres on nearby Bank Street. 
 There are smaller projects around the city as well. Pfizer itself is constructing an 18,000-square-foot day-care center on a 3.1 acre site opposite its new research center, which will eventually accommodate 168 children. It also has a lease agreement with a developer that is planning a $3 million renovation of 42 waterfront apartment units on Pequot Avenue, to be used by employees temporarily assigned to New London or house hunting in the area. 
"There seems to be a general feeling and general uplifting of everything in the area, as a result of what's happening with Pfizer," said Bruce Hyde, director of the city's Office of Development and Planning. "The rest of the country is in a recession, but for the most part it doesn't seem to be affecting this area." 
Barry Weiner, chairman of the New London Redevelopment Authority, said: "It's a resurgence for our city, no question about it. And I don't think the people in New London and the businesses in New London have felt the full impact yet. I think it's going to enhance and improve our city's life and each year that goes by. It's like a new lawn -- it's going to get richer and more beautiful with time." 
But there is also development taking place that has no apparent connection to the pharmaceutical company, like the decision by Inncom, based in Old Lyme, a company founded almost 20 years ago to provide environmental and access control systems for hotel rooms, to construct a new plant and offices on a 4.3-acre parcel near the Adm. Harold E. Shear State Pier.
Julian Enterprises has proposed a 135,000-square-foot office complex at Shaw's Cove, a half mile from the Pfizer complex, but Andrew J. Julian Sr., president of the company, noted that his company's involvement in the city dates to the mid-1990's, with the purchase and renovation of large commercial buildings on Shaw Street and Eugene O'Neill Avenue. "We always felt New London was the place to be" Mr. Julian said." "But Pfizer has certainly had a positive impact on the city."
THE United States Coast Guard has also announced plans to develop its national museum in New London, and the Cross Sound Ferry Company has announced plans to invest $12 million in its terminal just north of City Pier.
Ned Hammond, the city's economic development coordinator, said, "I'm getting a lot more calls from commercial brokers from the Hartford and Stamford areas who have an interest in New London." 
New London was still reeling from the closing of the Naval Undersea Warfare Center, which once generated about 6,000 direct and indirect jobs in the city, in 1996 when Pfizer announced in 1998 that it would build a huge research complex in New London, as the headquarters of its Pfizer Global Research and Development program.
At the same time, the state announced a $78 million makeover of the entire Fort Trumbull area, adjacent to the Pfizer development. The fort, built to defend the harbor in the Revolutionary War, has been turned into a state historical park, a $19 million waterfront park has opened and roads and other infrastructure have been improved.
The development has not been without controversy. The New London Development Corporation was authorized by the City Council to oversee the development in the area, which required the taking of dozens of small properties. A group of seven property owners have filed suit to challenge the right of the development corporation to use eminent domain for economic development purposes. That court challenge is pending.
The emphasis of economic development planners has been to try to build an entire industry on the base that Pfizer has created. The state has started a 15-week professional-development program to train clinical data managers at the University of Connecticut, for instance. The program coordinator, Armelde Pitre, said that from the first class, which finished this fall, about half of the 13 students had been placed in southeastern Connecticut, including some at contract research organizations that do data analysis for Pfizer and other companies. "Part of our vision is to help build a bioresearch corridor in Connecticut, and to do that you have to supply a skilled work force," Ms. Pitre said.
But others think the amount of work thrown off by Pfizer might be limited. John C. Markowicz, director of the Southeastern Connecticut Enterprise Region, an economic development agency, said his office had done extensive marketing of the area as a biotechnology haven over the last few years.
"The first question everyone asks us is, 'Can you provide us with some contacts at Pfizer?' " Mr. Markowicz said. "There are a few biotechnology start-ups around, but they're not counting their employees in the thousands yet, and a lot of what happens in that sector is going to depend on what Pfizer wants to happen." 
The biggest impact, most expect, will involve not biotechnology companies that spring up around Pfizer but retail and service companies that come in to serve its 2,100 employees in New London. A Pfizer spokeswoman, Liz Power, said that the company supported other development in the city but that aside from the day-care center it was not planning to take an active role in it.
"One of the things attractive about New London is there was an infrastructure already in place, the dry cleaners and coffee shops and restaurants," Ms. Power said. "From the beginning, when we announced that we were moving to New London, we have always said we perceive our role as a catalyst. We hope the development proceeds and it is handled well, but it is in the hands of the city."
There has been considerable activity involving service companies that could benefit from the presence of Pfizer employees. Several new restaurants have opened or expanded on State Street, the main business district. And Mr. Hammond, the economic development coordinator, said there was more interest in the housing market, with projects that range from a two-man team renovating four large apartments in the business district to a plan by Oaktree Development and Design in Boston to construct 220 condominium units on Bank Street.
Gwendolyn G. Noyes, a partner in Oaktree, said that while the project was not tied to Pfizer, "the market conditions in New London have changed considerably since Pfizer made a commitment to be there."
Marty L. Jones, president of Boston-based Corcoran Jennison Company, which has proposed the largest development project in the area, said cooperation involving Pfizer, the state and the city had created the kind of momentum that would make the other projects possible. "It's a classic public-private partnership -- I don't think either side would have jumped in without the other, but together the investment, the commitments made a lot of sense," Ms. Jones said.
Corcoran Jennison will build a 100-room hotel, a conference center and marina in the first phase of a $115 million project. Planning will begin soon for the second phase: 100 units of rental housing in a six-story building on the waterfront and renovation of some offices that were abandoned by the Navy. The final phase will consist of new office construction.
Ms. Jones said Pfizer's speed in filling up its office complex had caught many developers by surprise and was one reason there are not more projects competing with hers.
"I think people are just starting to realize that Pfizer is actually there, not just planning to be there," she said. "Once people start to realize that, you're going to see a lot more interest in New London."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pfizer employs 2,100 at its $300 million Global Research and Development complex on the Thames River. (George Ruhe for The New York Times) Map of Connecticut shows the location of Pfizer Global Research and Development.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
The New Year Is Bringing New Breaks for Taxpayers

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
THE passage of tax legislation this year has brought a reduction in most people's tax rates, along with rebate checks, and further breaks will kick in at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday.
 "Jan. 1 is the best time of year to start your year-end tax planning," said Laurence I. Foster, a partner in Richard A. Eisner & Company, an accounting firm in New York. Mr. Foster is also chairman of the committee for personal financial specialists for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. 
 Two big breaks in 2002 will come to those who save for retirement and college. Contribution limits are rising on retirement accounts, and people who are 50 or older next year can also make "catch up" contributions to such accounts. Money withdrawn from state-sponsored education savings plans will be tax-free when used for qualified expenses. 
Here are a few other changes in store for taxpayers in the new year:
* The tax credit for people who adopt children will double to $10,000 a child. Credits reduce taxes dollar for dollar. Thus, a $10,000 credit reduces taxes by $10,000; in contrast, a $10,000 deduction for someone in next year's 30 percent bracket will reduce taxes by only $3,000.
* Employer-provided educational assistance of up to $5,250 a year will be excluded from income, meaning that it will not be taxed. And the coverage has been expanded to include graduate courses. So if you are thinking of going back to school, whether to take a course or two or to get an advanced degree, "talk to your employer -- make it part of the package," Mr. Foster said.
* People can give away more money with no tax consequences. The annual gift exclusion is rising to $11,000 per recipient from $10,000, so that a couple can give $22,000 to each of their grandchildren, for example, without having to file gift-tax forms. Also, the point at which the total of an estate and gifts above the exclusion becomes taxable will rise to $1 million from $675,000. Those who had already reached the limit can give away an additional $325,000. That can be especially important for people who own businesses and who give interests in them to their children, thereby transferring ownership gradually at today's values, instead of leaving everything in a will. 
* Tax rates fall an additional one-half of 1 percentage point for people in the 27.5 percent, 30.5 percent, 35.5 percent and 39.1 percent tax brackets. And everyone gets the benefit of the new 10 percent tax rate. It applies to the first $12,000 in income for married couples filing jointly and the first $6,000 for single filers. Each personal exemption, meanwhile, will be worth $3,000 on 2002 returns, up from $2,900. And the standard per-mile rate for business use of a personal vehicle goes up to 36.5 cents a mile from 34.5 cents.
People still have one day to make gifts for 2001, Mr. Foster noted, and "the check is in the mail" may be good for more than a sardonic laugh. If the charitable gift is postmarked by Dec. 31, or charged to a credit card by that date, you can take a deduction for this year. But for a personal gift, Mr. Foster warned, the I.R.S. looks at the deposit date, so don't just write a check to your grandson. Make sure he deposits it.
Many people plan to make gifts in 2002 by setting up state-sponsored education savings accounts, often called Section 529 plans after the section of the Internal Revenue Code that authorizes them. "Section 529 plans are very hot; our clients are rushing to get them established," said Joseph P. Toce Jr., partner in charge of Andersen's private client services practice in New York.
Many states allow residents a tax break on the money they put into their state's plan. Under federal law, people can "bunch up to five years of gift exclusions into one year" in these plans, Mr. Toce said, meaning that an individual can put in $55,000 in 2002 free of gift taxes, instead of waiting to put in $11,000 a year for five years, and a couple can invest $110,000. What is new for 2002 is that the account's earnings will be free of tax when distributed for qualified education expenses. Previously, the earnings were taxable at the beneficiary's rate, and they could be again after 2010, when the present tax law expires.
But taxes are not the only consideration in these plans. Investment performance is also important, and because most states contract with private companies to administer the programs, performance varies widely. Some accounts have lost money during the market slide of the last two years.
Another variable is how much money can be put into the plans. People can invest in plans outside their own state, so comparison-shopping can pay off. A good place to start is www.savingforcollege.com, maintained by Joseph Hurley, a certified public accountant who rates state plans.
Mr. Toce said Andersen liked several plans: an Alaska plan administered by T. Rowe Price and allowing contributions of up to $250,000; Colorado (Salomon Smith Barney, $235,000); Nebraska (Union Bank and Trust, $250,000); and New Hampshire (Fidelity Investments and until an account balance reaches $233,240). Most plans offer a menu of investment options.
New York provides a state tax credit to residents who invest in its plan, which is administered by TIAA-CREF and has a contribution limit of $100,000. A resident might consider establishing two plans, Mr. Toce said -- a New York plan to take advantage of the credit, and an out-of-state plan to achieve stronger investment results and to allow additional contributions, although the New York contributions might have to be subtracted from the other state's limit.
T. Rowe Price has calculated that annual contributions of $5,000 to such a plan for 18 years would grow to $278,000 if they compound at 10 percent. The earnings, $188,000, would escape taxation when used for qualified education expenses.
Another big opportunity for 2002 lies in tax-deferred retirement savings. Martha Priddy Patterson, national director of employee benefits policy at Deloitte & Touche in Washington, advised making the maximum allowable contributions to 401(k) or 403(b) plans. "It's a great way to save," she said. "It can also be an emergency fund because hardship distributions are allowed, and most plans have loan provisions."
The contribution limit will rise $500 in 2002, to $11,000, and will climb gradually to $15,000 for 2006. But for many people, changes in complex federal rules may mean that the allowable increase next year will be far more than $500. Many employers have limited employee contributions to 10 percent of salary, lest they run afoul of rules that could have caused them to be liable for an excise tax. But employers can now deduct up to 25 percent of payroll for retirement contributions and no longer have to include employee contributions in their deductions. As a result, they can let employees contribute up to the legal limit without adverse consequences.
"Watch what your employer is putting out in terms of plan changes," Ms. Patterson said. "Many may be putting them out during the year, not on Jan. 1."
People who will be over 49 during 2002 can make an additional $1,000 catch-up contribution, provided that the plan sponsor allows it. Individual Retirement Account limits are to rise to $3,000 from the longstanding $2,000, and $500 catch-up contributions will be allowed to those 50 and older.
AS in the case of the Section 529 plans, an important consideration is how to invest the money, and most plans offer a menu of choices -- stock and bond mutual funds, guaranteed investment contracts and, often, company stock.
David M. Stein, chief investment officer at Parametric Portfolio Associates in Seattle, which specializes in tax-efficient investing, suggested that people who have both a tax-deferred retirement plan and regular taxable accounts be broadly diversified. He recommended putting securities that generate ordinary income, like bonds, into the tax-deferred account because once it is time to withdraw money, it is taxed as ordinary income, even if some of it came from long-term capital gains.
He said people who like to trade actively, incurring short-term capital gains that are taxable as ordinary income, could also use the tax-deferred account for that part of their holdings. 
Mr. Foster of Richard A. Eisner had one warning for taxpayers. "If the economy doesn't improve, a lot of the tax breaks may be truncated," he said. When the 2001 tax law was passed, budget surpluses were predicted, he said, but given the recession and the cost of war in Afghanistan, the nation is now looking at deficits.
Ms. Patterson agreed, advising people to take tax breaks "while the getting is good."

HEADLINE: Closing the Trunk Lid On a Topsy-Turvy 2001 

BYLINE:  By JAMES G. COBB

 BODY:
THINK back to 1998. Chrysler was the hottest company around, with fresh products, a can-do attitude and an $8 billion hoard of cash.
 Two years later, Ford was on top of the auto world. It had plunged into the dot-com economy, built a stable of European luxury brands and seemed poised to dislodge General Motors as the largest carmaker. 
 Meanwhile, G.M. meandered, churning out rental-quality cars that enthusiasts loathed, bouncing from one reorganization to another, steadily losing market share and handing immense power to marketing gurus with scant automotive knowledge. 
Now, Chrysler is run by Germans and paddling in red ink, desperately trying to pawn parts of itself. Ford is closing one of its worst years, which included more of the Explorer-Firestone fiasco, its chief executive's departure, embarrassing recalls, bungled introductions and poor quality ratings.
Suddenly G.M., the industry's plodding mastodon, seems to have momentum. A perilous detour into Procter & Gamble-style brand management -- which coincided with a further drop in market share -- is ending. Interest-free financing bolstered G.M. sales and hurt weaker rivals. Detroit's favorite car wizard, Robert A. Lutz, is waving his wand in G.M.'s design studios.
And there were plenty of other upside-down events -- and vehicles deserving special notice -- in the year just past:

Ask the Talib Who Owns One
The truck of the year, at least in Central Asia, is surely the Toyota Hilux. The compact pickups (not sold in North America) have been everywhere in the war in Afghanistan, driven by Taliban friend and foe. (Leaders of Al Qaeda preferred Land Cruisers.) Putting the best face on a double-edged endorsement, Wade Hoyt, a Toyota spokesman, said, "It shows that the Taliban are looking for the same qualities as any truck buyer: durability and reliability."

Tread Lightly?
The Jeep Liberty has the right name for these patriotic times, but at least a few New Yorkers have squirmed at a commercial showing one climbing the Statue of Liberty. Aside from calling attention to a feat that no Jeep would dare attempt (at a time when two magazines have found the Liberty may be overly tippy in certain circumstances), is this a good time to send vehicles crawling over -- even with digital enhancements -- cherished national monuments?

Deals and Steals
Competition is intense, the economic outlook is murky and recent financing deals may have inflated 2001 sales at the expense of 2002. And because it costs so much for the Big Three to shut down plants -- the pension costs are enormous -- they pretty much have to keep cranking out cars and trucks, then offer generous deals to get them off dealer lots. It is a tough time to be a car company, but a good time to be a customer. 

The Best Get Better
I'd never buy a Toyota Camry, but I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it. The '02 is seamless, and it helps to explain why Toyota is Detroit's worst nightmare (and why the Camry is the sort of Everycar that the Chevy Impala once was). Toyota could have dislodged Chrysler from the Big Three already, had it tried, and it soon will. Plus, its customers are loyal, and they progressively move up to more profitable cars.

Assault on Truckville
Trucks will outsell cars this year, but that is small comfort for the Big Three, whose last stronghold -- big pickups and S.U.V.'s -- is under assault from the Japanese, led by Toyota. Nissan, back from the brink of collapse, is newly energized. The Europeans, plus Lexus, have walked away with the luxury market. And not a single Big Three vehicle made Consumer Reports' "top picks" list for 2001.

New in the Neighborhood
As if things weren't grim enough, the Koreans are demanding to be taken seriously, with more than 600,000 American sales this year. And these are no longer marginal econoboxes. Kia is selling a bargain minivan, the Sedona, and its corporate cousin, Hyundai, has a convincing facsimile of a midsize luxury car, the XG 350. Aside from the styling -- call it Nouveau Soviet Apparatchik -- the XG is a nice piece of work.

Shiftless Wonder
Continuously variable "gearless" transmissions -- with ever-changing ratios set by moving belts -- have existed for a while, but Audi is the first company to put one in a powerful sedan. The Audi A4's multitronic is eerily efficient, with no pauses, lurches or noticeable gear changes.

Park That Big Thing
G.M. has made it a little easier to handle a mammoth truck: its GMC Sierra Denali comes with Quadra-
steer, a four-wheel-steering system that gives the big pickup the same turning radius as a small Saturn.

Bright Lights, Big City
Acura owners in New York reported a rash of thefts of high-intensity headlamps, often with costly fender damage. Young customizers put the blue-white beams on their hot rods.

Improved, With an Asterisk
Some new vehicles are undeniably better than their predecessors. But they can be better without being great. Here are some cases in point:

Ford Explorer: It is smoother, roomier and presumably safer, but it still feels like an ungainly truck.

Dodge Ram: The best-looking, least-polished big truck has received a polishing, and it now feels competitive with Ford's dated F-150. But old powertrains separate the Ram from the leaders, from Toyota and G.M.

Honda CR-V: Unlike other Hondas, the old CR-V felt tinny and cheap, and it committed a cardinal cute-ute sin: it wasn't much fun. The '02 is much improved, but it it still doesn't come with a laugh track.

Infiniti Q45: This big sedan is striking and fast, but it is saddled with irritating computer-screen controls and is short on luxury car refinement, with a noisy cabin and luggage-crushing trunk hinges.

Jeep Liberty: I like a lot about the Cherokee's replacement, especially its classy cabin and off-road prowess. But on pavement -- as opposed to trails -- it doesn't measure up to the car-based Ford Escape.

Declasse Luxury
"Entry level" has taken on new meaning since I heard a British executive refer to a future $140,000 model as an "entry-level Bentley," but there's no question that "entry luxury" cars make up the hottest part of the market. Jaguar has plunged in with its X-Type, a pleasant sedan with every big-cat styling cue the designers could toss at it. But while the X-Type seems nice enough, especially given its European Ford bones, it lacks the peculiar feline grace that makes a Jag a Jag.
Mercedes moved further downscale with its $26,000 C230 Sports Coupe. Unfortunately, that hatchback has an unexceptional engine, an oddly rounded rear end and a general lack of joie de vivre. The Acura RSX is more fun, for less money.

Topless Contrarian
I'm in the minority here, but the year's two hot convertibles left me cold. I couldn't get past the bulbous, love-it-or-hate-it look of the Lexus SC 430, which otherwise felt like the nicest Buick I'd ever driven. And by the time a local dealer got his supply of a dozen Ford Thunderbirds, they sat on his lot covered with snow. Two years of previews and production delays made the T-Bird seem like old news. Though the car looks great with its top down, its rough-road shake, soggy ride and Lincoln-issue dashboard kept reminding me that it isn't as special as it pretends to be.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
A Roster Of Awards Better Off Unawarded

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
MEASURED by its stock market action alone, 2001 was clearly a disappointment. But judge the year instead by the audacity of its corporate schemers, Washington scalawags and Wall Street rogues, and 2001 becomes tough to top. 
 Although most investors probably prefer to look forward and not back, the end of the year is always a splendid time to review with fondness the players and the moves that dominated the business stage. So it is time again to announce the Augustus Melmotte Memorial Prizes, named for the stock manipulator and arriviste at the heart of "The Way We Live Now" by Anthony Trollope. Mr. Melmotte, a man of uncertain fortune and lineage who nevertheless rose to the top of London society in the late 1880's, met his downfall when he was caught selling shares to investors in a railroad company that existed only in his imagination. 
 Come to think of it, didn't Enron, the year's grandest corporate disgrace, ultimately exist more in the imagination of investors than in reality? Yes, but even Mr. Trollope, a master of the fictional fantastic, could not have dreamed up the Enron story. 
Although the wealth-wrecking crew at Enron could walk away with every one of the Melmotte prizes this year, there were others whose actions should be noted and appreciated. 
Here are the prizes and their winners.

THE WHAT I DON'T KNOW CAN HURT YOU AWARD -- To Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of Enron, who presided over the loss of $61 billion in investor wealth in 2001 and one of the quickest corporate collapses ever. Claiming to be a somewhat bewildered bystander, Mr. Lay told a reporter, "You're getting way over my head," when asked about transactions Enron made with mysterious partnerships set up by company insiders. Mr. Lay seemed happy to let his underlings act without interference, a management style that hereafter may be known as Laysez-faire.

THE I ALSO HAVE A BRIDGE TO SELL YOU AWARD -- To Jeffrey K. Skilling, the architect of Enron's rise to stock market stardom but a man who takes no responsibility for its spectacular fall. Mr. Skilling, Enron's chief executive for a six-month period that ended in August, has said he knew nothing about the off-balance-sheet partnerships set up by Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's chief financial officer, which benefited Mr. Fastow but helped bring down the company. Mr. Skilling said he left his Enron post for personal reasons he declined to specify. Mr. Lay was more forthcoming; he said the reasons were "things with fairly short time fuses on them." Hmm.

THE HEADS I WIN, TAILS YOU LOSE AWARD -- To Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer at Enron, who pocketed more than $30 million from the behind-the-scenes partnerships he set up as vehicles for the company's trading businesses. While the partnerships enriched Mr. Fastow, they made paupers of Enron shareholders, who were ultimately on the hook for some of the partnerships' obligations.

A TURNAROUND IS MORE THAN TALK AWARD -- To Gary C. Wendt, who since arriving at Conseco as chief executive 18 months ago has told investors repeatedly that the company's revival is just around the corner. Most of his forecasts, made in folksy memoranda in which he attacked company doubters, have not transpired. Shares of Conseco, which rose 17 percent when he was hired to save the company, have lost almost 70 percent of their value this year.

THE ONLY THE LITTLE PEOPLE PAY TAXES AWARD -- To Republican lawmakers who actually voted to repeal a tax intended to ensure that wealthy corporations pay something in income tax. Never mind that -- thanks to the tax treatment on stock options -- some of the nation's largest and richest companies paid little or no taxes in recent years. Icing on this particular cake was billions of dollars in rebates to companies like I.B.M. and General Electric. Thankfully, this dumb idea died, a victim of partisan bickering.

THE OFTEN WRONG BUT NEVER IN DOUBT AWARD -- To Ron Barone, the research analyst at UBS Warburg who covered Enron, or perhaps more accurately, who through it all was one of Enron's loudest apologists. On Aug. 17, after analysts met with Mr. Lay, the Enron chief, Mr. Barone told Bloomberg News: "Ken met with us to reassure us that there is nothing wrong with the company. There is no other shoe to fall and no charges to be taken." Less than three months later, one of the biggest shoes in corporate history descended when Enron announced that it would restate earnings for the previous four years, eliminating $600 million. A believer until the bitter end, Mr. Barone waited until Nov. 28, when Enron's shares had more value as wallpaper than as stock, to replace his "strong buy" label on the stock with a "hold."

THE IT WAS FUN WHILE IT LASTED AWARD -- To Henry Blodget, who will abandon his post as chief Internet analyst at Merrill Lynch tomorrow, after all but 2 of the 18 stocks he followed collapsed in a heap. A certifiable bull-market genius, Mr. Blodget learned how unfun bear markets can be -- and that worshipful investors who hang on an analyst's every word are far preferable to the tediously litigious sort who sued him and Merrill in July.

THE BALANCE SHEET DOES MATTER AWARD -- To Jack Grubman, the telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney who has lost investors so much money that he could give new meaning to the term "Neutron Jack." His breathless buoyancy on the sector drove investors into dicey telecom stocks. Now that many of his former darlings have dropped dead, victims of too much debt that his firm helped to pile on, he has taken a new approach. He now has a "neutral" rating on 16 of the 26 stocks he follows. But those who followed his advice are probably anything but neutral on him.

THE SELLER BEWARE AWARD -- To Henry Silverman, the chairman of Cendant, who finds his company once again pained by an accounting mess of someone else's creation. This time, the accounting irregularities showed up at Homestore.com, a real estate Internet site whose largest shareholder is Cendant and on whose board a Cendant representative serves. The affiliation began last February, when Cendant sold its Internet subsidiary, Move.com, to Homestore, producing a $525 million gain. Now, Homestore shares have stopped trading until the depth of the accounting faux pas is known. Of course, the impact of Homestore's woes on Cendant will be nothing like the nightmare that grew out of the company's purchase of CUC International in 1997. That deal resulted in the restatement of three years of earnings by Cendant -- which had to deduct a total of $640 million that prosecutors said was created out of thin air at CUC.

THE STYLE IS NICE BUT SUBSTANCE RULES AWARD -- To Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, who can spin with the best, but whose delivery of the goods, a k a earnings, has been lacking. Even though she's one of the best C.E.O. cheerleaders out there, if she fails to complete her planned merger with Compaq Computer, she may go to the showers a loser.

HEADLINE: The World; 
A Business Plan For Islam Inc.

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TWO weeks after Osama bin Laden's operatives staged the Sept. 11 attacks, the Senate passed a bill approving a free trade agreement with Jordan, the first of its kind with an Arab nation.
 Every American knows about the terrorism. Few have heard of the trade deal. But some experts see in these events two possible futures for the Islamic world, and a role for the West in determining which one is realized. That role is to help Islamic countries create material hope for their people. 
 To many Westerners, Islamic nations often seem out of touch with, and hostile to, modernity. One billion Muslims from Algeria to Indonesia live in poverty. Corruption and illiteracy are endemic. Religious radicalism is on the rise. But in the economic realm at least, Islam presents a more diverse, and possibly more hopeful, picture. 
Today, Malaysia and Turkey stand as Muslim success stories at the geographical poles of the Islamic world. Both have weathered the financial crises that afflicted emerging market economies in recent years, and now have mostly open economies, diversified exports and a high degree of integration with neighbors.
Jordan and the United Arab Emirates have also become substantially more open in recent years, while Tunisia has led a reform drive in North Africa (it now has a women's day to promote equality in the work force). Indonesia and Malaysia today have more in common with East Asia than the Middle East. Egypt recently passed laws giving women some economic rights they never had before. Even Syria and Iran are to varying degrees seeking to simplify regulations, to expand trade and to attract foreign investment.
These are potentially optimistic developments for the United States and its allies, as they try to counter the appeal of Islamic radicals. That is because many development experts say that helping countries to manage their economies better is as important to challenging the terrorist vision as educational and political reform.
"We need to resist the idea that the Islamic world is somehow culturally incapable of development." said Jeffrey D. Sachs, a development expert at Harvard University. "There's a tremendous opportunity to bring globalization to places that have not seen much of it."
WHICH is not to say that all the economic news is encouraging. Far from it. The wealthiest Islamic countries, led by Saudi Arabia, are dependent on revenue from a single export, oil, much of which has been squandered. Other countries, like Sudan, appear to be moving backward, with hard-line fundamentalists exerting more control over all aspects of life.
Pakistan has long flirted with Western-style economic programs, but corruption and demands for religious orthodoxy have kept the economy in shackles. And Egypt has never shed the legacy of Gamel Abdel Nasser, who embraced national socialism and a state-controlled economy after the country emerged from colonial rule. 
Even Indonesia, the largest Muslim nation, has stumbled badly after a quarter century of rapid growth, and is struggling to contain rising fundamentalist and separatist movements. 
But while the problems are widespread, most experts contend that they are not somehow religiously preordained. Yes, Islam bans earning interest on loans. But, then, the Roman Catholic church had its usury laws. In fact, Islamic society was once at the forefront of economic life. In medieval times, it had more vibrant urban economies and a higher standard of living than Christian Europe. Muslims were the first to have a paper economy (a millennium ago, a check written in Baghdad could be cashed in Fez). 
Mr. Sachs suggests that to spur economic development, the United States and Europe should help more students from Muslim nations gain the technocratic skills their countries need by studying in the West. They were underrepresented in leading universities even before Sept. 11, and since then many returned home to avoid a police dragnet in the wake of the attacks. 
Afghan reconstruction presents another opportunity, Mr. Sachs said. Rather than focusing solely on restoring agricultural production and rebuilding roads, he said, the West should present a broad plan for easing the isolation of all of Central Asia, improving transportation, communications and increasing trade along the ancient Silk Road. 
STRENGTHENING the economies of Islamic countries will sometimes be politically difficult. For example, some economic experts have also pressed the United States to grant Pakistan a higher quota for textiles, its main export, despite opposition from the domestic textile lobby in Washington. And some Iran experts want to encourage the reform movement in that country by relaxing the sanctions imposed on it in the wake of the Iranian revolution. For its part, Turkey would like to be admitted to the European Union on an expedited schedule, despite problems with its human rights record. 
"The West in general and Europe in particular has made a major mistake over the past 15 years in sending signals that Islamic countries are not really part of their world," said Timur Kuran of the University of Southern California, who studies Muslim economies. "The West has to do more to encourage those people -- really the majority in many countries -- who want to integrate, not turn their backs.
"There may be a tendency after Sept. 11 to think of the Islamic world as monolithic," he added. "If we do, unfortunately, it will be the Malaysias, the Turkeys and the Tunisias that suffer the most."

HEADLINE: A Music Tradition That Plays On in the Key of D, for Diversity 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: PURCHASE 

 BODY:
NO one remembers exactly how Music America began 10 years ago. 
 According to Elaine Palmer of Pepsico, who was there at the beginning, Pepsico wanted to sponsor a new community event at Purchase College after the demise of Summerfare, a critically praised arts festival that outgrew the campus. Jacqueline Millan, also of Pepsico, recalled that the company approached the Westchester Philharmonic (then called the New Orchestra of Westchester) about a concert that would celebrate the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King. 
 Paul Lustig Dunkel, music director and conductor of the orchestra, thinks it was his wife, Barbara, who proposed that the concert benefit nonprofit human service organizations devoted to Dr. King's goals of nonviolence and racial harmony. 
That idea stuck, and since 1992 groups like the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency, the Westchester Martin Luther King Jr. Institute for Non-Violence, the Union Child Day Care Center and the Westchester Holocaust Commission have joined together for a commemorative concert presented by the Westchester Philharmonic each January. Music America has become a cherished county cultural institution, in which nonprofit groups work side by side to raise money. 
"People are always calling us and asking when Music America will be," said Blanche Walker, executive director of College Careers Fund of Westchester in White Plains, which helps minority youth attend college. "It highlights racial interaction and nonviolence in a special, uplifting way."
This year's concert, to be held on Jan. 19 at 7:30 p.m. at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, will focus on jazz. The program, "Satchmo, Bird and the Duke: 3 Jazz Legends," which was planned by Mr. Dunkel, departs from the mix of classical music and spirituals presented at Music America in past years. The evening will feature the trumpet player Freddie Hendrix, the saxophonist Charles McPherson and the pianist Roland Hanna, 
Groups must apply to take part. Then each group (there are 15 this year) is obliged to sell a minimum of 60 concert tickets. Groups receive the tax-deductible portion of all $85 benefactor tickets and $70 patron tickets that they sell; proceeds from sales of tickets that are not designated for anyone are divided evenly among the groups. Benefactors and patrons are listed in the program book and also may attend a pre-concert reception at the Performing Arts Center. Other tickets are priced at $30 and $20. A dress rehearsal on Jan. 19 at 10 a.m. at the Performing Arts Center will be presented free, although a $5 donation is requested.
In recent years, Music America performances in the 1,300-seat Concert Hall have been sold out. Money, however, is not the main reason that some groups have been involved for 10 years. The concert "symbolizes the diversity of Westchester coming together in a community event," said Winston A. Ross, executive director of the Westchester Community Opportunity Program, a social service agency based in Elmsford. "The board feels good about being involved because of the program's goals."
Last year the undesignated share of the proceeds received by each of 14 groups was $230; in 2000, 15 groups each received $255 from the common pot. The total amount raised by most organizations is often under $1,000 (although last year the Mount Vernon Fire House Hip/Hop Museum made more than $5,000). Participants say raising prices to increase the pot would exclude many of the people Music America aims to attract.
"We fund-raise in other areas, so for us it's about anything but money," said Sylvia Bloom, director of communications for the Center for Preventive Psychiatry in White Plains. "This event represents diversity at its best. Never do you go to any event in Westchester at which you see such total racial and religious integration."
Ms. Bloom thinks the event should be a model for other cities, and has suggested that the Westchester Philharmonic invite orchestra leaders nationwide to the concert. 
Elaine Carroll, the new executive director of the Philharmonic, said she recently mailed invitations to selected orchestras in large metropolitan areas.
"There was no response, but it's a seed," Ms. Carroll said. "We'll send them the program afterward and tell them in plenty of time when next year's program will be."
Only once since 1992 was there no Music America. That was in 1994, when Pepsico, which had sponsored the event from the start, bowed out. 
"It was becoming a Pepsico event," said Ms. Palmer, manager of corporate information for the company. "It was very successful, but it was not achieving the goal of getting nonprofit organizations to work on their own with various corporations and the arts."
The event was missed so much that "it came back by public acclaim," Ms. Palmer said. 
Pepsico returned, and has been joined in major sponsorship by J.P. Morgan Chase & Company and the Abraham Fund/Alan B. Slifka Foundation. A breakfast is held at Pepsico's headquarters each fall where representatives of each group gather for a preview of the coming concert. At this and two other yearly meetings bonds have formed among the participants, but most say that the diversity of Music America has not spilled over to other cultural events in Westchester.
Ms. Walker said it was hard to talk about "lasting relationships" among the organizations when many nonprofit groups are struggling to raise money in a post-Sept. 11 economy.
Other sponsors this year are Consolidated Edison, Diversified Investment Advisors, Heineken USA, Verizon and First Union National Bank.
Besides the music of Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker and Duke Ellington, the concert will include a piece composed by Mr. Dunkel, who has conducted Music America each year. The work sets words by Dr. King to music, and will be narrated by an interfaith group of clergy.
For more information or tickets, the number is (914) 682-3707 ext. 10.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 2395 words

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: 3,225 (AT LAST COUNT), D. SEPT. 11, 2001; 
Order of Magnitude

BYLINE:  By Margaret Talbot 

 BODY:
It took awhile to unlearn the number 6,000. Though the estimated death toll at the World Trade Center has been falling steadily since early October -- and has by now shrunk by half -- the smaller number proved hard to absorb. As late as Thanksgiving, the larger figure was still being cited by disc jockeys and pundits, by Northern Alliance fighters and admirers of Osama bin Laden. Maybe even now it remains embedded in the minds of Americans who have been paying less avid attention to the news than they did in September. And of those fully aware of the revised number, many seemed reluctant to adopt it. When lower death estimates were first reported, few Americans were in the mood for revisionism, even of the most benign and understandable sort. Nobody wanted to insert the word "only" in front of a new tally of the dead. Body counts often become a proxy measure of a tragic event's significance; as the historian Karel Bartosek has written, they are "a mathematical truth" that "transforms mass deaths into a kind of sacrament." Viewed in this light, insisting on precise new estimates can seem morally obtuse, beside the point. Lowering the body count can -- perversely, irrationally -- feel like a sad thing, as if it were an exercise in diminishing the weight of Sept. 11. 
 Although it soon became clear that 288 people died at the Pentagon and in Pennsylvania, the World Trade Center body count was an unfolding narrative, a series of jagged highs followed by a staggered decline. In the first weeks following the attacks, wild numbers flew around like scraps of paper in a whirlwind. Almost all of the early predictions turned out to be overestimates, but in context they made sense. Eleven thousand body bags were ordered by the city on Sept. 12. Ten thousand people were feared dead in the first week. Seven thousand the next. Two or three hundred Britons alone had been killed, Tony Blair incorrectly predicted. On Sept. 21, after foreign consulates reported their missing citizens, the estimated death toll provided by the city stood at more than 6,300. By October, it had fallen to 4,500; by Nov. 21, to 3,948; by Dec. 20, to 3,011. At least one source, USA Today, has lowered the number further, to 2,800, which includes, as all the figures do, rescue workers and passengers on the hijacked jets. 
 The truth is nobody had ever made a calculation like this one, and coming up with an accurate total turned out to be devilishly hard. The initial estimates of casualties were reasonable mistakes based on known facts and brute realities. Although it was reported that 50,000 people worked in the towers at the height of the day, the World Trade Center was a vast public space; who knew exactly how many people might have been walking through the area when the planes hit? Making matters worse, investigators had no solid records, like a list of visitors cleared by security. There were other complications: so few bodies could be recovered relative to the number dead (only 550 had been identified as of Dec. 21); medical examiners would have to contend with tens of thousands of individual tissue samples; it took time to cull the multiple reports of the same missing persons and the misspellings of names from disparate lists. The events of that day were such a literal and grotesque embodiment of worst fears that worst estimates seemed entirely plausible. Indeed, to look at ground zero is to be shocked that so many people -- more than 12,000, it is now believed -- did make it out. Those who did were beneficiaries of their locations in the buildings -- above the 92nd floor of the north tower, no one survived -- of improved evacuation plans following the 1993 bombing and, most heartbreakingly, of the rescue workers who rushed in and who, we now realize, made up almost 15 percent of the dead. 
Behind the falling numbers there are other stories, though, that are disorienting because they have nothing to do with the larger story. They are not about terrorism and they are not tragedies; they open a door onto other destinies, smaller sorrows and, sometimes, tawdriness. There were, for example, people who lied -- not many, but a handful that we know of, who faked their way onto lists of the bereaved. Several, like 42-year-old Alan Braker of Orange, N.J., who has been charged with filing a false report, told stories about nonexistent, missing children. Indeed, a popular trope among the fakers -- or "sickos," as The New York Post succinctly described them -- was of parents and children separated, then reunited, then torn apart again by the cataclysm of Sept. 11. Braker's made-up daughter, Mya, was a 6-year-old supposedly visiting his former wife, who worked on the 107th floor of the World Trade Center. Waldo Fernandez conjured a grown son he'd just been in contact with for the first time and was about to go meet. Maybe they figured lost children garnered the most sympathy, and children parted from their parents in regret-ridden, postdivorce lives are a common enough story of our time, after all.
Speculation and rumors further muddied the conjectures about how many people died on Sept. 11. Think of the story popular in parts of the Islamic world, for example, that 4,000 Jews supposedly fled the towers ahead of time -- evidence" of Israeli involvement in the attacks. (Conspiracy theorists are like metaphysical statisticians, forever citing specific, random numbers.) And the myth of the World Trade Center Orphans -- as many as 15,000 of them, according to some estimates -- persisted for weeks, despite evidence that the city had not turned up a single case of a child who lost both parents in the attacks. Good-hearted souls from around the world volunteered to adopt one or more. It was as if the thwarted impulse to help innocent victims kept roaming around looking for a place to alight. Surely it was bad enough that many children did lose one parent, but that sort of loss seemed to leave fewer options for outsiders to set things right. As long as there were thousands of orphans to rescue, there was something to be done; that comforting thought alone held the myth aloft for a time.
Some real people reported missing by well-intentioned friends and acquaintances were never missing at all, just out of electronic communication in an era and at a moment when that alone could seem troubling. A 30-year-old New Yorker named Matt Heard, whose picture turned up on flyers after a casual friend said she thought he'd worked at the World Trade Center, did not work there and in any case was on vacation in France on Sept. 11, unaware of the anxiety about him at home. A woman who heads the New Jersey office that helps relatives of those missing after Sept. 11 was mistakenly reported missing herself. In the first few days, e-mail that went unanswered even for a few hours produced panic. The availability of instant communication allowed many people to obtain reassurance about their friends and relatives, but also meant that some of those who couldn't make contact jumped to dire conclusions. If you knew anyone in New York, you called them, and if you couldn't get through, you worried, even against your better judgment or your knowledge that they worked nowhere near the towers. So deep did Sept. 11 hit that it felt peculiar not to know someone directly affected.
All of these tendencies were compounded when it came to immigrants, whose relatives at home may have had only the filmiest notion of what their lives in America were like. One major reason that the initial estimates were so high is that other nations produced inflated reports of their missing citizens, based on frantic calls from relatives abroad. Indeed, the highest possible death toll cited came after these overseas reports were first tallied. The numbers for virtually all of these countries fell sharply, but in some cases, it took weeks for consular staff to follow up on all the leads and know for sure. The Mexican consulate, which initially received 1,000 calls or e-mail messages reporting people who might have been missing, has since winnowed the list down to 17. Britain now says 77. Newspapers in Colombia reported that 300 Colombians were missing after Sept. 11, but staff members at the consulate in New York tracked down all but 20 of them, many living far from New York City. Consular staff members think 10 more might be dead, but no more than 30 total. 
"A lot of people called who had never been in the United States," says Diana Garcia, the Colombian consul for legal affairs. "They know somebody who lives in the States, they haven't heard from them in a while, they're scared about them, but they don't know the geography, they don't know what life is like here, that upstate New York is not the city of New York or that Florida is nowhere near." The consulate of Turkey got 475 reports of people missing after the attacks, though only 50 Turks worked at the World Trade Center and only 1 is still missing. 
To their families at home, maybe there is always a sense in which immigrants are missing -- missed, long gone, leading novel lives the families can't quite imagine. The list of "disappeared people" reported to the Asociacion Tepayac, an advocacy group for Mexican immigrants in New York, is full of question marks, partial information, blanks. Eloisa Cruz Cabrera, 22, is listed as "a domestic worker. They don't know where." Felix Toto Cobaxin, 44, is said to "work in a restaurant, name unknown." Someone from Hidalgo simply "works in New York." Meanwhile, the fates of some undocumented immigrants who actually did work in the trade center or as delivery people servicing it may never be known because their employers won't come forward to prove their existence, says Brother Joel Magallan of the Asociacion Tepayac, and maybe family members won't either, despite the I.N.S.'s promise not to prosecute in such cases.
"The largest group of World Trade Center victims we'll probably never know the fate of are the undocumented workers," says Steven Stehr, a professor at Washington State University who studies disaster-relief efforts.
There are people who see the falling count less mercifully. These people argue that the higher numbers were useful for the war effort, and that that is why they stood uncorrected for weeks, and why everyone from Colin Powell to Don Imus kept citing them. Stephen Glover, writing in the British magazine The Spectator, refers to "a brutal calculus: the greater the number of victims, the easier it is to justify military action." Sometimes, of course, death tolls from disaster and war are overestimated (or underestimated) on purpose. During the Vietnam War, inflated estimates of Vietnamese killed became a substitute measure of American success in a campaign whose substantive objectives were proving elusive. For many years after the San Francisco earthquake of 1906, city officials, anxious not to scare off tourists and investors, insisted on a figure of 674 killed or missing, almost certainly a gross underestimate. (Recalculations in the 1960's put the number at 3,000; some historians think the number is yet higher.) Before federal-disaster relief, there was little economic incentive to provide accurate numbers and considerable incentive to lower them. Besides, as the historian Ted Steinberg points out in "Acts of God: The Unnatural History of Natural Disaster in America," until the mid-20th century, few officials bothered to count some populations struck by calamity -- blacks in South Carolina hit by hurricanes, the residents of Chinatown in San Francisco. In those cases, the historical record had to be rescued from chroniclers with an interest in distorting it.
Sometimes, though, it's no one's agenda, but the nature of the event itself -- the scale of it, the lack of precedent, the details of destruction -- that makes calculating the precise death toll so hard and makes a larger number seem, for a time anyway, to make more sense. The truth is there are plenty of complicated, real-life exigencies that explain why the World Trade Center numbers fell and why a precise final figure may be a chimera. And in any case, an event's singularity, or its horror, is not measured only in numbers, nor should it be. For a while, journalists casting about for a context and a comparison kept citing Pearl Harbor or Civil War battles. At some point in later November, it was duly noted that Sept. 11 was no longer, in fact, the bloodiest day in American history. That distinction went to Sept. 17, 1862, when 3,654 soldiers died in the battle of Antietam. I suppose it was worth pointing out, but I'm not sure it struck many people as particularly salient. The attack on the World Trade Center killed American civilians, outside of wartime, and it killed them on TV, making most of the rest of us unwilling witnesses to a mass murder, and that places it in a context of its own. We watched the towers burn and collapse, in real time. And we watched the bodies drop from the sky -- a sight that most of us will never be able to forget.
In the end, the surprising thing about the lowered death toll is how little it alters our sense of Sept. 11. I don't mean that the task of getting it right should be abandoned, even if the likely presence of homeless people, undocumented workers and others means that total certainty is impossible. A careful count matters -- to families, in the allocation of funds, in what historians record. But whether the number is 6,000 or 3,000 does nothing to shrink the magnitude of the attacks in our minds or, for most of us, the justification for war.
"The count would have had to fall quite a lot more -- into the low hundreds, probably -- before we could have concluded that the terrorist attack wasn't magnitudes greater than anything we've experienced or ever could have expected," as James Burk, a sociologist of war at Texas A&M University says. "We do regard civilian deaths as a moral matter and almost beyond any kind of market calculus. How much money can we send to the victims? The thinking seems to be no amount is too much. How many people were killed? A bunch. The moral issue is overriding." 
Indeed, maybe the number that comes closest to right is the number Mayor Giuliani evoked on that first day, when reporters pressed him about what the death count might turn out to be -- more, ultimately, than any of us can bear."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Looking Into a Crystal Ball, Or Else a Rear-View Mirror

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE 

 BODY:
There's an old New Jersey saying, or ought to be: to see ahead, look back. No, not just that the traffic will get worse next year or that property taxes will go up or that public employee pension deals will get sweeter. But in politics, things to come are usually connected to, if not explained by, things past.
 So let's look back to see ahead. The big political story next year will be Senator Robert G. Torricelli's race for re-election, and the possibility that the Republicans borrow a page from the Democrats and shop around for a man rich enough to pay his own campaign bills. After all, Mr. Torricelli did that when he helped recruit Jon Corzine, the Wall Street millionaire, to run last year for Frank Lautenberg's former seat. 
 Mr. Corzine went on to spend more than $60 million to win, and the deep pockets who are getting bored sitting around their corner offices up and down the state these days must be asking themselves, "If a cuddly guy like Jon Corzine can write a check to move from the executive suite to the United States Senate without bothering with lesser offices, why can't a hard-grabber like me do it too?"
Lewis Eisenberg, the former chairman of the Port Authority and a very wealthy man, is probably the leading name being dropped by Republican Party leaders who are hopeful that he will take on Mr. Torricelli. Mr. Eisenberg is well known in the party and would be a powerful fund-raiser -- in the event he is willing to give it all up for a chance to jump into the pit with one of the Senate's canniest campaigners.
Two newcomers have also put their toes in the ring. Douglas Forrester of West Windsor, who runs a medical services business, and Kenneth Pasternak, the former head of a large Jersey City brokerage, have expressed interest in the race. In the unlikely event that all three got into a primary campaign spending spree against each other, the most likely beneficiary would be the guy without any money and who did bother with those lesser offices. Jim Treffinger, the Essex County executive, who ran last year and lost in the primary to Bob Franks, is popular and well known.
Mr. Treffinger has something that money can't buy, which is experience on the campaign trail. It is a commodity that wealthy first-time candidates particularly need, since they tend to be people who are used to being respected and obeyed, and correspondingly not used to having to beg and smile.
Mr. Corzine evidently knew this: he resigned as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs in March 1999 -- 15 months before the primary -- and immediately started putting out feelers and getting himself known. And what got lost in all the talk about Mr. Corzine's money was the fact that he turned out to be a very effective campaigner -- at ease, fluent and friendly. The latest crop of wealthy would-bes are getting a late start in learning those qualties.
The most interesting race from New Jersey for the House of Representatives will be the one to fill the Fifth District seat that Representative Marge Roukema is vacating next year after 22 years in office next year. If the seat stays Republican, Assemblyman E. Scott Garrett figures to be rewarded for the dogged primary challenges he has brought against Ms. Roukema in the 1998 and 2000 primaries. Earlier this month, Mr. Garrett won the endorsements of a long list of Republicans as a warning against other challengers. And given that he came within 2,000 votes of defeating Ms. Roukema in last year's primary, he should be a lock to win the nomination at least.
But Mr. Garrett is an unvarnished conservative from rural Sussex County, and most of the Fifth District voters in Bergen County -- just the kind of well-off, well-educated older suburb that, in New Jersey and elsewhere in the Northeast, has been leaning toward the Democrats lately. 
In November's gubernatorial race, James E. McGreevey outpolled another conservative, Bret D. Schundler, by 11 percentage points in Bergen, so both state and national Democratic parties are certain to make the Fifth a major battleground.
Another place to look backward for clues to the future is legislative, not electoral: will the new Governor McGreevey have to resort to raising taxes to fill the huge gap between recession-depressed revenues and the state budget?
There are plenty of liberal Democrats in the Legislature -- Democrats Mr. McGreevey needs to keep control of an ideologically unbalanced Legislature -- who would like to see another Florioesque grand gesture: new taxes to plug the deficit and pay for the many social programs, from child health care to education to social services, that they believe were neglected during eight years of Republican governors.
But Mr. McGreevey didn't get where he is by repeating the mistakes of others. He knows that Jim Florio's tax increase upon taking office a decade ago threw the Democrats into outer darkness for the rest of the 90's, so he will look somewhere else for the money? Where?
Well, millions from the tobacco settlement are headed toward Trenton each year, Stephen Salmore, a Republican campaign consultant, noted.
"McGreevey has said he won't do it," Mr. Salmore said, "but I bet the Legislature wouldn't mind."

 The New York Times

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 2409 words

HEADLINE: What New Yorkers Want From Their Next Mayor 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg becomes mayor on Tuesday at one of the most difficult moments in New York's history. He must also follow an incumbent who has become a national hero. Mr. Bloomberg says he is optimistic and enthusiastic, ready to take on the challenges and make his own mark. Below, New Yorkers of different backgrounds and interests offer some suggestions about where he should concentrate his energies.

Wendy Wasserstein,
playwright, author of "The Heidi Chronicles."
 New York needs both healing and a master plan. But what was so indelibly proven on Sept. 11 is that we have courage and heart. It's crucial that the new mayor keep his finger on the pulse of that impressive heart. 
 We are a city of working people. The new mayor needs to commit to the education and culture of all five boroughs to serve the families of all New Yorkers. So many people voted for "Mike" Bloomberg because he "wasn't a politician." Then let him be a man of the people.
New York City is more than Manhattan and the Upper East Side, where Mr. Bloomberg spent most of his time as a businessman. A mayor should take the subway to the Avenue M station in Brooklyn, around the corner from Edward R. Murrow High School; know the Italian bakeries on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx and the Korean delis on Main Street in Flushing; see the view of Manhattan from Nixon Avenue in Staten Island.
Whatever one thinks of Rudy Giuliani or Ed Koch, each of them was one of us: characters straight from Characterville. Each had a New Yorker's individuality. Some Bloomberg supporters have said to doubting Democrats, "Oh listen, he ran as a Republican but he's really a Democrat." I don't particularly care, as long as he's genuine. New Yorkers can always tell when someone isn't.

Diane Ravitch, research professor of education at New York University.
Mr. Bloomberg has a historic opportunity to reshape the public schools by negotiating new contracts with teachers and principals. Both unions are now operating without contracts. In addition to providing for competitive salaries to attract and retain top-notch teachers and executives, Mr. Bloomberg must insist on new working arrangements to deregulate the schools and ensure that principals have the authority to make decisions. The city should abolish the provision in the previous contract that relieved teachers of the obligation to monitor students at lunch, on the playground and in homerooms. Teachers should be responsible for students throughout the school day, not just when they are in the classroom.
The contract with principals should give them greater control over their schools' budgets, staffing, purchasing and meals by shifting authority from the bureaucracy at central headquarters to individual schools. In the new contracts, the city should guarantee that both teachers and principals will receive the professional training they need to meet their responsibilities.

Charles Schumer, senator from New York.
One of the first and most important things Mr. Bloomberg needs to do is marshal support for additional federal funding for New York from Washington, especially among Republican leaders. While the stream of Federal Emergency Management Agency funds -- which reimburse the city government for disaster-related expenses like the cleanup and rebuilding of the subways -- seems to be largely assured, lower Manhattan desperately needs new tax breaks to help existing businesses survive and to lure new ones, both large and small, below Canal Street.
There are also many nonprofit agencies, hospitals and individuals that were affected by the Sept. 11 attacks and need aid but are not eligible for assistance from FEMA. Mr. Bloomberg is clearly familiar with these issues and the city's needs. During his first month in office, he should meet with President George Bush, Speaker Dennis Hastert and House Whip Tom Delay, as well as Senate Minority Leader Trent Lott and Minority Whip Don Nickles, to persuade them of the urgency and immediacy of New York's cause.

Thelma Golden, deputy director for exhibitions and programs at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
Our new mayor needs to make artists and arts and culture an essential part of his vision of New York City. The city's spirit, as well as its physical spaces, must be rebuilt. The vibrant arts community can help with that job.
The drop-off in visitors and donations to cultural institutions, large and small, after the shock of Sept. 11 showed how fragile the arts economy in this city is. The new administration must create and finance support services that can help bring people into the city's cultural institutions. The city also needs to create a public cultural endowment fund, unhampered by bureaucracy and politics, to expand the creation and presentation of the arts throughout the city for all New Yorkers. This support should reflect the range of voices, cultures, and opinions found in every neighborhood in this richly diverse city. Cultural institutions are vital social and educational anchors in communities. Mr. Bloomberg should make innovative cultural policy part of his agenda.

Richard Parsons, incoming chief executive, AOL Time Warner.
The city's future is in the extraordinary brain power gathered in offices, theaters, studios, banks, libraries, universities, digital start-up companies and long-established businesses.
The effort to repair the damage inflicted on Sept. 11 can't begin and end with new structures, office space and monuments. In the long term, New York's recovery depends on building and maintaining an education system that trains literate, technologically proficient graduates who can secure this city's place in a global economy.
The performance of the city's schools will determine whether a chasm separates a privileged elite from masses of underemployed and unemployed. Only with successful schools can New York retain and expand its middle class and maintain a tax base sufficient to modernize a fraying infrastructure.

Alfonse M. D'Amato, former senator, now managing director of Park Strategies, a business consulting company.
Mr. Bloomberg must ensure that lower Manhattan remains the financial capital of the world. If there is a single first step in this gargantuan task it is this: to have in place by Sept. 11, 2002, a suitable memorial, a place where all Americans and all people can come to see that New York City will rise from the ashes.
New York's position at the pinnacle of the world's financial markets is what allows it to be the cultural and communications capital of the world. We must rebuild the infrastructure, but more important, we must repair and restore the spirit of this city.
The terrorists' target was intentionally symbolic. We must be equally symbolic in our response. We must build a memorial that both pays respect to those who lost their lives and demonstrates the awesome economic and human strength of the world's greatest city.

Dennis Rivera, president of 1199/S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union.
Mr. Bloomberg's first priority should be to pass a living-wage bill. In more than 70 cities and counties across the country, a living wage is now required by law. Private businesses contracting with local government or receiving public subsidies must pay their employees enough so they can afford food, shelter and other necessities. In New York City, they need far more than the minimum wage, currently $5.15 per hour.
Such legislation would be a huge boost to the city's 50,000 home-care workers -- mainly women, and many single heads of households -- who bring aid and comfort to our frail elderly residents. They now make an average of $7.65 an hour. This is a scandal for such a rich city. These workers perform a valuable service and save the city money because home care is cheaper than that provided in a hospital or nursing home.
The huge disparity between rich and poor is sure to be exacerbated in the current recession. New Yorkers want fairness for people who work hard, and a living-wage law can help ensure that fewer workers live in abject poverty.

Donald Trump, real estate developer and author, with Dave Shiflett, of "The America We Deserve."
To many people, New York City represents the pinnacle of the American dream. Maintaining this ideal is a huge responsibility for anyone who becomes mayor. My advice to Mr. Bloomberg is to be aware of, yet not intimidated by, the position he will be taking on. It is not an enviable position, but it could become a heroic one. 
It has often been said that real estate is to New York what oil is to Texas. In these difficult economic times, it is especially important that the mayor encourage not only the construction of new buildings but also the redevelopment of existing ones. Modernizing buildings can lure people to New York even more quickly than constructing new ones can, and to further expedite the recovery, the mayor needs to get rid of the city's infamous red tape on zoning applications and tax abatements.
This could turn out to be an important time when we look back historically. One cannot be a hero in easy times, and a city cannot prove itself in purely affluent times. Our city has dealt with a very difficult situation, and our new mayor will show us how to take the next step and rebuild.

Jennifer J. Raab, president of Hunter College.
As a businessman, Mr. Bloomberg was not afraid to put his name on his product. The same fearlessness and accountability is needed to transform the city's public school system. Currently, six different elected officials (the mayor and the borough presidents) select seven people for the Board of Education -- leaving no one person accountable. The mayor must then funnel billions of dollars into the school system while having no direct control over how the money is spent.
Mr. Bloomberg should push hard for state legislation to end this structure and replace it with one that gives the mayor real authority to run the public schools. As we have seen in the last eight years in areas like public safety and children's services, when the mayor selects his executives and holds them accountable, great improvements can be achieved.

Andy Darrell, New York regional director, Environmental Defense.
The quality of the downtown environment is important to families and businesses deciding whether to stay in lower Manhattan or relocate. Reconstruction at the World Trade Center site may take six years, and Mr. Bloomberg can make downtown air much safer by requiring that contractors working there install filters on engines of their pollution-spewing cranes and bulldozers and use low-sulfur fuel. Boston has similar requirements at its Big Dig redevelopment project.
To reduce downtown traffic and the pollution and congestion it brings, the new mayor should make Mayor Giuliani's limits on single-occupant vehicles permanent or add congestion pricing, now in use on Hudson River crossings, to East River crossings. More ferries and water taxis could get people across the rivers.
The new administration should also be vigilant about guarding open space downtown. Projects like Hudson River Park and parkland in a reused Governors Island should not be threatened by fiscal cuts and political uncertainties.

John Wang, president of the Asian-American Business Development Center in Manhattan.
The Sept. 11 attack made Chinatown, a community already on the decline, even more vulnerable. Not only was tourism virtually halted, but severe traffic restrictions because of the cleanup at the World Trade Center threaten to bankrupt some garment businesses and wholesale and distribution operations.
To revitalize Chinatown as an important economic and political center for Chinese-Americans and as a major tourist attraction requires some bold thinking. Mr. Bloomberg should have city planners work with the community to produce a zoning study that analyzes the best and most appropriate land use for Chinatown. A major aim should be to preserve the garment industry businesses now in Chinatown while also exploring the feasibility of eventually relocating them to the outer boroughs as Chinatown diversifies its economic base. Chinatown itself needs a comprehensive program to turn underutilized space into a mixture of market-rate and low- and moderate-income housing.

Mark Green, outgoing public advocate and Mr. Bloomberg's opponent in the November election.
New York should develop and nurture a national reputation as a city that uses information technology well, both for internal efficiency and to expedite services to businesses. If so many of us e-bank from home, why not e-government from home? Professional and business licenses and permits should be obtainable via the Web; the city should take service requests and receive complaints by e-mail. Responses can be faster if city agencies and officials do more of their own work on computers and online as well. Now most city workers don't have access to the Internet or e-mail. And most city agencies are miles behind the Police Department in collecting data and using it to hold managers accountable for their departments' performance.
Mr. Bloomberg should appoint a high-profile chief technology officer, reporting directly to him, to work with every agency for higher productivity, lower costs and better service.

Myron Magnet, editor of the Manhattan Institute's City Journal.
Upon election, the first thing Michael Bloomberg declared was that New York was open for business. That's the message he should embrace as mayor: that he will make New York the Opportunity City, in which a growing private economy offers jobs for all.
The no-new-taxes promise Mr. Bloomberg made in his campaign is a fine start, but as the recession ends, he should institute tax cuts significant enough to encourage businesses to expand and to attract new businesses. Mr. Bloomberg should junk the city's income-tax surcharge and the commercial rent tax in Manhattan's central business districts. Then he should move to eliminate the city's income tax altogether, to make clear that he means business about economic growth. Cutting a tax on wealth creation is better than cutting the sales tax, a tax on consumption, and it would benefit not just retailers but all businesses, especially job-creating small outfits.
A bigger economy will ensure that city revenues will fall by little or nothing. And Mr. Bloomberg's promise to make city government smaller and more efficient will pave the way for further tax cuts and still more private job growth.
